Colombia is offering help (financial support) to informal workers (maids, cleaners, street vendors) announced on march 27
Colombia  announced the 'I train at home' initiative to activate physical activity in Colombian homes on march 31
Colombia (The National Liberation Army (ELN)), announced that the guerilla groupe will suspend its actions as a humanitarian gesture throughout April due to the coronavirus disease starting April 1.

Colombia is making masks obligatory in public transport and areas where there is a massive influx of people (market places, supermarkets, banks, pharmacies, among others). Also, people with respiratory symptoms and risk groups such as adults over 70 years old, with cardiovascular diseases, with diseases that compromise the immune system, cancer, HIV, pregnant women and chronic respiratory diseases announced on April 4

In Colombia, the Ministry of Science, Technology & Innovation will invest COP 26 billion to finance COVID-19 projects related to Public health, Diagnostic Systems, Prevention and Treatment Strategies, Equipment and Devices and Monitoring Systems.

Colombia announced the campaign" helping is good for us", in conjunction with the private sector and civil society, to supply those compatriots who need it most during the national quarantine for the Coronavirus.

Colombia made Self-isolation mandatory for all people arriving after March 11, 2020 (Resolution 380 of 2020 of the Ministry of Health). This norm implies the citizen commitment in the containment of the Coronavirus propagation.

Colombia is enforcing a 11 days quarantine for all adults over 70, the Government decreed their compulsory preventive isolation, starting on Friday 20 March at 7 a.m. until 31 May.
All adults over 70 years of age must remain in their homes, except for the supply of essential consumer goods, the use of health services, the purchase of medicines and access to financial services.
Colombia has announced that guidelines have been given (Circular 000012 of 12 March 2020) to hotels for the containment of Coronavirus in the hotel environment, following strict health guidelines.

Colombia is enforcing Telework or work from home For working public servants who have recently arrived from a country with an incidence of COVID-19 cases Who have been in contact with patients diagnosed with COVID-19. For those with mild and moderate respiratory symptoms, without abandoning their position
It is important to clarify that each employer is responsible for taking action to this effect and it will be the responsibility of the teleworker to comply with this measure in order to make it effective, in terms of preventive social . Face-to-face meetings or concentration of several people in reduced work spaces with low ventilation, to avoid the risk of contagion of respiratory diseases and COVID-19 by close contact on March 13.

Colombia announced a ban on the consumption of alcoholic beverages, crowded meetings staring March 19. That the consumption of intoxicating beverages in open spaces and commercial establishments be prohibited. The sale of intoxicating beverages is NOT prohibited.

Colombia's Ministry of Health and Social Protection implemented biosecurity protocols so that hairdressers, beauty salons, barbershops and related can operate. Scheduled appointments will be required to monitor capacity, customers will need their temperatures taken and must be asked about possible symptoms, a distance of two meters must be maintained between vanities, the use of Personal Protection Equipment is mandatory and employees must be equipped with gowns, head caps, safety goggles, plastic mask and disposable gloves. Disinfectant use is expected, and tools are recommended to be disposable. This goes into effect on June 16th.
Colombia is allowing the reopening of drive-in theaters starting June 18th with social distancing measures in place.

Colombia announced that from March 14 to April 30, 2020 there will be total closure of cultural spaces throughout the country. On the same dates, virtual activities related to the collections and cultural services will be programmed, but not activities in the physical spaces.

description: Colombia will be allowing the reopening of museums with the following restrictions starting June 16th: virtual payments must be enabled, capacity restrictions must be in place, social distancing must occur, health-related materials or trained staff must communicate recommendations for health and safety upon entry, and hand sanitizer must be available (60% to 90% alcohol).

description: Colombian is enforcing the restriction of activities in the following areas: Bars, nightclubs, casinos, billiards, gambling establishments, gyms, swimming pools, spas, saunas, sports courts/centers, amusement parks and playgrounds. This will last until July 1st starting June 1st.

In the Colombian cultural field, theatres will only be used for creative, artistic activities of the performing arts, without at any time allowing the entry of public or the realization of group activities that generate agglomeration.
Colombian mass public transport cannot exceed an occupancy of 35% of its capacity.
Group exercise and sports practice in public places is not allowed. Swimming pools and sports centers can only be used for sports on an individual basis by professional and high performance athletes.

description:
14.04.2020:
Under the slogan ""Con vos podemos"", the official campaign was launched to receive financial donations in order to bring humanitarian aid to vulnerable people and families affected by the emergency caused by Covid-19.

The campaign -which will last until April 30- is promoted by the Government of the Republic together with the Costa Rican Banking Association (ABC), the Federation of Savings and Credit Cooperatives (FEDEAC) and k "lbi.

This campaign is a public-private alliance so that people can make their financial donation, which will be translated into basic supplies such as food and hygiene kits for vulnerable families.

The inputs will be purchased from national farmers, enterprises and businesses in each community, which will in turn allow the local economy to be reactivated.

The distribution will be in charge of the Municipal Emergency Committees and food will arrive at the beneficiaries' house to avoid crowds.

On Thursday, April 16, Grupo Mutual and Mutual Cartago (MUCAP) joined the  "Con vos Podemos " campaign, enabling their accounts so that people can make their donations by electronic transfer or Sinpe M "vil.

Costa Rica, 03.04.2020:
The President of Costa Rica and the Minister of Health establish the following fines:
a) A person with risk factors for a serious illness due to a contagious disease, who is the object of an isolation order, will be fined the amounth of a base salary for violating the isolation order.
b) A person suspected of a contagious disease or one who, even without presenting obvious symptoms or signs of said disease, is the object of an isolation order due to being close contact with a causative agent of the disease, will be fined a fixed amount of three base wages.
c) A person who, medically or clinically, has been diagnosed with a contagious disease, will be fined a fixed amount of five base salaries.

15.04.2020:
The Board of Directors of the Central Bank of Costa Rica (BCCR), in a session held on Monday, April 13, 2020, empowered its Administration to acquire, in the secondary market, holdings from the Ministry of Finance in colones for a maximum amount of  " 250,000 million.

The acquisition in the secondary market by the Central Bank of titles of the Ministry of Finance does not constitute financing to the Government, since the purchase of the holdings would be made to a third party, who would be the one who receives the money for the acquisition made by the Central Bank.

Given that this instrument is an exceptional mechanism, the Central Bank restricts its participation to situations of systemic tension, and therefore limits the amount of its intervention and imposes restrictions on the type of holdings that can be acquired and their issue and placement date.

The Central Bank will publish on its website the information on the secondary market transactions carried out under this agreement, at the end of each day in which it carries out said transactions.

16.04.2020:
The Ministry of Science, Technology and Telecommunications (MICITT) makes <U+20B5> 791 million available to finance actions in innovation, science and technology in order to fight COVID-19.

The first call was opened on April 16 and is part of the Innovation and Human Capital for Competitiveness Program (PINN), with the support of the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB).

These are PINN innovation and technology transfer projects to support the health emergency, with an investment of up to <U+20B5> 712 million.

The maximum amount to be awarded per project will be <U+20B5> 142,000,000 and the maximum execution period will be 12 months.

Meanwhile, the Incentive Fund will open a call for an amount of up to <U+20B5> 79 million on May 15 to support research on issues related to COVID-19.

MICITT is promoting three areas of work:

1. Provide resources for research in detection, prevention and treatment of COVID-19

2. Empower the community of national, transnational companies, researchers and national scientists to develop national prototypes

3. Promotion of capacity development in small and medium-sized enterprises to better cope with the economic consequences of COVID-19.

Costa Rica, 17.04.2020:
The President of the Republic, the Minister of Labor and Social Security and the Minister of Human Development and Social Inclusion announce the creation of ""Bono Proteger"" as a temporary unemployment benefit to contribute to the social protection of households affected by the change in their working conditions and/or income as a consequence of the National Emergency caused by COVID-19. It will be granted on a monthly basis, for the national state of emergency caused by COVID-19, and for a period of up to three months from the first deposit if the circumstances that motivated the granting of the subsidy persist, as long as there are resources  available. The amount is 125.000 colones for the laid off or suspended employees, affected self-employed and informal workers as well as those whose working time has been reduced by more than 50%. The amount of 62.500 colones will be granted to workers  whose working time has been reduced by less than 50%.

Apr. 1st - In the framework of Holy Week, the Government of Costa Rica reinforces measures to contain the contagion by COVID-19

Measures do not restrict access to basic services. From Friday, April 3 and until Tuesday, April 7, the night vehicle restriction is extended throughout the national territory from 5:00 pm to 5:00 am.
Long-distance public transport will also be restricted and establishments will be closed with sanitary operating permits and attention to face-to-face public, home services are allowed.
Starting Saturday, April 4 and until Tuesday, April 7, the daytime vehicle restriction will apply from 5:00 am to 5:00 pm throughout the country, with license plate distribution.
From Wednesday, April 8 to Sunday, April 12, the movement of vehicles and public transport is restricted, with exceptions.

There is also a total restriction on vehicular traffic with the following exceptions: access to supermarkets, suppliers, grocery stores, pharmacies and health centers, without time restrictions.

Costa Rica, 21.04.2020:
The Ministry of Public Education announced the cancellation of the application of the FARO national standardized tests, which would begin to be applied this year to eleventh-year students of academic schools, in the face of the coronavirus crisis.

Costa Rica - From Saturday June 20, 10am, until Monday June 22, 5am complete vehicular restriction.  Exceptions: supermarkets and supply places (odd vehicles plates on Saturday, even on Sunday), medical emergencies and funeral funeral vehicles, productive activities, transfers to work place with the proof, public transportation and taxis, delivery services and hotel reservation with the proof.
Croatia announced a 14 days suspension of classes in schools and universities starting from March 16.
The Croatian government announced that effective May 11, schools (grade 5 and above) and universities will remain closed until further notice.

On Mar 22 the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared: people will be banned from leaving their place of residence as of Mar 23. 
Exempt from the measure are: those are important for transport that is necessary for supply, daily migrations, the employed in important services for healthcare and veterinary protection, delivery of medicines, sanitary materials, maintaining utilities, water supply and sewage, provision of natural gas and electricity, informing the public, journalists, citizens that require urgent medical assistance, vital family reasons, travelling to work and from work if doing a job is absolutely necessary and can "t be done from home, as well as urgent operative services that are taking part in preventing spread of the disease.
On Feb 24 2020 the Croatian Ministry of Health raised the alert level due to the risk of coronavirus.

On Feb 24 the Crisis Headquarters of the Croatian Ministry of Health presented additional measures that Croatia will take against the spread of coronavirus including increased surveillance of border crossings to Italy.
On Feb 24 the Croatian Ministry of Health issued a recommendation to schools recommending not to take school trips and excursions to Italy.
On Mar 17 the Croatian National Civil Protection has decided to close 27 border crossings with neighboring Slovenia.
Croatia is banning transit through all its border crossings for 30 days, excluding cross-border workers, freight carriers, healthcare professionals, diplomats and transit passengers on March 19.

On 24 January 2020 the Croatian government has raised the Coronavirus prevention and protection measures at international airports and seaports in Croatia, in cooperation with the border police, emergency medical services, sanitary border inspectors, county epidemiologists and air carriers.

On Feb 2 the Croatian government ordered: On international flights arriving in Croatia, a systematic survey of passengers was introduced using special forms designed to identify passengers who could potentially have been exposed to infection.

On 24 January 2020 the Croatian Ministry of Foreign Affairs raised the Coronavirus prevention and protection measures at international airports and seaports in Croatia, in cooperation with the border police, emergency medical services, sanitary border inspectors, county epidemiologists and air carriers.

On Feb 27 the Government of the Republic of Croatia approved the amount of HRK 2,250,000 to finance the procurement of nine artificial ventilation devices, to provide the necessary prerequisites for preventing further spread and treatment of coronavirus.

On Mar 19 Croatian troops began erecting a tent for a medical camp outside the Dubrava hospital in Zagreb with a capacity of 270 beds to accommodate infected patients and it is expected to be erected by Saturday.
On Mar 29 the Croatian government has secured more than 20 tons of protective masks, protective suits and protective goggles from China.

On Mar 31 the Croatian Science Foundation with financing from the Ministry of Science and Education has invited scientists to apply for 14 million kuna in grants for research related to the coronavirus. The research is not limited to medicine and public health, but also the social aspects of the pandemic and its effects on the education system. The researchers have 18 months to complete their projects.

On May 4th, both hair and beauty salons will be opening up with hygiene regulations including: mandatory posting of information on hygiene, social distancing (1.5 meters) between clients and staff (Plexiglass barrier recommended for regular cleaning and disinfection), disinfectants (must be available in waiting rooms/entrance area, payment desk, and work area). It is recommended that towels and gowns are replaced by disposable towels and gowns and that both staff and clients wear gloves and face masks.

On Mar 21 the Croatia national civil protection authority decided to suspend all public transportation services, including transport by rail, bus and tram, for the next 30 days, and the decision goes into force on Sunday, March 22.
All railway and bus stations will be closed. Travel to islands will be possible only for people who live on islands.

On Apr 1 the Croatian coronavirus crisis team declared that as of April 6 leaving one's place of residence will be possible only with an e-pass. The e-passes will be issued for a period of one to fourteen days, depending on the reason.

On Feb 13 the Croatian Government has established the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia to coordinate all services in the event of the occurrence of COVID-19 coronavirus in Croatia.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On 2 February 2020 in cooperation with Croatian and French authorities, four Croatian nationals, among 250 passengers from fifteen European countries, were evacuated from China and arrived by a special French aircraft to the Istres military airport near Marseille.
On Mar 30 the Croatian Police Directorate has called upon all foreigners on short stay in Croatia who are not able to leave Croatia to send their information to the police in order to be registered.

On January 23, at the initiative of the Ministry of Health, the Croatian Institute of Public Health has published a multilingual leaflet and a notification on coronavirus for travellers to China (in Croatian, English and Chinese).

26 February 2020 The daily sessions of the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia were introduced at 9 am and 4 pm, after which press releases were issued and published on the website Civil Protection Directorate.
On March 18, the Croatian government established a COVID-19 call centers where epidemiologists and other professionals can answer citizens questions every day from 8am to 4pm.

On April 14, the Croatian Ministry of Health introduced Andrija - the first digital coronavirus assistant in Croatia. The app helps people recognize symptoms of coronavirus infection (self-assessment of their own health status), connects people to competent institutions, allows people to report relevant information from their household, and helps nursing home employees understand health protocols.

On April 27, the  The Croatian Institute of Public Health and the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Croatia established an Open Data Portal which collects data regarding COVID-19 and ensures transparency with real-time data that citizens can access at any time.

On 2 February 2020 after the evacuation of four Croatian nationals, who arrived by a special French aircraft from China to the Istres military airport near Marseille, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs ordered their isolation due to precautionary measures to prevent the spread of the COVID-19 coronavirus epidemic. They were kept in quarantine for 14 days i.e. during the incubation time of the disease.

On Feb 21 the Croatian Institute of Public Health initiated the quarantine of persons who were identified or suspected to have been in direct contact with patients with COVID-19 while on board ships. The designated quarantine unit is at the Infectious Diseases Clinic  "Dr Fran Mihaljevic " in Zagreb.

On Feb 23 the Croatian Crisis Headquarters of the Ministry of Health presented additional measures that Croatia will take against the spread of coronavirus including: 
For all persons who have been in close contact with a patient, self-isolation is foreseen in their own home with daily contact with the epidemiologist or organized quarantine if there are no conditions for self-isolation.

On Feb 23 the Croatian Crisis Headquarters of the Ministry of Health presented additional measures that Croatia will take against the spread of coronavirus including: 
All travelers coming from the affected areas are foreseen to be placed in self-isolation with health surveillance and are obliged to report daily to the epidemiologist. The affected areas include China, the Republic of Korea (South Korea) and the provinces of Lombardy and Veneto in Italy.

Croatia is enforcing a 14 days quarantine on passengers arriving from areas with high risk of infection. These areas are:
China: Hubei province
Germany: the County of Heinsberg in the state of North Rhine-Westphalia
Iran
Italy
Slovenia: Bela Krajina and Dolenjska regions
South Korea: the city of Daegu and the County of Cheongdo

On Mar 26 the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared to liberalize the procedure related to Croatian and foreign citizens that drive for Croatian employers in international transport. Following loading or unloading they can be in self-isolation at their homes and no longer have to go into quarantine. If they notice any kind of symptoms they must contact their doctors.

On March 19 the Croatian government ordered the suspension of all businesses for 30 days with the exception of grocery stores, food and hygiene items, market and fish markets, specialized stores selling and dispensing (pharmacies), specialized stores selling and dispensing veterinary medicinal products, agricultural pharmacies, gas stations, kiosks, bakery, chemical laundry, specialized stores selling orthopedic and other aids, specialized baby equipment stores, specialized animal feed stores, issuance of construction materials based on retail order
logistic and distribution centers for food, beverages and hygiene products and wholesalers.
On Mar 22 the Croatian Ministry of Interior ordered the closure of farm produce markets.
On March 19, the government of Croatia ordered the closing of libraries, museums, and galleries in order to limit the spread of COVID-19.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: 9 March 2020 the Croatian National headquarters for coronavirus introduced new measures to prevent spreading of virus: It is recommended to postpone all public events with more than 1000 people. If organizers however decide to organize such events, they must ensure high hygienic standards.
On March 19, Croatian government cancelled religious services (all public events, gatherings, and meetings of more than 5 persons in one place).
On March 19 Croatia is putting a ban on the gathering of more than 5 people in one place for 30 days.
On March 21, the government of Croatia announced that only immediate family and religious community representatives may attend funerals.

On March 3 the Croatian Institute of Public Health has issued recommendations for the preservation of health of persons over 60 years of age and those suffering from chronic diseases who should avoid visits and entry into crowded public areas and routine check-ups and visits to general practitioners and hospitals should be skipped unless there is a need for urgent health care services.
On March 16, the Ministry of Health in Croatia announced their recommendation for people suffering respiratory infection symptoms to wear a mask.

In Croatia on March 19, the government implemented a strict measurement of social distancing to avoid close personal contact at a distance of at least two (2) meters indoors and one (1) meter outdoors for 30 days.
On April 24, the Croatian Institute of Public Health issued a recommendation for drivers of public transportation (buses and trams) to wear masks.

On May 14, the Croatian Institute of Public Health issued recommendations of social distancing for visitors at  beaches as well as freshwater and sea swimming areas. These recommendations include  a maximum number of 15 people per one hundred square meters on the beaches and maintaining 1.5 m physical distance between individuals in the water.
Czech Ministry of Health bans the physical presence of students in primary, secondary and grammar and vocational schools as well as in universities.
In-person education of primary school pupils, as well as various extracurricular activities of these pupils, are allowed again as of Monday May 25th by the Czech government.
Government of the Czech Republic announces a state of emergency. By default, this lasts 30 days (without consent of the Parliament needed).
Czech Republic bans all international airlines from operating direct flights from China to Czech Republic.
Czech Republic's Security Council discourages from traveling to the Italian regions of Veneto and Lombardy.
Czech Republic's Ministry of Health temporarily banned direct flight connection from South Korea as well as from all airports in the Italian regions of Emilia-Romagna, Piemont, Lombardy and Veneto.
Czech Republic's Ministry of Health temporarily banned direct flight connection from South Korea as well as from all airports in the Italian regions of Emilia-Romagna, Piemont, Lombardy and Veneto.
Czech government implements "akce Korona" - an operation where law enforcement carries out temperature checks on border crossings.
Czech Government bans Czech citizens and foreign citizens with permanent residence in Czech Republic from leaving the Czech Republic.

Czech Government bans all foreign nationals from entering the country, with the exception of individuals with long-term residence in Czech Republic and individuals whose entry is in the interest of the state.

On March 18 the Czech Government issued a policy addressing cross-border workers, ordering them to limit their movement within Czech Republic. This policy also cancelled some of the exceptions from free movement restriction (policy from March 15). Cross-border workers will be subjected to temperature checks while crossing the border and a COVID-19 test will be administered to them if they show symptoms of the illness.

On April 7, Czech Government announces the travelers' obligation to declare the date and means of their repatriation to the embassy of the country from which they are departing. Special online form was set up on the website of Ministry of Foreign Affairs for these purposes.

On April 27th, new emergency directive issued by the Czech Government takes effect. It restates some previously instated policies and loosens some travel restrictions, allowing Czech citizens to cross the border in certain special circumstances (such as work obligations or visiting family). These citizens must present themselves with a negative COVID-19 test no older than 4 days upon inbound travel or enter 14-day quarantine.

On April 14, 2020, Czech Ministry of Health informs about the purchase of medical devices and medical equipment intended for health service providers. The ministry ordered 359 lung ventilators and 520 thermographic cameras. A total of 44 lung ventilators have already been delivered.
Czech Ministry of Health bans the export and sale of type FFP3 respirator masks to organisations or individuals outside the medical or law enforcement sectors.
Czech Ministry of Health bans all persons - aside from manufacturers - from exporting hand sanitizer products.

Czech Government plans to re-orient two hospitals exclusively on care for COVID-19 patients. Specifically, this should be Nemocnice na Homolce in Prague and Fakultn " nemocnice u sv. Anny in Brno, each with the capacity of around 300 hospital beds.
On March 15, 2020, Czech government prohibits all employees in the medical profession/healthcare staff from taking leave during state of emergency.
On March 17, Czech Government issues a ban on re-export of medical supplies and medicines which were originally meant for Czech markets.

Czech Government prevents all residents from appearing in public (outside of their homes) without a physical cover of their mouth and nose. Respirators, face masks, home-made masks as well as scarves are admissible.

On April 1st, Czech Government orders all regional administrations to secure special COVID-19 hospital wards with the capacity of at least 60 hospital beds per 100 000 residents of the region, to be used flexibly according to the development of the pandemic. The hospital wards are to be clearly marked as reserved for COVID-19 patients.

On April 9, 2020, Czech Ministry of Health announces that hospitals will have to report all changes in the availability of intensive care capacities for both COVID-19 positive patients and other patients as well as the number of doctors and healthcare staff who have been put into the quarantine.

On April 9, 2020, Czech government announces the payment of extraordinary remuneration to employees of regional hygienic stations, health institutions and healthcare providers for their extraordinary work related to the management of the COVID-19 epidemic.

On April 9, 2020, Czech government mandates public health authorities, emergency services and major hospitals to use the capacities of university and high school students in the final years of their studies to assist in the healthcare system.

On April 9, 2020, Czech government changes the criteria for identifying a critical infrastructure elements. Pharmaceutical product manufacturers with significant production capacities in the Czech Republic have been granted critical infrastructure status.
As of Monday May 25th, visits to patients who are currently hospitalized were allowed again by the Czech government.
On March 15, 2020, Czech government calls soldiers and customs officers to help the Czech police to perform tasks related with the measures against the spread of the COVID-19

Czech Government dedicates special hours in grocery stores specifically for individuals of 65+ years of age; anyone younger who is not a legal guardian of an elderly customer nor employee of the store cannot enter the store facilities between 10am and 11am.

Czech Government mandates shops which sell baked goods which are not prepackaged to maintain special hygiene measures. Shops are to ensure that people are able to maintain 2m distance, preventing overcrowding.

On April 6, Czech Government decides to allow individual outdoor sports (such as cycling, tennis or running). These will be able to be carried out without a face mask if people maintain 2 meters distance from each other.

On April 9, 2020, at the request of the Minister of Culture, Czech government approved financial assistance to cultural institutions and artists who lost their livelihoods due to government quarantine measures. The Ministry of Culture will receive from the government budget reserve 770 million Czech crowns to support non-state artistic entities and up to 300 million Czech crowns for remediation of impacts on contributory organizations of the Ministry of Culture, depending on whether the restrictions adopted by the government will continue after May 31, 2020. The Ministry will support, for example, access to art through digital technologies, etc.

Czech Republic Ministry of Health implements a protective measure targeted specifically at the Prague International Airport and its employees. It includes a verbal announcement about what to do should travelers develop COVID-19 symptoms in every plane landing in Prague, gathered in an information leaflet.

Czech Republic Ministry of Health implements an exception to the mandatory quarantine measures from March 6, 2020, relevant to freight transportation employees, medical ambulance crews and commercial pilots. If observing symptoms of COVID-19, such individuals are to report to their general practitioner. They are mandated to use increased hygiene measures during their work (including respirators type FFP2 or FFP3).

Czech Government imposes mandatory home quarantine on individuals traveling from (or recently residing in) risk countries, which were specified as: China, South Korea, Iran, Italy, Spain, Austria, Germany, Switzerland, Sweden, Netherlands, Belgium, Great Britain, Norway, Denmark and France.

Czech Government encourages citizens over 70 years of age to isolate at home, only leaving to obtain necessary medical care. Mayors and local governments are asked to assist senior citizens with securing groceries and other necessities.

On March 30, Czech Government announced that all travelers entering the country will have to undergo strict at-home quarantine for the duration of at least 14 days, no matter the country they visited.

On April 14, 2020, Czech government presented a medium-term plan to abandon the extraordinary restrictions such as quarantine or lockdowns. The presented government strategy, which is about to start on April 20, 2020, includes actions in the time period until June 8, 2020. However, all these steps are indicative only and are subject to possible change.

Czech Government manned law enforcement workers from pursuing an additional income outside of their employment in law enforcement. This policy is to last as long as the national state of emergency is in place.

On April 1, Czech Government introduces new exceptions to restrictions of non-essential business. Starting April 2 at 6am, home-ware stores will be allowed to open - given that they sell cloth face masks or supplies from which cloth face masks can be created.

As of April 9, the Government asks all open businesses (to whom exceptions from general restriction of non-essential businesses apply) to provide rubber or plastic gloves and hand sanitizer to all customers entering the store's facilities. Customers are also expected to maintain 2 meters distance while shopping. Government issued information brochures detailing this policy are to be displayed inside the store.
As of Monday May 25th, indoor as well as open-air pools are allowed to reopen by the Czech government.
As of Monday 25th, businesses which require the breaking of skin (such as tattoo parlors, piercing salons, permanent makeup stores) are allowed to re-open by the Czech Government.

On Monday May 25th. the indoor areas of restaurants, cafes (including those situated in shopping centers over 5000 meters square), hotels, campsites, castles and historical sights, zoos, botanical gardens, dendrological gardens, saunas and wellness centers are allowed to open. Therefore, these businesses are allowed to resume operation. Special hygiene measures still apply (such as wearing a mask when required, sanitizing hands and keeping a social distance).
All taxi services (which were currently forbidden) are allowed to operate as of Monday May 25th.
Czech Government ruled that all events over 5000 participants need to report to their local hygienic station.
Czech Government bans cultural, educational and sports events with over 100 participants. Court proceedings, governmental meetings and board meetings are exempted.
As of April 24th, Czech government allows public gatherings of up to 10 people. This applies to public spaces as well as outdoor sporting grounds.
As of Monday May 25th, events of up to 300 participants are allowed again by the Czech government.

Czech Ministry of Health decides that the planned BMW IBU World Cup Biathlon as planned between March 5 and March 8 2020 (annual sports event with thousands of attendees) will go on without an audience.

Czech Ministry of Health cancels public visiting hours in hospitals, social services provider centers and retirement homes. Exception applies in the case of underage patients, patients who require legal guardianship, pregnant women and patients in final stages of a terminal illness.

On March 24 (effective at 6am), Czech Government restricts free movement of residents in groups bigger than two individuals. Exception applies to families, work or business activities and funerals.

Citizens are advised to keep a distance of 2 meters from each other at all times.

On April 9, 2020, Czech Ministry of Health regulates the regime in prisons. In order to limit the risk of spreading COVID-19, the Prison Service should accommodate the prisoners according to their respective workplace classification.

On April 9, 2020, Czech Ministry of Health extends the mandated limited operation of authorities and institutions until 19 April. Starting April 20, all public authorities and administrative institutions are to comply with stricter hygiene rules. (a distance of minimum 2 meters, hand disinfection available, increased disinfection of spaces)
Denmark is enforcing school closure (universities, gymnasium) after march 13
Denmark has closed all its public schools and universities. This was announced on 11 March and implemented on 16 March 2020. At first it was announced for two weeks.

The government of Denmark is enforcing a restriction of external borders: Denmark closed its borders to all but Danish citizens, individuals with Danish work or residency permits, and those the Danish government determines have a critical purpose of travel after March 14.
Denmark is asking its residents to install a symptom-tracker app since April. Government-issued digital IDs are used to authenticate users.
Denmark is enforcing a Health Resources Measure: Widening Test capacity in all hospitals after Feb 25.
Denmark is enforcing a new health resources measure: no one should wear a face mask (with/without symptoms, risk group or not) after March 3.
Denmark is enforcing health resources measure: in four bigger hospitals in the country drive-in testing is possible after March 11.
Denmark is enforcing a health resources measure: non-essential operations should be postpone after March 17.

Denmark is expanding its testing efforts: not only people with severe symptoms of Covid-19 will be tested, but all people with respiratory symptoms should take a test from April 20 on. To that end, mass testing centres have been set up across the country.

Denmark is promoting free vaccines for the over-65s and vulnerable groups under 65 (pneumococci), health workers and vulnerable groups (flu) and pregnant women (whooping cough). The goal is to reach a 75 percent sign-up rate for the pneumococci and flu vaccinations. This goes into effect on April 22.
Denmark has invested 120 million kroner (about  "18 million) in antibody tests produced in China.

Denmark is giving out new guidelines for professions with close contact with infected or potentially infected people (especially in the health and care sectors) from April 24 on. The key point is mandatory protective gear.
Denmark is enforcing a Public Awareness Campaign after March 17: New Hotline.
Denmark is issuing new information about to use a face mask on May 5.
Denmark is enforcing a Quarantine on all positive-tested covid19-cases and their close contacts after Feb 28.

Denmark is ordering home quarantine for all infected people that have no or mild symptoms and are not considered particularly vulnerable are placed with daily contact from health professionals. Anybody that has been in close contact with someone who is known to be infected by SARS-CoV-2 is placed in home quarantine as well. Quarantine in those cases is enforced for 14 days. The policy was announced on 29 February 2020.
Denmark is enforcing a voluntary Quarantine on all travelers from risk areas who returned to denmark after March 2.
Denmark is recommending that all workers with non-essential work should work from home if possible after march 11.
Denmark closed all its zoos on March 18.
Denmark is enforcing a restriction of non-essential govt-servives after March 11: everyone not critical should stay home.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Denmark is enforcing a restriction of mass gatherings after march 11: it is recommending to cancel events with more than 100 participants.

Denmark is lowering the maximum number of people allowed to assemble, from 100 to 50, in 17 municipalities of the Copenhagen region, along with Odense municipality. This is to combat the recent rising transmission rate of COVID-19 in these places.
Denmark is enforcing Social Distancing for nursery homes, facilities for elderly people and hospitals after march 17.

Following the declaration of an emergency situation, studies in educational establishments changed. From the 16th of March "schools are required to suspend regular classroom studies and switch over to remote and home studying"

Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020

Education in lower secondary schools, upper secondary schools, vocational education institutions and higher education institutions (except in research and development institutions  of universities and research institutions), as well as in continuous education institutions, informal education and hobby activities, and the activities of open youth centres must follow the 2+2 rule; students may work in groups of no more than 10 students (except for exams); when organising the exams the students must be dispersed in the exam room, the movement of groups of students must be dispersed, and all items in common use must be disinfected after use.
Estionian Government declared an emergency situation in Estonia on the 12th of March which is to be effective until the 1st of May 2020.
In Estonia, on Monday, May 18, the nationwide state of emergency that has been in place for two months has been lifted.

Due to the emergency situation declared in Estonia, listed Estonian shipper Tallink Grupp announced on Saturday (March 14) that it is temporarily suspending the traffic of its vessels on the Tallinn-Stockholm route beginning Sunday in a measure to ensure the health and safety of people in the Baltic Sea region.

To set up full border controls from 17 March on, with only the following people allowed to enter the country: citizens of Estonia, permanent residents, their relatives, and transport workers carrying out freight transport.

Estonia - From Friday, May 15, movement between Latvia, Estonia, and Lithuania is free unlike in other parts of Europe. At midnight, the nearly two-month-long joint work of Estonian police officers, auxiliary police officers, the Tax and Customs Board (MTA), and the Defense League (Kaitseliit) ended at the Ikla-Aina_i border checkpoint.

On 15 May 2020, the Foreign Ministers of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania gathered in Riga to sign a trilateral Memorandum of Understanding on lifting travel restrictions between Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania for land, rail, air and maritime transport and cooperation thereof during the COVID-19 crisis. This memorandum is accompanying the decision initially taken by the three Baltic states " Prime Ministers on 6 May 2020 to reciprocally open the borders on 15 May 2020 to restore the movement for the three countries " citizens, and persons legally residing in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, and respective individual decisions by the Governments of the Baltic states.

Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020  " As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18, the Government approved four orders.
Tallinn-Stockholm cruises will not take place.
The prohibition of excursions for tourism remains in force on Tallinn-Stockholm shipping route.

Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020  " As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18, the Government approved four orders. 
RESTRICTIONS ON CROSSING THE STATE BORDER AND QUARANTINE
Thirdly, the Government approved an order extending the restrictions on crossing the Estonian state border. Latvian or Lithuanian citizens, holders of residence permits, or persons with a right of residence in these countries who have no symptoms of the disease, may enter Estonia without an obligation for quarantine.

Finnish citizens, holders of residence permits or persons with a right of residence in Finland, who have no symptoms of the disease, who come to Estonia to work, study or for unavoidable family reasons such as meeting with their close relatives, attending a funeral or a wedding, or need to visit due to a case of illness, can also enter Estonia.

A foreign national without any symptoms of the disease, traveling to their home country is also allowed to transit through Estonia.
People without symptoms of the disease, who have had the right to enter Estonia previously without an obligation to stay in quarantine, may continue to do so. For example, people transporting goods and raw materials, persons involved in the international carriage of cargo and passengers, persons involved in the technical work of a company operating in Estonia, health care providers, diplomats, people arriving within the framework of international military cooperation, etc.

From Monday, March 16, going on sick leave can be done as a temporary measure online in Estonia, following the government's declaration of an emergency situation due to the coronavirus pandemic late last week.
An increased workload for family doctors and the health sector as a whole means that getting in touch with a doctor may be more difficult; those in need of filing an official sick note (Haigusleht) with employers can do so via the Patient Portal, the Health Insurance Fund (Haigekassa), family doctors association (perearstide selts) and health and well-being center (Tervise ja Heaolu Infos "steemide Keskus) say.

Estonian prime-minister, J "ri Ratas, has signed an order according to which all sales and service halls that are open to customers must be equipped with disinfectants. The order takes effect from April 4.

On 16 April 2020, the government decided to support two sero-epidemiological studies in Estonia to determine the extent of the spread of coronavirus in the country. Testing will be carried out under the research project of the COVID-19 monitoring system and will be carried out by the research team of the University of Tartu. People will be selected based on random selection for testing across Estonia. Weekly, 2,000 people will be tested, regardless if they have symptoms or not, so it would be possible to assess the spread of the infection across the country in different counties and population groups.

Stenbock House, 6 July 2020 - Upon arrival from countries outside the European Union where the number of infected persons per 100,000 people is more than 16, people entering Estonia for the purpose of work or study must remain in isolation. Both transport and living during the 14-day period of self-isolation must be ensured, and the person must pass two coronavirus tests, one of which is performed upon arrival in Estonia and the other on the 14th day of stay. The employee can start working in Estonia on the 15th day of their stay in Estonia if their second test is negative.

Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020  " As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18, the Government approved four orders.
When entering and exiting the sales and service premises, both employees and customers must be provided with the possibility of using disinfectants.

Both the Health Board (Terviseamet) and the government agree that wearing face masks in public in an effort to curb the spread of the coronavirus need not be made mandatory. The authorities say research on the use of masks has been controversial, and that wearing them incorrectly can do more harm than good.
10.08.20
They are recommended for those who have contracted the virus who have to leave home for unavoidable reasons, and those who have been in close contact with a carrier, or in enclosed, crowded public spaces like public transport.
"The Health Board and the government are of the opinion that face masks should not be mandatory in Estonia, but should remain only recommended for patients in situations where leaving home, or close contact with someone with the virus, is unavoidable," Hanna Sepp, chief specialist at the board said.
Estonia is heading the preparation of the coping and exit strategy under the leadership of the Government Office led by the planning group which will take part in Government Committee on April 14.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description:
Estonia joins statement on safety of journalists and access to information during the COVID-19 crisis
15. April 2020 - 16:40
Everyone has the right to comprehensible, accessible, timely and reliable information concerning the nature and level of the threat COVID-19 poses to their health, allowing them to follow evidence-based guidance on how to stay safe.We welcome a range of initiatives aimed at supporting journalists " and media workers " safety in the light of COVID-19 undertaken by international organisations, such as UNESCO and civil society, media associations as well as social media companies.

Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020  " As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18, the Government approved four orders.
Public religious services and other religious rites are allowed if the 2+2 rule is complied with and the provision of disinfectants is guaranteed.

Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020  " As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18, the Government approved four orders during the e-sessions of the Government. 
First, the Government approved the order to continue to restrict the sale of alcohol at all places selling alcohol, including restaurants and bars, from 22:00 to 10:00. The restrictions do not apply on board of a ship or an aircraft used for international passenger transport and to a sales premises located in the security area of the international airport or port. The restriction on the sale of alcohol applies to catering establishments, including bars and other similar sales premises until July 1.

Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020 
When visiting museums and exhibition institutions, the 2+2 rule must be observed; for visiting groups, there may be a maximum of ten visitors in the group; the availability of disinfectants must be ensured. The surfaces frequently touched by visitors must be cleaned frequently. If possible, the organiser offers digital information materials instead of physical materials. Creative workshops will not be organised using commonly used tools or, if organised, they will be disinfected after each user.

Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020  " As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18, the Government approved four orders during the e-sessions of the Government yesterday, confirming restrictions and easing of restrictions in force after the end of the emergency situation. 
It is allowed to engage in sports, to train and hold sports and exercise events if the 2+2 rule is observed and the number of participants does not exceed 10 persons, and the organiser has ensured the availability of disinfectants.

Tallinn, Stenbock House, 11 June 2020  " The government clarified its previous order and provided that a person arriving in Estonia from a country with a higher COVID-19 infection rate would be subject to a 14-day restriction on freedom of movement. Quarantine was previously required, but for the sake of legal clarity, the wording of the order was clarified by adding a restriction on freedom of movement.

Similarly to the current regulation, the specified order stipulates that the restriction of freedom of movement is applied during the latent period of infection, or 14 days. This means a prohibition on leaving the place of residence or permanent residence, except on the instructions of a healthcare professional or a police officer or in the event of an emergency endangering a person "s life or health. People can also leave home to receive healthcare services or if it is not possible to obtain food, basic necessities, or medicine in any other way.

Tallinn, Stenbock House, 18 June 2020  " As of 19 June, the government has decided to replace the 2+2 rule with a requirement for people to disperse. This means that a safe distance between people must continue to be maintained, but the state no longer requires compliance with the 2+2 rule.
Dispersion requirements will replace the 2+2 rule in all public spaces, such as stores, service points and public-use spaces at shopping centres, as well as at casinos and slot machine locations. In place of the 2+2 rule, dispersion must also be ensured at public events, public meetings and religious services.

The requirement will apply to public saunas, spas, swimming pools and water parks, as well as bowling, billiards and children's playrooms. Along with the organisation of activities in basic schools, upper secondary schools, vocational schools and institutes of higher education, training centres, hobby schools, recreational activity providers, and public youth centres. It will also be in place at children's and student camps, sports and museum and exhibition visits.

The Ministry of Education has said that guidelines it is providing to schools ahead of the academic year starting on September 1 are just that, and not mandatory responsibilities, adding that these have taken on board lessons learned during the spring coronavirus peak and are aimed at avoiding a return to remote learning.

Estonian schools have not had in-classroom teaching since March, due to the pandemic. After some discussion about schools returning early, in mid-August, for the 2020-2021 academic year, the decision was made to stick to the traditional September 1 first day of school.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs
Starting from 1 September, people with a negative COVID-19 test arriving from countries with an increased risk of infection (with an infection rate exceeding 16 and marked as red or countries not included in the following list https://vm.ee/en/information-countries-and-self-isolation-requirements-p...) are permitted to go to work if it is absolutely crucial, and on the condition that they immediately test negative for the virus on their arrival. All contact with other people must be avoided while waiting for the test results. In case of a negative test result, the restriction on the freedom of movement applies for the first seven days, i.e. it is allowed to go to work or shop for essentials in case of emergencies but non-essential contacts should be avoided. They must take a second test no earlier than 7 days after the first test and if the test is also negative, they are free to continue their everyday life. This means that the 14-day restriction on the freedom of movement does not apply to them after two negative tests.

Secondly, the Government confirmed the order to establish quarantine after the end of the emergency situation for COVID-19 patients and people living with them who are in close contact with the patients.
People infected with COVID-19 are prohibited from leaving their place of residence from the time of diagnosis until recovery. This also applies to the people using shelters and other such services who must remain in quarantine at their place of stay.

People in close contact with infected persons may move outside their residence to a limited extent only if they have no symptoms of the disease.  It is allowed to leave the home if it is unavoidable, and for spending some time outdoors, if all the measures are taken to prevent the spread of the disease, and instructions of the Health Board are observed.

The person may also leave their residence if they have received an order from a health care worker or a police officer instructing them to leave the place of residence or permanent stay, or in the event of an emergency which threatens the person's life or health.

From 1 June, Estonia allows entry to individuals without symptoms arriving from a member state of the European Union or the Schengen area, or the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. Mandatory self-isolation for passengers arriving in Estonia depends on whether the coronavirus infection rate in their country of departure is above 16. Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020  " As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18, the Government approved four orders. Fourthly, the Government approved an order extending the majority of movement restrictions and specifying the conditions for their implementation.

2+2 rule
In public places and indoor premises, the so-called 2+2 rule remains in force, which means that both outdoors and indoors up to two people may be together, keeping a distance of 2-meters from other people. The rule does not apply to families or at homes. The rule applies to all activities in Estonia that do not take place in domestic conditions.

With effect from 19 June, the Government of the Republic decided to replace the 2+2 rule with a requirement for people to disperse. This means that a safe distance between people must continue to be maintained, but the state no longer requires compliance with the 2+2 rule, as Estonian residents understand and accept the need to keep their distance. The requirement will apply in public saunas, spas, swimming pools and water parks as well as bowling alleys, billiard rooms and children's playrooms. It will also apply in basic schools, upper secondary schools, vocational education institutions and higher education institutions, as well as in organising the activities of continuing education institutions, hobby schools and open youth centres. It will also extend to youth camps and student camps, sports activities and visits to museums and exhibitions.

Tallinn, Stenbock House, March 24, 2020 - Additional measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 have been agreed by the Government Emergency Committee. The new measures concern people-to-people distance in public space.

On March 16, the Finnish Government's Ministry of education and culture has adopted policy recommendations for the education sector. "Early childhood education and care units and the pre-primary education associated will be kept in operation. However, the Government recommends children being cared for at home."For primary and lower secondary education, school premises will be closed until 13 April 2020 and contact teaching will be suspended. As an exception, pre-primary education organised in schools and contact teaching for pupils in grades 1 to 3 will continue for the children of parents who work in sectors critical to the functioning of society. The premises of schools, educational institutions, universities, universities of applied sciences, basic art education as well as civic education and other liberal education institutes will be closed until 13 April 2020, and contact teaching will be suspended. Teaching and guidance will be organised as widely as possible in alternative ways, including distance learning. All national and municipal museums, theatres, the National Opera, cultural venues, libraries, mobile libraries, services for customer and researchers at the National Archives, hobby and leisure centres, swimming pools and other sports facilities, youth centres, clubs, organisations " meeting rooms, day care services for the elderly, rehabilitative work facilities and workshops will be closed until 13 April. These arrangements were entered into force on Wednesday 18 March 2020. On March 31, the exceptional arrangements for education were announced to be extended until 13 May, and considering the situations of the pandemic, possibly to the end of the term.

On 29 April, the Finnish government decides to reopen early childhood education, childcare facilities, and primary and lower secondary education institutions in a controlled manner under strict guidelines. The guidelines that must be met include:
- avoidance of unnecessary physical contact
- arranging teaching premises more spacious than usual
- school break times and school meals must be held with the student's own class or group
- no large gatherings, such as spring festivals
- personnel must work with the same group of children and hygiene guidelines must be strictly respected

The school year is set to end on 30 May.

On 6 May, Finland's Ministry of Social and Health lifts restrictions on upper secondary and vocational schools, universities, as well as adult education as of 14 May. The ministry recommends continuation of distance education, if possible. Educational institutions must comply with hygiene guidelines and physical distancing measures.

"On 4 August, Finland's Ministry of Education amends the Act on Vocational Education and Training temporarily. If, for reasons attributable to the coronavirus epidemic, a demonstration of the professional skills and competence required to pass a qualification module cannot be conducted in authentic work situations and processes, a student may demonstrate his or her professional skills and competence by performing other practical tasks that are as similar to authentic work situations and processes as possible. In addition, the demonstration of skills and competence can be supplemented with other types of competence assessment more flexibly than at present.

In higher education institutions, a student may register as a non-attending student during the first academic year if he or she is prevented from starting his or her studies due to an official regulation related to the epidemic or for another epidemic-related serious reason. If studies are delayed due to exceptional teaching arrangements introduced by a higher education institution because of the coronavirus epidemic, this will be taken into account when deciding on the extension of the right to study. The amendments made to the Act on Vocational Education and Training, the Universities Act and the Universities of Applied Sciences Act will remain in force until 31 July 2021."

On 4 August, Finland's Ministry of Education announces new measures for early childhood education and care. Early childhood education and care should be organised so that groups are not mixed or combined. Staff members in early childhood education and care should also work with the same group of children. Children starting school or early childhood education and their parents will be given an opportunity to familiarise themselves with activities in advance, provided that good hygiene is ensured and there are not too many people in the same space at the same time. Children may bring along an important toy and take it home at the end of the day.

On 4 August, Finland's Ministry of Education announces new measures for schools and educational institutions. In primary schools, the different teaching groups should be kept separate throughout the school day. Activities should be staggered with the aim that that there are few people in the same space as possible. Staff members should also avoid assembling, which means, for example, that teachers should hold their meetings remotely. If contact teaching cannot be organised safely - as will be assessed in cooperation with regional authorities, then contact teaching and distance learning can be alternated, by placing groups in distance learning in alternate weeks. This does not apply to students in years 1-3 who have special needs support or students in extended compulsory or preparatory education. Students have the right to school meals, support for learning and school attendance, study guidance, and students benefits during exceptional arrangements.

On 4 August, Finland's Ministry of Education announces new measures for schools and educational institutions. In lower secondary schools and in optional subjects, teaching groups may change if the teaching cannot be organised any other way. Safe distances of 1 to 2 meters should be maintained in general upper secondary schools, vocational education and training institutes, higher education institutions and liberal adult education. Providers of general upper secondary education and vocational education and training and higher education may flexibly decide on safe and appropriate teaching methods and arrangements. If teaching is arranged for a large number of people, it is advisable to use remote connections.

On 16 March 2020, the Finnish Government announced that there is a state of emergency in the country as a result of the coronavirus outbreak. On March 31, the exercise of powers under the Emergency Powers Act is extended until 13 May 2020.
On March 16, Finland announced that it will halt inbound passenger travel 'as soon as possible' with the exception of Finnish nationals and residents returning home to Finland.
Finland restricts its citizens from travelling abroad on March 16. Finnish tourists abroad are advised to return to Finland immediately.

Finland has started restricting its cross-border traffic at Finland "s borders starting on Thursday 19 March at midnight. Border-crossing points will be closed and border controls will be reintroduced. People must not travel abroad at all between 18 March and 13 April. This applies to travel by land, by sea and by air. A person returning to Finland from abroad should remain in quarantine-like conditions for 14 days. Finnish citizens and permanent residents in Finland are always allowed to return to Finland. Foreign travellers in Finland can leave the country.

On 10 March, Finland decides to suspend decisions on visa applications in Finland's missions until further notice. 'Passports related to visa applications under consideration will be returned' and will not be processed, with the exception of those from Russia. Individuals who are applying for a visa who have Finnish citizen family member may also fall under this exemption.

Finland places restrictions on its external borders starting Thursday, March 19. All individuals arriving from abroad are asked to fill in a form to assess their exposure before arriving at border security. Their forms will then be assessed and passengers will then be directed to either go home or be to directed to a health checkpoint. Those experiencing symptoms will be directed to sampling and brought to a hotel accomodation to wait for results. If the result is positive, they will be transferred to healthcare.

The Finnish government bans workers who commute from Estonia to Finland on 20 March. Workers who permanently reside in Estonia but commute for Finland for work must choose where they reside. 'Hopefully, people working permanently in Finland will stay in Finland', the Finnish Minister of Interior said. Finland will not obstruct Estonians from leaving Finland, but those who do, will not be able to re-enter the country from March 22.

On 24 March, the Finnish government allocates 4 million euros in funding to the Ministry for Foreign Affairs to arrange 'reasonably priced repatriation flights for travellers who are no longer able to return to Finland using commercial connections'. The government urges all Finnish travellers remaining abroad to submit a travel notification and return to Finland as soon as possible.

On 7 April, Finland decides to reduce movement 'in the common travel-to-work area along the borders with Sweden and Norway' to strictly 'necessary travel'. Employees must 'carry a certificate from their employer stating that their work is essential'. Finland calls on employers to 'explore ways of reducing the cross-border movement of workers, for example by providing employees with accomodation near where they work'.

Finland recommends that 'shipping companies operating to Finland from Sweden, Estonia and Germany stop the sale of passenger tickets for ships departing on or after 11 April 2020, with the exceptions of goods and freight transport'.

"On 7 April, Finland decides to reduce movement 'in the common travel-to-work area along the borders with Sweden to strictly 'necessary travel'. Employees must 'carry a certificate from their employer stating that their work is essential'. Finland calls on employers to 'explore ways of reducing the cross-border movement of workers, for example by providing employees with accomodation near where they work'.

On 20 May, the Finnish Immigration Service decides to lower the cost of visa processing fees from EUR 520 to EUR 150 for adults and from EUR 270 to EUR 100 for minors. This will be specifically for cases where the permit is applied for because of the travel restrictions imposed because of the COVID19 pandemic. It will enter into force on 22 May 2020 and will end on 31 October 2020. 
Possible applicants include: people whose visa-free stay, visa, or residence permit has expired.

On 29 May, the Finnish government decides to allow 4,500 non-EU seasonal workers into Finland, provided they have the necessary permits for entry and for working, and their employer has filled in a form justifying the necessity of their entry into the country. The final decision to be made by the Border Guard.

On June 12, the Finnish government decides to make changes to its border control policies. Border controls will be lifted on June 15 from the land border between Finland and Norway, on air services and scheduled ferry services between Finland and Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, and recreational boat travel (i.e. private boats). 
Border controls will continue between Finland and the Schengen countries, besides those mentioned above, and Finnish citizens are advised not to travel to any other country besides those above.

On July 8, the Finnish government lifts border control restrictions for the following EU countries: the Netherlands, Belgium, Italy, Austria, Greece, Malta, Germany, Slovakia, Slovenia, Hungary, Liechtenstein, Andorra,  San Marino, Ireland, Cyprus, the Vatican, and Switzerland. In a statement, the Government said it will lift restrictions in countries where the coronavirus infection rate is below 8 new cases per 100,000 within 14 days. Finland had previously lifted it's restrictions for Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania.
On 23 July, the Finnish government reinstates border restrictions against Australia and Algeria, based on their rising infection rates.

On 23 July, the Finnish government announces that it will reinstate border controls between Finland and Spain, Luxembourg, Portugal, Poland, France, Sweden and Czech Republic, with exception of leisure boating.

On 23 July, Finland decides to reinstate border controls from traffic between Finland and Austria, Slovenia, and Switzerland based on an increase in infections in those countries. These restrictions will enter into force on 27 July and are set to end on 25 August.

On 6 August, the Finnish government reinstates border restrictions against Netherlands, Belgium, and Andorra due to rising infection rates in those countries. The restrictions will enter into force on 10 August.

On 6 August, the Finnish government reinstates border restrictions against Netherlands, Belgium, and Andorra due to rising infection rates in those countries. The restrictions will enter into force on 10 August.
On 19 August, the Finnish government restricts flights from Skopje in North Macedonia.
On 19 August, the Finnish government reinstates border restrictions against Ireland, Cyprus, San Marino, Japan, Iceland, Greece, Malta, Germany, Norway and Denmark.

On 27 August, the Finnish government decides to restricts entry of berry pickers coming from non-EU countries. This change will not affect, fo9r example, Thai berry pickers, as Thai residents are not subject to restrictions on entry.

On 11 September, the Finnish governments adopts new decisions on the regulation of external borders and will now categorise countries and regions with more than 25 cases per 100,000 inhabitations within 14 days as areas with a high infection rate.  The Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare will assess the categories of these incidences on a weekly basis. Aside from certain exceptions, a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken less than 72 hours prior to arrival would be required for those arriving from areas with a high infection rate.
On 11 September, the Finnish government places restrictions on Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Malta, Slovenia, USA, Russia, China and Ireland.
On 11 September, the Finnish government places restrictions on Switzerland, with exception of leisure boating.

On 24 September, the Finnish government places restrictions on Estonia, Germany, Iceland, Norway, Slovakia, Sweden, Canada, Georgia, and Tunisia.Thus, Finland has restrictions on: Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, and Switzerland.

On April 1, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health says that a surgical masks, protective gloves, and a medical gown or apron must be worn by home care service providers whenever treating patients with a respiratory infection. Staff must pay close attention to early stages of the coronavirus.

The telecommunications company Telia says that it will begin to provide the Finnish government with anonymised location data on the movement of Finnish citizens to help combat the COVID-19 outbreak. The data is gathered by Telia's telephone network towers and can track large human flows.

The Ministry of Social Affairs and Health urges the municipalities and social welfare units to pay special attention to appropriate action and prevention of the coronavirus in housing service units providing 24-hour care.

On 9 July, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health announces an amendment to the Communicable Disease Act that will allow for an information system consisting of a mobile application to track the chains of infection of COVID-19
On 31 August, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health releases the Koronavikku contract tracing app, available in both Finnish and Swedish. An English version is set to release in autumn.
On March 10, Finland says it will contribute one million euros to the World Health Organization for its work in developing countries to contain the COVID-19 outbreak.

The Finnish Medicines Agency (FIMEA) strongly advises against excessive stockpiling of medicines at home on 16 March. FIMEA instructs pharmacies to sell one one package of over-the-counter pain and fever medicines per customer.
The Finnish government announces that non-urgent healthcare and social welfare services will be reduced on March 16 to increase capacity to combat COVID-19.

On 16 March, Finland announces the ramping up of healthcare and social welfare services in both the public and private sector and that the capacity of the private sector will be mobilised for public use as necessary.
On 17 March, the Prime Minister of Finland adopts a measure that will limit the sale of medical supplies and pharmaceuticals used in the public health care system.
On March 17, the Finnish Prime Minister adopts a measure that will relieve municipalities of the duty to provide non-emergency care.

On 18 March, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health says that dental facilities must have ensure that clients are not exposed to infections and that the 'occupational safety of staff must be ensured at clinics even when treating patients with coronavirus'.
On 25 March, the Finnish government issues a decree to oblige healthcare professionals, between the ages of 18-68, to work, under the Emergency Powers Act.

On April 7, the Finnish national government calls on the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health to ensure the safeguarding of Aland hospital in cooperation with the government of Aland. Transfers of necessary doctors will be arranged from Finland to Aland, with assurances given that Finnish health staff have a level of fluency in Swedish.

On April 8, the Finnish government decides to increase the minimum staffing level for elderly clients in service housing with 24 hour assistance and in institutional care. Elderly and institutional support services are also under review.

The government proposes 600 million euros of funds be allocated 'for the acquisition of COVID-19 relevant protective equipment, devices and medicines' on 8 April, which will be acquired through the National Emergency Supply Agency.

On April 8, the Finnish government decides on a 12 million euro roadmap for making 'pharmaceutical services more cost-effective, safeguard pharmaceutical safety and guidance, and to secure the availability, accessibility and the smooth running' of pharmaceuticals. The roadmap also lays out a framework for the control of new medicines.

On April 8, the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health says that municipalities must make 'every effort to find alternative ways to continue rehabilitative work even in emergency conditions' if the client wishes to do so. These alternatives may include 'online coaching, remote tasks, individual guidance, and activities in workplaces where there is no risk of infection' and that these alternatives 'must always be carried out in agreement with the client'.

In Finnland, supplementary budget is granted to the administrative branch of the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health to be used for various kinds of social security benefits and the acquisition of COVID-19 relevant protective equipment, devices and medicines through the National Emergency Supply Agency.

On 23 March, the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health decides to begin distributing protective equipment from the country's Center for Security of Supply (IGC) to five university hospital districts. The protective equipment is that which is used primarily by professionals treating infected patients, such as face shields, respirators, surgical masks, protective jackets, etc.

The Ministry of Social Affairs and Health places measures in place to restrict the sale of asthma medication to one month of treatment on April 9. The restrictions are placed to 'ensure equal and fair access to medicines for all patients through Finland'.

On 12 May, the Finnish government extends a decree made under the Emergency Powers Act to the healthcare and social services sector to better respond to any acute personnel shortages caused by the pandemic. The decree allows employers to suspend or postpone the employee's leave and also waive the provisions of the Annual Holidays Act. Furthermore, employers may order employees to work overtime without the employee's consent for covertime and deviate from provisions regarding to rest periods. These decisions may only be made if legislation and collective bargaining agreements are insufficient to secure and safeguard operations.
Finland decides on granting additional funding for the World Health Organization (WHO) on April 15, to the level of 5.5 million euros.

On 18 April, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and health says that they do not recommend the use of medical face masks or fabric masks when moving in a public place for the general population. In its statement, the Ministry says that the respiratory protective equipment should be necessary for health care personnel openly and that the use of self-made fabric masks in public places 'may, at worst, lead to a false sense of security'.
The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) will provide testing equipment needed in detecting COVID19 to member states. Finland supports the initiative with EUR 200,000 in voluntary funding.

On 13 May, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health issues new guidelines for facilities providing 24-hour care and treatment. These guidelines include that staff who come into close contact with patients must wear disposable surgical nose-masks or washable or disposable fabric masks that cover their nose and mouth in order to protect against any disease.

On 13 May, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health orders social welfare workers staff to wear a mask when dealing with clients. If surgical nose-mouth masks are not available, washable or disposable fabric masks or visors may also be used.
