On 27 May, the Finnish Ministry of Economic Affairs and Employment announces that the domestic production of respiratory protective devices and protective garments for the healthcare sector has begun. In March-April, the Ministry began the project aimed at launching the domestic production of protective materials.

Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health announces 5 million EUR of discretionary funds to be granted to organisations and foundations in the health and service sector to respond to the needs for psychosocial support caused by COVID-19. The announcement was made on 28 May.The funding to be granted is allocated for 2020, but can be used until the end of 2021.

On 26 May, the Finnish government announced a new set of regulations for rehabilitative work, overriding the previous policy that was set back in April. Beginning from 1 June, municipalities are to open their rehabilitative work facilities, including work activity centres, group-based social welfare services, group activities in social rehabilitation, or work and day activities for people with disabilities. Many municipalities closed their facilities when the government banned gatherings of more than 10 persons on 16 March, the national government encourages municipalities to reopen and use their discretion in deciding which alternative forms of rehabilitative work are offered.

On July 9, the Finnish government decides to amend the Medicines Act, the Act on Obligatory Storing of Medicines, and the Communicable Diseases to to ensure the availability and sufficiency of medicines in all situations. The bills give the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health the power to temporarily restrict or target the distribution and sale of medicinal productions in an actual, or expected, incident that may affect the availability of medicines to protect public health.

On 30 June, the Finnish government announces that the terms and conditions for the sale of personal protective equipment for professional use will change. The emergency situation allowed certain regulations concerning PPEs not to be met. As of 31 August 2020, the regulations will return to EU standards.

The Finnish government decides to increase sampling and testing to identify cases of COVID-19 and mandates healthcare and social workers to be test under 'even the slightest suspicion of illness' on 30 March.

The Finnish government decides to increase sampling and testing to identify cases of COVID-19 and mandates healthcare and social workers to be test under 'even the slightest suspicion of illness' on 30 March.

Finland's national Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) announced plans to begin random COVID-19 anti-body testing on working-age capital area residents on April 7. Research and testing is expected to expand beyond the capital and to all age groups in order to 'get a picture of the situation across the entire country'.

The Finnish Ministry of Social Affairs and Health appoints a 'coordination group to support preparedness and management in healthcare and social welfare' in response to the COVID-19 outbreak on 25 February. The coordination group will 'plan, manage and coordinate measures' to prevent the virus's spread and will support the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL), the Finnish Medicines Agency (Fimea), the National Supervisory Authority for Welfare and Health (Valvira), as well regional state administrative agencies, and municipalities and joint municipal authorities to prevent its spread.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On 16 March, Finland's Ministry for Foreign Affairs forms a new emergency management organisation that will be in charge of responding to the pandemic and will coordinate the situation in the Foreign Service in order to safeguard operational capacity and assist Finnish citizens abroad to help with repatriation.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On 26 March, Finland's Ministry of Economic Affairs and Employment appoints a joint ministerial working group to decide what constitutes essential travel and traffic and to establish a common understanding among public officials thereof.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On 22 April, Finland's Prime Minister appoints a 13-member multidisciplinary scientific panel to provide evidence-based support for the working-group in 'assessing and anticipating the effects of COVID-19 crisis from the perspectives of social, health, economic and ecological sustainability and the resilience of individuals, communities, and society'.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On 26 May, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health announces the formation of a working group to strengthen the rights of the child and the wellbeing of children and families in the aftermath of the COVID-19 epidemic. The assessments of the working group will be used to form the National Child Strategy.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health and the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Employment form an expert group, chaired by Archbishop Emeritus Kari Makinen, to look for tools to strengthen the wellbeing and equality of Fins in the aftermath of the COVID19 crisis. The aim is to provide a report to highlight the critical cornerstones, such as those most affected by the epidemic, to help prevent society from collapse.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On 13 July, the Finnish government forms a working group tasking with ensuring health security along Finland's borders. In line with this mandate, the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health has appointed a working group aimed at ensuring cooperation between authorities in combating COVID-19 at border crossing points.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On 3 September, Finland appoints an independent investigation team, in connection with the Safety Investigation Authority, to look into measures the country has taken as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. The investigative team is tasked to look at the decisions that were made in line with protecting the population from the pandemic and to improve public safety and security and will focus on the period from 1 January to 31 July.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Ministry of Social Affairs and Health adds the novel coronavirus to the list of generally hazardous communicable diseases on 13 February.

Finland's Ministry of the Interior announces that 'exceptions will be made to the provisions of the Working Hours Act and the Annual Holidays Act in the case of critical personnel'. Trained professionals in internal security, such as police officers and border guards, may be obligated to perform work as necessary. Students in training may be called in as well.
Finland's Chancellor of Justice launches an investigation on April 11 into how the government and ministries are using the user data provided by Telia communications company.

On March 4, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health announces the opening of information terminals at passenger ports and commercial airports to provide travellers information about the coronavirus.
Finland enlists social influencers in its efforts to contain COVID-19 to reach all parts of the Finnish population, including those who do not consume traditional media.

On April 3, the Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health and the National Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) distribute a letter to every household to 'provide every citizen with information' on the Coronavirus and on ways to avoid getting infected. According to the Director of Communications, Riikka Nurmi, 'there is a lot of talk about the coronavirus, the need for reliable information is on the increase. In the letter, we explain how you can protect yourself from getting coronavirus and how to act in case you get infected. In addition, the letter includes advice for people over 70 years of age because for them getting coronavirus may be a bigger risk'. The letter is expected to arrive at every household by April 9.

Finland's prime minister announces the FINLAND FORWARD communication campaign focused on bringing visibility to 'the great everyday work being done by various actors in society' who help one another during the COVID crisis.

Finland's Prime Minister Sanna Marin, Minister of Education li Andersson, and Minister of Science and Culture Hanna Kosonen, hold a coronavirus info session for children on Friday 24 April. The questions to be addressed were collected from primary school pupils and schools.

Finland's Ministry of the Interior launches the #virutaaliveappu campaign, which encourages people to celebrate the annual vappu event, which marks the end of winter, at home. The campaign gives Finns alternative ways to spend vappu together through quarantine concerts and sima tasting on the sofa. Social media influencers are also taking part in spreading awareness. Vappu is traditionally celebrated together with friends and family outdoors.
The Finnish government announces on 29 April that the national flag will be flown in honour of the those working against the coronavirus on Labour Day, May 1.
Finland imposes a 14 day mandatory quarantine on Finnish citizens and permanent residents of Finland returning from abroad.

Updated on March 30, 2020, Ministry for foreign affairs of Finland is recommending Finish citizens to "avoid travel abroad until further notice. This applies to travel to all countries and to both road, sea and air transport. Foreigners travelling in Finland can leave the country." All Finnish citizens and permanent residents who are returning to Finland from another country are required to remain in conditions equivalent to quarantine for 14 days

Finland announces measures on March 25 to deal with Finns repatriating after travelling from abroad, where the Border Guard will distribute instructions to those arriving directing them to a two-week home quarantine and will give them 'informative brochures on the coronavirus, mitigation measures and treatment'. Healthcare professionals, including personnel from the Finnish Red Cross (SPR) will advise passengers upon landing. Passengers are also asked to maintain a safe distance of at least one metre from one another.

On 7 May, the Finnish government announces that persons entering Finland across the Schengen border for employment, commissions, or other essential traffic must enter 14 day self-isolation and must restrict unnecessary close contact. The person is allowed to move between their workplace and place of residents and for other essential reasons. This policy does not apply to first responders, emergency service personnel, or members of the Border guard or customs. The policy will remain in place until 14 June.

On June 12, the Finnish government announces that 14 day quarantine measures are voluntary for those entering Finland from countries that are still subject to border controls, such as Sweden and Russia. Those arriving in Finland will be informed of the Finnish hygiene and safety guidelines and are recommended to avoid physical contact with groups for 14 days.

On June 12, the Finnish government announces that 14 day quarantine measures are voluntary for those entering Finland from countries that are still subject to border controls, such as Sweden and Russia. Those arriving in Finland will be informed of the Finnish hygiene and safety guidelines and are recommended to avoid physical contact with groups for 14 days.

On 4 August, Finland's Ministry of Education recommends that no one should go to early childhood education, school or workplace if they have any symptoms of respiratory infection until the possibility of a coronavirus infection has been ruled out by tests.

On 4 August, Finland says that nobody should go to early childhood education, school, or workplace if they have any symptoms of respiratory infection until the possibility of a coronavirus infection has been ruled out by tests. The recommendations emphasise good hand hygiene, cough hygiene, and advanced cleaning.

On 11 September, the Finnish government says that persons arriving from a country/region that is deemed to have a high incidence rate (25/100,000) should be in quarantine. Quarantined persons may end their quarantine upon receiving a negative test result from a second COVID test taken 72 hours after entry.
On March 16, Finland orders private and third-sector operations, including religious institutions, to cease operations.

On 26 March, Finland's Ministry of Transportations issues a policy to extend driving times and shorten rest periods of drivers of buses and heavy goods transport vehicles to ensure a steady of flow of goods and to bolster the security of supply. The policy will begin on 27 March and end on 25 April and will shorten the daily rest period of drivers 'to 9 hours and weekly rest period to 24 hours' and 'proposes that the required minimum rest period of 45 minutes be allowed to be more freely split into periods of 15 and 30 minutes within a period of four and a half hours'.  Outside of COVID, 'the maximum daily driving time is no more than 9-10 hours so that a break of at least 45 minutes must be taken after four and a half hours of driving'.

On 31 March, the Finnish Government issued a decree restricting the operations of restaurants throughout the country. All restaurants must be closed starting from Saturday 4 April 2020. The restrictions will remain in force until the end of May. The restrictions apply to all restaurant operations except for preparing food for take away and for delivery by food couriers. The restrictions do not apply to canteens or restaurants that are essential for food supply such as canteens in schools, hospitals and similar establishments, or personnel restaurants that serve in-house personnel only.

On 14 April, Finland's Ministry of Transportation decides on measures to ensure that the transportation of dangerous goods confirm with regulations, including inspections. Special agreements may be made for road and rail that are used to transport these dangerous materials.

On 29 May, the Finnish government announces the reopening of domestic tourism and set in a number of specific guidelines to be followed. This includes:
- sick persons should avoid all travel
- symptoms must be reported immediately to healthcare services of the municipality or city where you are staying
- if a domestic tourist becomes infected with the coronavirus,the physician responsible for diseases in the municipality or hospital district is responsible for tracing the infection

On 19 May, the Finnish government decides to lay down provisions on restrictions for restaurants:
- the number of seats in restaurants, cafes, and bars would be reduced in order for customers to maintain a sufficient distance between one another
- customers must be provided with instructions on how to avoid contracting the virus
-  food and beverage service providers must make sure to adequately clean all surfaces and objects that customers touch
- customers are not allowed to serve or dish out their own food or drinks, for example, at a buffet table
- food and beverage service businesses are allowed to be open to customers between 06:00-23:00
- alcohol may served only between 09:00 - 22:00; if a customer buys an alcoholic beverage before 22:00, then it must be consumed by 23:00
- food and beverage services must draw up a plan on how to implement these regulations

The Finnish government announces on 17 June that it will ease restrictions on food and beverage services, beginning on 22 June. The following restrictions have been changed:
- businesses may open at 04:00 and must close by 02:00
- buffets are once again permitted
- three-quarters of the number of persons permitted in the serving license or building plan may be present in the indoor premises at one time

All customers are still required to have their own seat and businesses must arrange their indoor and outdoor furniture to maintain a safe distance between one another. These businesses must also ensure that customers can wash or sanitise their hands upon arrival and have visible instructions on handwashing, maintaining safe distances, and other measures to prevent the spread of COVID19.

On 29 September, the Finnish government decides to place restrictions on the opening hours of establishments that serve food and beverages. Establishments that serve food and beverages, including alcohol, may open as of 04:00 and must be closed by 01:00. Alcohol sales may begin no earlier than 09:00 and must end by 23:59. In areas seeing an accelerated rate of infection, food and beverage establishments must close by 23:00 and alcohol sales must end by 21:59. Decisions on further restrictions will be made on a weekly basis. Businesses will be given a one-week transition period and must comply to these restrictions by 8 October.

Finland's Ministry of Education and Culture and the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health issues a recommendation to 'providers of healthcare and social welfare services' in both the public and private sectors on 12 March. The ministries recommend employees to stay at home if they have returned from an area affected by the coronavirus or if they are experiencing flu symptoms and ask employers to allow employees to work from home.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Finland's Ministry of Education and Culture and the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health issues a recommendation to 'providers of education and training, including early childhood education, and higher educations' in both the public and private sectors on 12 March. The ministries recommend employees to stay at home if they have returned from an area affected by the coronavirus or if they are experiencing flu symptoms and ask employers to allow employees to work from home.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On 16 March, the Finnish government decrees that all state-and municipality-run museums, theatres, cultural centres, club and recreational facilities, swimming pools and other sporting venues will be shut down. Elderly, rehabilitation and employment services will also halt operations. On 9 April, the Finnish governments decides that the 'policies and guidelines issued on 16 march to curb the spread of the coronavirus and [to] protect vulnerable groups' will continue to be in force until 13 May. On May 4, the Finnish government lifts certain restrictions, therefore ending the previous overarching policy.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: As of June 1, the Finnish government decides to reopen national and municipal museums, theatres, the national opera, cultural venues, libraries, mobile libraries, national archives, hobby and leisure centres, swimming pools, and other sports facilities. However, the reopening of these premises are restricted to mass gatherings of more than 50 people.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On 13 August, the Finnish government recommends employers of public sector employees to shift to remote work as extensively as possible
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health advises the Regional State Administrative Agencies to prohibit all events with over 500 attendees until the end of May, under the Communicable Diseases Act.
Finland prohibits the gathering of more than 10 people and recommends that people avoid public spaces unless absolutely necessary.
On 23 April, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs Health announces that the national Mother's Day celebration will not be held on 10 May but that it will be announced at a later date.

On May 15, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health announces that restrictions on mass gatherings will be eased, beginning on 1 June. The restriction of public gatherings will be eased from the current 10 persons to a maximum of 50 people. Public events with more than 50 people indoor and enclosed outdoor spaces will also be allowed, provided that every person can keep a safe distance of 1-2 meters from other people. Events with more than 500 attendees will remain prohibited until 31 July.

On June 17, the Finnish government announces the removal of the restriction that barred visits to hospitals and primary healthcare units. The government says that a cautious approach must be taken when arranging visits and that the operating unit is in charge of making practical arrangements, such as the use of PPEs and appropriate meeting places.

Units providing 24-hour care and treatment must provide their older clients and others belonging to risk groups with the opportunity to meet their loved ones safely, by ensuring adequate protection in an outdoor location or by arranging separate, protected, meeting facilities.

As a general rule, the government recommends that access to premises providing 24-hour care and treatment remain limited to staff.
On 13 August, the Finnish government recommends the use facial coverings and face masks.
On 13 August, the Finnish government recommends employers of private sector employees to shift to remote work as extensively as possible
From March 16, 2020, President Macron announced that "from Monday, on [16] and until further notice, all nurseries, schools, and universities will be closed" in France until at least April 15, 2020.

In France, high schools will remain closed across the country during the first phase of d "confinement in France from May 11 through June 1. Further updates are expected to come at the end of May, and reopening is expected for the beginning of June.
From May 11 in France, middle schools in red departments will remain closed through Phase 1 of d "confinement through June 1.

From May 11 in France, kindergartens (classes maternelles) and primary schools ( "coles  "l "mentaires) will reopen across France regardless of department color, with a limit of 15 children per group. Attendance is voluntary.

From May 11, cr "ches will be allowed to reopen regardless of department color, with a limit of 10 children per group. Masks will be required for staff but not children under 3 years old. Attendance is voluntary.

In France from May 18, middle schools can reopen in green departments only, starting with sixi "me (age 11) and cinqui "me (age 12). Classes sizes are limited to only 15 students per class and masks are mandatory for all faculty and students.

From June 2 in France, all types of high schools, general, professional and technical, will be allowed to reopen in green zones. Attendance is voluntary; masks are mandatory; and classes are limited to 25 students at a time.

From June 2, middle schools (coll "ges), which had so far only been able to reopen in green zones, will reopen as of June 2nd across all of France,  "both in green and orange zones, ". Attendance is voluntary; masks are mandatory; and classes are limited to 15 students at a time.

Starting from June 22, 2020, all student in kindergartens, elementary schools and middle schools in France are required to attend school in-person and comply with the social distancing guidelines, mask-wearing rules and hygiene measures encouraged by the government.
In France, as of March 17, 2020, 12 PM, a curfew for all residents with few exceptions for at least 2 weeks is put in place.
On March 23, 2020, in France President  Macron announced a state of health emergency for at least two months.

As of March 16th, France will stop issuing visas in all of its embassies and consulates abroad, until further notice. Affected by the decision are all types of visas, including short-stay Schengen visas, long-stay visas to France, visas to overseas territories, even ones for which an appointment had already already made.

As of March 18, the French government recommends that "French citizens who have their permanent residence outside the European space...that they avoid international travel insofar as is possible, even to return to the national territory, unless imperative reasons require such travel" for a period of 30 days until April 16.

From March 17, 2020, France announced that "Nationals of other countries [...] cannot enter France in the next 30 days, although there are exceptions for those who reside permanently in France". This does not affect the exit from national territory.
From March 31, 2020, at 11:30 pm, "A "roports de Paris is authorized to temporarily suspend the commercial operation of Paris-Orly airport".
As of April 8, 2020, at midnight, all travelers are required to fill out and carry a travel certificate according to their situation when entering the country.

From 25 May 2020, travelers entering France are also requested to fill out and carry with them a statement certifying they do not have any symptoms of a COVID-19 infection. This statement is to be presented to transportation companies before boarding, as well as to border control authorities.

In a press release from June 12, 2020, it was announced that France will progressively start to open its Schengen Area external borders from 1 July. This is in line with the European Commission "s recommendations  inspired by French proposals. This will occur gradually and in a differentiated manner depending on the health situations in third countries, and in line with the European procedures to be issued by that time.
In France, the French government will launch its Covid-19 tracking app, StopCovid, on Tuesday June 2nd to coincide with the start of France "s stage 2 of deconfinement.

In France on February 23, the Minister of Health announced that 70 additional hospitals will be "activated" by March 24, so that "all metropolitan departments have at least one hospital center capable of welcoming patients and taking care of them from start to finish"
On March 6, 2020, France allowed the preparation of hydro-alcoholic solutions intended for human hygiene by pharmacies and pharmacies in the event of a shortage of supply.
On March 21, 2020, French Health Minister Olivier V "ran announces that the government ordered 250 million FFP2 health masks.

In France, on March 24, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health announced it was mobilizing 40,000 social work students who are not currently on an internship to form a social reserve to actively contribute to the maintenance of social and medico-social action. They will be placed in institutions housing the most fragile or vulnerable citizens, including elderly care institutions, special needs institutions, child protection institutions, emergency accommodation centers, child care and other centers.

In France on March 25, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health announces it will fund 11 research projects related to COVID-19 with a maximum of almost 9 million euros. These projects cover a large part of the continuum of health research, from diagnosis to psychological and physical treatment for both patients and caregivers.

In France on March 25, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health called on all healthcare professionals, active, retired, or volunteer, to volunteer to provide support to healthcare structures affected by the COVID-19 epidemic, which need staff reinforcement.

On April 4, 2020, France announced additional provisions and principles of action in order to support people with disabilities, including to reinforce setups and real-time monitoring of the development of the epidemic in the disability sector, strengthen preventive measures in establishments supporting people with disabilities, not to leave establishments and services alone to deal with covid-19 cases, to anticipate and organize treatment at the hospital when necessary, to strengthen the continuity of medico-social support during the duration of the epidemic, and to take the greatest care in identifying the respite needs of carers exposed to a risk of physical and mental exhaustion, as well as support needs of isolated people.

Beginning April 28th, the French National Government will cover 50% of the costs for masks purchased by communities to be sold to the general public. This will cover any masks purchased from April 13th through June 1st.
As of April 21, France expanded medical coverage for some treatments.

As of April 21, France has temporarily expanded its export restrictions to include certain drugs from pharmaceutical distributors. The temporary restrictions include export bans on antibiotics, painkillers such as atracurium and rocuronium, sedatives and muscle relaxants, remdesivir, hydroxychloroquine, lopinavir and ritonavir, and insulin.
France, the National Government announced on May 1st that it will provide 5 million washable masks per week to at-risk citizens via the Central Social Activities Fund and other public aid groups.

France will implement a new doctrine on COVID-19 testing on May 11 with the aim of testing everyone who has come into contact with people who are infected, Prime Minister Edouard Philippe told parliament. He said the government had set itself the goal of carrying out at least 700,000 tests per week starting from May 11.

On May 20th, the French National Government announced that the Covid-19 viral test is 100% covered by national health insurance. The cost for a test is 54 euros. If asked to pay at the time of the test, individuals will receive a reimbursement.
The French Ministry of Health announced, on June 25, 2020, that a "large-scale" test campaign would be organized in  "le-de-France to identify possible "dormant" clusters of Covid-19.
As of May 11, 2020, in France "it will be compulsory to wear masks on all public transport, in taxis and hired cars such as Uber, and on school buses."
Starting March 17, all rail traffic in France will be reduced by 50% compared to normal to help ensure the continuity of transport while discouraging most French people from traveling.

"On Sunday, March 22, authorities announced the cancelation of all flights from mainland France to overseas territories, including Martinique, Guadeloupe, Mayotte, La R "union, Saint-Martin, and Saint-Barthelemy, from Tuesday, March 23, until at least Wednesday, April 15, amid the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic."
In France as of March 24 until March 31, trips linked to individual physical activity or taking pets for walks are restricted to remaining within a 1 kilometer radius of the home.

As of 1 June 2020, France is allowing increased use of public transportation with added criteria. The criteria include: bringing an employer certificate, wearing a mask, and a valid ticket with ID. Travel is also restricted to 100km per day.
In France, French President Emmanuel Macron announced a 15-day nationwide lockdown beginning Tuesday, March 17th and ending on April 1st in a stepping up of the country's efforts to fight the virus.
In the Green zone, the parks and gardens will be open to the public from the 11th of May, 2020

On April 3, 2020, France announced the appointment of chairman as well as the members of the committee of scientists established under the state of health emergency declared to deal with the covid-19 epidemic.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description:
In collaboration with the French Red Cross, Chad's Ministry of Public Health has initiated a workshop program for the strengthening of the prevention of COVID-19 in urban communities. 

The program, which has been established in N'Djamena region, intends to train 140 health workers, provide protective equipment such as testing kits and hygiene kits and support food management for patients and medical professionals.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 19, 2020, France lifted "bans on the movement of goods transport vehicles over 7.5 tonnes total weight authorized laden at certain times" until April 20, 2020.
On March 30, France  announced that "it would put victims of domestic violence in hotel rooms and finance pop-up counselling centres in grocery stores."
On April 9, 2020, France announced it will fund additional facilities for the storage of coffins before cremation or burial in Rungis.

On April 9, the French president, in collaboration with the major religions in the country, announced the establishment of a hotline support structure for those who feel the need for spiritual support during the pandemic. The hotline is available through the government's toll-free information number on the COVID epidemic, and through certain health establishments and medical professionals.
As of April 17, the Ministry for Economy and Finances has announced that the limit for contactless payment was raised from 30 to 50 Euro after consultation with French banks.

On May 1st, the French Post Office created an e-commerce platform to facilitate the distribution of 10 million masks to freelancers and small businesses with fewer than 50 employees. Masks will be available for purchase for businesses with between 10 and 50 employees starting at 6pm on May 2nd. Businesses with less than 10 employees can purchase masks beginning May 4th.
On January 24, the France began distribution of flyers and information posters about COVID-19 in English, Mandarin, and French at French airports.
On February 25, France began a nationwide distribution of informational posters about COVID-19 in train stations.
On April 16, 2020, France published a list of companies which showed solidarity while companies that behaved poorly are monitored but not published publicly.
On April 28, the French government released a video detailing how to live a healthy lifestyle and prepare meals during the pandemic.

On May 1st, France published a series of images depicting how masks slow the spread of Covid-19, how to properly wear and wash your mask, and other important measures to slow the spread of Covid-19. The latter image reminds people to maintain at least 1 meter of distance, avoid shaking hands with others, wash their hands regularly, and properly dispose of tissues.

In France on May 7, in a response to a notable decrease in the number of doctors visits, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health released a press release calling on citizens to remain attentive to their health and to seek treatment without delay and not postpone the care they need, despite the current health context. Their recommendation "particularly concerns vulnerable people such as infants or pregnant women" and people with chronic illnesses.

In France on May 20, the French government published a video detailing what to do in case of symptoms, how is to get a test and what testing is like, and what happens if your test is positive or negative.
As of April 5, 2020, France advises travelers from China, Hong Kong, Macau, Singapore, South Korea or the Italian regions of Emilie-Romagne Lombardy or Veneto to self-quarantine for 14 days.

The Health Minister of France announced that any traveler entering France face a 14-day quarantine. This, however, "will not apply to Europeans arriving from the European Union, Schengen countries or the U.K.".

From 25 May 2020, the French Government is putting in place a voluntary 14-day quarantine measure for travelers arriving from countries outside the European area (includes all countries of the world except EU members, Andorra, Iceland, Lichtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland, Vatican City). There is an exception to this measure: for travelers arriving from European countries whose authorities have decided, in an uncoordinated fashion, to apply 14-day quarantine measures to travelers entering their territory from European countries, a voluntary 14-day quarantine period will be reciprocally requested. Therefore, travelers from UK and Spain are subject to a voluntary quarantine regardless of their nationality due to their country's policies.

As of March 18, the French maritime prefecture of the Mediterranean specifies that the activities of yachting, tourism or water sports also prohibited in the Mediterranean Sea until March 31, 2020. These provisions are intended to actively fight against the spread of COVID-19 by restricting all movements.
In France, from May 11, bars, restaurants, and caf "s will remain closed.

In France, as of May 11, retail shops will be allowed to reopen with health measures in place. You must wear a mask if the shopkeeper requires it. Businesses must comply with safety guidelines outlined by the national government, encompassing "maintaining social distance between workers and customers, ...capacity restrictions, and markings on the ground to indicate required distances."

Across France, bars, restaurants and caf "s will be allowed to reopen on June 2 with the following health restrictions
(1) groups of no more than 10 per table
(2) minimum of one metre (3.3 feet) between tables.
(3) masks mandatory at all times for wait and kitchen staff
(4) masks mandatory for customers upon entering and exiting
(5) drinking at the counter in bars is prohibited

In France on March 15, S "curit " Routi "re (Road Safety) announced that  the driving license exams, practical and theoretical, which were too be held on and after March 16 are postponed for an indefinite period.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: From March 9, 2020, the prefects of Corsica and Corse-du-Sud in France announced an obligation for sports events to take place behind closed doors.
On April 28, France has announced a separate policy banning mass gatherings of over 5000 people until August 31.
In France, public gatherings remain limited to 10 people from May 14 until June 2 in accordance with the Phase 1 of d "confinment.

In France, from May 14, private gatherings of more than 10 people are allowed, but the interior ministry cautioned the French must still demonstrate their "civic responsibility" and apply caution and strict hygiene measures to all a gatherings.

In France from May 23, the government will allow the resumption of religious gatherings. Worshippers have to comply with coronavirus regulations, including the wearing of masks, a distance of at least one metre between worshippers and hand-washing.

On June 4, "France will cancel its traditional July 14 military parade this year due to coronavirus social distancing requirements, replacing it with a ceremony to pay tribute to medical personnel at the forefront of the pandemic battle."

On August 4 in France, gatherings of over 5000 will be allowed from August 15 with some conditions. From August 15-August 31, events of this size will still need prior prefectural approval to go ahead. On August 11, the French government reversed this statement, extending the ban on mass gatherings of 5,000 people or more until October 30.

France's national state-owned railway company, SNCF, is supplying masks and bottles of disinfectant to its on-board staff of TGV Paris-Turin-Milan, TGVs connecting with trains from Italy, from the North and regional TER trains from the Provence-Alpes-C "te-d'Azur region going to Ventimiglia at the Franco-Italian border. It will also supply the Railway security officers.

From Tuesday, March 17, the French government is asking citizens to "practice social distancing" when in public, "keeping at least 1m apart from the nearest person - including when waiting in a queue"
As of 20 July 2020, all persons of age 11 or older must wear masks in closed public spaces and respect the barriers of social distancing in France.
Germany offers a website  with information around fake news and false information to combat misinformation from May 15.
Since June 9, 2020, Germany has been providing information about the "Corona Warn App" on the website of the Federal Government to disprove false information.

The German Olympic Sports Association (DOSB)  is now discouraging athletes and trainers from traveling to Italy and South Korea, building on an earlier recommendation to avoid travel to China from Febuary 27
On March 10th, 2020 the german federal government announced stricter entry controls on the borders of Southern Germany.
On March 10, 2020 the german ministry of foreign affairs discourages traveling to Italy.

On March 17th, 2020 the german ministry of foreign affairs has initiated a returners program for german citizens in other countries who want to return. Countries that will be covered include Marocco, Egypt, The Dominican Republic, the Phillipines and the Maledives.
The German Federal Government on the 1st of April 2020 prohibits all transportation, Air and sea, of all passengers from Iran to Germany.

Foreigners stuck in Germany on expired visas due to coronavirus-related travel restrictions will not have to fear fines, said Federal Interior Minister Horst Seehofer. That period without fines will extend from April 9 until June 30.

On 1st of February 100 German nationals have been brought back to Germany from Wuhan (China). At the arrival in Germany they were asked on board for their health condition and medically checked a second time by a medical assessment center at the airport.

Reporting obligation for medical personnel in cases they encounter a patient who is infected with or has deceased to "2019-nCoV" starting Feb 1st, 2020. This is under the "infectious disease protection law" and applicable on recognition of symptoms as defined by the Robert-Koch Institute (see  " 4 Absatz 2 Nummer 1 of the Infectious Disease Protection Law).
Germany launches smartwatch app to monitor coronavirus spread on April 7.

The state of Hesse (Germany) announced, that there will be an obligation to report to the respective competent health authority for establishments, which accommodate several seasonal workers in collective accommodation. This measure comes into force at May 19th 2020.

At June 16th the state government of Hesse implements the Corona-App devloped by the german federal government. The App is voluntary and should help to track infected persons and contain the spread of the pandemic.
From June 16, a warning app can be used in Germany for contact tracing.
Germany (03.04.2020): Farmacies are allowed to produce hand disinfectant to sell. This policy is taken due to a threat of the public health by Sars-Cov-2.
On March 11th, 2020 the german ministry for research and education announced the provision of 145 million  " for research purposes on the coronavirus.

On March 23th, 2020 the German federal government released a law the offers support and incentives to hospitals, doctors, care centers and health insurers to ease financial strain during the crisis and provide more necessary resources (e.g. intensive care beds, etc.)

On the 30th March 2020, Germany is establishing a drive to increase the supply for protective medical equipment. They have launched a new "Protective Medical Equipment Procurement" Taskforce to co-ordinate with private business as to promote, organise and co-ordinate local production of protective medical equipment. This includes offers for an firm that can supply more than 25,000 FFP2 respirator masks, mouth and nose protection surgical masks and protective gowns by before the end of April at a fixed price.    

On the 9th April 2020, Germany augmented the existing policy by establishing an additional "Production Process and Capacity" Taskforce to oversee and increase domestic production of protective material. This taskforce is run by and through the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Energy, though it is assisted by the Ministry of Health, Ministry of Innovation and Tech and Chancellery. The Taskforce's roles is to take over from the short term effects of the "Protective Medical Equipment Procurement" Taskforce. The new force is supporting the medium term expansion of German and European value chains for medical protective equipment.
From April 3, intensive care bed capacities are to be reported in Germany.
Germany purchaded AVigan tablets as a treatment drug for the new coronavirus. Local media said the ministry will buy several million tablets to treat patients with severe symptoms from April 3.

On the 8th April 2020 Germany announced an immediate suspension of selected regulation on the supply of pharmaceuticals by pharmacies and hospitals. Pharmacies and Hospitals are now allowed to supply equivalent rather than exact drugs for proscriptions, trading stock between themselves in event of shortages, or otherwise deviate from regulation to insure adequate and prompt supply. This is to last until 30th September 2020.

On May 8th the federal government of Germany released a note saying that they secured the supply of medical equiment as facial masks coming from China. The equipment is ment to supply the healthcare system.

Germany's vaccines regulator approved human testing of a potential vaccine against the COVID-19 virus developed by German biotech company BioNTech on April 23. The trial, only the fourth worldwide of a preventive agent targeting the virus behind the global pandemic, will be conducted on 200 healthy people aged between 18 and 55 in the first stage, and on further people, including those at higher risk from the disease, in a second stage.

Based on the paper issued by the Federal Ministry of Health (BMG) on April 27 "A new daily routine also for hospital operations in Germany", these regulations also apply to Hesse in a first step. This means that 25% of the total number of intensive care beds available for COVID-19 patients must be made available and the operating theatre capacity is open for up to 70% for elective procedures.

At June 3rd, the federal government of Germany has announced that o protect Germany from possible shortages, Federal Health Minister Jens Spahn wants to build up a permanent reserve of medical protective equipment. This was decided by the cabinet today.

Germany has enacted a regulation that from October 19, 2020, people with cold symptoms can have a medical certificate from a doctor for work via telephone so that they do not have to enter the doctor's office and thus possibly infect doctors, practice staff or other patients with COVID-19.

Germany: On 1st of February 100 German nationals have been brought back to Germany from Wuhan (China). At the arrival in Germany they were asked on board for their health condition and medically checked a second time by a medical assessment center at the airport. Some have been tested for the virus.

The German Olympic Sports Association (DOSB)  is now discouraging athletes and trainers from traveling to Italy and South Korea, building on an earlier recommendation to avoid travel to China. Athletes returning from these countries to Germany are encouraged to get tested for coronavirus from Febuary 27.
In Germany, from April 6 not only people with symptoms + contact can get tested but also people with symptoms + mass infections (hospitals, care facilities...).

From April 9, in Germany people with symptoms + preconditions or worsening of respiratory diseases or people with symptoms + high risk of contact with infected (wor of voluntary work eg in hospitals) can get tested.
From April 16, all people with symptoms + contact to an infected person/stay in a risk area can get tested in Germany.

Germany (07.21.2020): 
The Healthministry released a new law which makes it possible to enforce the healthinsurances to cover the costs for testing. Also people who are likely to get infected or to infect others (working within the healthcare- or nursingsystem) should be tested easier.
Negative testresults have to be reported.

At June 9th the federal government of Germany has announced, that in the future, people can also be tested for the coronavirus if they do not show any symptoms. The tests will be paid for by the statutory health insurance companies. Comprehensive tests in nursing homes, schools or day-care centres will also be possible in future. All persons in these facilities can be tested if a COVID 19 case has occurred there. In nursing homes and nursing services, tests can also be carried out independently of cases that have occurred. 
The new test regulation, which was presented by Federal Health Minister Spahn at the end of May and which came into force retroactively as of May 14.
On July 28th it was released that people returnig to Germany from a country listed as riskfull for the Coronavirus have to do a mandatory Virustest. This shall start in the first week of August.
Since August 8, 2020, the government of Saxony-Anhalt, Germany, and the Federal Government decided that COVID-19 tests are mandatory for all returnees from risk areas.

At April 21 the state government of hesse (germany) has announced that wearing a mask if a local public transport vehicles or use the public areas of shops, banks and post offices is used. The measure comes into place at April 21.
Germany reommends to avoid private trips and journeys on April 22.
Health minister Jens Spahn urges all Germans to stay at home whenever possible on March 9.

On February 28th, 2020 the constitution of a task force to deal with the spread of the Corona Virus in Germany. It consists of of members of the federal ministries of public health, internal affairs, foreign affairs and the federal police. Selected input of expertise from other government agencies will also be sought after.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description:
Germany is from the 1st, April 2020 is introducing a new online platform 
that all hospitals that provide intensive care are required to register onto. Registered hospitals must publish daily on the platform their number of unused intensive care beds .
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: April 21st: Germany installed a new task force to check that hospitals have no economic loss due to the pandemic.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description:
In Germany federal minister of Education and Research Anja Karliczek announced on April 30 all students would be able to receive interest-free loans of up to  "650 a month via state-owned development bank Kreditanstalt f "r Wiederaufbau.
Additionally, the ministry would provide students in  "particularly acute emergencies " with non-repayable grants. The  "100m would be distributed to students by the Deutsches Studentenwerk (DSW).
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On June 17th, Germany announced plans to spend a further 24.8 billion euros on measures to counter the economic consequences of the corona pandemic. The money is to be used to secure jobs and prosperity in the long term and to get the economy moving again quickly. To this end, the Federal Government has launched this second economic stimulus package. Capital expenditure will increase to 71.8 billion euros. To finance this, Germany will take out loans of 218.5 billion euros this year.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The German Foreign Office paid for flights home for 67,000 people and will now bill them for 40% of the cost. The billing was announced on June 27th but the repatriation flights have taken place over the last few months.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description:
Germany (March 10th for four weeks): 
Doctors can sign people sick for 7 days after a consultation by telephone. Patients don't have to attend a physical examination.

On March 19th the federal minister of defense Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer  declared that the german military will support the healthcaresystem as good as possible to supply the civil society. 2336 reservist have been recruited to help in the situation.

On April 1st Germany changed the regulation for medical students to make it more flexibel. They aim for medical students to help in the healthcare system without having a disadvantage in their education.
On April 9, in Germany a new law came into effect for protecting renters of flats/accommodations and for protecting enterprises in the event of insolvency

On April 21st Germany releases a note that allows farmacies to be more flexible in the supply of customers. That means that they can change the medicine if the prescribed one is not at hand. Also they can change the size or quantity of the prescribed medicine. With that a better supply of the cititzens is aimed. This regulation is in power until further notice and max. until 03.31.2021.

At May 7th the German Bundestag has announced, that periods of short-time work due to the Corona crisis are not taken into account when calculating the amount of parental benefit. As a result, the parental allowance is as high as that calculated by the expectant parents. Parents have no further losses.
There is greater flexibility in the use of the parental allowance months and the partnership months for parents in systemically important occupations.

At May 7th the German Bundestag has decided on assistance for students and doctoral candidates. Students can get an interest-free KfW loan - up to 650 euros a month, "quickly and without time-consuming examinations".
In emergencies, grants are available from the relevant student union. The hardship fund will be increased by 100 million euros for this purpose. Individual case decisions count here. If students help in system-relevant areas to cope with the consequences of corona, they can keep the income from this in full. This income will not be credited towards BAf "G payments.
The upper limit for fixed-term employment contracts in science is initially extended by 6 months. An extension for a further 6 months is possible. Above all, it should be possible to successfully complete further dissertations despite the corona restrictions.

At May 5th 2020 the German Bundestag has announced, that periods of short-time work due to the Corona crisis are not taken into account when calculating the amount of parental benefit. As a result, the parental allowance is as high as that calculated by the expectant parents. Parents have no further losses. There is greater flexibility in the use of the parental allowance months and the partnership months for parents in systemically important occupations.

At May 14th the German government has announced the Social Protection Package II.
The short-time working allowance will be increased. Anyone who is on short-time work for at least 50 percent will receive 70 percent of the lost net wage from the fourth month of receiving short-time work compensation and 80 percent from the seventh month. Employees with children receive 77 and 87 percent respectively. 
The opportunities for earning additional income from short-time work are being expanded: As of May 1st they can earn up to the full amount of their previous monthly income in all professions. The restriction to systemically relevant occupations will be lifted. The regulations apply until the end of the year. 
The payment of unemployment benefits will be extended by three months for those whose entitlement would end between 1 May and 31 December 2020. Access to unemployment benefit II has been simplified. There is no question of housing situation or assets.

At MAy 2oth the German Bundestag has announced, that parents who are unable to work due to the closure of day-care centres and schools during the Corona crisis will in future receive much longer wage compensation from the state than before. On Wednesday, the federal cabinet passed a bill extending the maximum period of entitlement to up to 20 weeks.

At June 25th, the Minister of Health has announced, that Germany is strengthening the World Health Organization (WHO) in the fight against the coronavirus. Today in Geneva, Federal Health Minister Jens Spahn assured the WHO of additional financial resources as well as protective masks and other medical equipment for countries that urgently need them. In total, the Federal Ministry of Health's support for the World Health Organization this year amounts to over 500 million euro.

At May 28th the German Bundestag decided to reduce the VAT rate for restaurant and catering services from 19 to seven percent. " The tax reduction will apply from 1 July 2020 to 30 June 2021, with the exception of the sale of beverages.

At June 4th the federal government of germany has announced that the economic stimulus package adopted by the coalition committee of the governing parties on 3rd June includes 9.5 billion euros to strengthen the healthcare system and improve protection against future pandemics.

08.18.2020: Federal government of Germany declared that the additional child-money will be payed to parents starting september. Every family will get additional 300,- " in two rates being added to the usual child-money.
On January 23, German health minister Jens Spahn raises awareness for SARS-CoV-2, although there is no case in europe yet.
On January 25, the German government tells hospitals to prepre for COVID-19 patients.
On February 3, German health Minister Jens Spahn informs the public about Coronavirus preparations.
German health ministry cooperates with Helmholtz Institut to produce series of videos on Coronavirus, including how to protect oneself from Coronavirus from Febuary 12.
German Robert-Koch-Institut starts issuing daily Coronavirus briefings on March 4.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel gives a TV-speech on the pandemic on March 18.
German Government issues recommendations to plan Easter shopping well, to limit public gatherings on April 7.
German Government disseminates information around COVID-19 via whatsapp or telegram from April 13.
Germany disseminated information related to COVID-19 via the warning app NINA from April 29.

Germany (02.01.2020): 100 German nationals and 22 passengers from other nations are brought back to Germany due to the Coronavirus. They have to fullfill a 14 day quarantine in national military station (St "tzpunkt Germersheim) close to Frankfurt.

The German Olympic Sports Association (DOSB)  is now discouraging athletes and trainers from traveling to Italy and South Korea, building on an earlier recommendation to avoid travel to China. Athletes returning from these countries to Germany are encouraged to remain at home in self-imposed quarantine for 14 days after their return from Febuary 27.
The federal government of Germany has decided in cooperation with the states that all returning travellers have to fullfill a 14 days quarantine at home.
Germany: On March 16th the federal government decided that all accommodation offers are not to be used for touristic but only for business purpose.
Germany: On March 16th the federal government decided to regulate that restaurant and bars can only open in between 6am and 6pm.

On March 16th the federal government of Germany decided to close all the following for public service: 
- Bars, Clubs
 - Theater, Operas, Concerthalls, Museums
- fairs, exhibitions, cinemas, parks
- brothels
- recreational centers
- public swimming pools
- all not further named retail businesses
- paygrounds

On the 8th of April 2020, Germany announced a regulation on companies  who import protective equipment or medical devices into Germany as part of a Government procurement or emergency policy. Supply and distribution of such imports are entirely in the hands of government. Sales are only allowed to approved customers, normal distribution networks/methods are prohibited.

With continued hygiene and social distancing rules, shops that are within 800 square meters can reopen. Car dealerships, bike shops, book stores, libraries and archives are not included in this policy.

On the 20th of April it was announced by the government of Rheinland-Pfalz that hairdressers are allowed to open again given specific hygiene rules and specific access controls to prevent queues, on the 4th of May.

On the 30th of April, the government of Rheinland-Pfalz announced that it would allow for playgrounds and museums to reopen on the 11th of May, given the decision of individual municipalities and following specific hygiene and social distancing rules.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: German Government recommends on March 10 to cancel public and private events with more than 1000 participants.
Germany: On March 16th the federal government decided to prohibit all gatherings in  events or gatherings. This also refers to club meetings and church services.
Germany: On March 22nd the federal government decided in cooperation with the states governments that any parties or meetings where people meet in groups eather indoors or outside are prohibited.
In Germany, gatherings of up to 10 people will be allowed in public from June 6.

Germany: In cooperation with the states the federal government has decided to released social distancing measures. People should only have contact with people living in the same household or one person from outside of this household. This one person can be seen outside. They should keep 1,5m distance. Any parties or group meetings are not allowed.
From April 22, Germany strongly recommends wearing masks in public transportation and when shopping.
Greece On 10 April, the Minister of Education Niki Kerameos announced that all educational institutions would remain closed until 10 May
Greece "Health screenings in airports and border crossings"
Greece "Proposal for digital synchronization of EU member states for data on COVID-19 submitted by Vasilis Kikilias"
measures for the reopening of the swimming pools
Greece Public services closure "
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Greece is enforcing the use of a mask on all employees and customers indoors since May 1

Greece permits, on an optional and temporary basis, to place a protection divider on public transport passenger vehicles (EDX), in order to protect passengers and the driver and to prevent the spread and spread of COVID-19.
Hungary is punishing the spread of false news that damages the government's defense against the spread of Covid-19 by imprisonment.
Hungary banned class trips abroad and suspended a summer language program for schools across the country
Hungary announced that students may not visit institutions of higher education
Hungary announced a two week curfew starting on March 28 where citizens could not leave their house except to go to work or run essential errands
Hungary declared a state of emergency due to COVID-19
The Hungarian police and National Ambulance Service are screening travelers entering Hungary at six major border crossings.
Mandatory screenings for all passengers arriving in Budapest airport from China
Hungary performs thermal screenings on all Iranian airplane passengers arriving in the country
Hungary suspended the admission of asylum-seekers attempting to enter the country through Serbia
Hungary suspended flights from Milan to Budapest and Debrecen
Hungary banned Iranians from entering the country
Hungary announced that law enforcement and public administration workers, health workers, contract soldiers, and military personnel may not travel abroad
Hungarian citizens who reside abroad must either leave Hungary or comply with quarantine regulations even if they show no symptoms of COVID-19
Hungary introduced border control at its borders with Slovenia and Austria
Hungary closed its borders to all foreigners

The Hungarian Minister of Technology is entitled to any relevant data regarding the spread COVID-19, and regional/municipal governments, businesses, and individuals are obligated to provide any data that the Minister of Technology requests.
Hungary delivered 300,000 masks from government stockpiles and started a production line with the capacity to produce 25,000 more
Hungary announced that the Hungarian Army Medical Center will continuously send proposals to the Operational Staff for how to control the COVID-19 outbreak
Hungary began construction on a "epidemiological mobile container hospital"
Hungary has assigned military officials to the country's health resource companies to ensure their proper allocation and operation
Hungary banned the export of hydroxychloroquine sulfate, a chemical substance used in the production of drugs used to treat COVID-19
The Hungarian government appropriated 15 billion HUF to the State Healthcare Center for the purchase of medical devices to combat COVID-19
The Hungarian national government stocked 51 hospitals with "hospital managers" who are responsible for coordinating stocks of medical equipment.
Hungary received 12 million face masks, 30,000 overalls and 200,000 face shields from China
Hungary reallocated 1.3 billion HUF to a fund dedicated to controlling the Covid-19 epidemic
The Hungarian government donated 100,000 face masks and 5,000 pieces of protective clothing to North Macedonia
Hungary imported  20.6 million surgical masks, 1.85 million face masks, 220 ventilators, 50,000 tests, and 10.6 million PPE items
Hospitals in Hungary were ordered to free up 50% of their beds to prepare for a massive influx of Covid-19 patients.
Hungary gave 50,000 face masks to the Vatican
Hungary donated 20 ventilators to Kyrgyzstan
Hungary announced a two-week lockdown. Citizens could travel, exercise, and work, but must maintain social distancing and cannot be in groups.
Hungary created an operative staff to coordinate and manage the governmental response to a potential COVID-19 outbreak.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Hungarian government created ten new "action groups" to create and help enforce policy for the COVID-19 pandemic
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Hungary set up a COVID-19 research group to develop drugs and vaccines to treat the virus
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Hungary extended the expiration date of government documents for 15 days after the end of the state of emergency
Hungary announced that all loan repayment obligations would be pushed off until the end of the year

Hungary has advised that all nursing homes appoint a Covid-19 mitigation manager, provide proper hygiene materials to workers and residents, be on call 24 hours per day, and isolate and observe infected residents.
Hungary tripled (from 5,000 to 15,000 forints) the limit for debit card payments not requiring a PIN code to keep germs from spreading via PIN pad.
Hungary publicly released a 28-point action plan regarding how its health and law enforcement agencies are to deal with COVID-19.
The Hungarian government launched a campaign to hang posters, create educational films and internet videos, and call citizens to inform them of the country's curfew policies
Hungary is forcing Hungarian citizens returning from Italy to undergo "official home quarantine"
Hungary announced a government-enforced quarantine at homes and hospitals for COVID-19 patients
Hungary announced that it would deport any non-Hungarian citizen who refuses to comply with quarantine guidelines

Hungary is forbidding visitation to "institutions that provide professional social care, child protection professional care, juvenile correctional facilities, and transitional homes for families and children" in order to protect social workers at residential social institutions.
Hungary closed all nightclubs, cinemas, and "visiting cultural institutions"
Hungary announced that all businesses could only be open until 3pm with the exception of grocery stores, pharmacies, and drug stores.

After starting reopening in the countryside, Hungary is continuing to force all non essential businesses to close. Essential businesses may remain open, and restaurants may operate later to deliver takeout in the evenings.
Hungary is only delivering official government documents by mail rather than allowing them to be picked up in person.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Hungary is forbidding citizens from visiting theaters, dance and music events, museums, libraries, and public cultural institutions. Only those employed by the institutions may visit.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Laos: The Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism has issued a notice discouraging the organisation of large events including weddings, as the government intensifies efforts to minimise the risk of a Covid-19 outbreak. Head of Office of the ministry, Mr Vansy Kuamua, signed the notice on March 10, giving provincial culture and tourism departments and relevant bodies nationwide authority to request the postponement of festivals and events, such as weddings, which draw a large crowd.
Hungary forbids gatherings of more than 100 people in a closed place and of more than 500 people in an open place
Hungary is only allowing sporting events to proceed "behind closed gates"
Hungary banned all events or meetings of any kind with the exceptions of religious services, marriages, and funerals
The Hungarian Government has cancelled all public celebrations scheduled for St. Stephen's day (August 20) with the exception of a small military ceremony.
Hungary placed a ban on hospital visitation

On June 12 (announced on June 13), following the lifting of the total ban on hospital visitations, the Chief Medical Officer of Hungary introduced a number of restrictions with regards to hospital visitations: Visitors must be healthy, wear masks, wash and sanitize their hands, and keep a distance of at least 2 meters from all patients other than the ones visited.
Iceland announced the closing of upper secondary schools and universities starting March 16th. Preschools and elementary schools will be place under special conditions.

The national commissioner of the Icelandic police raises the alert level of the response to COVID-19 to emergency phase on March 6th, following the confirmation of the first transmissions of the virus within Iceland.
Iceland issues travel ban on non-EU/EEA/EFTA or UK national starting from March 20th
In Iceland from June 15th, tourists will be able to provide a health certificate or opt for a coronavirus screening at Keflavik airport, instead of completing a two-week quarantine.

In Iceland, from July 13th, for Icelandic residents and citizens returning home have to on arrival complete a period of  "heimkomusmitg "t " (home-coming contagion caution). This means will they be tested for COVID-19 at the border and they will also be required to undergo a second free PCR test at a local healthcare centre four to five days later. Until they get the results of the second test Icelanders should:

Maintain two-metre distancing
Only attend gatherings of up to ten people
Avoid high-risk individuals e.g. the elderly
Avoid physical contact

Heimkomusmitg "t is not the same as quarantine; Icelanders will be  permitted to use public transport, go to shops and meet family and friends whilst they await test results.
Iceland launched a tracing app on April 1 to track potential Covid-19 infections.
Icelandic health authorities have in cooperation with the medical research company deCode Genetics undertaken for the COVID-19 virus among the Icelandic population since the 13th of March.
Iceland allows everyone to be tested for the corona virus.

Icelands Chief Epidemiologist and deCODE Genetics start collecting blood samples from the general public in order to help determine how widespread COVID-19 infection has been within the Icelandic population on May 4. Donating blood for the survey is voluntarily. People undergoing blood tests for other reasons will also be asked to donate a sample. The blood samples will also be tested for antibodies. Those, who give blood will be notified of their test results.
The government of Iceland announced on September 16th 2020 to conduct random testing within the University of Iceland as well as the greater Reykjav "k area due to a spike in cases.

Iceland launches website on March 13 that informs about Covid-19 containing what one need or want to know about the virus, including how to protect oneself, how Iceland is responding, and special information for tourists
The State of Iceland rents the Fosshotel Lind in Reykjav "k it will be converted into a quarantine for tourists and others, unable to be in quarantine at home during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Iceland is enforcing a 14-day quarantine is for all residents of Iceland entering the countrystarting March 19th.
Iceland announced fines between $360-3590 for violations of the quarantine, starting from the 29th of March
The chief epidemiologist of Iceland implemented isolation for all persons who are ill with COVID-19 or suspected to have the virus from the 13th of March.

Iceland sets ut guidelines for restaurants and tour operators from March 14. Restaurants were asked to re-arrange their seating to at least two meters between seats, asking that only families and other groups in regular close contact would be seated together, that menus would be washed between each use, and that hand sanitation be available at entry and encourage guests to use them. Tour operators have been asked to offer hand sanitiser at every entry point and encourage passengers to use them, to use back doors if available, make sure that passengers embark and disembark with enough space in between each, and skip using every other row to ensure proper space between passengers.

Iceland government announced that from March 24 to April 12 grocery stores and drug stores are allowed to have maximum 100  people in the stores, as long as a distance of 2 meters between people can be ensured.

Iceland ordered the closure of swimming pools, gyms, bars, clubs, slot machines and museums starting on March 23. Operations and services that require close contact between individuals or risk close contact are also prohibited. This includes sports clubs, hairdressers, beauty salons, and massage parlours.
Iceland allows bars and restaurants to be open but they must close by 11pm from May 25.

Iceland announce that from August 5 the number of people allowed at swimming pools and bathing places is reverted back to the ruling from earlier this summer. That means that the number of guests may never exceed half of the maximum number of guests allowed under the operating license. Children born in 2015 and later are not included in this number. This is valid until August 13.

Iceland announced that From august 5 Supermarkets over a thousand square meters in size may allow a maximum of 200 customers in total. Smaller supermarkets may accommodate up to 100 people at a time, provided that the conditions for distance limits are met. The changes are valid until August 13th.
Icelands parliament will only address Covid-19 related matters from March 20 to April 20. All meetings related to matters that do not concern COVID-19 will be postponed until later in the year.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Icelandic government announced a ban on gatherings of more than 100 entering into force on the 16th of March.

Iceland cancels a number of events and festivities over Merchant "s weekend that takes place August 4 to August 6. This as a response to the new COVID-19 restrictions in Iceland, such as Einnar me_ allur in Akureyri, S "ludaga in Vatnask "gur and Innip "kinn in Reykjav "k. Pride, the Skjaldborg Festival in Patreksfj "r_ur and _j "_h "t "_, the annual outdoor festival held in Vestmannaeyjar, have likewise been canceled.
Iceland announced that from August 5 to August 13  there will be no permits given for any sort of entertainment gatherings/events which can be expected to attract groups of people after 23:00.
Iceland announces that people will have to keep a distance of 2 meters in common areas starting from the 24th of March
Iceland allows visitors in nursing homes again starting at may 4th. Only one person will be allowed to visit at a time.
Iceland announce that from July 31 wearing masks will be mandatory on public transport, including planes and ferries. This is expected to be in place until August 13th.
A wave of misinformation and rumour on Covid-19 making rounds among the public in India on 10th March which had forced the Indian Government to issue an advisory.

Ministry of Home Affairs issues guidelines on the measures to be taken by Ministries/ Departments of Government of India, State/Union Territory Authorities for containment of COIVD-19 Epidemic in the country.
Schools and colleges to remain closed in India till July 31
India announced a curfew of 21 days which came into effect on 25th March 2020. This was further extended to last until 3rd May 2020. The policy will be applicable across all parts of India.

India issues another travel advisory  " 
"Indian travelers are hereby advised to REFRAIN FROM TRAVELING TO CHINA.
Those planning a visit to India from China:
o Existing visas (including eVisa already issued) are no longer valid for any foreign national travelling from China.
o People traveling to China henceforth will be quarantined on return. "

India's Union Minister of Health and Family Welfare, Dr. Harsh Vardhan reviewed the status of preparedness and actions taken so far in handling the situation arising out of the outbreak of COVID-19 on 21 February 2020 and was informed that the screening of passengers is being done at all 21 airports, 12 major and 65 non-major seaports, and border crossings.

On 22 February 2020, India issued a travel advisory on Singapore and asked its citizens to avoid all non-essential travel. This was decided at a high level review meeting taken by Cabinet Secretary Rajiv Gauba on COVID-19. Four new countries were added to the list for screening at airports. After a detailed review, in addition to the universal screening as per earlier advisories, universal screening at airports was now being planned for flights from Kathmandu, Indonesia, Vietnam, and Malaysia.

The Indian embassy in South Korea issued an advisory on 24 February 2020 to its citizens urging them to reconsider non-essential travels to Daegu and Cheongdo county in Gyeongbuk in the wake of rising coronavirus cases in South Korea.

India issues new Travel Advisory with following additional recommendations (In addition to China, recommendations for which already existed in Travel Advisory on 02-05-2020)  " 
"Indian citizens are further advised to refrain from non-essential travel to the following
countries:
o Singapore
o Republic of Korea
o Islamic Republic of Iran
o Italy"

On 26 February 2020, the government issued a travel advisory against all non-essential travel to South Korea, Iran, and Italy in view of the developing situation vis- "-vis the spread of coronavirus in these countries.
An official from India's Directorate General of Civil Aviation, on 27 February 2020, said that all flights to and from Iran were cancelled.

India issues following visa policy  " 
"Regular (sticker) visas/e-Visas granted to all foreign nationals who have travelled to Peoples Republic of China, Iran, Italy, South Korea and Japan on or after 01.02.2020, and who have not yet entered India stand suspended with immediate effect.  Such foreign nationals may not enter India from any Air, Land or Seaport ICPs. Those requiring to travel to India under compelling circumstances may apply for fresh visa to nearest Indian Embassy/Consulate."

India issues following screening advisory  "
