Israel's Ministry of Health released an updated version of its Hamagen app, phasing out the previous version. It includes bluetooth capability and better accuracy than the original version.

On August 14 in Israel The Health Ministry has called on the public to avoid entering Kfar Yarka because of the high number of Coronavirus patients in the city. However, no official lockdown was imposed on the town.

On September 1, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu posted an Instagram video welcoming students to the new year. At the end of the video, he tells students to wear masks, socially distance, and look out for each other and their parents and grandparents.

On February 20, 2020, in Israel it was published that "the Ministry of Health wishes to clarify that the violation of the quarantine order may result in criminal charges, with a penalty of up to 7 years imprisonment if the violation was intentional, and up to 3 years imprisonment if it was negligence. This act constitutes "a potentially disease spreading act" in accordance with Article 218 of the penal code, as well as a violation of Article 287, "Violation of a Legal Order." Whoever wishes to report a violation of the home quarantine order may do so through the Ministry of Health's task-specific Coronavirus information website."

On February 22, 2020, it was announced that "following a report received from South Korea regarding 9 tourists from a group that recently stayed in Israel between 8.2.2020  " 15.2.2020 and subsequently identified as coronavirus patients upon returning to South Korea. 
The Ministry of Health wishes to instruct the Israeli public as follows:
 
1. Anyone who came in close contact (at a distance of less than two meters and for at least 15 minutes) with members of this group according to the dates and location detailed below, is requested to enter home quarantine for a duration of 14 days since last date of contact with the group and report this at the Ministry of Health's website or Kol Habriut Hotline, *5400.  Furthermore, should you develop the symptoms of the disease (fever over 38, coughing, or other respiratory symptoms) seek medical assistance in accordance with the Ministry of Health's instructions on the website, all the while calling ahead of time and following the Ministry's guidelines.
2. Anyone who was in the same locations at the same time detailed below as the group *but without close contact* is not required to enter home quarantine but is asked to remain vigilant to the symptoms of the disease (fever over 38, coughing or other respiratory symptoms)."

On February 2, 2020, in Israel it was announced that "any individual who visited South Korea or Japan in the last 14 days must remain in a 14-day home quarantine counting from the latest date he/she left these places, in addition to travelers from China, Hong Kong, Macau, Singapore, and Thailand."
On February 26, 2020, in Israel: "The Ministry of Health issued a Decree that all travelers from Italy in the last 14 days must be placed under a 14-day home quarantine."

In Israel on February 27, 2020: "The Ministry of Health discloses that ELAL flight LY382 from Italy, which landed in Israel on February 23 2020 16:10, had onboard a confirmed COVID-19 patient.
All passengers must be directly placed under home quarantine for 14 days from the date of landing and send a questionnaire to the Ministry of Health or call the Ministry of Health Hotline at *5400."

On February 28, 2020, in Israel, it was announced that "a passenger [that tested positive for Coronavirus] arrived on commercial Turkish Airline flight TK53 from Tokyo to Istanbul, and on flight TK84 from Istanbul to Tel Aviv that landed in Israel at 08:55.
All passengers who were onboard the flight that landed this morning and who were on the same flight as this person must enter home quarantine immediately for 14 days, and report this at the Ministry of Health's website or at Kol Habriut Hotline at *5400."

In Israel, on March 4, 2020: <U+200B>"Israelis citizens who left France, Germany, Switzerland, Spain and Austria must be placed under a 14-day home quarantine. This requirement is retroactive, meaning it is valid from the date of departure from these locations."
It is announced in Israel on March 4, 2020 that "Israeli residents returning from conferences outside of the country must be placed under a 14-day home quarantine."
Israel said on March 9th that it would mandate a two-week quarantine for anyone arriving on an international flight, from all countries.

On March 10, Israel required citizens to report violations of self-quarantine to the Ministry of Health. On August 10, the Knesset extended this policy, with a 3,000 shekel minimum fine, until August 31.

Beginning around March 17, the Israeli Defense Forces began operating quarantine hotels for people to quarantine upon contracting Coronavirus or entering the country. On May 11, the IDF eased the hotel regulations, permitting people with the means to self-isolate at home to do so. On August 11, the hotel quarantine policy was extended until August 31.

In Israel, on May 11, 2020, it is announced: "Those returning from abroad who demonstrate the ability to maintain proper home isolation (such as those with an apartment / house of their own or a completely separate housing unit with no other occupants) may be allowed to undergo their 14 day required isolation at home or another suitable location available to them."

In Israel, "International travelers, or any person who has had close contact with a confirmed COVID-19 patient or any person with respiratory symptoms must immediately enter home isolation" for 14 days.
The Leonardo Hotel in Beer Sheba, Israel, agreed to the Israeli Ministry of Defense's request that the hotel turn into a quarantine hotel for people infected with Coronavirus on July 9, 2020.

Israel's Ministry of Health updated its quarantine regulations. Whereas a 14 day quarantine was enforced previously, as of July 22, 2020, quarantine is only required for 10 days since the beginning of symptoms or a positive test result, including at least 3 days without symptoms. A second test showing a negative result is not necessary.

In Israel on March 11, 2020, it was announced: "Responsibilities of stores, malls and shopping centers  "to ensure no crowding and regulate occupancy, at any given moment, to avoid crowding and take care to maintain a reasonable distance between people."

Israel declares on March 15, 2020 that all malls, clubs, bars, pubs, and food establishments, gyms, swimming pools, water parks, zoos, the Safari, petting zoos, cinemas, theaters, and other cultural establishments etc. will be closed.

The Emergency regulations limiting the number of workers in the workplace, which were announced on April 7, 2020, in Israel, have been extended until April 19, 2020: "No more than 10 employees or 15% of the workforce will be employed at the same time, whichever is higher."

On April 7, 2020, in Israel, it was announced that "it is forbidden to have employees in the workplace during the Passover holiday", which refers to the time span between Wednesday, April 08, 2020 at 15:00 and Friday, April 10, 2020 at 06:00.

Israel declares on April 26, 2020 that all malls, clubs, bars, pubs, gyms, swimming pools, water parks, zoos, the Safari, petting zoos, cinemas, theaters, and other cultural establishments etc. will remain closed.
Israel declares on May 7, 2020 that non-essential business' "malls, markets, and gyms" can reopen providing they follow specific guidelines

Israel declares on April 26th, 2020 "regulations allow the sale of food from restaurants in a  "take-away " style, with no sit-downs, as well as the opening of hairdressers, beauty salons, and other cosmetic services such as laser hair removal and the opening of stores in the public space"

Israel on May 26 announced that restaurants, bars, pubs, pools, youth centers, community centers, and other non-essential tourist attractions will be allowed to reopen starting May 27, subject to restrictions on capacity, physical distancing, masking, and hygiene. 

Masks must be worn at all times except when eating. Restaurants/bars with capacity greater than 100 may only operate at 85% capacity. Business owners must maintain a ratio of 7 sq meters per customer. Pools must maintain a ratio of 6 sq meters of space for each customer.

Israel's "Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Finance Minister Moshe Kahlon Monday night [March 30] presented an 80 billion shekel ($22.3 billion) economic program to help the economy get through the impact of the coronavirus pandemic."

4 elements of plan:

"10 billion shekels in extra health care spending.

About 20 billion shekels for a safety net for salaried workers and the self-employed, of which 17 billion is slated for jobless benefits.

For small, medium-sized and large businesses, 32 billion shekels in aid.

About 8 billion shekels to boost the economy after the crisis eases."

Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet announced on July 16, 2020, that "all non-essential businesses and institutions, including hair salons, markets, malls and public pools, will be closed to the public. Hotel pools will remain open"on weekends from 5 pm Friday until 5 am Sunday morning.

On July 16, 2020, Israel's Coronavirus cabinet announced that "Food courts in workplaces will be closed to visitors. Takeout is allowed.
> Gyms and studios used for sports training or choreography will be closed, with the exception of competitive and olympic sports, according to existing regulations
> Caf "s, restaurants and other food-related businesses will be closed to the public. Takeout and food delivery are allowed.
> Hotel restaurants' visitor capacity will be limited to 35%."

The Israeli Knesset's Coronavirus Committee will allow tourist attractions, such as zoos, to open on weekends beginning July 24 in accordance with health regulations, while gyms will be allowed to reopen Sunday, July 26.
Over the July 31-August1 weekend, Israeli police issued warnings to 59 businesses and ordered 28 businesses to close that were violating restrictions of being open on weekends.

For Israel's election on March 2, 2020, "thousands of Israelis quarantined due to possible exposure to the coronavirus are voting in special polling places set up to allow them to safely cast their ballots."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Israel is restricting public transportation on March 17, as transportation service for the weekends will cease on Thursdays at 8 p.m. and only resume early Sunday morning. The regulations apply to buses, trains and the light rail.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: In Israel, on March 25, 2020, it was decided that "public transport services would be reduced to around 25%".
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: In Israel starting on Monday April 20, urban and suburban transportation (buses only, not railways) will double in all parts of the country, from 25% of activity in which it currently operates to 50% of activity. High-speed intercity transport will not be increased except for the "train kissing" lines such as line 480 from Tel Aviv Arlozorov to Jerusalem, and line 910 from Tel Aviv to Haifa, which will operate at least twice an hour. Passengers will be required to wear a mask, there will be a limit of 20 passengers on each bus, and passengers will not be allowed in the first row near the driver.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description:
In Israel, "some 20 national parks and nature reserves all over the country will open on Wednesday [May 6] as part of the coronavirus reopening announced Monday [May 4].

Obligatory advance registration, via a website (in Hebrew) set to open Tuesday [May 5], will ensure that the various sites adhere to Health Ministry requirements. Visitor quotas will be set for each site and the duration of visits will be limited."

"The nature parks set to open include Ma "ayan Harod (Harod Stream), Caesarea, Yarkon Tel Afek, Yarkon Park, Apollonia, Beit Guvrin, Herodium, Castel, the Ein Gedi archaeological park, Masada and Ein Habesor.

The list of nature reserves includes Banias, Snir Stream, Ayun Stream, Yehudiya, Ein Afek, Hula, Taninim Stream, Enot Tsukim, Ein Gedi and the Zin Cliffs Nature Reserve."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: In Israel, "Trains will begin running again on Monday [June 22, 2020]. Trains have been halted for three months and the date for resuming service has been postponed several times."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description:
Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet announced on July 16, 2020, that "Ministries will be closed to the public. All civilian contact with ministries will be online.
> Ministries will be limited to a 50% worker capacity."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet announced on July 16, 2020, that, on weekends beginning July 24, "Beaches will be closed to the public."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 4, 2020, it was announced that "international conferences in Israel are forbidden".
In Israel, on March 4, 2020: "All large public events / mass gatherings of more than 5,000 people are not permitted."
Israel is restricting gatherings to no more than two people, except nuclear family members who live in the same home, Netanyahu announced on March 30.
In Israel, "People will be allowed to pray in groups of 19 in an open space" between April 18 and May 3, 2020.

In Israel, "The so-called coronavirus cabinet also approved the reopening of cultural venues, which could be permitted to open as soon as the weekend [June 19-20, 2020].

Events will initially be capped at 250 attendees, the same as for religious ceremonies such as weddings, though Culture Minister Chili Tropper is reportedly pushing to allow up to 500 people."
In Israel, "senior army officials approved holding a mass prayer service with thousands of participants at Joseph "s Tomb in Nablus on June 23," 2020.

Israel's "Health Minister Yuli Edelstein on Sunday [June 28, 2020] said he had recommended reimposing restrictions on public gatherings and events."

"Edelstein said his recommendations as presented to the government were to lower the number of people allowed to attend weddings and other religious events like bar mitzvahs, as well as the number of participants in synagogue services, without specifying how many would be allowed to gather."

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced on July 2, 2020 that, beginning July 3, crowds in closed spaces including synagogues, event halls, bars, and nightclubs will be limited to 50 people. Other closed spaces, including private homes and places of work, business, and shopping, will be limited to a capacity of 20 people. Previously, event halls were limited to 250 people and restaurants were permitted full capacity up to 100 people, or 85% capacity past 100 people.

Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet decided on the following restriction on July 6, 2020:

"1. Event halls, clubs and bars - closed
2. Restaurants - 20 people sitting inside, up to 30 outside
3. Synagogues - 19 people
4. Gyms and public pools - closed
5. Cultural performances - closed
6. Organized sporting events - without fans
7. hotels and tourism - clubs and bars closed, hotel restaurants 20 people (closed seating)
8. Summer camps - closed for children from fourth grade
9. Buses - up to 20 people per bus, with windows open and no air-conditioning
10. Gatherings - up to 20 people, two meters apart with masks
11. Government offices - 30% of staff required to work from home"

On July 16, 2020, Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet announced that "gatherings will be limited to 10 people in enclosed spaces and 20 people in open spaces, with the exception of workplaces and immediate families. This restriction will apply starting Friday [July 17] at 5:00 p.m."
On August 5, 2020, Israel's Coronavirus Committee "agreed to allow cultural events in outdoor areas in cities with low rates of infection, flagged as green. "

Israel's Ministry of Culture and Sport announced on August 18, 2020, that event halls will be allowed to open on September 1 in accordance with the Coronavirus Czar's plan. The number of people permitted to attend events has not been specified.

On March 4, 2020, it is announced:"The recommendation for older adults over 60, and for people with chronic diseases such as heart conditions, diabetes, hypertension, respiratory diseases or immunosuppression, is to avoid gatherings, contact with international travelers, contact with sick people, and contact with people suspected of a coronavirus infection."
In Israel, on March 10, 2020: "Visits to hospitals and to facilities for the elderly are to be avoided."
In Israel, on March 11, 2020: "Health staff responsible for treating patients  " may gather only for work purposes, and in groups not over 15 people."

On April 2, 2020, the Ministry of Health issues public guidances ahead of the Passover vacation in Israel: Family meetings will not be held, apart from celebrations with the the members of our household.
In Israel, "people not wearing masks in public spaces will be fined 200 shekels ($58), after being cautioned once," from April 18-May 3, 2020. On June 22, the fine increased to 500 shekels ($145).

Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet established a limit on the number of people in certain public spaces: one person for seven meters, or in accordance to gathering guidelines. This policy excludes restaurants (up to 20 people inside and up to 30 people outside), restaurants in a hotel (35% of capacity), and 1 person for every 6 meters in hotel swimming pools. Businesses must post signs with these restrictions to inform guests.

On August 9, 2020, Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet announced a restriction on the number of passengers allowed to travel in private vehicles. The new restriction permits 2 passengers not including the driver, and one passenger for each additional row, excluding people who live together.
On August 9, Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet announced that, beginning August 11, all deliveries must be placed outside the home.

On August 16 Israel expanded the definition of "people living together" for social distancing and gathering size purposes to now include the companion of a person with a disability. Furthermore, when ordering delivery, a person with a disability may request to bring the delivery into the house.
On April 16th, the Italian Ministry of Health published refutations of leading fake news surrounding the virus.
Italy is enforcing a nationwide school closure after March 4.
On May 13th, the Italian Minister of Education announced that schools will reopen in the fall, starting September.
Italy is enforcing a Curfew in the whole country after March 10.
Italy is declaring a nationwide state of emergency after Jan. 31
January 30, 2020: Italy suspends all flights to and from China to protect the country from further infections. This order is set to be enforced for 90 days.
Italy is enforcing External Border Restricions for all flight-passangers between Italy and China, after Jan. 31
Italy is enforcing External Border Restrictions on all travelers who want to enter or leave Italy for touristic reasons after march 9.

The Italian government has announced that law enforcement authorities would establish checkpoints at airports and train stations to collect self-declaration forms from travelers specifying the purpose of their movement and destination.
On April 8th, the Italian government has ruled that it won't let charity refugee boats dock and let refugees enter the country, until July 31st.
Italy slaps a 3 month ban on Bangladeshi citizens and travelers from Bangladesh after COVID-19 positive people found with fake certificates, ban will remain until October 05. announced on July 08.

The Ministry of Health releases an informative notice outlining the guidelines for the identification and treatment of suspect cases among people returning from Wuhan, and the recommendation to avoid further spread.
Italy is enforcing a Health Monitoring in all passangers going to italy after Jan. 23.

January 24, 2020: The Italian Ministry of Health released a notice outlining the procedure for monitoring the health state of passengers arriving from China. The duties will be performed onboard by the plane captain.

February 1, 2020: The Ministry of Health releases the guidelines to follow for all the students and teachers going to or returning from COVID-19 affected areas in China. The notice also includes instructions to identify the symptoms of COVID-19 and how to behave in case of contact with an infected person.

Precautionary health checks, which involving taking people's temperature with thermal scanners or thermometers to monitor for signs of fever, will be extended to air passengers transiting through Italian airports, will be carried out in Italy from February 12.

Italy is enforcing Health Monitoring on all travelers having stayed in areas at epidemiological risk, as identified by the World Health Organization, or transited or stopped in the municipalities of the "red zone" (Bertonico; Casalpusterlengo; Castelgerundo; Castiglione D'Adda; Codogno; Fombio; Maleo; San Fiorano; Somaglia; Terranova dei Passerini; Vo') after Feb 16.
Italy is enforcing Health Monitoring on all Travelers returning from Wuhan (China) to Italy after Feb 21.

On 24th March, Italy issued an ordinance announcing a free concession agreement to the use of a contact tracing software, designed by Bending Spoons S.p.A. The software, which will function through an App called  "Immuni ", was selected among a total of 300 tenders by the experts of the Task Force set up by the Minister of Technological Innovation and Digitalization, in agreement with the Ministry of Health. (Health Monitoring)
On April 16th, the Italian government approved digital contact-tracing software to track proximity among individuals through smartphones.
Italy is enforcing a Health Resources management after Jan. 28: Everyone who stayed in a risk area and has respiratory symptoms should wear a face mask.
Italy is enforcing a Health Resources Measure (Increasing ICU Beds and recruiting 20,000 health workers) after March 7.
In Italy, the region of Tuscany implements medical tents in the prisons of the region starting March 7.
Italy is enforcing Healt Resources regulation after March 13.
Italy is enforcing Health Resources Measure: In the region of Calabria two buildings were confiscated and converted into infirmaries after March 16.
Italy is enforcing a Health Resources Management (Students of Medicine) after March 17.
Italy is enforcing Health Testing Restrictions: Just people with symptoms will be tested after Feb. 26.
On May 4th, Italy plans to conduct antibody tests on 150,000 people in all 20 regions.

On 23 February, the Italian government announced that 11 municipalities will have a lockdown imposed upon approximately 50,000 residents, meaning that no one may enter or leave the municipalities and residents must self-isolate in their homes.
Italy is enorcing internal border restrictions on all citizens in ten Municipalities in Lombardy

Italy bans people from cities under quarantine (Codogno; Castiglione; d "Adda; Casalpusterlengo; Fombio; Maleo; Somaglia; Bertonico; Terranova dei Passerini; Castelgerundo; San Fiorano; Vo) from boarding any airplane from febuary 26.
On 8 March, Italy announced that 15 provinces of about 16 million people are being put under lockdown, meaning no one may enter or leave these regions until at least 3 April.
Italy is enforcing a nationwide Internal Border Restriction after March 10.
Tripoli follows Italian government in declaring its seaports  "unsafe "
Italy is establishing a Ministry-Taskforce after Jan. 22
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: January 29, 2020: The Italian Farnesina Crisis Unit declares it will organize a flight departing on January 30, 2020, to repatriate Italian citizens stranded in Wuhan. Medical personnel and equipment will be on board and security protocols will be performed on arrival.
January 31, 2020: President Giuseppe Conte confirms the first two positive cases to COVID-19 in the country, a couple of tourists from China landed in Milan on January 23.
Italy is setting up a Hotline and Website to inform the public about Coronavirus after Jan. 27.
Italian Government promotes smart working at home for public administrative units on March 4.

Italy is setting up a public awareness campaign to stay at home: #iorestoacasa on March 12. It is a sign spread by the government to be put on the doors of the citizens to raise awareness for the existing quarantine,

On April 14th, the Italian Ministry of Health launches a Telegram channel, soon thereafter garnering more than 300 thousand followers, informing the public of all updates surrounding the virus and the health measures mandated by the government.
In Italy, travellers on a cruise ship were isolated after a passenger from Macau developed symptoms of COVID-19 for a day (January 30th), until the negative test was made official.
Italy has asked children travelling from China to stay away from school for two weeks voluntarily from February 10th.

Italy, February 12: The government has dispatched a military plane to China to evacuate a 17-year-old Italian national who was barred from another repatriation flight after showing signs of fever, Di Maio said on Monday. The teenager, who tried to return from the city of Wuhan with some 50 other Italians last week, has tested negative for the coronavirus.

The other evacuees are being held in precautionary quarantine at a military facility in the south of Rome, where they are due to remain for another six days.

Italy is enforcing a two-week Quarantine for all close contacts (Health care professional in the care of a suspected or confirmed case of COVID-19, having been in close contact (face-to-face) or in the same closed environment with a suspected or confirmed case of COVID-19,
living in the same house with a suspected or confirmed COVID-19 case or having traveled by air in the same or two rows before or after a suspected or confirmed COVID-19 case,) of confirmed or suspected COVID-19 cases after Feb. 21.
Italy is enorcing a Quarantine on all passagners that returned from affected regions in China in the last 14 days, after Feb. 21
Italy is enforcing a Quarantine on all travelers that traveled to Italy from affected regions in China in the last 14 days after Feb 22.
Italy is enforcing a two-week quarantine on all people with symptoms of covid-19 after March 9.
Italy is enforcing a twoo-week quarantine on all people tested positive for covid-19.
Italy is enforcing a two-week quarantine for all people that travelled between regions in italy after March 28.
Italy is enforcing a Quarantine for all travelers entering Italy after March 28.
April 10, 2020 Italy, confirms the lockdown until May 3, 2020 with the exception of some activities: stationery stores, bookstores, clothing stores for children.

(Italy) April 26, 2020 the government issues a new decree called "phase two":

- Generally travelling is still prohibited, except for family visits
- Any kind of crowd is still prohibited
- Returning to one's home or residence is allowed
- Parks, gardens and villas reopen, with attention to avoiding crowds
- Churches reopen only for funeral celebrations
- Return to work for the manufacturing and construction sectors, together with all wholesale activities
Italy is enforcing Restriction of Non-Essential Businesses after March 5

On 8 March, Italy announced that all non-essential businesses must close in 15 provinces, with the exception of restaurants and bars (which must ensure social-distancing of at least 1 meter for every employee and customer) until at least 3 April.
Italy is enforcing Restriction of Non-Essential Businesses after March 8.
Italy is enforcing Restrictions of Non-Essential Businesses after March 11
Italy is enforcing Restrictions of Non-Essential Businesses (closing) after March 23.

On April 14th, at the same time as the lockdown is extended until May 3rd, bookstores, stationery stores, and shops selling baby clothes and supplies are allowed to reopen nationwide, provided they adopt rigorous sanitary measures.
On August 16th, the Italian government mandated the closure of all dance clubs until at least September 7th.

The Italian government is banning all sporting matches and public events until next month in several regions of Northern Italy (restrictions of mass gatherings).

The new measures, approved last night, extends the urgent steps the government is taking for the containment of the coronavirus outbreak outside the exclusion zone. 

The decree bans all events and sport matches in public and private locations from Febuary 26 until March 1.

Italy: the start of the Venice Architecture Biennale has been delayed from May to August due to disruption caused by the coronavirus outbreak in Italy.
Organisers of the world's most prestigious architecture biennale announced today that the event will begin on 29 August and run until 29 November. 
The biannual event was scheduled to run from 23 May to 29 November. It has now been shortened to just three months instead of the usual six.
Italy, March 4: Professional football matches and other big sporting events will take place without fans present until April 3 said Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte.

The March 8 Decree prohibits the following types of mass gatherings and activities:
- sporting events and competitions of all kinds and
disciplines in public or private places shall be suspended
-  all events organised, as well as events in public or private
places, including those of a cultural, recreational, sporting,
religious or trade fair nature, shall be suspended (e.g.  cinemas, theatres, pubs, dance schools, game rooms,
betting and bingo halls, discos)
-  the opening of places of worship shall be subject to the
adoption of organisational measures such as to avoid a gathering
of persons

Italian officials have cut short the Venice Carnival for restriction of mass gathering reasons as they try to control what is now the worst outbreak of the coronavirus in Europe.

Authorities in the Veneto region said the event would end later on Sunday, two days earlier than scheduled. (February 23)
On May 18th, the Italian government announced that it is allowing concerts, provided certain conditions are met, starting June 15th.
Italy is enforcing a Social Distance measure after March 5.
Italy is enforcing social distance measures on all people within italy (park closed)

On April 26th, the Italian government announces that, after the lockdown ends on May 4th, all citizens are strongly recommended to socially distance and wear masks. Masks are mandatory on public transportation.
From August 16th, the Italian government will mandate the use of masks in all public spaces between the hours 6:00 p.m. and 6 a.m, both indoors and outdoors, until at least September 7th.
On January 23, 2020, the Coordination Office of Measures on Emerging Infectious Diseases, Cabinet Secretariat (Japan), established a website on "Countermeasures Against the Novel Coronavirus".

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In this context, it was agreed to  "d) Take necessary measures for children who have temporarily returned from China, including supporting their acceptance and preventing bullying at schools. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In this context, it was agreed to  "b) Call on consumers and businesses to remain calm and refrain from overstocking, to ensure there are enough masks and other goods necessary for the people. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) will  "call for a calm response in order to prevent confusion including panic buying of food, medicine and daily necessities. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka)  "will work with the government in informing the residents that the emergency measures are different from "lockdown" (city blockade). "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). In order to guarantee the (1) Provision and sharing of information, it was agreed to  "[i]nform the public that the government will not take measures such as "lockdown" (city blockade), and call for a calm response from the people (self-restraint of travel across prefectures, such as nonessential visits to hometowns and travel, avoiding flooding of shops and panic buying). "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". As for  "(3) measures to control the infection, " it was agreed that  "B) b) Prefectural governments, etc., shall request schools and other institutions to take appropriate measures including presentation of infection control policies at their facilities and temporary closures of schools.

On February 29, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe held a press conference on COVID-19, where he announced that the  "government will do everything possible to support local government efforts including making the same arrangements at after-school care programs as during spring break. "

Japan's "Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said Thursday the government will request all elementary, junior high and high schools in Japan to close from Monday until the end of a spring break through early April".

Japan's Ministry of Education "suggests keeping schools closed, but sets no clear policy", thus "recommend[ing] continued closures of schools in areas with increasing numbers of novel coronavirus infections but again le[aving] the decision to local authorities" on April 1, 2020. The Ministry "sent revised guidelines to prefectural education boards nationwide concerning the reopening of schools".

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology will  "present guidance on securing childcare during such temporary closure for children of medical staff, those who need to continue working to maintain social functions, and those who have difficulty taking off work including single-parents. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare  "will provide guiding principles of nursery schools and after-school children's clubs, etc. regarding the down-sizing of childcare and temporary closure of facilities. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology  "will disseminate the guiding principle on temporary closure of schools. "

On April 22, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "has issued a directive to local authorities to ensure that day care centers look after children of healthcare workers who are on the frontlines of the coronavirus outbreak." "However, some medical institutions treating coronavirus patients are reporting that their staff members' children have been refused entrance to or asked to refrain from using day care centers. Ministry officials say healthcare professionals are taking anti-infection measures when treating patients, and that discrimination and prejudice against their children must not be tolerated."

On May 1, 2020, the Minister of Education, Science and Technology of Japan (MEXT) Hagiuda Koichi announced the release of "guidelines on how schools closed due to the coronavirus outbreak could resume classes in stages." "The guidelines propose staggered attendance by grade or class, with priority given to the first and final grades of elementary schools and seniors at junior high schools." The Ministry "also said that schools should divide children into groups by using unused classrooms and keep distances of one to 2 meters between seats. The notice proposed staggered class schedules by time and by day. It also said that physical education and other activities should not be conducted in congested environments."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to regulate "5) Handling of schools" it was decided that "ii) The Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) will provide guiding principles for nursery schools and after-school children's clubs, etc. on the down-sizing of childcare and temporary closure of facilities."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to regulate "5) Handling of Schools" it was decided that "i) The Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology will gradually restart school education activities according to the status of infections in each region, and create an environment where students can learn, while placing utmost attention on preventing infections."

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to regulate  "5) Handling of schools " it was decided that  "ii) The Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) will provide guiding principles for nursery schools and after-school children's clubs, etc. on the down-sizing of childcare and temporary closure of facilities. "

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). Accordingly,  "[t]he Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) will provide guiding principles for nursery schools and after-school children's clubs, etc. on the down-sizing of childcare and temporary closure of facilities. "

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). Accordingly,  "[t]he Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology will swiftly develop comprehensive measures to ensure an environment for students to learn according to the situation of infections in each region, while placing utmost attention on preventing infections. "

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). Accordingly,  "[t]he Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) will provide guiding principles for nursery schools and after-school children's clubs, etc. on the down-sizing of childcare and temporary closure of facilities. "

The Parliament of Japan enacted on March 13, 2020, "a law amendment giving Prime Minister Shinzo Abe the power to declare a state of emergency and take drastic measures in the fight against the spread of the new coronavirus." "The revised law, newly covering the coronavirus, will allow the government to declare a state of emergency to authorize governors of the 47 prefectures to place restrictions on the private rights of citizens." The law will be enforced from March 14, 2020.

On May 14, 2020, the Government of Japan "lifted the coronavirus state of emergency for 39 of the country's 47 prefectures." "Prime Minister Shinzo Abe explained the standards for ending the state of emergency. He also said the government will reassess conditions in the remaining eight prefectures including Tokyo and Osaka on May 21 to determine whether to lift the measure there."

On April 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzo declared that "the virus has been spreading in six prefectures  " Hokkaido, Ibaraki, Ishikawa, Gifu, Aichi, and Kyoto  " to the same extent as in the seven prefectures where the state of emergency originally applied. Those seven are Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Hyogo and Fukuoka." Accordingly, the "13 prefectures have now been designated as "special alert prefectures" where it is necessary to promote efforts to prevent the spread of infections."

On May 4, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzo announced that the Government of Japan "intend[s] to request the Expert Meeting to assess the [emergency] situation" on May 14. The Government of Japan will "ask the Expert Meeting to conduct detailed analyses on the trend of new cases in each area and the degree of pressure on medical treatment structures."

On May 6, 2020, the Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi, in charge for Economic Revitalization, announced that "[l]ifting state of emergency to be reviewed on a weekly basis." "Having extended its nationwide state of emergency by a month, the government now says it will consider week by week whether to lift it earlier and offered May 21 as a new date, depending on infection rates."

On January 31, 2020, at the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that Japan "will deny entry of individuals who are infected by the virus in accordance with the Immigration Control and Refugee Recognition Act. Furthermore, it is also necessary to strengthen immigration controls to respond to the cases in which infection has not been confirmed. Based on the fact that individuals have tested positive for the virus with or without symptoms, [the Government] must further improve the effectiveness of border controls."

Japan "designated the infectious disease related to the novel coronavirus a Designated Infectious Disease under the Act on the Prevention of Infectious Diseases and Medical Care for Patients with Infectious Diseases" on February 28, 2020, planned its enforcement on February 7, 2020, but brought it forward to February 1, 2020. The announcement took place on January 31, 2020.

From February 10, 2020, "regular flights between mainland China and at least 13 regional airports in Japan will be completely suspended due to the coronavirus outbreak." The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism of Japan (MLIT) stated that the affected airports will be Hanamaki, Sendai, Niigata, Ibaraki, Toyama, Shizuoka, Okayama, Yonago, Takamatsu, Matsuyama, Kitakyushu, Nagasaki, and Kagoshima.

From February 10, 2020,  "regular flights between mainland China and at least 13 regional airports in Japan will be completely suspended due to the coronavirus outbreak. " The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism of Japan (MLIT) stated that the affected airports will be Hanamaki, Sendai, Niigata, Ibaraki, Toyama, Shizuoka, Okayama, Yonago, Takamatsu, Matsuyama, Kitakyushu, Nagasaki, and Kagoshima.

On February 12, 2020, during the Seventh Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, the Government of Japan "has made a "high-level" political decision to flexibly interpret existing legislation to deny entry into the country to some foreigners in a bid to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus."
On February 12, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on its nationals in China [...] to immediately consider returning to Japan, in response to the spreading outbreak of the new coronavirus."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". As for  "(5) border control measures, " it was agreed that  "[b]ased on the viewpoint of preventing a sudden inflows of infected persons into Japan, current entry restrictions and the recommendation for travel suspension will remain in effect. "
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued a "Travel advice and Warning on Infectious Diseases Level 2: Avoid Non-essential Travel" for Iran on February 26, 2020.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued a "Travel advice and Warning on Infectious Diseases Level 1: Exercise Caution" for South Korea (whole country) on February 28, 2020.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued a "Travel advice and Warning on Infectious Diseases Level 2: Avoid Non-essential Travel" for South Korea on March 6, 2020.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued a "Travel advice and Warning on Infectious Diseases Level 3: Avoid All Travel" for the provinces of Alborz, Isfahan, Qazvin, Golestan, Semnan, Mazandaran, Markazi, and Lorestan (Iran) on March 10, 2020.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued a "Travel advice and Warning on Infectious Diseases Level 1: Exercise Caution" for Switzerland, Spain, Germany, and France on March 10, 2020.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued a new "Travel advice and Warning on Infectious Diseases Level 2: Avoid Non-essential Travel" for Italy (whole country) and Vatican City on March 10, 2020.

From March 11, 2020 0:00 JST "until further notice, entry to Japan will be denied to foreigners who have visited" San Marino "within 14 days prior to the application for landing", in accordance with Article 5, Paragraph (1), Item (xiv) of the Immigration Control and Refugee Recognition Act, "unless exceptional circumstances are found". "Japanese nationals are exempted."
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued a "Travel advice and Warning on Infectious Diseases Level 1: Exercise Caution" for Qatar and Bahrain on March 12, 2020.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued a "Travel advice and Warning on Infectious Diseases Level 1: Exercise Caution" for Iceland, Austria, the Netherlands, Sweden, Slovenia, Denmark, Norway, Belgium, Monaco, Liechtenstein, Andorra and Luxembourg on March 12, 2020.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued a "Travel advice and Warning on Infectious Diseases Level 2: Avoid Non-essential Travel" for Egypt on March 17, 2020.

From March 19, 2020, Japan "denies permission to land in Japan to foreigners [...] who have stayed within 14 days prior to the application for landing" in the following areas: Autonomous Community of Navarre, Basque Country, Madrid Region, La Rioja (Spain).

Japan "denies permission to land in Japan to foreigners [...] who have stayed within 14 days prior to the application for landing" in the following areas: Aosta Valley, Trentino-Alto Adige, Friuli-Venezia Giulia, Liguria Province (Italy).
