The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued a "Travel advice and Warning on Infectious Diseases Level 2: Avoid Non-essential Travel" for Indonesia, Singapore, Thailand, the Philippines, Brunei, Vietnam and Malaysia on March 25, 2020.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued a "Travel advice and Warning on Infectious Diseases Level 2: Avoid Non-essential Travel" for Indonesia, Singapore, Thailand, the Philippines, Brunei, Vietnam, and Malaysia on March 25, 2020.

From March 27, 2020 0:00 JST "until further notice, entry to Japan will be denied to foreigners who have visited" Iran (all areas) "within 14 days prior to the application for landing", in accordance with Article 5, Paragraph (1), Item (xiv) of the Immigration Control and Refugee Recognition Act, "unless exceptional circumstances are found". "Japanese nationals are exempted."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to regulate "6) Border-control measures" it was decided that "The Government will continue to implement entry restrictions, travel warnings, strengthened quarantine, and visa restrictions, from the viewpoint of preventing the flow of infected people into Japan and the spread of infections throughout Japan."

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to implement  "7) Border-control measures " it was decided that  "The Government will continue to implement entry restrictions, travel warnings, strengthened quarantine, and visa restrictions, from the viewpoint of preventing the flow of infected people into Japan and the spread of infections throughout Japan. "

Under the current travel ban imposed on May 27 by Japan, people with permanent residency and long-term resident and spousal visas who had left Japan for any of the listed countries before the restrictions were imposed are allowed to return  "in principle. "

At a press conference on June 23, 2020, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan MOTEGI Toshimitsu announced that "it has been decided to operate special flights from Japan to Viet Nam over the three-day period on June 25, 26, and 27 arranged by the Japanese Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Viet Nam. Through these flights, it is planned for about 440 Japanese residents and businesspeople to travel to Viet Nam. They will be the first flights from Japan to Viet Nam since the agreement to relax restrictions partially and gradually on mutual travel between our countries. For this travel, the people who go to Viet Nam will enter the country in accordance with Viet Nam "s designated process of measures to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus. Also, among the travelers, businesspeople who will return to Japan after a relatively short time are expected to enter Japan in accordance with the trial measures for entry based on the decision made last week on June 18 by the National Security Council (NSC) and the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters. Specifically, on the condition that they comply with additional infection control measures, it is expected that measures will apply to them that enable limited business activities during the 14-day waiting period, such as waiting at home."

On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting decided that "if it is confirmed that a person is infected at a medical institution, the National Institute of Infectious Diseases should  arrange proper inspection and retrace the close contacts of the infected person."

On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting decided to "implement national border control measures, such as checking the health status of people entering the country from areas with a high risk of infection, with tools such as thermographies at quarantine stations."

On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that "[t]aking into consideration the fact that individuals have tested positive for the virus despite exhibiting no symptoms, it is necessary for us to phase up our responses including quarantine measures. [...] We will introduce a measure, aimed at all people entering Japan with any history of travelling to Wuhan or related areas, that checks their contact information while in Japan and follows up on their health status, regardless of whether or not they have exhibited any symptoms."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order for the  "(4) health system to deliver medical care, " it was agreed to  "A) b) Encourage people to contact the Call Center for Japanese Returnees and Potential Contacts, which refer suspected patients to outpatient facilities from the viewpoint of accurately grasping the situations of outbreak and preventing the further spread, as seeking medical care without consulting due to the anxiety from potential infection may lead to increased risk of infection. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order to  "(2) understan[d] the situation of infection in Japan, " it was agreed to  "B) Establish the surveillance system to grasp the epidemic situation in Japan, while switching to use of PCR test for the confirmation of diagnosis necessary to treat pneumonia patients who require hospitalization, in communities where the number of patients continues to increase."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order for the  "(4) health system to deliver medical care, " it was agreed that  "B) a) The elderly and those with underlying diseases are encouraged to seek appropriate medical care at the early stage, given their vulnerability to the infection. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly,  "[t]ake every possible precaution to prevent workers from being a source of infection by thoroughly avoiding the place where "3Cs" overlap at the same time, by making sure for workers to wear masks, wash and disinfect hands, disinfect regularly shared facilities, maintain a certain distance each other when eating and drinking, keep their daily health tracks and stay home if their physical condition is not perfect. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, prefectural governments  "will provide guidance to school operators on infectious disease countermeasures such as health management. "

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "7) Strengthening counter-cluster measures" it was decided that "i) Active epidemiological investigations will be organized to identify individuals who have been in close contact with infected persons, monitor their health conditions, request them to refrain from leaving home, and properly grasp the scale of the spread of infections for appropriate infection control."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) will "Identify suspected disease carrier and conduct tests that the doctor considers necessary."

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). With regards to  "8) Strengthening counter-cluster measures " it was decided that  "i) Active epidemiological investigations will be organized to identify individuals who have been in close contact with infected persons, monitor their health conditions, request them to refrain from leaving home, and properly grasp the scale of the spread of infections for appropriate infection control. "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) will  "Build a framework for effective surveillance, such as surveys on antibody prevalence. "

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). To continue  "(2) Surveillance and information gathering efforts, " the MHLW will  "Develop a system for sharing information about patients, etc. as soon as possible; [and] Use the system to gather and analyze statistical data for more effective and efficient measures. "

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). With regards to  "8) Strengthening counter-cluster measures " it has been decided that  "i) Active epidemiological investigations will be organized to identify individuals who have been in close contact with infected persons, monitor their health conditions, request them to refrain from leaving home, and properly grasp the scale of the spread of infections for appropriate infection control. "

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). In order to guarantee the (2) Surveillance and Information gathering, it was agreed to  "[b]uild a framework for effective surveillance, such as surveys on antibody prevalence. "

On June 19, 2020, the Government of Japan has begun "offering a smartphone app that alerts users of close contact with people infected with the novel coronavirus. The Cocoa app is aimed at preventing the spread of the virus by urging users with infection risks to get tested as soon as possible. [...] When users who have installed the app on their smartphones are located within a meter of each other for 15 minutes or more, their devices will exchange information of the encounter via the Bluetooth wireless technology and record it for 14 days. When a user is confirmed to be infected with the coronavirus, the local public health center will issue a code that the user can enter on the app. A server will gather information on the individual's encounters with other users, and notify them via the app that they had been in close contact with the infected patient."

On August 12, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that it "plans to ask elderly facilities to simulate a coronavirus outbreak by the end of August, as part of its resurgence response." "Staff at the facilities will also be asked to check stock levels of sanitary goods such as disinfectant and face masks and how they are checking the health of the staff. With the steps, the ministry aims to prevent an infection cluster among elderly people with a higher risk of developing serious conditions." "Facilities will have to report to the ministry by early September on whether they have taken the steps. Facilities required to carry out such simulations are special elderly nursing homes, nursing care facilities, homes for the elderly with care services and other establishments where many old people live together."

On August 28, 2020, at the 42nd Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government  "implement[s] regular screening all at once for all those who work at medical institutions and care facilities for the elderly so as to prevent group infections among people at high risk of developing severe symptoms. "

On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe clarified that, concerning the 210 Japanese nationals returned to Japan from Wuhan as of January 30, 2020, the Government "intend[s] to take all possible measures in monitoring their health, while continuing to make sure that all individuals who wish to return to Japan are able to do so [and] conduct thorough health checks regardless of symptoms, including virus screening, and make government facilities such as training centers fully available for accommodation for the duration of that process."

On January 31, 2020, at the Fourth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that "[e]ven for those individuals who have tested negative, [the Government is] thoroughly monitoring health condition of each and every person under appropriate controls, by stationing doctors at all accommodation facilities on a round-the-clock basis, [and] also providing push-mode support for daily living essentials, including face masks, sanitizers, thermometers, and other daily items, to those privately-owned accommodations and government facilities who have pledged their cooperation."

On February 5, 2020, at the Fifth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that the Government is "working on developing systems to enable private testing institutions to conduct screenings that the National Institute of Infectious Diseases and Public Health Institutes have been conducting."

"The Government of Japan decided to provide China with 4,800 safety goggles and 5,200 isolation suits, which are part of the equipment stockpiled by Asia-Europe Foundation (ASEF) and financed by Japan "s contribution, as in-kind contribution from the Government of Japan. This in-kind contribution was transported to Wuhan by the chartered flight which left Japan on Wednesday, February 6, and handed over to the Chinese side at Wuhan Tianhe International Airport on Thursday, February 7."

On February 6, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) instituted a new "telephone consultation service" for the new coronavirus. The new consultation desk will be reachable free of charge from 9am to 9pm at the number 0120-565653, starting from February 7, 2020.

On February 13, 2020, at the Eight Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that the Government "will extend supports to secure over 1,800 beds among medical institutions across Japan that are capable of accommodating patients."

On February 16, 2020, at the Tenth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that "the Government will more closely collaborate with local governments and implement various measures, including [...] increasing of the number of medical institutions with enhanced medical treatment systems in place from the current 726 to 800."

On February 16, 2020, at the Tenth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that "the Government will more closely collaborate with local governments and implement various measures, including [...] a 24-hour response, including Saturdays and Sundays, by the 536 consultation centers which were established in each and every prefecture."

At the end of February 2020, Japan National Tourism Organization (JNTO) "published a webpage titled, "For Safe Travels in Japan: Guide for when you are feeling ill," which allows users to find medical professionals in their area that speak English, Chinese, and Korean, plus other languages (Polish, French, German) that are less available. It also includes a brief guide for how to use travel medical insurance and typical Japanese hospital procedures. The tourism site also launched the Bebot x JNTO chatbot, which gives users information on COVID-19, restrictions on travel from China, travel insurance, as well as the option to "speak to human.""

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order for the  "(4) health system to deliver medical care, " it was agreed to  "A) e) Provide health professionals with appropriate information on treatment while also engaging in development of treatment, drugs, vaccines, and rapid diagnostic test kits. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order for the  "(4) health system to deliver medical care, " it was agreed that  "B) a) outpatient care for Japanese returnees and potential contacts is to be gradually reduced starting from the designated medical institutions for infectious diseases, which are expected to receive a large number of severe cases. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order to  "(2) understan[d] the situation of infection in Japan ", it was agreed to  "A) b) Improve laboratory functions at the institutions concerned such as local public health institutes (including private testing institutes). "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order for the  "(4) health system to deliver medical care, " it was agreed to  "A) a) Establish and operate 24-hour Call Centers for Japanese Returnees and Potential Contacts who suspect for their infection with the novel coronavirus. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order for the  "(4) health system to deliver medical care, " it was agreed to  "B) a) Establish the system in advance where elderly persons with no flu-like symptoms, or persons with underlying diseases who are receiving ongoing treatment and medication, can receive necessary care such as their prescriptions without visiting medical institutions as much as possible, including by phone, from the view of infection control. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order for the  "(4) health system to deliver medical care, " it was agreed to  "A) d) Secure beds and mechanical ventilators in medical institutions in preparation for the potential increase of patients. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In this context, it was agreed to  "a) Request related businesses to ramp up production and ensure the smooth supply of masks, disinfectants, etc. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order for the  "(4) health system to deliver medical care, " it was agreed to  "B) b) Establish a system for providing appropriate hospitalized medical care, including by securing beds and mechanical ventilations, and assigning roles to medical institutions in the community (i.e., arrangement of medical institutions that give priority to severe cases requiring intensive care, etc.), considering the possibility of further increases in patients and the characteristics of the novel coronavirus disease. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order for the  "(4) health system to deliver medical care, " it was agreed to  "B) a) Accept suspected patients of the novel coronavirus infection at outpatient facilities of general medical institutions after fully implementing the infection control measures including separating treatment hours and the flow of patients, in communities where the number of patients have significantly increased. (Local communities should discuss and consider in advance the medical institutions that do not accept the suspected cases of the novel coronavirus infection (i.e.: dialysis and obstetric medical institutions, etc.)). "

On February 25, 2020, at the 13th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that "[i]n response to the request from the Governor of Hokkaido yesterday, we will today dispatch a response team to Hokkaido."

According to the Ministry of Justice of Japan (MOJ), inmates of "seven prisons in Aomori, Kyoto, Osaka, Hyogo, Yamaguchi and Kochi prefecture" have been sewing "cloth face masks" since March 2020. "Having received orders from private-sector companies, these prisons now have the combined capacity to sew some 66,000 such masks a month. They also started preparations to make medical gowns that are in short supply as well."

On March 1, 2020, at the 16th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government "will materialize necessary response measures that include the development of a medical treatment structure, such as securing more than 5,000 hospital beds and installing the necessary facilities."

On March 3, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) instructed the manufacture and sale of masks to importers in order to ensure their distribution from March 5, 2020 to the areas of Kitami, Nakafurano, Setana, Kikonai, Shiriuchi, and Biei (Hokkaido).

On March 5, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe declared that the Japan "intend[s] to secure 15 million facial masks as the Government, by asking companies in Japan to increase the production and expanding import from overseas." The "supply of facial masks in the domestic market" will be encouraged "by providing support to mask manufacturers to increase their production."

Japan will provide "15 billion yen in contributions for international organizations" in order to implement "appropriate support measures" such as "technical cooperation and materials provision targeted at matters such as medical care, health workers, medical facilities, hospitals, and quarantine facilities". Around 2.5 billion yen will be allocated to Iran.

In the framework of the "Cabinet Order for the Partial Revision of the Order for Enforcement of the Act on Emergency Measures for Stabilizing Living Conditions of the Public", Japan promulgated on March 11, 2020, that, from March 15, 2020: "It is prohibited to [i] resell face masks that you have bought at retail stores, online shopping malls or other businesses [ii] to unspecified persons or a large number of people online or through stores or other businesses [iii] at prices higher than the acquisition prices."

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee (2) Surveillance and information gathering, it was agreed to  "[c]ontinue to develop simple test kits for rapid diagnosis. "

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee (2) Surveillance and information gathering, it was agreed to  "[s]trengthen the testing system by utilizing local and private institutes " and to [g]rasp and coordinate the PCR testing system. "

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). As for (4) Medicare, it was agreed to  "[s]ecure a flexible medical provision system in each region, depending on the spread of infection " and to  "[t]o prepare for possible significant increase of patients in Japan, secure medical provision structure including through considering division of roles among medical institutions in each region. Secure necessary beds, personnel, and necessary medical equipment such as respirators. "

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). As for (4) Medicare, it was agreed to  "[s]trengthen the system for [ "] accelerat[ing] clinical research and treatment to verify the effects of therapeutic agents. "

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee (3) Pandemic prevention, it was agreed to  "[s]ecure and foster experts in measures against cluster and strengthen the health center system. "

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). As for (4) Medicare, it was agreed to  "[s]trengthen the system for providing medical interpreters."

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). In this context, it was agreed to guarantee the  "[s]upply of goods and materials (increase production and ensure smooth supply of masks, disinfectants, foodstuffs, etc.; distribute such items by the government to medical institutions and nursing care facilities for the elderly; prohibit resale of masks, etc.). "

"Japanese Defense Minister Taro Kono issued on Saturday [(March 28, 2020)] an order to dispatch Self-Defense Forces troops as part of his country's efforts to strengthen quarantine steps amid the spread of the new coronavirus. From Saturday, the dispatched troops are engaged in the work to quarantine people arriving at Tokyo International Airport at Haneda and Narita International Airport in Chiba Prefecture, east of Tokyo. They are also supporting the transport of such people to designated facilities. The Defense Ministry dispatched SDF members on a voluntary basis based on a judgment that the current situation represents a case stipulated by the SDF law where the ministry should not wait for a dispatch request from a prefectural governor."

Japan will distribute two reusable/washable cloth face masks to each registered household, prioritising the regions with most coronavirus infections. This policy was announced on April 1st and is part of a wider economic package that will be published after April 6th. The distribution will be carried out at the end of April.

Japan declared that the country "plans to provide the anti-flu drug Avigan for free to 20 countries hoping to use it to treat coronavirus patients" on April 3, 2020. "The 20 countries receiving the drug, which is currently undergoing clinical tests, include Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Indonesia, Iran, Myanmar, Saudi Arabia and Turkey, with an additional 30 countries showing interest".

On April 6, 2020, at the 26th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government of Japan  "will increase production of Avigan, the medicine expected to be effective, and make all necessary preparations to increase the domestic stockpile from current 700,000 doses to 2 million doses. "

Japan announced on April 6, 2020, that the country "will boost its capacity for the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests for the novel coronavirus to 20,000 per day, [...] the number of ventilators to treat COVID-19 patients will be increased to 15,000 or more and that of hospital beds to 50,000".

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Under  "(6) Other important considerations " it was requested to enhance  "emergency transportation. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the  "Government and prefectures will prioritize securing personal protective equipment such as masks for medical institutions that conduct PCR tests and admit patients for hospitalizations."

The Japan Medical Association announced on April 8, 2020 that it will offer financial assistance to the medical support non-profit organization "AMDA Medical Information Center", which "will set up a multilingual hotline to help foreigners in Japan for inquiries regarding the new coronavirus" from April 10, 2020.

On April 11, 2020, Japan has announced measures to "ease the shortages of medical supplies at medical sites". "45 million surgical masks [will be distributed] to medical institutions nationwide; a further 10 million to these institutions in the seven prefectures" affected by the declaration of a state of emergency. "Regarding medical gowns and face shields, [...] 1 million of each [will] be distributed to the seven prefectures, subject to the degree of scarcity. As for N95 and KN95 masks, [...] 70,000 masks within next week and 700,000 by the end of the month [will be delivered].

On April 13, 2020, the Japan Business Federation (Keidanren, <U+7D4C><U+56E3><U+9023>) called "on member companies to supply industrial masks that can be repurposed for medical use. Keidanren put out the call to its roughly 1,400 members on Monday, in response to a government request." "Keidanren is specifically asking if members have surplus stocks of N95 and DS2 masks."

The Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi announced on April 19, 2020 that the Government of Japan "has secured over 210,000 hotel rooms nationwide to accommodate those with mild coronavirus symptoms as well as asymptomatic patients as the country tries to contain the spread of the virus."

The National Tax Agency of Japan announced on April 21, 2020, "that it will temporarily allow the sale of sake brewers' alcohol as disinfectant liquid, which is running short amid the novel coronavirus outbreak." "The agency will also promote the use of hard spirits and liquors made by adding fruits and herbs to redistilled "shochu" spirits as disinfectants. To this end, it will promptly issue a limited license to many shochu distillers across the country."

On April 21, 2020, "Japanese Foreign Minister Toshimitsu Motegi and his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, agreed [...] to share information on the COVID-19 infectious disease in a swift and transparent manner. During their one-hour telephone talks, Motegi called for the Chinese government's cooperation to facilitate shipments from China of face masks, protective suits and other items related to the pandemic."

On April 22, 2020, the Government of Japan expressed its plan "to strictly limit foreign investment in makers of medical goods and drugs amid the novel coronavirus pandemic." "The government fears that if foreign capitals, particularly Chinese, buy up Japanese manufacturers of ventilators and other advanced medical apparatuses, it will become difficult to sufficiently check domestic production and exports of such products, whose stable supply is indispensable to national security."

On April 24, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "[m]ore day care and short-stay facilities for the elderly have shut as the government expanded the state of emergency over the coronavirus crisis nationwide April 16." "The ministry is asking providers of the services to try to keep their facilities open as much as possible."

On April 27, 2020, it was announced that a "group of forensic pathologists in Japan says cases have occurred in which bodies of the deceased have been returned to families without undergoing coronavirus tests, despite experts' requests to carry out such checks." "To resolve the problem, forensic researchers in several universities have decided to carry out their own coronavirus tests."

At a news conference on April 28, 2020, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan MOTEGI Toshimitsu announced that "Japan will begin providing the anti-flu drug Avigan for free to 38 countries as early as this week for treating patients with the new coronavirus." The Minister added that "over 70 countries, including the 38, have made requests for Avigan to Japan, which has decided to offer a $1 million grant to the United Nations Office for Project Services to buy and distribute the drug, also known as favipiravir, to countries that want it."

At the beginning of May 2020, the Cabinet Office of Japan told Japanese local governments "to make preparations to prevent the spread of the coronavirus at evacuation centers if natural disasters occur, ahead of the rainy and typhoon seasons." The Cabinet Office prompted "the local governments to set up as many evacuation centers as possible in the event of disasters and consider in advance how to cope with infected evacuees."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "i) A hospital treatment system will be secured that focuses on providing medical care to those with severe symptoms" it was decided that  "A system will be set up to coordinate the acceptance and transfer of patients. Medical institutions' information-gathering systems will be utilized so that the institutions can visualize information necessary for coordinating patient acceptance."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "i) A hospital treatment system will be secured that focuses on providing medical care to those with severe symptoms" it was decided that Asymptomatic pathogen carriers and patients with mild symptoms who do not require hospitalization will recuperate at lodging facilities, etc."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "8) Strengthening counter-cluster measures" it was decided that "ii) Experts will be secured and trained to conduct the counter-cluster measures and strengthen the health center system. Technologies such as apps and social networking systems will also be utilized to promptly introduce a system for efficiently controlling infections and quickly grasping the infection situation."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "i) A hospital treatment system will be secured that focuses on providing medical care to those with severe symptoms" it was decided that "Temporary lodging facilities such as hotels will be secured and managed for this purpose."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "viii) Others [medical care measures]" it was decided to aim for "Providing medical interpreters for foreigners."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "ii) [Securing] an outpatient and testing system  " for suspected COVID-19 patients", this system would "Secure efficient medical care and testing systems by having institutions established that focus on conducting tests (local outpatient/testing centers), sending medical workers to Outpatient Services for Returnees and Contact Persons, and providing so-called drive-through and walk-through medical care in large tents and prefabricated buildings."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "ii) [Securing] an outpatient and testing system  "for suspected COVID-19 patients", this system would "Provide outpatient services to suspected COVID-19 patients under proper infection control by having them access Outpatient Services for Returnees and Contact Persons via the Call Centers for Japanese Returnees and Potential Contacts."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) will "Develop a system for sharing information about patients, etc. as soon as possible.; Use the system to gather and analyze statistical data for more effective and efficient measures."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "v) Securing the supply of medical goods" it was decided that "A secure manufacturing system will be set up for medical supplies, medical equipment, and medical materials to provide them promptly and smoothly to medical institutions that need them." It specified that "In particular, the securing of supplies of personal protective equipment, such as masks for medical institutions that conduct PCR tests and admit patients, will be prioritized."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "(6) Other important considerations" it was decided to keep consideration for "Supply of goods and materials necessary for the medical operation."

On May 5, 2020, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) announced that "Foreign Ministry's "Tabi-Regi" email-based security information service for Japanese travelers overseas will become available for users of the Line free messaging app. By improving user convenience, the ministry hopes to encourage people making foreign trips to register for the service, ministry officials said. The ministry aims to start the service for Line users in early 2021 at the earliest after a system upgrade."

On May 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW)  "approved remdesivir as the first treatment for COVID-19 in Japan, three days after the Japanese subsidiary of U.S.-based Gilead Sciences Inc. submitted the application. The process was accelerated under a special exception clause for pharmaceuticals that are approved by another nation with comparable standards as Japan "s. "  "The health ministry will initially manage the supply and distribute remdesivir to hospitals with patients with severe symptoms. The drug will be provided for free at first. "

On May 9, 2020, it was announced that a "group of researchers at the University of Tokyo has started clinical trials of [...] [n]afamostat mesylate, [...] marketed under the brand name Futhan. The tests are being conducted on 160 patients with pneumonia stemming from the coronavirus at the University of Tokyo Hospital and five other medical facilities in Japan. The patients are divided into two groups. One group is administered Futhan and anti-flu drug Avigan. The other is given only Avigan. University of Tokyo Professor Inoue Junichiro is involved in the trials."

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) will  "Continue to support the development of simple test kits for rapid diagnosis; [and] establish a domestic supply system. "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). With regards to  "i) A hospital treatment system will be secured that focuses on providing medical care to those with severe symptoms " it was decided that  "Asymptomatic pathogen carriers and patients with mild symptoms who do not require hospitalization will recuperate at lodging facilities, etc. Temporary lodging facilities such as hotels will be secured and managed for this purpose. "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). With regards to  "ii) [Securing] an outpatient and testing system  " for suspected COVID-19 patients ", this system would  "Secure efficient medical care and testing systems by having institutions established that focus on conducting tests (local outpatient/testing centers), sending medical workers to Outpatient Services for Returnees and Contact Persons, and providing so-called drive-through and walk-through medical care in large tents and prefabricated buildings. "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). With regards to  "i) A hospital treatment system will be secured that focuses on providing medical care to those with severe symptoms " it was decided that  "A system will be set up to coordinate the acceptance and transfer of patients. Medical institutions' information-gathering systems will be utilized so that the institutions can visualize information necessary for coordinating patient acceptance. "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). It was decided that  "iii) A medical service system will be established for entire regions, including service for patients with diseases other than COVID-19 " by  "Dividing roles among medical institutions in each region. "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). With regards to  "viii) Others [medical care measures] " it was decided to aim for  "Providing medical interpreters for foreigners. "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) will  "Strengthen the testing system by utilizing local and private institutes; Introduce new testing technology promptly in the medical field; Promote the utilization of private testing institutes; [and] grasp the PCR testing system and make necessary coordination. "

With regards to  "ii) [Securing] an outpatient and testing system  " for suspected COVID-19 patients ", this system would  "Provide outpatient services to suspected COVID-19 patients under proper infection control by having them access Outpatient Services for Returnees and Contact Persons via the Call Centers for Japanese Returnees and Potential Contacts. "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). "

On May 22, 2020, it was announced that the Government of Japan "will support nine domestic studies aimed at developing a coronavirus vaccine with subsidies totaling 7.2 billion yen, or about 67 million dollars." "The funds are designed to support basic research and segments of clinical trials for an experimental vaccine. The nine projects were selected by the Japan Agency for Medical Research and Development. Four are led by companies; another four involve universities; and one, a research institute."

"

On May 22, 2020, the Government of Japan "adopted an ordinance revision [...] to ban the resale of sanitizers and products that can be used as an alternative to disinfectants at prices higher than the acquisition costs." "The revised ordinance, which will come into force on Tuesday, will cover the resale of pharmaceutical and quasi-pharmaceutical products, such as sanitizers and alcohol-based hand soap products, and sanitizing products with an alcohol concentration of 60 pct or higher. Products without alcohol or not designed for disinfection will not be covered. Consumable alcohol of high concentrations will not be restricted either if it is resold for consumption."

On June 4, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzo said that "Japan will provide about $300 million to a global organization dedicated to increasing access to vaccinations in developing countries. The financial support to Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, will be extended for five years from 2021 to make contributions to global public health efforts. [...] The Japanese government provided around $95 million to Gavi for the previous five-year period from 2016 to 2020. The upcoming donation of $300 million, including $100 million already pledged in April, is the largest amount Japan has provided to the nongovernmental body to date."

On June 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "opened a website where users pick the type of problem they are facing over the novel coronavirus to look for support measures that match their needs." "The website also has a mental health test function." "Smartphone users found to be stressed out can directly seek advice using the Line free messaging app."

on 26 June, the Nauru Bulletin announced that Japan granted Nauru AU$1.3  million to enable  the procurement of equipment to support the efficient delivery of health and medical services in Nauru. This will assist with preventing the spread of covid-19 in Nauru.

On July 31, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that the Government of Japan "has agreed to receive a supply of 120 million doses of a coronavirus vaccine for 60 million people by the end of June next year from U.S. pharmaceutical giant Pfizer Inc. and its German partner BioNTech SE., if they succeed in developing the vaccine."

On August 16, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "the government is preparing to send hospital and public health nurses to Okinawa Prefecture." "Nurses will be sent from other prefectures as a further spread of infections is expected to strain the island prefecture "s health care system in terms of hospital beds and personnel." On August 16, 2020, Okinawa Governor Denny Tamaki "asked for such assistance at a meeting with state minister of health Gaku Hashimoto. The central government will work with the National Governors " Association so that about 10 hospital nurses will be dispatched within a week. The number will be raised to about 50 eventually. [...] The health ministry will also consider sending to Okinawa medical workers who can handle extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, or ECMO, life support systems and taking COVID-19 patients to hospitals outside the prefecture."

On August 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced "that over 27,000 hospital beds will be secured across the country for treating patients of the novel coronavirus at the peak of infections. [...] The plans seek to balance medical institutions' responses to coronavirus patients with treatments of people with other diseases or injuries by adjusting the number of beds for patients of the virus in line with the state of infections."

On August 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that  "[a]ccording to plans drawn up by the country's 47 prefectures, more than 21,000 rooms will also be secured at accommodation facilities at the peak time for quarantining people with light or no symptoms of the virus, the ministry said. The plans seek to balance medical institutions' responses to coronavirus patients with treatments of people with other diseases or injuries by adjusting the number of beds for patients of the virus in line with the state of infections."

On August 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "adopted on Friday a plan to secure novel coronavirus vaccines for the whole population of the country by the first half of 2021. The plan was included in the government's policy for its future response to the COVID-19 crisis, adopted at a meeting of its task force on measures against the coronavirus. [...] The government will prepare a legal framework ensuring state compensation in case coronavirus vaccines cause side effects."

On August 28, 2020, at the 42nd Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government  "intend[s] to fundamentally enhance the structures, including securing the capacity to conduct an average of 200,000 tests per day at regional medical institutions. "

On August 25, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced that it "will set up a toll-free telephone hotline at 0120-762029 on Sept. 1 to offer consultations to foreigners having trouble making a living due to the pandemic. The service will be available in 14 languages, including Japanese."

On September 25, 2020, at the 43rd Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, it was announced that Japan will  "install antigen quantitative test equipment, expand test booths, and secure test waiting areas in quarantine stations at airports. It is expected to secure inspection capacity of more than 10,000 people by the end of September. "

On September 23, 2020, the Government of Japan announced that it "plans to open a website in October to book polymerase chain reaction tests for novel coronavirus infections before overseas travel. The website, named "TeCOT," will allow those planning international trips to check the necessary conditions for travel, which differ by destination, and reserve PCR tests."

On October 22, 2020, it was announced that a "coronavirus testing center will open next month at Narita airport near Tokyo, enabling departing travelers to obtain a certificate for a negative test result within two hours." From November 2, 2020, "two facilities will be set up [...] at two terminal buildings at the airport mainly for people departing Japan" by the Nippon Medical School Foundation and Narita International Airport Corporation.

On August 7, 2020, the Government of Japan "has reached a basic agreement with AstraZeneca PLC to receive a vaccine against the novel coronavirus from the British drug giant if it is successfully developed." "Under the agreement, Japan will receive 120 million doses of the vaccine starting early next year. Of the total, 30 million doses will be supplied by the end of March. AstraZeneca will produce the vaccine also in Japan, in cooperation with JCR Pharmaceuticals Co." "The company plans to start trials in Japan later this month."

On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe clarified that, concerning the 210 Japanese nationals returned to Japan from Wuhan as of January 30, 2020, the Government "intend[s] to take all possible measures in monitoring their health, while continuing to make sure that all individuals who wish to return to Japan are able to do so [and] conduct thorough health checks regardless of symptoms, including virus screening, and make government facilities such as training centers fully available for accommodation for the duration of that process."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order to  "(2) understan[d] the situation of infection in Japan, " it was agreed to  "A) a) Identify suspected patients based on notification from physicians based on the Infectious Diseases Control Law, and conduct PCR tests when the physician deems necessary [and] identify close contacts of confirmed patients through active epidemiology surveys, in accordance with the Infectious Diseases Control Law."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order for the  "(4) health system to deliver medical care, " it was agreed to  "A) c) Report a suspected case of the novel coronavirus disease found at the outpatient facility for Japanese returnees and potential contacts in accordance with the Infectious Diseases Control Law, and conduct the PCR test. As appropriate, follow hospitalization procedures in accordance with the Infectious Diseases Control Law. "<U+2028>

The Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare announced on March 5, 2020, that "[t]ests for COVID-19 will be covered under Japan's national health insurance system starting" from March 6, 2020. "With the insurance coverage, the government will allow people to undergo testing at hospitals or contracted private testing companies without being referred to by health centers."

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee (2) Surveillance and information gathering, it was agreed to  "[i]dentify suspected disease carrier based on the notification from the doctor, and conduct tests that the doctor considers necessary. "
Starting from 3 April 0:00 JST, PCR tests will be conducted on arrival for those who have visited, within 14 days prior to their entry into Japan, countries and regions subjected to entry bans.

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the  "Government and prefectures [ "] will take the initiative to ensure PCR tests conducted for medical personnel, workers and inpatients. "

On April 17, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe announced that Japan will "expand testing with drive-thru facilities and general practitioners helping to collect samples." During a news conference, Abe declared that "[w]ith help from regional medical associations, we will set up testing centers. If home doctors have decided testing is necessary, test samples are taken at these centers and sent to private inspection firms."

On April 20, 2020, the National Institute of Infectious Diseases of Japan (NIID) "has changed the definition of people who had close contact with patients of the COVID-19 disease, caused by the novel coronavirus. According to the new definition, people who were at a distance of one meter, enough to touch by hand, from an infected person for 15 minutes or more without taking infection prevention measures, such as wearing a face mask, two days before the person started to display symptoms or later are regarded as those with close contact with the patient."

On April 24, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Kato Katsunobu announced that MHLW "has begun checking the performance of several test kits that could be used to see the existence of coronavirus antibodies in blood samples." The Minister stated that "the ministry began the evaluation to pave the way for a quick implementation of antibody testing in Japan."

On April 26, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "has decided to allow dentists to collect samples from people suspected of being infected with coronavirus in an effort to strengthen the country "s ability to conduct polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests for detecting infection." "Dentists who have taken relevant training will be able collect samples from patients at the special outpatient facilities for a certain period."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). To continue "(2) Surveillance and information" gathering efforts, the MHLW will  "identify suspected disease carrier and conduct tests that the doctor considers necessary."
The government will start testing 10,000 people in Tokyo, Osaka and Miyagi prefectures for coronavirus antibodies next month as part of efforts to better understand how it spreads.

On May 24, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "has decided to fully cover the cost of coronavirus PCR tests for near-term pregnant women." "Specifically, the ministry will provide subsidies to local governments subject to some conditions, which include that they decide in advance where to accept pregnant women who test positive."

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). In order to guarantee the (2) Surveillance and Information gathering, it was agreed to  "[i]dentify suspected disease carrier and conduct tests that the doctor considers necessary. "

On May 22, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Kato Katsunobu announced that the Government of Japan"will conduct testing for coronavirus antibodies in Tokyo and two other prefectures, starting early next month for about 10,000 people." "The test will cover Tokyo and Osaka Prefecture, where the number of coronavirus cases per 100,000 people is relatively large, and Miyagi Prefecture, which has fewer cases."

On May 15, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Kato Katsunobu announced that the Ministry "will conduct COVID-19 antibody testing for about 10,000 people as early as next month. The testing will cover several prefectures, including those with many coronavirus cases and those with a few cases. The ministry plans to find out whether people have antibodies against the new coronavirus and the amount of antibodies a person has."

On June 2, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "it has approved the use of saliva samples in polymerase chain reaction tests for the novel coronavirus. Saliva use is available within nine days after people start developing symptoms of COVID-19, the respiratory disease caused by the coronavirus. [...] The new method is less risky as saliva samples are enclosed in special containers by patients themselves," thus reducing the "infection risks to medical workers."

On August 28, 2020, at the 42nd Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government  "will make all possible efforts to secure screening capacity for over 10,000 people at Narita Airport, Haneda Airport and Kansai International Airport by next month, and further advance the preparation of the necessary screening structures at other airports as well. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order for the  "(4) health system to deliver medical care, " it was agreed to  "B) c) Strengthen infection control measures and secure essential goods for controlling the infection in medical institutions. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". As for  "(3) measures to control the infection, " it was agreed to  "A) c) Take general infection prevention measures at public transportation facilities, roadside stations, and other facilities where a large number of people gather. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". As for  "(3) measures to control the infection, " it was agreed to  "A) b) Take general infection prevention measures in facilities such as facilities for the elderly. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order for the  "(4) health system to deliver medical care, " it was agreed to  "B) d) Take general infection control measures thoroughly to prevent the infection from spreading in the facilities for the elderly if there is a suspected case of the novel coronavirus infection, while ensuring the smooth transition to hospitalized medical care for those with the high risk. "

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee (3) Pandemic prevention, it was agreed to  "[e]nsure thorough infection control measures in places including the followings ":  "Medical institutions; Elderly facilities; School; Public transport; Workplace (actively promote tele-work and staggered commuting). "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly,  "[t]ake every possible precaution to prevent workers from being a source of infection by thoroughly avoiding the place where "3Cs" overlap at the same time, by making sure for workers to wear masks, wash and disinfect hands, disinfect regularly shared facilities, maintain a certain distance each other when eating and drinking, keep their daily health tracks and stay home if their physical condition is not perfect. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) will encourage  "thorough measures to prevent infection " in the workplace.

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Government and local governments  "will encourage restaurants to take necessary infection control measures to prevent places where the "3Cs" (closed spaces, crowded places, and close-contact settings) overlap. "

On April 27, 2020, the Ministry of the Environment of Japan (MOEJ) announced that it will "provide subsidies to help restaurants introduce high-performance ventilation systems to reduce the risk of infection with the novel coronavirus." "The subsidies will be paid to cover half to two-thirds of costs to install such advanced ventilation systems, which each costs about 500,000 yen. The ministry expects that the aid will cover a total of some 3,000 ventilation systems at 800 to 1,000 locations across the nation."

In Sendai starting from May 14, 2020 in regards to restaurants: as a measure to prevent new coronavirus infectious diseases, keep in mind the latest information (policy and advice) that is appropriately released from the national and local governments.
Continue business while ensuring that the following basic items are met.
<U+2713> Food safety and hygiene management
<U+2713> Cleaning and disinfection of stores and facilities
<U+2713> Check employee health and thoroughly manage individual health and hygiene
<U+2713> Device for setting and securing social distance

On July 22, 2020, at the 41th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe asked "people to make every effort to avoid the three Cs (closed spaces, crowded places, and close-contact settings), refrain from activities that involve raising their voices, and take full preventive measures such as wearing face masks, hand-washing, sanitization, and ventilation."

Japan's government has asked residents in the seven prefectures affected by the state of emergency declaration (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, Fukuoka) "to refrain from travelling to other prefectures as part of efforts to contain the coronavirus outbreak" on April 7, 2020.

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) will  "ask people to refrain from travel across prefectures. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) will encourage people  "to refrain from visiting eateries with hospitality services in downtown areas, regardless of age, etc. "

The economic and fiscal policy minister Yasutoshi Nishimura, on behalf of Japan's government, urged prefectures covered by the state of emergency declaration (Tokyo, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Osaka, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) "to ensure residents avoid crossing prefectural borders" on April 11, 2020.

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to promote "1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)" it was decided that "ii) All designated prefectures will request citizens to refrain as much as possible from moving to other prefectures for reasons such as non-urgent and unnecessary homecoming visits or trips."

On May 13, 2020, the Government of Japan issued a request to "citizens not to travel between areas where its coronavirus state of emergency is in place and others once the measure is partially lifted." The Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi "made the comments after the association proposed that the government ask citizens not to travel across prefectural borders even after the state of emergency is partially lifted."

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to regulate  "6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures " it was decided that  "i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. One such sustainable measure was given as  "Promote avoiding movements of people between prefectures with relatively higher risk. "

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate  "6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures " it was decided that  "i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully. " Prefectures not subject to emergency measures can  "Promote avoiding movements of people between prefectures with relatively higher risk. Avoid going to places with  "3Cs ". "

Note: The "3Cs" refer to closed spaces with poor ventilation, crowded and close-contact settings.

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). Section 3 addresses "Pandemic Prevention" and in order to promote  "1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later) " it was decided that  "ii) All designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa] will request citizens to refrain as much as possible from moving to other prefectures for reasons such as non-urgent and unnecessary homecoming visits or trips. "

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). In order to work toward (3) Pandemic Prevention, all prefectures will  "request citizens to refrain as much as possible from moving to other prefectures for reasons such as non-urgent and unnecessary homecoming visits or trips. "
On June 19, 2020, the Government of Japan "fully lifted its request for voluntary restrictions on traveling across prefectural borders, issued to stop the spread of the novel coronavirus."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". As for  "(3) measures to control the infection, " it was agreed that, B) a) In communities where the number of patients continues to increase; [to] switch to broader calls for refraining from going out, while reducing the scale of active epidemiology surveys and health observations on close contacts [and to] continue and strengthen the responses to clusters of patients, depending on the situation in the community. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Government and local governments will  "ensure that request for self-restraint in going out to entertainment facilities such as cabarets and nightclubs is widely known, based on the current circumstance where clusters emerge in such place. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka)  "will at first request a self-restraint of going out while indicating the period and area as necessary. Examples of outing that are not covered by such request would include activities necessary for maintaining daily life such as visiting hospitals, purchasing food, medicine and daily necessities, going to work as necessary, exercising outdoors or taking a walk. "

On 2020-04-23, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan's Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled "Regarding Preventing the Spread of the Novel Coronavirus at Shopping Districts and Supermarkets, etc". In this document, residents were urged to avoid going out shopping at times when these locations are likely to be crowded, and to restrict the number of people going out shopping to the minimum.

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to promote "1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)" it was decided that "ii) All designated prefectures will discourage citizens from visiting eateries with hospitality services in downtown areas where clusters have emerged."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to promote "1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)" it was decided that "i) The Prefectures under Specific Cautions, in particular, will request cooperation in refraining from leaving home to "reduce the contact among people by 70% at minimum or 80% ideally."  "(Activities necessary for maintaining daily life and health, such as visiting hospitals, purchasing food, medicine and daily necessities, going to workplaces as necessary, exercising outdoors or taking a walk, are excluded.)"

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). It was stated that  "vi) In-house infections at medical institutions and facilities for the elderly will be thoroughly prevented " by  "Temporarily prohibiting visitors except for emergency cases in order to prevent infection. "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). (Activities necessary for maintaining daily life and health, such as visiting hospitals, purchasing food, medicine and daily necessities, going to workplaces as necessary, exercising outdoors or taking a walk, are excluded.) "

"

Section 3 addresses "Pandemic Prevention" and in order to promote  "1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later) " it was decided that  "The Prefectures under Specific Cautions [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo, and Kanagawa], in particular, will request cooperation in refraining from leaving home to  "reduce the contact among people by 70% at minimum or 80% ideally "  (Activities necessary for maintaining daily life and health, such as visiting hospitals, purchasing food, medicine and daily necessities, going to workplaces as necessary, exercising outdoors or taking a walk, are excluded.)
