On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters" in order to "comprehensively and strongly promote countermeasures by the government."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters" in order to "comprehensively and strongly promote countermeasures by the government."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) set up a call centre for parental support on March 13, 2020, following the announcement of closure of elementary schools. The call centre will inform parents about subsidies and other social welfare measures and assist them through the application.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Government of Japan established on March 26, 2020 "new headquarters on the fight against the new coronavirus, under a special law that was revised recently to boost measures to prevent the spread of the virus. The launch of the new headquarters under the law is one of the procedures needed for allowing the Japanese leader to declare a state of emergency over the coronavirus outbreak. The new body will be headed by the prime minister." "The headquarters will hold its first meeting immediately after Abe's cabinet decides its launch" on the evening of March 26, 2020.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 26, 2020, at the 23rd Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that "each prefectural governor shall immediately set up a prefectural response headquarters."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On May 2, 2020, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) announced that it "plans to set up a mobile team that will help Japanese expatriates return home if an infectious disease breaks out or a terrorist attack occurs overseas." "The ministry will stockpile necessary supplies, including medical goods and protective suits, as well as build a system that will allow the government to swiftly send employees with knowledge of the affected region and fluent in the area's language in the time of an emergency."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "(5) economic and employment measures" it was decided that "By implementing the measures under the "Emergency Economic Measures for Response to COVID-19" (Cabinet decision April 20, 2020), including the supplementary budget for FY2020, nationally and locally, the government will work to prevent the spread of infections while making every effort to quickly end this situation, as well as strive to maintain employment, continue business, and support people's lives."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to implement  "3) Restrictions on using facilities (related to restricted events mentioned earlier, excluding schools and other facilities mentioned later) it was decided that  "ii) In designated prefectures that are not included in the Prefectures under Specific Cautions, decisions will be made based on the local situation from the viewpoint of preventing the spread of infections and maintaining socio-economic activities. "
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). With regards to  "9) Other common issues ", it was decided that  "i) Designated prefectures will take effective emergency measures that consider the characteristics of each area. The measures must be the minimum necessary, and prefectures must carefully explain the details and need for the measures to their residents. "
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On June 8, 2020, the Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) Kajiyama Hiroshi announced that "his ministry will examine whether it outsourced operations to provide cash relief to businesses hit by the coronavirus crisis at appropriate costs. The ministry will take the unusual measure of conducting an interim inspection of the key stimulus step, joined by outside experts." "He also said that the ministry will establish a panel of outside intellectuals to review its project outsourcing system in general."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: New support center opens in Tokyo for foreigners, effective on July 6, 2020
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On August 25, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced that "it will allow foreigners who completed technical training courses to get jobs outside their area of specialization if they are unable to return to their countries due to the coronavirus pandemic. In early September, the agency will start accepting applications for up to one year of employment under the new program, which is intended to rescue former trainees having difficulty finding jobs in Japan at a time when many companies are scaling down their businesses and cutting job openings amid the health crisis. The agency expects applicants to find jobs in agriculture, food and beverage manufacturing and other sectors suffering severe personnel shortages."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Japan is dispatching 3rd aircraft for repatriation of Japanese residents from Hubei Province (China), arriving Jan.31 in Japan.

Japan dispatches 4th aircraft for repatriation of Japanese nationals and their family members from Wuhan area China on Feb.6 (arrival Feb.7).
 "198 passengers aboard today "s chartered flight were Japanese nationals as well as spouses, parents, and children related to Japanese nationals who lived in Hubei Province. " (119 Japanese, 77 Chinese, 2 Taiwanese people)

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In this context, it was agreed to  "f) Prevent problems at airports, ports, medical institutes, etc., by exercising vigilance as necessary. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In this context, it was agreed to  "e) Act with due consideration to the human rights of patients and those involved in the infection control activities. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In this context, it was agreed to  "g) Prevent various crimes that capitalize on chaos while strengthening the enforcement. "

Japan decided that "the immigration counters will be accepting applications to change the status of residence and applications to extend the period of stay from those foreign nationals (excluding foreign nationals with the status of residence of  "Temporary Visitor " and  "Designated Activities (Departure Preparation Period ")) whose expiration date (see note 1) for their period of stay is due in March or April (see note 2) for an extended period of one month from the expiration date of the period of stay of the relevant foreign national."

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). Under  "(6) Other important notes " the document mentioned  "consideration of human rights. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Under  "(6) Other important considerations " the document mentioned  "consideration for human rights including prevention of reputational damage of medical personnel, etc. "

Japan's Immigration Services Agency announced on April 17, 2020, that the "Japanese government will exceptionally allow foreigners employed in the country as technical trainees or specified skilled workers to get jobs outside their area of specialization if they become jobless due to the coronavirus crisis." "Applications for employment under the measure will be accepted from Monday," April 20, 2020. "The measure is also designed to encourage foreign workers to switch to industries facing severe labor shortages."

On April 23, 2020, the chairman of the Japan Business Federation (Keidanren) Hiroaki Nakanishi prompted companies  "to be flexible in their recruitment activities for students graduating in spring next year amid the coronavirus crisis. He called on firms, for example, to allow such students to start working later than usual if the virus pandemic leads to a delay in their graduation and makes it difficult for them to join the companies on scheduled dates. "
Japan is  "dispatching a chartered plane, for repatriating Japanese residents of Hubei Province " (Wuhan, China) on 2020/01/28

Japan government dispatch 2nd aircraft to repatriate Japanese residents from Wuhan (China), further the government "asked that passengers without obvious symptoms agree to be transported by a bus provided by the government for virus tests at the National Center for Global Health and Medicine in Tokyo's Shinjuku Ward"

On May 10, 2020, the Japan Society for Oriental Medicine announced that it "is set to study whether and how ethical herbal medicines and antipyretics given to novel coronavirus patients for symptomatic treatment have led to worsening in their conditions. The organization asked medical institutions in the country to provide data, including details of the drugs prescribed to patients and suspected patients of the COVID-19 disease from the virus to contain their fevers or coughs, developments of their symptoms in the 14 days since the start of treatment and whether their symptoms worsened or not. The group hopes to collect data on about 1,000 cases and analyze the data using a statistical method."

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). With regards to  "9) Other common issues ", it was decided that  "iv) A help desk for business operators will be established, logistics will be secured, and a robust lifeline system will be ensured, etc., in order to support the smooth operation of businesses. "

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). To continue  "(2) Surveillance and information gathering efforts, " the MHLW will  "Build a framework for effective surveillance, such as surveys on antibody prevalence. " The current system will also be improved to  "appropriately grasp excess mortality in flu and pneumonia deaths. "

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). Concerning the  "5) Handling of schools, " it has been decided that  "ii) The Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) will provide guiding principles for nursery schools and after-school children's clubs, etc. on the downsizing of childcare and temporary closure of facilities. "

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate  "6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures " it was decided that  "i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully. " Prefectures not subject to emergency measures [thus excluding Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa and Saitama] can  "Promote measures to reduce contact between people, including teleworking, staggered work hours, and bicycle commuting ".

On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting called for "swift and accurate information to the citizens, and endeavour to ensure safety and security." Moreover, the Ministerial Meeting prompted to "pay sufficient attention when handling personal information of infected persons."

On January 24, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe asked "that the public strictly adhere to prevention measures against the common cold and behave calmly without overly reacting."

On February 17, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "advised people to consult dedicated coronavirus-related offices at public health centers or other relevant facilities if they run a fever of 37.5 degrees Celsius or over for at least four days. Also asked to do so were people feeling lethargic or breathing difficulties severer than such conditions for influenza." In addition, the "ministry advised elderly people, those suffering from chronic diseases such as diabetes, and heart and respiratory problems, people on dialysis, those using immunosuppressive or anticancer drugs, and pregnant women to use the consultation services if their suspected new coronavirus symptoms continue for around two days, because their conditions could rapidly deteriorate if they are infected with the COVID-19 virus."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order to guarantee  "(1) information sharing with individuals, private sectors, and regions, " it was agreed to  "d) Provide appropriate information and support to Japanese who are staying in countries where the infection is spreading. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order to guarantee  "(1) information sharing with individuals, private sectors, and regions, " it was agreed to  "a) Provide accurate and easy-to-understand information and call on the people to encourage calm responses; "  "b) Urge companies to encourage employees and other personnel to take leave if they have fever or other flu-like symptoms, and promote teleworking and staggering commuting hours, in order to reduce the opportunities for contact with patients and infected persons; "  "c) Request, based on the opinions of the experts meeting, communities and companies to re-examine the necessity of hosting public events from the viewpoint of infection control, taking into account the spread of infection, and the conditions of venue, while the nationwide voluntary restraint shall not be requested at this time; "  "d) Provide appropriate information and support to Japanese who are staying in countries where the infection is spreading; "  "e) Provide appropriate and prompt information to the public, foreign governments and foreign tourists, to prevent the spread of infection in Japan, and to prevent rumors. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order to guarantee  "(1) information sharing with individuals, private sectors, and regions, " it was agreed to  "e) Provide appropriate and prompt information to the public, foreign governments and foreign tourists, to prevent the spread of infection in Japan, and to prevent rumors. "

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee the  "(1) Provision and sharing of information, " the following polices will be adopted:
 "a) Provide accurate information and clear message for the public, promote awareness-raising to help change people "s behavior, and encourage calm response.
- Provide accurate and clear information
- Ensure implementation of basic countermeasures against infection
- Ensure that people do not go to workplace, attend school or leave home if they are sick
- Dissemination of guidelines for visits to medical institutions (call for prior telephone consultation)
- Prevent discrimination against infected persons, close contacts and medical personnel. "

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee the (1) Provision and sharing of information, the following polices will be adopted:
 "b) Provide appropriate information to Japanese nationals who live in countries where infection is spreading, and those who have returned to Japan, as well as to foreign nationals living or staying in Japan. "

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee the (1) Provision and sharing of information, the following polices will be adopted:
 "b) Provide appropriate information to Japanese nationals who live in countries where infection is spreading, and those who have returned to Japan, as well as to foreign nationals living or staying in Japan. "
On March 31, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) released "a video featuring popular fashion models" "to raise awareness of COVID-19 prevention among young people."

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka)  "will take effective emergency measures taking into account the characteristics of each area and provide careful explanation to the residents. "

From April 13, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "has started using an illustration of "amabie," a kind of yokai, or ghost, which is believed to have the power to ward off pestilence, to call on young people for cooperation in the fight against the novel coronavirus. An awareness flyer with the illustration of amabie urging people to "stop the spread of the virus" has been posted on the ministry's website."

The Ministry of Defense of Japan (MOD) "has released an educational manual on the new coronavirus on its Joint Staff website" on April 14, 2020. "The manual, titled "To protect the safety of the people from the new coronavirus" [...] contains 39 pages of information on COVID-19. It was compiled under the supervision of the Ground Staff Office. The information is based on the knowhow of Japan's Self-Defense Forces (SDF) against infectious diseases."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to guarantee the (1) Provision and sharing of information, it was agreed to "provide appropriately and expeditiously related information for Japanese national as well as foreign nationals living or staying in Japan and foreign governments."

Prefectures not subject to emergency measures can  "Spread awareness among residents about establishing the "new lifestyle" for preventing the spread of infections, including continuing the basic infection prevention measures. "

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). To guarantee the  "(1) Provision and sharing of information, " the public will be provided with  "accurate information and a clear message, " in a  "timely manner " and  "promote awareness raising to help change people "s behaviour and call for a calm response ".

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). The list of  "9) Other common issues, " outlines that  "iii) Prefectures will inform their residents that the emergency measures are different from the "lockdowns" (city blockades) that are being implemented in other countries, and they shall call for a calm response through asking people not to panic-buy food, medicines and daily necessities. "

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate  "6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures " it is necessary to  "ii) Monitor the infection situation and provide residents with information properly. "

Prefectures not subject to emergency measures are Aomori, Iwate, Miyagi, Akita, Yamagata, Fukushima, Ibaraki, Tochigi, Gunma, Niigata, Toyama, Ishikawa, Fukui, Yamanashi, Nagano, Gifu, Shizuoka, Aichi, Mie, Shiga, Kyoto, Osaka, Hyogo, Wakayama, Nara, Tottori, Shimane, Okayama, Hiroshima, Yamaguchi, Tokushima, Kagawa, Ehime, Kochi, Fukuoka, Saga, Nagasaki, Kumamoto, Oita, Miyazaki, Kagoshima and Okinawa.

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). The list of  "9) Other common issues, " outlines that  "i) Designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Saitama, Kanagawa] will take effective emergency measures that consider the characteristics of each area. The measures must be the minimum necessary, and prefectures must carefully explain the details and need for the measures to their residents. "

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). In order to guarantee the (1) Provision and sharing of information, it was agreed to  "[p]rovide the public with accurate information and clear message on the following points in a timely manner, promote awareness-raising to help change people "s behavior and call for calm response. "

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). In order to work toward (3) Pandemic Prevention, all prefectures will  "inform residents using the "Ten tips" "New lifestyle practices (examples)," etc. presented by the Expert Meeting. "

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). In order to guarantee the (1) Provision and sharing of information, it was agreed to  "[p]rovide appropriately and expeditiously related information for Japanese national as well as foreign nationals living or staying in Japan and foreign governments. "

On July 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on the public not to panic after a record 224 new coronavirus cases were reported in Tokyo," declaring that the "current situation is not as tense as it was in April, when the government declared a state of emergency over the pandemic." Prime Minister Abe Shinzo "called on the public, especially young people, to take steps to avoid infection."

On July 22, 2020, the Government of Japan kicked off the "Go To Travel campaign", a discount travel campaign. The campaign will be financed with  "1.35 trillion yen "to promote domestic travel by anyone to any destination [within Japan] they wished with an up to a 50 percent discount via deals and vouchers. [...] But after a spike in coronavirus cases in Tokyo, the government announced a sudden decision to exclude travel to and from the capital." "The government hopes to support the tourism industry, hurt by the coronavirus pandemic, while taking care not to spread the virus further. Travel and accommodation businesses are required to take full precautions."

On October 23, 2020, the Government of Japan "decided to request major business organizations to show flexibility and extend the holiday period to allow employees to take breaks until Coming-of-Age Day" on January 11, 2020. "Yasutoshi Nishimura, the economic revitalization minister who is also in charge of the government "s handling of the pandemic, told reporters after the meeting that public employees as well as members of Keidanren (Japan Federation of Economic Organizations), the nation's largest business group, and other leading business groups will be asked to cooperate."

On February 1, 2020, at the Fourth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that from February 1, 2020, "it has become possible to implement measures as a Designated Infectious Disease, including hospitalization for the patients infected by the novel coronavirus."

On February 12, 2020, during the Seventh Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, the Government of Japan "has made a "high-level" political decision to flexibly interpret existing legislation", "open[ing] the way to forcibly quarantining those suspected of having the virus by broadly interpreting relevant legislation."

On February 13, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "Japan will revise an ordinance to enable the isolation of those infected or suspected of being infected with the new coronavirus during quarantine". From February 14, 2020, authorities will be allowed "to conduct compulsory hospitalization of infected people with no symptoms. [...] Under the revised ordinance, authorities will be able to isolate infected people through hospitalization and make people suspected of being infected stay at designated facilities, during the quarantine procedures before they enter the country. As people with no symptoms will be subject to the compulsory hospitalization measure, the government will cover their medical costs."

On February 13, 2020, at the Eight Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that the Government will designate, from February 14, 2020, "the novel coronavirus as an infection subject to quarantine or detention in accordance with the Quarantine Act with a government ordinance to ensure the thorough prevention of infections."

On February 13, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that, from February 14, 2020 onwards, "the isolation of those infected or suspected of being infected with the new coronavirus during quarantine" will be allowed. Authorities will also be allowed "to conduct compulsory hospitalization of infected people with no symptoms." "Under the revised ordinance, authorities will be able to isolate infected people through hospitalization and make people suspected of being infected stay at designated facilities, during the quarantine procedures before they enter the country. As people with no symptoms will be subject to the compulsory hospitalization measure, the government will cover their medical costs."

On February 18, 2020, at the Eleventh Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe invited "the public [...] to refrain from going outside, taking leave from school or work, when experiencing symptoms of a cold, such as a fever. [...] Creating an environment that makes it easy for students and employees to take days off is crucial and I would like to ask cooperation in this regard. Making use of means like tele-working is another effective approach."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". As for  "(5) border control measures, " it was agreed that,  "from the viewpoint of securing medical resources in Japan, quarantine operations will be shifted, according to measures to prevent the spread of infection in Japan and systems for providing medical care. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order for the  "(4) health system to deliver medical care, " it was agreed that  "B) a) patients with mild flu-like symptoms should stay at home unless otherwise specified, and seek medical care after consulting the call center or a family doctor, if their conditions change. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". As for  "(3) measures to control the infection, " it was agreed to  "A) a) Take the following measures in accordance with the Infectious Diseases Control Law if a patient is identified by notification of a physician or other means: the active epidemiology survey to be conducted by the public health center; and close contacts to be monitored for their health conditions and requested to refrain from going out. The local government shall use active epidemiology surveys to identify a cluster based on individual patient outbreaks in cooperation with the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare and experts, and request the necessary measures including closure of the related facilities and voluntary restraint of events if there is a possibility that such a cluster exists. "

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). As for (4) Medicare, it was agreed to  "[e]stablish a system for those with mild symptoms to be cared at home, in areas where there is a risk that an increase in patients of the Coronavirus may interfere with the provision of hospitalized medical care for other severely ill patients. "

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). As for (4) Medicare, it was agreed to  "[p]erform tests at the discretion of the doctor and, if a patient is found, provide recommendations and necessary measures for admission to hospitals to provide appropriate medical care. "

From April 2, 2020, the Ministry of Defense of Japan (MOD) "has started introducing a rotating work-shift system to ensure that its operations can continue without disruptions in the event someone within its structure becomes infected with the coronavirus." "The notification points out that anyone who had close contact with those infected will be asked to self-quarantine at their home."

On April 6, 2020, at the 26th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government of Japan  "will ask patients with mild symptoms to in principle stay at home and, if there is a risk of the transmission to the patients " family members, we will secure facilities for them to stay. To that end, we will hire hotels in the private sector. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly,  "[i]solate a suspected case immediately and implement infection countermeasures under the guidance of public health centers, in case of suspecting a new case of COVID-19 infection from hospitalized patients or users. "

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). It was stated that "vi) In-house infections at medical institutions and facilities for the elderly will be thoroughly prevented" by "Isolating suspected patients/users immediately and implementing counter-infection measures under the guidance of public health centers."

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). It was stated that  "vi) In-house infections at medical institutions and facilities for the elderly will be thoroughly prevented " by  "Isolating suspected patients/users immediately and implementing counter-infection measures under the guidance of public health centers. "

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order to guarantee  "(1) information sharing with individuals, private sectors, and regions ", it was agreed to  "b) Urge companies to encourage employees and other personnel to take leave if they have fever or other flu-like symptoms, and promote teleworking and staggering commuting hours, in order to reduce the opportunities for contact with patients and infected persons. "

Japan's Japan Sports Agency and Agency for Cultural Affairs, part of the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT) "asked some large sports and cultural events to be cancelled or postponed voluntarily by their organizers".
Japan Post stops "accepting all types of international mail to Mongolia until the flights are resumed" from March 3, 2020 onward.

Japan Post decided that "acceptance of mail items destined to China will be temporarily suspended from March 13, except for some letter-post items such as letters, postcards and mail for the blind by air."

The Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI), "with the cooperation of internet auction platform operators, requests that masks and antiseptics not be put up for auction for an unspecified period" from March 14, 2020. Accordingly, "Yahoo! Japan annouced on March 4 that it will cease to display masks on its auction platform for an unspecified time from Saturday, March 14" and "Mobaoku announced on March 5 that it will cease to display masks and antiseptics on its auction platform for an unspecified time from Saturday, March 14."

From April 2, 2020, Japan Post "has announced that it will temporarily stop accepting international mail destined for 153 countries. For 126 of those countries, the suspension is limited to EMS and air mail", whereas any type of delivery is suspended for the remaining 27. Moreover, "[i]tems which have already been accepted and cannot be dispatched to their destinations will be returned from the delivery offices to the senders in order."

On April 1, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzo invited airlines to "reduce the number of arriving air flight passengers from overseas" during the 25th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, by "[r]equesting airlines concerned to curb the number of arrival passengers to Japan by such measures as reducing the number of passenger arrival flights in order to ensure the appropriate implementation of quarantine measures." The measures should be implemented by April 3, 2020 0:00 JST "until the end of April, for the time being."

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly,  "[t]emporarily cease reception of visits except for emergency in order to prevent infection from visiting persons. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly,  "[c]onsider measures such as suspending or restricting temporary use of facilities such as day-care, limiting outings and overnight stays of inpatients and users, in areas where infection is prevalent. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka)  "should strongly promote teleworking. Even in case of going to work, efforts to reduce contact with people, such as staggered work hours and bicycle commuting will be promoted even more strongly than ever."

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, businesses  "that perform operations essential for ensuring the stability of people's lives and the national economy (exemplified in the attachment), are required to continue their operation, depending on the characteristics of the business, while fully taking measures to prevent the spread of infection. "

On April 23, 2020, the Government of Japan "notified the country's 47 prefectures of guidelines on procedures for publishing the names of business operators that defy requests for suspending operations amid the novel coronavirus pandemic."

On 2020-04-23, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan's Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled "Regarding Preventing the Spread of Novel Coronavirus in Shopping Districts and Supermarkets, etc". In this document it was stated that prefectures where it is judged that people are gathering in large numbers in supermarkets, these prefectures would call on the relevant businesses to take the following policies:
* Implement socially-distanced queuing when entering the business and paying
* Disinfection/sterilization of shared spaces, thorough implementtation of hand sanitiser when entering and leaving
* Ensure space when talking, erect partitions when facing each other
* When the business becomes crowded, appropriately implement entry restrictions and one-way guidance in the establishment.

On April 23, 2020, the Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy
of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi, in charge for Economic Revitalization, "issued guidelines on what kind of steps governors can take to get business owners that continue to ignore government requests to suspend their operations." "The guidelines say governors are authorized to issue stronger "requests" or "instructions" to those who refuse to comply with initial requests without legitimate reasons.
The names and addresses of the businesses given such stronger warnings will be disclosed online or by other means."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to implement "3) Restrictions on using facilities (related to restricted events mentioned earlier, excluding schools and other facilities mentioned later) it was decided that "iii) Business operators and related organizations will take voluntary measures to prevent  infection that take into account both sustainable actions for the future and recommendations from the Expert Meeting."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to regulate "4) Going to workplaces" it was noted that, "ii) Based on the expectation that all designated prefectures will need sustainable measures in future, Measures to reduce contact with people, including teleworking, working in rotations, staggered work hours, and bicycle commuting, will continue."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to implement "3) Restrictions on using facilities (related to restricted events mentioned earlier, excluding schools and other facilities mentioned later) it was decided that "i) Prefectures under Specific Cautions will issue requests to follow restrictions on the use of facilities that may cause infections to spread. If such requests are not met and no justifiable reason is given, prefectures will issue further requests and instructions based on the Act, and they shall publicize the fact. Additionally, considering the impact of the extended measures on society, the economy, and the lives and health of the citizens, the Governors of each prefecture may make appropriate decisions on opening facilities such as museums, art galleries, libraries and outdoor parks."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to regulate "4) Going to workplaces" it was decided that "i) Particularly in Prefectures under Specific Cautions, working in rotations at workplaces that require employees to come to work and teleworking will be strongly encouraged to reduce contact, including aiming for a "70 percent reduction in employees coming to work."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). On May 7, 2020, the Government of Japan called "on companies in Tokyo and 12 prefectures that are on a special coronavirus alert to reduce by at least 70 percent the number of their employees traveling to work."

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to promote  "1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later) " it was decided that  "ii) All designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Hokkaido, Ibaraki, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Ishikawa, Gifu, Aichi, Kyoto, Hyogo, Fukuoka) will discourage citizens from visiting eateries with hospitality services in downtown areas where clusters have emerged. "

On May 14, 2020, the Japan Business Federation (Keidanren, <U+7D4C><U+56E3><U+9023>) released guidelines "for protecting workers from COVID-19 are expected to be referred to when companies resume business activities while taking precautionary measures, following the government's lifting of the coronavirus state of emergency for most of the country's 47 prefectures. The guidelines are intended for long-term use at least until treatment for the disease is established and a vaccine is developed." Moreover, it "called on member companies to introduce a four-day workweek system to reduce coronavirus infection risks" and suggested "further promotion of remote working, staggered commuting and social-distancing measures in workplaces." Keidanren asked companies to "take measures, keeping in mind that steps taken at workplaces will lead to the prevention of a further spread of the virus across the entire society."

Japan "s Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI), "launches free remote health consultation service to address COVID-19 related concerns" in order "for people to avoid visiting medical institutions only based on their concerns over the novel coronavirus disease without first appropriately consulting with experts and unnecessarily visiting any environments where people are more likely to be infected by the disease".
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 13, 2020, the Imperial Household Agency (Japan) announced that "[d]ue to the current situation, we regret to announce that new applications for prior registration and walk-in applications for The Imperial Palace Guided Tours will not be accepted until further notice."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 27, 2020, the Imperial Household Agency (Japan) announced that "[a]s a measure against the further spreading of corona virus, the East Gardens of the Imperial Palace will temporarily be closed until further notice."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: "Japan's National Tax Agency has decided [on April 3, 2020] to have some 1,100 new employees receive a training program at their homes, switching from the original plan to conduct it at a facility in Saitama Prefecture, due to a flood of complaints from local residents amid the outbreak of the novel coronavirus."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) closed the application desk of the Certification section of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Tokyo headquarters) from April 6, 2020. Only phone and e-mail inquiries and the application and reception of authenticated certificates by post remain possible.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) has closed the application desk of Certification section of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Tokyo headquarters) from April 6, 2020. Phone and e-mail inquiries, as well as the application and reception of authenticated certificates by post, remain possible.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Since the declaration of state of emergency on April 7, 2020, the offices of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) have decreased "the number of people who commute to work by utilizing teleworking" and implemented "measures for double shifts in various divisions". Large-scale trainings for new personnel and large meetings are being avoided. Within its diplomatic missions abroad, MOFA has been promoting infection control measures "such as hand-washing and cough etiquette, utilizing teleworking and staggered work hours, and preventing suspension of functions by dividing personnel into teams and coming to work". In addition, "various business trips and the like have of course been reduced to the absolute minimum amount necessary", and officials "either work at home or commute to work" according to a "split-team structure". Over-the-counter services have been affected by "shortened counter hours", the introduction of "appointment systems", and extensions to "document processing times".
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka)  "should strongly promote teleworking. Even in case of going to work, efforts to reduce contact with people, such as staggered work hours and bicycle commuting will be promoted even more strongly than ever. "
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) has closed the application desk of Certification section of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Osaka Liaison Office) from April 9, 2020. Phone and e-mail inquiries, as well as the application and reception of authenticated certificates by post, remain possible.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On April 7 and April 9, 2020, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued declarations concerning  "MOFA "s structure and efforts in the case of the declaration of a state of emergency, " which was realised on  Planned and adopted measures include  "teleworking ",  "the introduction of a split-team structure " where  "personnel [is divided] into two teams that either work at home or commute to work, including for diplomatic missions, " and decrease of  "the total number of hours spent working in person at MOFA. " Moreover,  "diplomatic missions have been taking infection control measures in the same way as MOFA including thoroughly promoting practices such as handwashing and cough etiquette, utilizing teleworking and staggered work hours, and preventing suspension of functions by dividing personnel into teams and coming to work. Also, various business trips and the like have of course been reduced to the absolute minimum amount necessary. "
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: "Senior Japanese ruling party and opposition officials agreed [on April 13, 2020] to cut the daily number of meetings of committees of the Diet, the country's parliament, and that of participating lawmakers in order to reduce the risk of infection with the novel coronavirus", in line with the goal of "reducing human-to-human contact in the country by 80%".
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description:
On May 1, 2020, the Cabinet of the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe 
"held its first meeting using a videoconferencing system." "Abe and Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga took part in the meeting from the same room at the prime minister's office, while other ministers called in from their respective ministry or agency offices."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to implement  "3) Restrictions on using facilities (related to restricted events mentioned earlier, excluding schools and other facilities mentioned later) it was decided that  "i) Prefectures under Specific Cautions (Tokyo, Osaka, Hokkaido, Ibaraki, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Ishikawa, Gifu, Aichi, Kyoto, Hyogo, Fukuoka) will issue requests to follow restrictions on the use of facilities that may cause infections to spread. If such requests are not met and no justifiable reason is given, prefectures will issue further requests and instructions based on the Act, and they shall publicize the fact. Additionally, considering the impact of the extended measures on society, the economy, and the lives and health of the citizens, the Governors of each prefecture may make appropriate decisions on opening facilities such as museums, art galleries, libraries and outdoor parks. "
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020).  "3) Restrictions on using facilities (related to restricted events mentioned earlier, excluding schools and other facilities mentioned later) " requires  "i) Prefectures under Specific Cautions [Tokyo, Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, and Kanagawa] will issue requests to follow restrictions on the use of facilities that may cause infections to spread. If such requests are not met and no justifiable reason is given, prefectures will issue further requests and instructions based on the Act, and they shall publicize the fact. Additionally, considering the impact of the extended measures on society, the economy, and the lives and health of the citizens, the Governors of each prefecture may make appropriate decisions on opening facilities such as museums, art galleries, libraries and outdoor parks. "
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On February 17, 2020, the Imperial Household Agency announced the cancellation of the "public birthday event for Emperor Naruhito at the Imperial Palace", which was originally scheduled for February 23, 2020. "Emperor Naruhito and Empress Masako were originally scheduled to greet the public three times on Sunday morning [(February 23, 2020)] from a balcony in the palace's Chowa-Den wing, together with Crown Prince Fumihito and his wife Crown Princess Kiko and their daughters Princess Mako and Princess Kako."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control ". In order to guarantee  "(1) information sharing with individuals, private sectors, and regions, " it was agreed to  "c) Request, based on the opinions of the experts meeting, communities and companies to re-examine the necessity of hosting public events from the viewpoint of infection control, taking into account the spread of infection, and the conditions of venue, while the nationwide voluntary restraint shall not be requested at this time. "

On February 27, 2020, at the 15th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe called for implementation of measures to prevent infections and limited number of participants at school entrance examinations or graduation ceremonies.

On February 17, 2020, Tokyo Marathon organisers announced that the "Tokyo Marathon 2020 will be held only for the marathon elites and the wheelchair elites." The event "was expected to have 38,000 people taking part" and was scheduled for March 1, 2020.

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee (3) Pandemic prevention, it was agreed to  "[r]equest that necessary measures [to] be taken, such as closing off facilities and refraining from holding events, if there is a possibility that a cluster may be occurring. "

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka)  "will make request to restrict the holding of events that may lead to the spread of infection. When a request is not met with no justifiable reason, instructions will be issued and these requests and instructions will be made public. "

"Japan's Imperial Household Agency said [on April 13, 2020] that it has decided to cancel this year's Imperial spring garden party, scheduled for May 27, because of the spread of the novel coronavirus. The event was due to be hosted by Emperor Naruhito and Empress Masako. The agency holds a garden party hosted by the country's Emperor and Empress in spring and autumn every year, at the Akasaka Imperial estate in the Motoakasaka district in Tokyo's Minato Ward, with some 2,000 guests."

On April 26, 2020, the All Japan High School Athletic Federation "decided to cancel this year's Interscholastic Athletic Meet," (otherwise known as Inter-High School Sports Festival) scheduled to be held from August 10, 2020 to August 24, 2020 "in venues in 21 prefectures." "This year's high school meet for 30 sports was expected to bring together 30,000 people."

On May 1, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced its "plan to utilize provisional release actively for foreigners detained in custody facilities before deportation due to illegal stays and other reasons." "The agency decided to utilize provisional release actively for detainees with no infection symptoms, except for those who have committed serious crimes, as custody facilities often have enclosed and congested environments involving close contact, with high infection risks. In addition, the guidelines include isolating new detainees for around two weeks and limiting visits to detainees to consular officers and lawyers."

On May 4, 2020, the Japan Sumo Association "has canceled the summer grand tournament in Tokyo due to the coronavirus pandemic." "The tournament was set to open on May 24 at the Ryogoku Kokugikan arena in the Japanese capital after a two-week postponement from its initial schedule due to the pandemic."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to implement "2) Restrictions on holding events" it was decided that "All designated prefectures will make requests not to hold events where clusters could emerge or have gatherings under 3Cs circumstances, especially in cases of nation-wide or large events and gatherings."

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to regulate  "6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures " it was decided that  "i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. One such sustainable measure was given as  "Have organizers of nationwide, large-scale events (larger than a certain scale) demonstrate caution by cancelling or postponing them. "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to implement  "2) Restrictions on holding events " it was decided that  "All designated prefectures will make requests not to hold events where clusters could emerge or have gatherings under 3Cs circumstances, especially in cases of nation-wide or large events and gatherings. "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to regulate  "6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures " it was decided that  "i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. One such sustainable measure was given as  "Avoid going to places with "3Cs." "

On May 20, 2020, "the Japan High School Baseball Federation and The Asahi Shimbun, a sponsor of the tournament, decided on the cancellation" of the summer National High School Baseball Championship, which was scheduled to start on August 10, 2020, "because of the novel coronavirus pandemic. At the same time, the prefectural tournaments to determine the 49 competing teams in the summer championship were also scrapped."

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). The MHLW implements  "2) Restrictions on holding events " and states that  "All designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa] will make requests not to hold events where clusters could emerge or have gatherings under 3Cs circumstances, especially in cases of nation-wide or large events and gatherings. "

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate  "6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures " it was decided that  "i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully. " Prefectures not subject to emergency measures [thus excluding Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa and Saitama] can  "Have organizers of nationwide, large-scale events (larger than a certain scale) demonstrate caution by cancelling or postponing them. "

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). Section 3 addresses "Pandemic Prevention" and in order to promote  "1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later) " it was decided that  "ii) All designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa] will discourage citizens from visiting eateries with hospitality services in downtown areas where clusters have emerged. "

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). In order to work toward (3) Pandemic Prevention, all prefectures will  "discourage citizens from visiting eateries with hospitality services in downtown areas where clusters have emerged. "

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). As for  "[r]estrictions on holding events, " all prefectures  "will make requests not to hold events where clusters could emerge or have gatherings under  "3Cs " circumstances, especially in cases of nation-wide or large events and gatherings. "

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). In order to work toward (3) Pandemic Prevention, all prefectures will  "avoid the "3Cs" while also taking basic measures to prevent infection. "

On June 5, 2020, it was announced that the 2020's edition of the "Fuji Rock Festival", scheduled to be held in Niigata Prefecture (Japan) from August 21 until August 23, 2020 will be postponed to August 2021.

On August 4, 2020, the Imperial Household Agency (Japan) announced that the "imperial garden party planned for the fall has been canceled to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus amid growing concern over a resurgence of infections." "Around 2,000 guests usually attend the parties at the Akasaka Imperial Gardens in Tokyo, where the emperor and empress greet and converse with those who have made notable constructions to the worlds of culture, sports and science."

On August 6, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe "urged citizens [...] to take thorough measures to prevent new coronavirus infection during the "Bon" holiday period in mid-August." Abe asked ""people to make sure to take basic infection prevention measures when visiting parents' homes" during the Bon period." "Regarding trips to hometowns, Abe also called on people to refrain from events at high risks of infection, such as dining in a large group, and take extra care to protect elderly people from the virus."

On February 14, 2020, at the Ninth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe asked "the elderly or those with underlying diseases to pay attention to prevention, including by avoiding visiting sites where a lot of people may gather."

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee (3) Pandemic prevention, it was agreed to  "[p]resent appropriate measures to prevent clusters and reduce contacts, based on the local situations " and to  "[c]all for cooperation in self-restraint in avoiding gatherings in closed spaces, crowded places, or close-contact settings. Pay particular attention to metropolitan areas. "

From April 2, 2020, the Ministry of Defense of Japan (MOD) "has started introducing a rotating work-shift system to ensure that its operations can continue without disruptions in the event someone within its structure becomes infected with the coronavirus." "The notification instructs all departments [...] to divide their staff members into several teams. The teams will be put to work in different times of the day or told to work at home every other day."

Japan "adopted a policy of having asymptomatic or mildly ill patients of the COVID-19 coronavirus disease stay at home, in hotels or certain other places, in areas where infections are rapidly spreading."

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly,  "[t]ake every possible precaution to prevent workers from being a source of infection by thoroughly avoiding the place where "3Cs" overlap at the same time, by making sure for workers to wear masks, wash and disinfect hands, disinfect regularly shared facilities, maintain a certain distance each other when eating and drinking, keep their daily health tracks and stay home if their physical condition is not perfect. "

From April 7, 2020, the government of Japan has asked the seven prefectures placed under a state of emergency (Tokyo, Chiba, Saitama, Kanagawa, Hyogo, Osaka, and Fukuoka) "to reduce the amount of physical contact among people by 80%". Prime Minister Abe has encouraged the population to "make efforts and reduce opportunities for person-to-person contact by a minimum of 70 percent, or ideally 80 percent" during the press conference regarding the Declaration of a State of Emergency on April 7, 2020.

Starting from April 17, 2020, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) stated: "Starting from today, we will livestream this press conference on the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official Twitter account. In addition to livestreaming on MOFA "s Japanese language account, we will also livestream the press conference with simultaneous interpretation on our English account. We will also be livestreaming my regular press conference in English too."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to regulate "4) Going to workplaces" it was noted that, "ii) Based on the expectation that all designated prefectures will need sustainable measures in future, Workplaces will be encouraged to put thorough measures in place to prevent infections and avoid the 3Cs."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to promote "1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)" it was decided that "ii) All designated prefectures will carefully avoid the "3Cs" while also taking basic measures to prevent infection, such as handwashing and maintaining social distancing between people."

On May 7, 2020, the Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi, in charge for Economic Revitalization, "asked prefectures on the special alert to continue to keep measures in place. The government is to analyze in detail the effects of calls by central and local governments to refrain from nonessential outings and hometown visits during the spring break."

On May 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on residents of 13 prefectures where special alert for the novel coronavirus is requested to continue efforts to reduce interpersonal contact by 80 pct. The government is concerned about the possibility of citizens in the 13 prefectures - Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa, Saitama, Osaka, Hyogo, Fukuoka, Hokkaido, Ibaraki, Ishikawa, Gifu, Aichi and Kyoto - relaxing their social distancing efforts."

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). With regards to  "9) Other common issues ", it was decided that  "v) Thorough measures to prevent infection will be taken in public transportation and other facilities where many people gather. "

On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). It was stated that  "vi) In-house infections at medical institutions and facilities for the elderly will be thoroughly prevented " by  "Thoroughly avoiding the 3Cs, wearing masks, and disinfecting to prevent workers from becoming sources of infection. "

On May 16, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on people to stay alert against the new coronavirus." The Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi stated that "carelessness can lead to a new wave of the outbreak, urging people not to relax efforts to contain the virus," calling on "residents of the 39 prefectures to continue containment efforts while resuming economic activities gradually. For residents of the eight prefectures where the state of emergency is still in place, Nishimura underlined the need for continued efforts to reduce contact by 80 pct."

On May 17, 2020, the Government of Japan "called for continued voluntary restrictions by residents of the eight prefectures where its coronavirus state of emergency remains in effect" (Hokkaido, Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Kyoto and Hyogo). "Economic and fiscal policy minister Yasutoshi Nishimura called for these residents' continued cooperation to ensure that the state of emergency is lifted within this month. "A second wave of infections could come. People should continue voluntary restrictions without becoming relaxed about them," Nishimura said."

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the  "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control " (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). The list of  "9) Other common issues, " outlines that  "v) Thorough measures to prevent infection will be taken in public transportation and other facilities where many people gather. "

From June 1, 2020, Japan's carrier All Nippon Airways "will make it mandatory for passengers to wear a mask aboard planes and at the airport." "[E]veryone will be required to wear a mask at all times on planes and at the airport, including at security checkpoints and boarding gates. The airline says it may deny boarding to people not wearing a mask or showing symptoms of illness, including fever. Exceptions will be made for small children and certain particular cases."

On July 22, 2020, at the 41th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe asked "people to make every effort to avoid the three Cs (closed spaces, crowded places, and close-contact settings), refrain from activities that involve raising their voices, and take full preventive measures such as wearing face masks, hand-washing, sanitization, and ventilation."

On August 6, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe "urged citizens [...] to take thorough measures to prevent new coronavirus infection during the "Bon" holiday period in mid-August." Abe asked ""people to make sure to take basic infection prevention measures when visiting parents' homes" during the Bon period [...] such measures as avoiding the three Cs of closed, crowded and close contact settings and not speaking loudly."
Latvia closes schools, kindergartens, universities and suspends all kinds of educational activities from March 13 on, online teaching planned

As of March 16, the government of Latvia announced that preschools and childcare facilities will only be available for children whose parents may prove that the child and family have not been abroad and have not been in contact with Covid-19 patients or their contacts during the last 14 days. Parents must also state in this certificate that it is not possible to provide childcare in any other way.
Latvia limits time for culture, entertainment, outdoor sports and other recreational activities from 8:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.
Latvia declares  state of emergency due to COVID-19 from March 14 until April 14 with possibility to be prolonged
On 26 May, the Prime Minister announced that Latvia is planning to end the country's corona-related state of emergency by June 9.
As announced on 4 June the state of emergency in Latvia will end on 9 June
Avoid travel to China's Hubei province, says Latvian Foreign Ministry on Jan 31

Latvia will stop nearly all foreigners entering the country from March 17 2020 on. All international travel, by air, railway, sea and road, will be cancelled. Latvians and foreigners with residency rights in Latvia will be able to enter the country, and tourists will be able to leave after the deadline.
The Latvian airline airBaltic suspended all flights from 17 March including those from Tallinn Airport.

From July 16, the government of Latvia will not accept applications for the long term category D visa for residents of countries with a total of 14 days of 16 or more new Covid-19 infections per 100,000 inhabitants.

On September 11, the government of Latvia restricted travelers from Estonia. The government will require travelers coming from Estonia to self-quarantine for two weeks, granting an exception to truck drivers, diplomats and others who need to cross the border for work to skip the self-quarantine with proof of employment.

On February 25, the Ministry of Health of Latvia announced persons returning from China, South Korea, Iran, Lombardy and Veneto in Italy who exhibit symptoms such as cough, fever, sore throat or difficulty breathing should call 113 to report their symptoms.

Latvia government stated on 29th March: For the purposes of conducting an epidemiological investigation and verifying the veracity of information on movement provided by a person and upon the request of the Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, the State Police will have the right to request information from electronic communications operators on specific persons who may have a status of the infected person or contact person.

From July 16, the government of Latvia announced all passengers of international transport will have to submit a completed questionnaire to the carrier before entering Latvia, indicating the countries visited during the last 14 days, contact information and chosen address where the two-week self-isolation period is planned. Information on passengers who have been in Covid-19-affected countries will be passed on to the National Police for self-isolation control and the Center for Disease Prevention and Control to identify possible contact persons promptly if necessary.

During Latvia's state of emergency (14 March-14 April), non-essential hospital services like in-patient surgical operations, paid visits to specialists, use of a podologist, and consultation of a physician in the Rare Diseases Room are restricted.
On March 19, Latvia relieves alcohol used for the production of disinfectants from excise tax (part of an comprehensive law on support measures for Covid-19-related damages and threats
Latvia made prioritization of medical item supply for national purposes

On April 23, the government of Latvia approved the use of accelerated Covid-19 testing processes. These tests are approved to be used in cases such as a patient in need of emergency surgery is admitted to hospital or in certain circumstances such as a heart attack or stroke.
On April 30, the Ministry of Education and Science of Latvia allocated half a million euro to Covid-19 epidemiological research.
On 30 April 2020, the government of Latvia approved the allocation of funding in the amount of five million euros for the state research program Covid-19 disease control and mitigation in Latvia.
On July 14, the government of Latvia decided to allocate 3.2 million euros to the health sector to cover the expenses of medical institutions for the diagnosis and treatment of Covid-19.

On August 11, the government of Latvia and the Latvia Ministry of Health allocated  "5 millions to the health sector to cover reimbursement of patient co-payments, to provide drug supplies to medical institutions and for the organization and performance of laboratory tests (test kits, testing sites, PPE for staff).

On April 14, the Ministry of Health of Latvia allowed employers of retail to test his or her employees with symptoms on COVID-19, if they wish to do so. In this case, a designated representative of the industry must contact the emergency medical service to schedule a test.
From June 10 to June 30 everyone in Latvia has the opportunity to take a state-paid Covid-19 test, even if there are no symptoms, according to Latvia's Ministry of Health.

As of July 28, the Ministry of Health of Latvia require guest workers from countries with high COVID-19 risk to be tested for the infection before starting work, specifically five to seven days after arrival in Latvia. Until a negative result comes back, the person must comply with self-isolation.

Latvian Finance Minister Janis Reirs " initiated a work group for support of entrepreneurship and the employed on Wednesday. At 1 April they decided to finance efforts to battle consequences from COVID-19 from the state budget. The work group ordered Economy Ministry to develop an economic recovery plan.
Later EU funds might be needed, Finance Ministry work group will review proposals on distribution of funding from EU funds.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 13, Latvia (Prime Minister + Finance Minister + Central Bank Governor) announces financial instruments (a billion-euro fund) to assist businesses via the state-owned ALTUM development bank. Possible measures are e.g.: tax holidays, paying for sick leave, import and export guarantees
Latvia recommends to cancel all unneccessary travel abroad
On March 24, the government of Latvia opened a phone number that will be available 24 hours a day for those living in Latvia to call and receive information regarding Covid-19.

Starting July 11, restaurants and places that serve food must clearly post information pertaining to the maximum number of persons who may be present at the restaurants and places that serve food, according to the government of Latvia.
