It is noted that this information must be posted at the very least near the entrance and the cashier.
On February 25, the government of Latvia announced children returning from countries affected by covid-19 must self-quarantine for 14 days at home, including staying home from school.
Latvia releases guidelines for quarantine: all persons returning from abroad and persons who have come into contact with a Covid-19 infected person should go into self-isolation at home for 14 days

From 3 June onward it will no longer be necessary to undergo a 14-day self-isolation measure when entering Latvia from the majority of European Union member states, as decided by Latvian government on Tuesday, 2 June. The main requirement is for origin countries to not register more than 15 new COVID-19 infection cases per 100 000 residents.

Latvia closes all non essential businesses from March 13. This includes: 
Nightclubs, entertainment centres, fitness clubs. Some restaurants and bars are open (e.g. take away). Shopping malls are closed. Exceptions are: food shops, press kiosks, pharmacies (incl. veterinary pharmacies), vaccination cabinets, opticians, pet food, dry cleaners, hygiene and household stores, building and garden supply stores.
As of May 12, the government of Latvia allow all shops in malls to open on holidays and weekends.

As of June 9, the government of Latvia issued rules and restrictions for the food service industry to continue operations, including requiring table disinfection after each visitor's meal, having no more than 4 visitors who are not members of the same household indoors at one table, 
having no more than 8 visitors who are not members of the same household at one table outdoors,  distance of two meters between the tables is observed, if there is no partition wall between them, and hours between 6:30-2:00.
Latvian government and public agencies (without further specification) will use remote methods of communication rather than face-to-face interviews wherever possible from March 12th
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Lavtiva bans large public gatherins with over 200 people from 13 March

As of May 12, the government of Latvia allowed non-contact sports training and lessons to occur in-person with the stipulation that indoor training may not exceed three hours. There is no limit for outdoor sessions.
As of May 12, the government of Latvia allowed non-contact sports to begin lessons and training with the stipulation that no more than 25 people gather in one training group at the same time.
Starting June 9, the government of Latvia requires public markets and food places to provide at least 4m^2 of space indoors per visitor.
From July 1 to July 31, the government of Latvia will allow no more than 1000 people to gather outside.
From July 1 until July 31, the government of Latvia will allow events with up to 500 people in larger indoor spaces.
Starting August 1, the government of Latvia will allow as many as 3,000 people to gather outside, provided that the epidemiological situation in the country does not deteriorate.
Starting from August 17, the government of Latvia will allow up to 1,000 people to gather indoors.
Latvia restricts private outside activities: two people only, exception for families, keeping a distance of 2 meters from anyone else

On 29 March, Latvia adopted stricter regulations: all persons must maintain a 2-meter distance (exception: 2 persons, persons living in one household, parents to minor children) and observe epidemiological safety measures in private and public events, as well as during public indoor and outdoor activities. All private arrangements (except funerals), public events, meetings, processions, pickets, indoor sports and religious activities are prohibited.

From 14 March, Latvia's prime minister announced that only groups of two people or families can gather at once in public places during state of emergency period, and that a 2-meter minimum distance must be maintained from other people.

On March 31 the Latvian government put a ban on people who have come to Latvia from abroad from using public transportation, having guests and going to meetings. 

The penalty for non-compliance with compulsory emergency epidemiological requirements will be up to EUR 2,000 for natural persons and up to EUR 5,000 for legal entities.
On May 12, Minister of Transport of Latvia began the requirement of mask use when using public transport.
Lithuania has introduced a state emergency status to make preventive steps against the possible arrival and spread of the virus.
Lithuanian Foreign Ministry advises Lithuanian citizens against travelling to China until the spread of the coronavirus has been contained.
Lithuania's borders are closed from 16 March - 13 April, to both inbound and outbound persons, with exceptions for delivery trucks, diplomats, etc.

On 7 April, the Parliament of Lithuania approved a pay rise of 60 "100 percent for healthcare workers, including medical residents, working in coronavirus hotspots during the lockdown. Respective amendments to the Law on Prevention and Control of Communicable Diseases in Humans were passed unanimously with 120 votes in favour. The salaries of medical workers working in the hotspots of highly dangerous communicable diseases would increase by 60 to 100 per cent. The pay rise would be financed from the national budget, instead of the Compulsory Health Insurance Fund.

On 8 April it was announced that Lithuania has allocated medical devices worth 100,000 euros to Italy and Spain. The prime minister said the funds would be used to buy essential devices produced in Lithuania, including protective shields, respirators, as well as medical equipment use to maintain the breathing function.

Announced 8 April and starting 10 April, it will be mandatory to wear facemasks in public in Lithuania. Up until now, it has been only recommended to do so. The Seimas of Lithuania earlier increased fines for people flouting quarantine requirement and they now face fines ranging from 500 to 1,000 euros. Executives of legal entities or other responsible person will face fines ranging from 1,500 to 6,000 euros.

On 27 April 2020, a plane from the Spanish Air Force took off from the Lithuanian Air Force Base near _iauliai (Lithuania) to deliver critical medical supplies to Spain, produced by Lithuania, as part of ongoing Allied efforts to contain the COVID-19 pandemic.
Lithuanian health specialists will consult people arriving from China and have been on standby at Lithuania's three airports.

From 10 April until 13 April, in Lithuania, people shall be restricted from going to the cities or towns of a municipality other than their place of residence, except the cases of the death of their close relatives or work, where the workplace is in another municipality, or urgent medical assistance.

On advisement of the country "s Ministry of Health, the government of Lithuania will be relaxing restrictions on leisure activities, travel (as of May 4), and will permit healthcare workers to resume regular services.
Lithuania sets up a State Emergency Operations Center, headed by Health Minister Aurelijus Veryga, to coordinate efforts against the spread of the COVID-19 virus
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The National Public Health Centers announced that people returning to Lithuania from China can claim 14 days sick leave and request temporary housing if they live with somebody else.

As of 25 March, the Lithuanian government requires people returning from any country abroad to self-isolate at home for 14 days, and if a person refuses, they will be forcibly quarantined in a municipal facility for 14 days.
Lithuania's government recommends avoiding mass events over the coronavirus. Government representatives also advise people in risk groups to avoid mass events.
Lithuania "s government recommended cancelling mass events in the northern city of Siauliai where the country's first case of corona was detected.

As of 24 March, stricter measures are imposed on all grocery stores in Lithuania. All visitors should disinfect their hands at the points of entry, shopping trolleys and shopping bags should be cleaned and disinfected after each use. Plastic panels should be installed between cashiers and clients, other protective equipment to be provided. Distance between staff members is at least 2 meters. Visitors should be encouraged to pay by cards. Ban on shopping in supermarkets for more than 2 individuals at a time comes into effect, family members have to go shopping by one.

On 27 March passenger carriers, transport organizers and passengers adopted security measures to reduce the number of carried passengers.

Passenger carriers have been ordered to limit the number of carried passengers. For example, buses are allowed to carry no more than 50% of passengers the bus has seats for.
Carriers also have to ensure the driver is distanced from passengers and perform regular disinfection of the interior of the vehicle.
Luxemburg is closing schools.
Luxemburg: Corona School Start

Luxemburg is restricting social movement to essential acitivities, including grocery shopping, essential travel to work, way to hospital, in order to visit people in need, in an emergency situation and in order to exercise (with 2 meters distance).

Luxemburg is declaring a state of crisis on 17 March, which gives the Government the possibility to set up emergency measures in order to face the crisis. Thus, a regulatory and legal framework is established, in line with the Luxembourg Constitution: the scope covered by this Article is limited to measures which cannot be taken in good time through the normal legislative procedure. The Chamber of Deputies can, at every moment, suspend or revoke the state of crisis: Parliamentary control is this fully guaranteed.

German frontier workers are excempt from the Luxemburg entry ban. The Luxembourg government has issued a certificate the worker needs to carry with them, as proof of the need to cross the border. 18 March.

Luxemburg banned third-country nationals to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy. The restriction was put in place, initially, for a one month period starting on March 18, 2020.  There are several exemptions from this ban, including for  Belgian, French, and German cross-border workers.

French frontier workers are excempt from the Luxemburg entry ban. The Luxembourg government has issued a certificate the worker needs to carry with them, as proof of the need to cross the border together with the attestation of necessary travel and the justification of necessary travel.

Belgian frontier workers ar exempted from the entry ban in Luxemburg, the Luxembourg government has issued a certificate the worker needs to carry with them, as proof of the need to cross the border. 18 March.
Luxemburg: Since 15 June, there have been no more controls at Luxembourg's borders with the 3 border countries.
Luxemburg is opening three specified medical centres for patients with coronavirus symptoms on 18. March.

Luxemburg bans all stationary visits in hospitals, all essential vitis need to be processed with higthened health security measures. Planned hospital acitivies are recommended to be canceled and staff is recommended to cancel leave.
Luxembourg: As of 4 May, hospitals are very gradually resuming their medical, surgical and care activities, based on the priority needs of patients
Luxembourg: As of 4 May, hospitals are very gradually resuming their medical, surgical and care activities, based on the priority needs of patients.
20.6. Luxembourg wants to prevent a second wave of corona with comprehensive tests of the entire population.
Luxembourg: Retirement and nursing homes - family visits no longer prohibited, sanitary restrictions stay in place
Luxemburg is recommending risk groups to reduce social interaction, travel and avoiding mass gatherings and hospital visits.
Luxemburg is recommending a visitors ban on care homes to all relatives and friends of residents of elderly homes.
Luxembourg: Covid-19: Introduction of family support leave
Luxembourg: COVID-19: New procedure for applying for short-time work in cases of force majeure due to the COVID-19 crisis announced on March 27.
Luxembourg: Partial unemployment extended until end of 2020
The Luxemburg Ministry of Health is starting a public health awareness campaigns surrounding COVID-19 on 29.92.2020.

Luxemburg is restricting non-essential business from 16 March onwards with the expection of grocery stores, pharmacies, other kinds of food shops and opptricians, pet food shops, telecom shops, fuel stations, shops for health equipment, night shops, kiosks.
Luxembourg's objective is to implement a gradual exit from confinement in phases while remaining cautious. Construction sites resumed their activities from 20 April  2020.
Luxemburg is restricting non-essential government services from 16 March onwards.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Luxemburg bans public gatherings in closed rooms with over 100 people and in open spaces with over 500 people.
Luxemburg is banning all social, cultural, festive, political and sportive activities from 16 March onwards for the entire public.
Luxembourg: Private meetings are limited to 10 persons

Luxemburg is launching a new online shopping platform for risk groups on 19 March in order to support people who cannot and should not leave their homes to buy essentials goods. The platform offers a delivery service.
Luxembourg bans major parties

The Ministry of Education and FP and RTVE launch 'We learn at home' (Aprendemos en casa) to facilitate the learning of all students ages 6-16 during the suspension of face-to-face classes on March 23, 2020.
'We learn at home' is a 5-hour a day special television program promoted by the MEFP to alleviate the lack of face-to-face classes motivated by the coronavirus crisis, especially among the most socially vulnerable students.

On March 14, 2020, the Mexican health and education ministries announced to extend the school break and close schools from March 23rd to April 17th, with classes resuming on Monday, April 20th. The measure affects all educational levels. This coming year, schools will remain closed and students will learn from home with the "aprende en casa" program until states enter the "green" level of the stoplight system.

On August 3, the Esteban Moctezuma, the education minister, announced that "Mexican students will be educated in the next academic year through a home-learning program broadcast by major networks such as TV Azteca until a drop in coronavirus infections allows for schools to be reopened." The start of the academic year in Mexico is August 24
On March 30, Mexico declared a Sanitary Emergency and suspended activities until April 30.  This Sanitary Emergency was extended on April 21 to last until May 30.
On January 10, 2020, the Mexican ministry of health issues a preventive travel warning to Wuhan, China (no travel restriction) and recommends to avoid unnecessary travel to China in general.
On March 16, "the Government of Mexico recommends Mexicans to avoid non-essential international travel."

The United States and Mexico entered a joint initiative March 21 restricting non-essential travel along the U.S.-Mexico land border to prevent the spread of the COVID-19 virus.  Non-essential travel includes travel that is considered tourism or recreational in nature.  The restrictions are in place until at least September 21.

On April 16 the Mexican Federal Health Secretariat issued a Preventive Travel Notice which emphasises to avoid all non-essential international travel in particular to the United States of America and areas with local community transmission of Coronavirus disease (Covid-19).
As of June 16, Mexico temporarily bans workers from going to Canada due to COVID-19.
On January 10, 2020, the Mexican ministry of health recommended travellers with symptoms returning from China or Wuhan, China to seek medical care and to mention their travel history.

"Passengers and aircrew members arriving at and departing from Mexican airports may be subject to health screenings, including temperature checks. " Those exhibiting symptoms may be subject to additional health screenings and/or asked to quarantine voluntarily."

On May 28, 2020,the Ministry of Communications and Transport (SCT), Telecommunications of Mexico (TELECOMM) and the satellite operator SES, will temporarily arrange for a high-performance broadband satellite network to support the Ministry of Health in telemedicine and in the integration, processing and sending of information generated by hospitals and health centres attending to the pandemic generated by the coronavirus.

On May 29, the Mexican government began the Stoplight System (Sem "foro) as a way to return to the "new" normal. The Yellow (Amarillo) phase allows All work activities, taking care of people most at risk of developing a severe COVID-19. The outdoor public spaces will be open on a regular basis, and indoor public spaces can be opened with a reduced capacity. As in other traffic light colours, these activities should be carried out with basic prevention measures and maximum care for people at higher risk of developing a severe COVID-19 frame.
On May 29, the Mexican government began the Stoplight System (Sem "foro) as a way to return to the "new" normal. The Green (verde) phase allows all activities, including schools to resume.

On May 29, the Mexican government began the Stoplight System (Sem "foro) as a way to return to the "new" normal.  The Red (Rojo) stoplight only permits essential economic activities, and people are allowed to go for walks around their homes during the day.  This is the most restrictive level.

On May 29, 2020 the Mexican Ministry of Health announced that it "has implemented a series of measures to ensure not only the highest level of specialized medical care in the area of psychiatric care and mental health in the six units under its authority, but also the prevention and mitigation of risks of contagion in the face of the health emergency which includes an installation of screens at all entrances to each medical unit to detect suspicious cases."

On May 29, the Mexican government began the Stoplight System (Sem "foro) as a way to return to the "new" normal. The Orange (Naranja) level allows essential economic activities, non-essential activities will be allowed to work with 30% of staff for operation,always taking into account maximum care measures for persons most at risk of presenting a severe COVID-19 table, open public spaces with a reduced capacity (number of people).

"On June 1, the Mexican government began phasing in non-essential economic activities in some states and municipalities using a national  "stoplight " (Sem "foro) system.  The four metrics to determine the colors in the Mexican government "s stoplight system are the trend in numbers of new cases; hospital occupancy trends; current hospital occupancy rates; and percentage of positive cases.  If one indicator is red, the whole state will be designated red.  The Mexican government will update the state-level designations every Friday, and the revisions will take effect the following Monday."

As of July 3, 2020, 17 states declared their risk was the Orange (High)  part of the Traffic Light Monitoring System. The "orange" risk states that "in addition to essential economic activities, companies with nonessential economic activities may conduct operations with 30% of their personnel, always taking into account the greatest degree of care for people with the highest risk (High Risk individuals) of presenting severe COVID-19-related symptoms.  Public spaces will be reopened with reduced capacity." Those states are: Aguascalientes, Baja California Sur, Campeche, Chihuahua, Mexico City, Durango, Guerrero, Hildago, Jalisco, Michoac "n, Morelos, Oaxaca, Quer "taro, Quintana Roo, San Luis Potos ", Yucat "n, and Zacatecas.

As of July 3 2020, 15 states declared their risk of Covid was the Red (Maximum) part of the Traffic Light Monitoring System.  The "Red" risk only allows "essential economic activities...and people will be limited to move outside their homes during the day."  Those states are: Baja California, Chiapas, Coahuila, Colima, Estado de M "xico, Guanajuato, Nayarit, Nuevo Le "n, Puebla, Sinaloa, Sonora, Tabasco, Tamaulipas, Tlaxcala, and Veracruz.

The Health Minister of Mexico announced on February 26 that the health system has prepared 2,738 intensive care hospital beds and 6,175 medical ventilators to deal with a possible outbreak of the virus. The director of the Health Ministry "s epidemiology department said that the country "s health services have a strategic reserve of 145,000 disposable and biodegradable hospital gowns, 111,000 surgical face masks, 32,599 propene face masks and 42,729 high-tech respirators to protect health workers.

The health ministry of Mexico announced on March 24, 2020, that "the Ministry of the Navy of Mexico adheres to the efforts of the Government of Mexico and puts its human and material resources at the service of citizens: it has 10 voluntary isolation centers with a capacity of 4,043 beds and 8 naval medical facilities with 79 beds, which will follow up on serious cases."

On April 2, 2020, the Mexican ministries of tourism and health agreed on certain measures, which include that the ministry of tourism in cooperation with the hotel industry "will prepare a list of lodging centres designed to concentrate all national and foreign guests with respiratory symptoms, and another for foreign guests without respiratory symptoms, while they await the support of their respective governments for their return."

On April 8, 2020 the Mexican Ministry of Health installed through the Health Institute for Welfare on orders of President Andr "s Manuel L "pez Obrador an air bridge with the People's Republic of China to purchase medical supplies abroad for the population and health workers (1 million masks and 800 000 medical gloves.
The government of Mexico purchased on April 9 5,272 ventilators from a range of countries, although the only one he cited was Denmark.

Mexico will buy US $56.6 million worth of medical supplies from China 
A shipment of masks and gloves will arrive on April 10. Mexico was able to secure a purchase of 11.5 million KN95 masks.

On April 10, 2020, the second flight of the air bridge with the People's Republic of China, organised by the Mexican Ministry of Health through the Health Institute for Welfare on orders of President Andr "s Manuel L "pez Obrador, arrived.  This flight included approximately two million medical masks.

On April 17, 2020 at a press conference, led by the Mexican President Andr "s Manuel L "pez Obrador, it was announced "that more than 160 countries are co-supporting the proposal presented by the Government of Mexico to the United Nations (UN) on international cooperation to ensure equal global access to medicines, vaccines and medical equipment to address the Covid-19."

On April 10, 2020, the fourth flight of the air bridge with the People's Republic of China, organised by the Ministry of Health through the Health Institute for Welfare on orders of President Andr "s Manuel L "pez Obrador, arrived in Mexico. This flight included approximately three million medical masks and 60 000 glasses.

On April 10, 2020, the third flight of the air bridge with the People's Republic of China, organised by the Mexican Ministry of Health through the Health Institute for Welfare on orders of President Andr "s Manuel L "pez Obrador, arrived. The medical supplies included 250 000 medical masks.

On April 13, the Mexican President Andr "s Manuel L "pez Obrador signed an agreement with private hospitals so that health authorities can use half of their beds for one month. Due to this agreement, there are additional 3300 hospital beds. 500 of them can be used for intensive care.

On April 17, Mexico's president urged medical workers aged 60 to 65 to return to their jobs and treat non-coronavirus patients from April 23 to May 23 to free up younger health workers for coronavirus cases. Before it was recommended for them to stay at home and they did not have to work as all people aged over 60.

On April 28, the Undersecretary for Prevention and Health Promotion, Hugo L "pez-Gatell Ram "rez, reported that so far there are 618 notifying hospitals in the information system called Serious Acute Respiratory Infection Network (IRAG) to report bed availability.

On May 17, "the Government of Mexico continues to strengthen the states within the framework of the strategy against the Covid-19 pandemic, so the Institute of Health for Welfare (Insabi) began the distribution of 1,226 hospital beds. (...) Specifically, there are 1,068 hospital beds, 140 beds for intensive care and 18 transfer beds."

On August 5, The United Kingdom and Mexico hosted the virtual seminar  "Accelerating access to COVID-19 vaccines in Latin America and the Caribbean." At this seminar, they discussed "the importance of the Access to COVID-19 Tools (ACT) Accelerator to ensure global access to vaccines, treatments and tests to face COVID-19... the need for collaboration between governments, international institutions and businesses." Specifically, Mexico Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard said: 'Mexico seeks to bring the governments of Latin America and the Caribbean closer to the leading multilateral institutions in the strategy for the development and distribution of the vaccine against COVID-19, in order to guarantee equitable access. We appreciate the support of the UK in opening spaces for dialogue and building inclusive responses to global problems.'
The Ministry of Health in Mexico announced on February 24 that it is testing over 5,000 blood samples from across the country for presence of COVID-19.

On March 24, 2020, the Mexican government implemented measures to stop the spread of the coronavirus. With regards to hygiene, the measure "advises individuals to wash their hands regularly; cover their mouths when they sneeze and cough with the inner side of their arms; apply distance precautions during greetings." The measure is effective until April 19, 2020.

The federal Health Ministry of Mexico said on April 7 that a properly disinfected Covid-19 cadaver  "poses no risk " and that the preferable way to dispose of one is cremation, but interment also acceptable. All ceremonies can follow traditional customs.

On March 26, the Mexican president signed a "decree that orders companies to allow the vulnerable population such as senior citizens, pregnant women, and people with chronic diseases to stay home from work while getting paid." This is set to end on April 19.

On January 20, 2020, the Mexican Ministry of Health announced a "Preparation and Response Plan" and activated the National Committee for Safety in Health, which will be coordinated by the Ministry of Health.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On April 7, the government decided to create a National Contingency Center (Centro National de Contingencias, CNC), where scientific, technical and operational efforts will be concentrated to combat the new virus. The CNC will be led by the president and two officials of the army and navy.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 21, 2020 the ministry of health launched a public campaign called "Susana Distancia" to raise public awareness about the importance of social distancing (1.5m) and health recommendations to prevent the spread of Covid-19. A comic hero "will tell you how you can help contain an epidemic like COVID-19."The ministry of health launched a twitter, facebook and instagram account for the campaign. (@Susana Distancia).

On March 25, 2020, the Mexican health ministry published information to inform about the usage of face masks, which they only recommend for persons with symptoms, health professionals and care workers of patients with a respiratory infection, if they are in the same room.

On January 25, 2020, the Mexican Ministry of Health recommended to "see a doctor (fever over 38 "C, headache, sore throat, runny nose, etc.) and stay home when you have a respiratory infection and follow your doctor's instructions."

On March 23, 2020, the measures of the "National Day of Healthy Distance" organized by the Mexican Ministry of Health started, which include the "the voluntary social isolation of the elderly. (from 60 years on)"
In Mexico, "Non-essential activities are ordered to be suspended immediately from 30 March to 30 April 2020 in order to mitigate the dispersal and transmission of SARS-CoV2 virus in the community""

On April 2, 2020, the Mexican ministries of tourism and health agreed on certain measures, which include that "the hospitality industry, which includes hotels, lodging platform services and the OTAs (internet travel agencies) will no longer accept reservations and will reschedule all those that they received during the period of "Sana Distancia" (March 23 until April 30)"

In Mexico, "Beginning June 1, 2020, businesses will be able to resume operations if they comply with the Guidelines and the epidemiological risk stop light system, and no prior authorization will be required. "

The United States Embassy and consulates in Mexico began limiting services from March 17 until further notice. Essential consular services to U.S. citizens as well as emergency visa services will continue to be provided.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 14, 2020, the Mexican Ministry of Culture and Health announced that "education, training and research facilities, following the criteria of the Ministry of Public Education, are extending the Easter holidays from March 20 to April 20."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The federal government of Mexico has officially deemed beach tourism a nonessential activity, ordering state and local governments to close beaches from April 2 in an attempt to mitigate the spread of COVID-19.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 30, 2020, the General Health Council (GHC) ordered " the immediate suspension of non-essential activities in the public from 30 March to 30 April 2020, private and social sectors" in Mexico.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 14, 2020, the Mexican Ministry of Health recommended to " "postpone massive events with more than five thousand people until further notice, that is, any event that meets this criterion, regardless of who organizes it and where it takes place."

On March 14, 2020, the ministry of health and culture announced that "from Tuesday 17 March 2020, the Cineteca Nacional will only allow 50% of its capacity in the screens and, for the time being, the open-air forum and the rest of the artistic programme will be suspended." in Mexico.

In Mexico on March 14, 2020, the Ministry of Culture and Health announced that "Art and culture events and activities in theatres, concert halls, cultural centres and archaeological sites (including the visit that is usually done on the spring equinox), scheduled between March 20 and April 20, will be rescheduled."

On March 14, 2020, the Mexican ministry of culture and health announced that "indoor and outdoor areas such as museums, galleries, archaeological sites, libraries and shops will remain open and the criterion of social distance (sana distancia) will be applied to limit the capacity."
On March 14, 2020, the Mexican President said in his speech that " from today on it is highly recommended that we avoid any greeting with a hand, a kiss or a hug (...).

The Mexican ministry of health published on March 24, 2020 within their campaign "Susana Distancia" recommendations on social distancing in 
queues, at work, in restaurants, elevators and supermarkets.

On March 30, 2020, the General Health Council declared a national health emergency which includes that in "sectors identified as essential, meetings of no more than 50 persons should be held and basic measures of hygiene, prevention and healthy distance should always be applied" in Mexico.
On March 30, the Mexican government issued a postponement of the population consensus and all other surveys.

On April 13, the Mexican congress passed a prisoner amnesty law. "It will allow for the release of low-level offenders, including those convicted of robbery and small-scale drug possession, as well women jailed on abortion charges. It will also apply to indigenous convicts who did not receive an adequate defense due to language barriers and those who were coerced to work with criminal gangs."

On March 12, the Netherlands pass new measures to fight the spread of the virus, requesting universities and institutions of higher professional education (HBO) to offer online lectures instead of large-scale lectures until March 31. Primary schools, secondary schools, secondary vocational schools (MBO) and childcare centres will remain open as usual.
As of April 21, secondary schools will remain closed until June 2.

In the Netherlands on April 21, parents are asked, when primary schools and childcare centres re-open on May 11, to take their children to school or childcare on foot or by bike wherever possible. This will prevent public transport becoming crowded.

From 1 July, schools and childcare centres in the Netherlands will no longer offer emergency childcare for parents working in the healthcare sector. This includes hospital staff, nursing staff, carers and home carers, ambulance staff and support staff, such as cleaners at hospitals and care homes, as well as doctors and other medical staff in the armed forces. The infrastructure will remain in place so that this service can be started up again quickly if necessary.

In the Netherlands, as of August 6, educational institutions should hold orientation activities online wherever possible. In-person activities can only take place in small groups and must be informative in nature.
Study associations and student sports clubs can only hold in-person activities if these are necessary to introduce students to their chosen programme of study or sport. Such activities can only take place in small groups and must end by 22.00 at the latest. No alcohol may be consumed.
The governing body of the educational institution in question and the head of the relevant safety region must give permission for such activities to take place. Student societies are not permitted to hold in-person recruitment or orientation activities.

As of March 17, the Netherlands are advising all Dutch people not to travel abroad in the coming period unless absolutely essential, thus marking travel advice for all countries at  "orange ": travel only if absolutely essential.

As of March 19, the Netherlands impose a 30-day travel restriction of all non-essential travel by persons from third countries to Europe (i.e. all EU member states, all Schengen countries and the United Kingdom) until April 18.

"The Dutch government strictly enforces the EU travel restrictions banning non-essential travel from outside the EU with limited exceptions. The ban went into effect on March 19, 2020, and has been extended until further notice. Currently," as of July 1 "the EU non-essential travel ban does not apply to the following countries: Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, and Uruguay."

The Netherlands Prime Minister Mark Rutte said he personally would have no problem flying in a full aircraft. He said the rate of air exchange has been researched extensively at that the risk of spreading a Covid-19 infection is very small.

Face masks are set to become a requirement for all travellers at Dutch airports, the government said. In line with advice from the RIVM, the changes will mandate that all passengers wear at least a non-medical face masks while on board flights, as well as while at check-in, security, and waiting at departure gates at Dutch airports.

The government said it was likely impossible to keep a physical distance of 1.5 meters between people on airplanes in part because of the highly regulated and stringent safety rules governing aircraft. However those rules will still apply at the airports.

Netherlands "will allow vacations in Europe, but not outside the continent.

 Some holiday options will be available to residents of the Netherlands this summer, Prime Minister Mark Rutte confirmed during a press conference on Wednesday. However trips to countries outside of the European Union and the Schengen Area will remain restricted to residents. 

"From June 15, we want to turn as many countries as possible back to yellow. The most important thing is whether the health risks are comparable, and this will be the case across Europe, except in the United Kingdom and Sweden," Rutte said. Tourists from the EU and Schengen Area will also be allowed in the Netherlands from that date, except those from Sweden and the United Kingdom.

As of March 18, the Netherlands allow nurses and doctors whose registration in the Dutch Healthcare Professionals (BIG) Register expired after 1 January 2018 to take up their former profession without having to go through the registration process again as well as suspending the obligation to renew registration for healthcare occupations until further notice.

The Netherlands, Germany, France and Italy joined forces earlier this month in the so-called 'Inclusive Vaccine Alliance' to ensure a strong negotiating position in the search for a corona vaccine.

The collaboration will enable them to quickly achieve results in discussions with key players in the pharmaceutical industry about promising vaccine initiatives.

The contractual agreements with AstraZeneca are the first agreements of the alliance to ensure that a potential corona vaccine for Europe can become available quickly. It initially involves 300 million vaccines, possibly expanding to 400 million at a later date.
On March 7, the Netherlands began random sampling in the province of Noord-Brabant.

Dutch authorities will introduce mandatory coronavirus testing on all mink farms after Agriculture Minister Carola Schouten confirmed that a farm worker contracted the virus from one of the animals.

Screening mink antibodies will be mandatory in  "the interest of the health of employees, " the Dutch government said in a statement. The employee who was infected caught a particular strain of the virus that has been circulating in minks.

the NZ prime mister 'Mark Rutte' spoke that "From 1 June, anyone with mild symptoms that may point to coronavirus will be able to phone a national hotline and make an appointment to be tested by the municipal health service (GGD). If we are to keep the virus under control now and in the weeks and months ahead, extensive testing and source and contact tracing are crucial. Loss of smell or taste have been added to the list of symptoms that may point to a coronavirus infection." at a subsequent press conference.

Dutch government's plan to ensure access to Covid-19 tests for any person with symptoms of the disease is set to come into effect in a little over a week, GGD director Sjaak de Gouw confirmed to the public broadcaster NOS on Saturday. The expanded access to mucus membrane swab tests will begin on June 1.

In the Netherlands, as of March 23, mayors will have the option of enacting an emergency bye-law, to more easily and more quickly initiate enforcement activities. Mayors can also order specific locations to be closed, including parks, beaches and campsites. People who violate the rules can be fined.

In the Netherlands, as of March 24, "Mayors will have the option of enacting an emergency bye-law, to more easily and more quickly initiate enforcement activities. Mayors can also order specific locations to be closed, including parks, beaches and campsites. And people who violate the rules can be fined." This aims at being able to enforce existing measures more effectively.

Social affairs minister Wouter Koolmees will fine firms up to 5% of the total wage support they have received if more than 20 workers lose their jobs, as long as there is no agreement with the unions. In addition, the new NOW support package is being extended to run to October 1, the sources said.

n addition, the new NOW support package is being extended to run to October 1, the sources said. Companies will also be able to apply for up to  "50,000 to pay fixed costs during the next four months, up from the  "20,000 mooted on May 20 under the revamped TOGS scheme, NOS said. The exact amount will depend on how much turnover has gone down by.

Netherlands government announce general rules for a new phase from 1 July. 

<General rules indoors>
Stay 1.5 metres away from others.
The maximum number of people in one space is limited to 100 (not counting staff). Everyone must have their own seat.
No maximum number of people applies if they have their own seat, have made reservations and have undergone a pre-entry health check.
In shops, museums, libraries and other settings where visitors move through the space, the rule is that people must stay 1.5 metres apart. It is up to locations to make sure people follow this rule. Here, no maximum number of people applies.

<General rules outdoors>
Stay 1.5 metres away from others.
No more than 250 people (not counting staff) can be present.
In outdoor seating areas at restaurants, caf "s and bars guests must have their own seat.
No maximum number of people applies if they have their own seat, have made reservations and have undergone a pre-entry health check.
At zoos, theme parks and other outdoor locations where visitors move through the space, the rule is that people must stay 1.5 metres apart. It is up to locations to make sure people follow this rule. Here, no maximum number of people applies.

The Netherlands announced new rules for the new phase from 1 July about transport.
"Non-medical face masks must be worn on public transport. Passengers can now use all seats on buses, trains, trams and metros. However, it is still important to avoid peak hours.
For other shared forms of transport, such as taxis, passenger vans and coaches, passengers must reserve and must undergo a pre-travel health check. Non-medical face masks must also be worn.
People travelling in a car or other private vehicle are advised to wear non-medical face masks if there are 2 or more people in the vehicle who belong to different households. 
For now, on other forms of transport the rule is: stay 1.5 metres apart."

On March 22, the Netherlands issued an NL-Alert (on people "s mobile phones) to remind people of the main rules for preventing the spread of coronavirus. The alert was sent out throughout the Netherlands by the National Crisis Centre in The Hague. The NL-Alert is also displayed on many digital billboards and departure time displays for public transport.
On March 6, the Netherlands introduce a quarantine for all residents of the province of Noord-Brabant who have symptoms.

On March 12, the Netherlands pass new measures to fight the spread of the virus, asking all vulnerable people (the elderly and those with weakened immune systems) to avoid large gatherings and public transport  until March 31.
On March 15, the Netherlands is prolonging previous measures, asking all residents to stay at home if they have a cold, a cough, a sore throat or a fever until April 6.

As of April 3, travelers arriving "to the Netherlands from a region where there is a high rate of coronavirus infection", you have to self-quarantine for 14 days. "Even if you do not have any symptoms or if you have tested negative for COVID-19." On August 18 this was reduced to 10 days.
As of "You should self-quarantine if you're travelling from: 

Andorra
Malta
Sweden: V "stra G "talands l "n
Romania
Bulgaria
Croatia
Aruba
Sint Maarten
France: Paris and the department Bouches-du-Rh "ne
Spain: Madrid, Navarre, the Balearic Islands of Majorca, Menorca, Ibiza and Formentera, the provinces Burgos, Salamanca and Soria (in the region Castile and Le "n), Almer "a (in the region Andalusia), Barcelona and Lerida (in the autonomous region Catalonia) and the provinces Huesca, Zaragoza and Teruel (in the autonomous region Arag "n)
Portugal; Vale do Tejo, this includes Lisbon
Belgium; Antwerp and Brussels-Capital Region
A country outside the EU, the Schengen area and the United Kingdom, except for:  Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay and China."
On March 12, the Netherlands pass new measures to fight the spread of the virus, encouraging all residents to work from home or stagger their working times if possible until March 31.
In the Netherlands, as of March 15, all bars, caf "s, restaurants, sports clubs, gyms, saunas, sex clubs and coffee shops will close from 18.00 on Sunday 15 March until Monday 6 April (inclusive).

The Dutch government has ordered the closure of mink fur farms amid fears that they could act as 'reservoirs' for COVID-19 after two workers caught the disease.

Nine infected farms will be closed from tomorrow, with thousands of mink  " whose glossy coats are prized for fur clothing  " to be culled in the cautionary measure.

The mandate followed advice from a team of veterinarians and infectious disease specialists that the infected farms could help the coronavirus remain in circulation.

"Fitness clubs and wellness centres, sports club canteens and casinos will be able to open on July 1 rather than September 1, if the Netherlands manages to keep coronavirus under control" and "But the entire package will only go ahead if there is room to do so, and if we continue to keep to the social distancing rules" prime minister Mark Rutte told a short press conference on Wednesday evening.
On March 12, the Netherlands close public places such as museums, concert venues, theatres, sports clubs and cancel sports matches and similar events until March 31.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: As of March 15, the government announced new measures to prevent the further spread of the coronavirus, also limiting the work of the Immigration and Naturalisation Service until at least April 6.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description:
Trains, buses, and trams will all resume their normal schedules from June 1  " but public transport companies strongly request passengers only use it for essential travel. And while face masks were encouraged in the past weeks, from Monday they will be mandatory  " you will not be able to enter transport with one. The following requirements will be in place:

    Mouth masks mandatory on all public transport for everyone over the age of 13.
        You can be fined  "95 if you do not wear a mask.
        You are not required to wear the mask inside stations and on platforms.
    Board buses by the back door to avoid contact with the driver. If you need a ticket purchase it beforehand at a service desk or shop. Otherwise travel with an OV chip card as much as possible.
    Ticket checks will avoid hand-to-hand contact with inspectors. Instead, hold your own ticket/telephone in front of the ticket reader.
    Travellers are requested to pay with pin cards for their tickets when purchasing at a service desk or shop. If necessary, cash is still accepted.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 12, the Netherlands pass new measures to fight the spread of the virus, asking all residents to cancel gatherings of more than 100 people, including the closure of public places such as museums, concert venues, theatres, sports clubs and the cancellation of sports matches and other events until March 31.

The general rule as of 1 June is that people who don "t live together must always stay 1.5 metres apart. For indoor gatherings, the maximum number of people is 30.

    People may also meet outside, but must still stay 1.5 metres apart. Enforcement action will be taken if 3 or more people are not keeping a distance of 1.5 metres.

    Buildings and other covered areas that are open to the public can admit up to 30 people at a time, not counting staff. Here, too, people must stay 1.5 metres apart. The possible health risks will be assessed beforehand together with the visitor. Stay at home if you have cold-like symptoms.
    Indoor gatherings with more than 30 people are permitted in these 2 cases only:
        gatherings required by law, such as parliamentary and municipal council meetings and some shareholders " meetings, can be held online. Physical gatherings are permitted but must not exceed 100 people. Participants must stay at least 1.5 metres away from one another;

gatherings necessary to ensure the continued daily operation of institutions, businesses and other organisations are permitted but must not exceed 100 people. Participants must stay at least 1.5 metres away from one another.
On March 12, the Netherlands pass new measures to fight the spread of the virus, asking all residents to avoid contact with others and practice social distancing until March 31.

In the Netherlands, as of March 20, nursing homes and small-scale residential accommodation for the elderly will be closed to visitors and anyone not involved in the provision of basic care until at least April 6.

In the Netherlands, as of March 23, the disability care and psychiatric care sectors, also including youth care homes, have adopted new visitors regulations, limiting visits as much as possible until April 6.

From 1 June young people aged 13 to 18 will be allowed to take part in organised sports activities outdoors under the supervision of sports clubs or professionals, without keeping a distance of 1.5 metres. This is already the case for children aged 12 and under. Competitions and matches will remain prohibited.

Netherlands announce the new rule for the new phase starting from 1 July. 
"<Children and young people>
Children aged 12 and under do not have to stay 1.5 metres away from other children or adults. This also applies in childcare and primary school settings.
Teenagers aged 17 and under do not have to stay 1.5 metres away from others under 18. This also applies in secondary schools to pupils of all ages. Secondary schools will re-open fully after the summer holidays. Students and staff must still stay 1.5 metres apart.
From the start of the new academic year, more on-site educational activities can take place at schools for secondary vocational education (MBO) and higher education institutions (universities and HBO). Everyone in these settings must stay 1.5 metres apart."

In the Netherlands, as of August 18, "the government strongly and urgently advises people to limit the number of guests they receive at home to a maximum of six (excluding children under 13). This includes both indoors and in outdoor spaces like gardens. Guests should also be asked whether they have any symptoms and if so, they should not attend. It goes without saying that people should always stay 1.5 metres away from each other."
NZ announces that "affected educational facilities" are closed at March 22.
NZ: Educational facilities closed.

On April 29, early childhood and schooling services will be physically open for up to Year 10 in New Zealand. Students in Years 11 to 13 will continue remotely, as will most tertiary education. This policy ended on May 18 as New Zealand decided to open all schools.
On Monday 18 May, all schools and early learning services can open on-site in New Zealand.
Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has announced a four-level Covid-19 alert system.

On March 25, 2020 at 12:21pm, New Zealand's Minister of Civil Defense P.E.G. Hanare declares a state of national emergency. "The state of national emergency comes into force immediately on the making of this declaration, and expires seven days after the time and date on which it comes into force (unless extended or terminated at an earlier time)."
On 11:59pm Monday 27 April 2020, New Zealand will move to Alert Level 3 until May 13.
On 11.59pm on Wednesday 13 May, 2020, New Zealand will be move to Alert Level 2.
On 11:59pm on Monday 8 June, 2020, New Zealand moves to Alert Level 1.
On August 12, New Zealand moved to an Alert Level 2 until August 26.
As of 11:59pm on Sunday 30, Auckland, New Zealand is at Alert Level 2 with extra restrictions. This will remain in place until at least Sunday 6 September 2020.
Starting 11:59pm on Sunday 30 August 2020, all of New Zealand is at COVID-19 Alert Level 2.
At 11:59pm on Monday 21 September, All of New Zealand (except Auckland) will be at Alert Level 1.
At 11:59pm on Wednesday 23 September, Auckland will move to Alert Level 2 with no extra restrictions.
At 11:59pm on Wednesday 7 October, all of New Zealand will be at Alert Level 1.
Any foreign travellers who leave or transit mainland China after 2 February 2020 New Zealand time will be refused entry to New Zealand.
On February 16, New Zealand closed its border to all persons until February 24.

On February 24, New Zealand will prioritize certain Skilled Migrant Category and Residence from Work Category visa applications over others on the queue. "We will continue to prioritise people with occupational registration and those earning twice the median wage... However, applicants for Talent (Accredited Employer) Resident Visas will no longer be prioritised."

On February 28, New Zealand their Border Entry instructions to expand the scope of the temporary border measures. With China on the list already, the measure refuses "entry permission to any person who has been present in or transited through Iran within the previous 14 days."
Cruise ships cannot enter to New Zealand "s territorial waters effective from 23:59 Saturday 14 March 2020. This will remain in place until at least 30 June 2020.
On March 19, New Zealand advised citizens travelling overseas to register with SafeTravel, in order to receive notification of any changes made to travel advice.
New Zealanders are advised not to travel overseas at this time. The New Zealand Government has raised its travel advice to  "do not travel "  " the highest level  " regardless of destination.
On March 23, New Zealand temporarily closed its Visa Application Centres and Call Centre in mainland China.

At 11.59 pm on 30 June 2020. Foreign ships are not permitted to arrive in New Zealand pursuant to the COVID-19 Public Health Response (Maritime Border) Order 2020. Exceptions given to cargo ships, fishing ships, Antarctic ships, foreign State ships that have been granted diplomatic clearance, and ships where all passengers are NZ citizens or those permitted to travel to NZ.

On July 4, New Zealand temporarily closed all its Visa Application Centres and call centres. Appointments and mail-in/courier application services to the New Zealand Visa Application Centres will also remain closed.

On July 7, New Zealand government announced changes to temporary work visas. "If you are in New Zealand on the 10 July 2020 and you hold an employer-assisted temporary work visa due to expire before 31 December 2020, it will be extended for 6 months."

On July 7, the New Zealand government reduced lower- Essential Skills work visas from 12 months to 6 months. "This change will affect all new lower- Essential Skills work visa applications lodged from 10 July 2020. Applications received before 10 July will still be granted a 12 months visa if approved."

On July 10, the New Zealand government is offering border exception for victims and families of the Christchurch mosque attacks intending to travel to New Zealand for the August sentencing. They will be able to request a border exception under humanitarian grounds. "People permitted to travel to New Zealand under this border exception will be required to go into managed quarantine for 14 days on arrival into New Zealand before attending the sentencing  " beginning 24 August 2020. The cost of this is currently covered by the New Zealand Government for all approved travellers."

On July 7, the New Zealand government is delaying the 12 month stand-down period for lower-paid workers. "If you are employed in a lower-paid role where you must stand down between August 2020 and of the 31 December 2020, you will be able to stay in New Zealand and work for the same employer in the same occupation and location for up to 6 more months, in line with your visa extension...If you are required to stand down from February 2021, you must leave New Zealand for 12 months before you can apply for another lower-paid work visa."

From 10 August 2020, people outside of New Zealand will not be able to apply for temporary visas for 3 months. The following visa classes are exempted from this restriction: (1) relationship-based visas for partners and dependent children of New Zealand citizens and residents, (2) visas for diplomatic, consular and official staff and accompanying dependants, (3) Antarctic Traveller Visitor visas and Antarctic Work visas, and (4) Recognised Seasonal Employer (RSE) Limited visas.

Effective 18 August 2020, New Zealand is extending Recognised Seasonal Employer scheme visas by six months, allowing workers the opportunity to stay and work in New Zealand. This will apply to all RSE workers whose visas are expiring between 18 August and 31 December 2020 and are in an employment relationship with a RSE employer. This does not apply to RSE workers who are currently outside of New Zealand.

From 20 August 2020 to 31 July 2021, New Zealand relaxed visa restrictions for some visa holders to work in supermarkets as supermarkets are facing immediate labour supply issues during COVID-19 and to meet the increased demand for shelf re-stocking. These changes apply to specified visa holders who are employed by a supermarket on the day before the region enters Alert Level 3 or 4: (1) Temporary work visa holders employed in a supermarket can work in addition to the conditions specified on their visa and (2) Students can work more than the maximum of 20 hours per week provided they continue to meet their study requirements.

Effective 4 September 2020, New Zealand is extending current onshore visitor visas that are due to expire between 4 September and the end of October 2020 by five months to help temporary migrants and visitors to remain in New Zealand lawfully while they arrange to leave the country. Some visitor visa categories will not be extended. These include the critical purpose visa holders, guardians of students, and partners or dependants linked to a work visa holder whose visa was extended previously.

11.59 pm on 6 September 2020. To gain permit to arrive in New Zealand, the master of a ship must give at least 168 hours " notice before the ship arrives in New Zealand. A notice of arrival must be completed and delivered in the manner and form specified by the Director-General pursuant to the COVID-19 Public Health Response (Maritime Border) Order (No 2) 2020.

On September 11, New Zealand is extending the visas of offshore visa holders currently outside New Zealand. Those whose travel conditions expired on or after 2 February 2020 will be issued a new visa, valid for 12 months.

On February 6, New Zealand Minister of Health strongly advised people  who traveled to China to register through "Healthline" to regularly check on their welfare and wellbeing while in self-isolation.

On March 30, New Zealand added survey questions to monitor COVID-19 on FluTracker website. It is a surveillance system for people and communities in New Zealand and Australia to log their symptoms and testing activities.
On May 13, New Zealand announced that all gatherings (except for private hone gatherings) are required record attendees to ensure contact tracing may be conducted if necessary.

On May 20, New Zealand Ministry of Health released the NZ COVID Tracer app to support contact tracing. The app will create a digital diary of the places app users visit, self-report any COVID-19 symptoms, and complete a daily health check-in through the app.
On August 6, New Zealand government will begin trial on its CovidCard technology (contact tracing) in Rotorua, Bay of Plenty.
On September 2, New Zealand released a NZ COVID Tracer booklet as an alternative method to contact tracing besides using NZ COVID Tracer app.

On March 18, New Zealand's Ministry of Health launched a COVID-19 public health campaign by making 400,000 more vaccines available in 2020 as well as more free flu vaccines for certain populations such as people over 65, who are pregnant, with certain chronic conditions, young children with respiratory illness, and health care workers.

On March 19, the New Zealand Minister of Health and the Medical Council of New Zealand is opening registration in the COVID-19 Pandemic scopt of practice. Registration in this scope of practice is intended to allow doctors to return to practice, to undertake roles identified by the Ministry in response to COVID-19. Registration in the COVID-19 Pandemic scope of practice will expire on 30 September 2020.  All practising certificates issued for practice within this scope of practice will be current only up to 30 September 2020.

New Zealand has made the decision to postpone all non-urgent surgeries and all non-urgent outpatient appointments, with effect from Tuesday 24 March and until further notice. The decision to postpone elective services is to reduce and control the spread of COVID-19 in our New Zealand communities and allow our health system to focus our precious resources on meeting the challenges of COVID-19.

On March 27, New Zealand Ministry of Health announced that it is seeking "expressions of interest" from health and care professionals who are able and willing to work for a limited amount of time for COVID-19 response. Health professionals can register for interest to work, and health organizations can request extra workers to help manage COVID-19.

On April 2, New Zealand's Ministry of Health is seeking assistance from nurses who may like to return to nursing for a limited time to assist with the COVID-19 pandemic. To do so, the Nursing Council is able to reissue your Interim Practising Certificate (IPC) until 31 December 2020 with the condition of restricted practice for the duration of the COVID-19 pandemic.

On April 22, 2020, the Ministry of Health prohibits the importation, manufacture, packing, sale, supply, or use of COVID-19 point of care test kits that have not been otherwise authorised by Medsafe. This does not apply to testing material supplied by the Institute of Environmental Science and Research or an alternate entity approved by the Ministry of Health. This notice is valid for one year (April 22, 2021) from the date of publication of this notice.

On May 8, the New Zealand Blood Service is contacting recovered COVID-19 patients to discuss whether they would be willing to donate their plasma to help treat others seriously affected by the virus. The treatment known as convalescent plasma.
On May 26, the New Zealand government "has allocated $37 million for local development of a Covid-19 vaccine and to join the international efforts."

On June 12, New Zealand Ministry of Health requested 4.9 million PPE masks be put on hold. "The masks were withdrawn as a precautionary move to allow further quality assurance from suppliers and manufacturers to take place."

The New Zealand Ministry of Health requests, as of June 30, that medical grade masks (ie not cloth masks) are made available to all passengers on inbound international flights. The Ministry of Health also requests that airlines consider providing passengers with masks in a package, which could also include hand sanitizer and a small pack of surface disinfectant wipes. Facilities for safe mask disposal must be provided. The Ministry of Health acknowledges that it will take time to procure and distribute the set of packed items. As a result, we ask that in the short-term, airlines work to:
 " Ensure an adequate number of masks are made available for passengers to use (minimum of masks in a
pack, with the flight crew having the capacity to provide additional masks if required)
 " Strongly encourage passengers to use these masks
Airlines can submit their procedures for face mask supply to the Ministry of Health for review and approval.

On June 24, the New Zealand Health Minister announced that the government is stepping up New Zealand "s COVID-19 testing system at the border as more New Zealanders arrive from overseas.
-Regular health check and asymptomatic testing of all border facing workers 
-Regular testing of quarantine exempt people such as New Zealand based air crew
-Testing available for anyone presenting to primary or secondary care with any type of COVID-19 symptom
-District Health Boards required to regularly review and take actions to increase testing in population groups if there is significant variation to the national average in their region

Priority for testing will be given to those who are most likely to have been exposed to COVID-19 which is at the border and airline staff and those arriving back in New Zealand. These workers include:
-Border workers in customs, biosecurity, immigration and aviation security at airports, and the people who clean at international airports or maritime ports in areas/conveniences visited by international arrivals 
-Staff who work in managed isolation and quarantine facilities, including those who drive people entering the country from the airport to the facilities
-International air and maritime crew.

August 14. New Zealand passed the COVID-19 Public Health Response (COVID-19 Testing) Order 2020. The order requires medical examination and testing for COVID-19, by no later than  17 August 2020, of persons who, since 21 July 2020, have worked at a Managed Isolation and Quarantine Facility (MIQF), worked at an affect port, or transported to or from a MIQF of a person required to be in isolation or quarantine under the Air Border Order or the Maritime Border Order. A person who does not comply with the testing requirement commits an infringement offence and is liable to an infringement fee of $300 or a court-imposed fine of up to $1,000.

New Zealand announced that starting September 7, targeted groups must undergo testing and medical examination for COVID-19 every 14 days. The targeted groups are outlined under Schedule 2 of the COVID-19 Public Health Response (Required Testing) Amendment Order 2020.

New Zealand announced that starting September 7, targeted groups must undergo testing and medical examination for COVID-19 every 14 days. The targeted groups are outlined under Schedule 2 of the COVID-19 Public Health Response (Required Testing) Amendment Order 2020.
Limit non-essential travel around NZ.

On August 12, Travel in and out of Auckland, New Zealand will be restricted to essential travel only, with checkpoints in place. The Police will be stopping vehicles and questioning drivers, and educating people and ensuring they are aware of the new restrictions at the 9 check points around Auckland's regional boundaries. This will remain in place until August 26.

On March 21, the Prime Minister of New Zealand announced: "If you are at high-risk, you are advised to stay at home regardless." Those that fall under high-risk are people over 70, people with medical conditions, people undergoing a treatment for cancer and blood conditions, pregnant women, residents of aged care facilities, and migrant and refugee community.

On April 26, New Zealand announced that high-risk people no longer advised to stay home, but may go work, exercise, access essential service, and "expand your bubble a small amount to bring in local close family / whanau, isolated people or caregivers."

On 15 July, New Zealand Prime Minister Ardern released the Government's COVID-19 response framework, which would involve localized lockdowns in the event there was another community-wide outbreak of COVID-19.

On August 12, New Zealand's Director-General of Health declared certain populations to (1) isolate at their usual home and (2) not go out to work, and remain isolated, until they are contacted by their national contact tracing service, and they receive further direction. This direction applies to any employees or contractors, visitors in the last 14 days, and any people who ordinary live with these employees, or contractors, or visitors at the following two places: Americold in Mt Wellington and Finance Now (the Dominion Road branch in Auckland).

On January 28, 2020 New Zealand Ministry of Health will "stand up the National Health Coordination Centre (NHCC). The NHCC is a structure through which the Ministry can nationally coordinate and manage the health responses to and recovery from emergencies.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On January 30, the National Health Coordination Centre (NHCC) within the New Zealand Ministry of Health was established in order to manage COVID-19.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Effective March 25, New Zealand issued the Epidemic Preparedness (COVID-19) Notice 2020. The notice also activates section 24 of the Epidemic Preparedness Act 2006, which will enable certain Judges and Associate Judges to, in particular cases, modify rules of court as they think necessary in the interests of justice to take account of the effects of COVID-19. The notice expires June 25.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Prime Minister of New Zealand issued an Epidemic Notice on 25 March 2020. The Social Security Act 2018 measures activated by notice goes into force on March 25, the notice expires on 25 June 2020. This notice activates certain dormant legislative provisions. This notice states that the application of the Social Security Act 2018 is modified in order to deal with the practical effects of the outbreak of the disease.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 25, New Zealand Parliament passed the COVID-19 Response (Urgent Management Measures) Legislation Act 2020. The act amends the Education Act of 1989 giving powers for Secretary of Education to direct institutions in relation to COVID-19 measures to close/open schools, control operation of education entity, and provide education in specified ways (e.g., distance or online learning).
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Prime Minister of New Zealand issued an Epidemic Notice on 25 March 2020. Immigration Act 2009 measures activated by notice goes into force on April 2, the notice expires on 25 June 2020. This notice activates certain dormant legislative provisions. This notice states that the application of the Immigration Act 2009 is modified in order to deal with the practical effects of the outbreak of the disease.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: New Zealand declares a "National Transition Period" effective on May 13 and ends on August 10. "A National Transition Period provides the National Recovery Manager and others access to special powers designed to assist with recovery.""Police constables can also exercise powers during a transition period."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On May 15, the COVID-19 Response (Requirements For Entities "Modifications and Exemptions) Act 2020 was passed. The Act provides processes for an "entity" affected by COVID-19 to use electronic means for doing things if its constitution or rules would otherwise prevent, and powers to temporary modify its constitution or rules to comply. These temporary powers can only be exercised up until November 30.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: New Zealand's Immigration (COVID-19 Response) Amendment Bill 2020 goes into force on 2020 May 16 and will expire in 12 months (2021 May 16). The The Bill introduces eight time-limited powers to the Ministry of Immigration regarding conditions for visa applicants and holders.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On August 19, New Zealand deployed 500 more defense personnel, making it 990 total defense personnel at its managed isolation facilities. Overall there is now a total of 1,200 personnels from the New Zealand Defense Force (NZDF) supporting the overall COVID-19 response.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On August 26, New Zealand's Ministry of Health created the "COVID-19 Surveillance and Testing Strategy Group."The group is intended to provide additional advice to the Government and oversee its surveillance and testing plans, and work with government agencies and stakeholders, including private sector employers and unions, to gather useful information.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description:
On 23 March 2020, the New Zealand Government announced a freeze of rent increases and an extension of no-cause terminations. This has been applied as law through the COVID-19 Response (Urgent Management Measures) Amendment Act, which came into effect on 26 March 2020.
These measures will support New Zealanders to stay in their rental properties with a six-month freeze on residential rent increases and increased protection from having their tenancies terminated.
There is a freeze on rent increases from 26 March  " 25 September 2020, unless extended.
Tenancies will not be terminated between 26 March  " 25 June 2020.

On March 30, New Zealand Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment sets up an email address (pricewatch@mbie.govt.nz) for the public to report cases of price gouging and increases on essential goods and services.

New Zealand Minister of Health announced a $500million COVID-19 response health package, which will fund three discrete initiatives:
1) the Mentemia app will provide practical tips and techniques to help Kiwis take control of their mental wellbeing
2) the Melon app will provide a health journal, resources and self-awareness tools to help people manage their emotional wellbeing. Melon will also provide an online community for New Zealanders to
connect and support each other and daily webinars for health and wellbeing
3) Staying on Track app will use cognitive behaviour therapy to teach practical strategies to cope with the stress and disruption of everyday life from COVID-19

The Prime Minister of New Zealand announced that the Government will roll out a raft of distance learning tools, including TV channels
hosted by Suzy Cato, for the new school term. The Government's learning from home package aims to increase the number of
students who have internet access and devices and will see the Ministry of Education deliver hard copy packs of materials for different year levels. The $87.7 million set aside for the package will also fund two television channels to broadcast education-related content - one for English medium and one for Maori medium, including content that is targeted to PaciWc and other communities.

On May 1, New Zealand's Manager Network Safety extended the  approval deadline date for testing reflective materials used in traffic signs from 24 May 2020 to 28 June 2020. Due to COVID-19 the testing of sheeting materials has been delayed meaning the original May 2020 date needs to be extended to 28 June 2020 to enable testing to be completed.

New Zealand Health Minister David Clark announced on May 9 a $3.5 million funding package, which will, among other mental health campaigns and resources, fund a New Zealand Drug Foundation's "Best Bubble" campaign to reach people with information on coping with the impacts of alcohol and drug use during COVID-19.

On May 12 in New Zealand, three initiatives to support the health and disability workforce through accommodation, mental health support and access to specialist clinical advice on COVID-19 were announced on International Nurses Day by Health Minister David Clark:
1)Temporary accommodation for health and disability workers living with a vulnerable person
2) Phone counseling service for frontline workers
3) 0800 COVID-19 clinical advice number

One-off government loans are available for New Zealand businesses and organizations impacted by COVID-19, including sole traders and the self-employed, to help with cash flow. Applications are open from 12 May to 24 July 2020. The small business cash flow loan scheme is open to small to medium businesses with 50 or fewer full-time employee equivalents.
Details of the loan include:
-$10,000 to be provided to eligible businesses
-an additional $1800 per full-time employee equivalent
-interest free if the loans are paid back within a year
-an interest rate of 3% for a maximum term of five years
-repayments not required for the first two years.
The maximum amount you can borrow depends on the number of full-time and part-time employees you have. If you are a business without employees, ie sole trader or self-employed, you can receive a loan of up to $11,800.

Temporary changes have been made to New Zealand "s parental leave law as of May 14, 2020 to allow some workers to go back to work temporarily during the COVID-19 outbreak without losing their remaining entitlement to parental leave, and its associated payments and protections. That means workers can return to work for up to 12 weeks, and then go back
on parental leave. This change applies if an individual is entitled to parental leave and needs to return to work early from parental
leave for reasons related to the COVID-19 outbreak, because:
Your skills, experience or qualification mean that nobody else can fill your role, or there is unusually high demand for workers in your role.

New Zealand's Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment announced a Wage Subsidy Scheme on June 11, 2020 designed to support employers and their staff to maintain an employment connection and ensure an income for affected employees during the initial impact of COVID-19.
Applications for the Wage Subsidy Extension are open from 10 June 2020 until 1 September 2020. To be eligible for the Wage Subsidy Extension, businesses must have had a revenue loss of at least 40% for a 30-
day period in the 40 days before they apply, compared to the closest period last year (eg June 2020 compared with June 2019).

In force June 30, New Zealand extended the deadline landlords must file a statement of their level of compliance with the 'healthy homes standard' to December 1, 2020. The impact of COVID-19 restrictions has meant that landlords have been unable to collect the compliance information needed for the statement.

The New Zealand Government is taking action to address the backlog of cases across the court system following the COVID-19 lockdown period, Minister of Justice Andrew Little announced today.
A $50 million investment is being made from the COVID-19 Response and Recovery Fund to provide for five District Court judges, four acting High Court judges, one acting Associate judge and around 40 full time support staff.
