The funding also provides for extra Police prosecution staff to support more criminal events in court; two extra Corrections prison officers to support those held on remand and for transport to-and-from court or AVL appearances; further resource for Oranga Tamariki for the increase in care and protection of children applications; and a small investment in Crown Law for increased Crown prosecution work.

On August 6, New Zealand amended several acts regarding deadline extensions for certain financial reports and information. The Crown Entities Act 2004 and State-Owned Enterprises Act 1986 were amended to extend the time limit to submit 2019/20 financial year reports and audits due to COVID-19. The Public Finance Act 1989 was amended to extend the time limit to submit 2019/20 financial year information. These amendments will be repealed on June 30, 2021.

On August 6, New Zealand amended the Local Government Act 2002 to extend the deadline for the board of council-controlled organizations and local authorities submit their 2019/20 financial year annual reports due to COVID-19 to November 20, 2020. The amended section will be repealed on February 1, 2021.

On August 6, New Zealand is allowing provisional taxpayers addicted by COVID-19 to ask the Commissioner to remit "interest accrued between 31 March 2020 and the taxpayer "s terminal tax date for the 2020 "21 tax year, both dates inclusive (the interest), on the amount."

On August 10, New Zealand government launched a new online, phone and onsite service to help New Zealanders connect to a range of employment support and products for workers and businesses affected by COVID-19 (Connected.govt.nz).

Starting August 10, to recover some of the costs from the managed isolation and quarantine system, the New Zealand government is charging traveler entering the country who have to quarantine for 14 days at a mandated managed isolation center. "Exemptions are available for certain groups of people and waivers from charges are possible on a case-by-case basis for undue financial hardship and in special circumstances (such as compassionate grounds)." "The charges cover less than half of the average total costs for managed isolation and quarantine. For a single person in a room, the charge is $3,100. Additional adults or children sharing that room will be charged $950 and $475 respectively and including GST."

On August 18, New Zealand announced a $40 million Lottery COVID-19 Community Wellbeing Fund to support groups that have lost access to funding sources, have extra demand on their services, or are now working in different ways in responding to COVID-19. "he Fund will provide one-off grants and is expected to be up and running in the last quarter of the year."

On August 20, New Zealand announced a $6 million rollout to improve managed isolation and quarantine system by installing additional security systems, such as thermal CCTV that triggers an alarm if returnees break out.

Between August 21 to September 3, New Zealand employers who are financially impacted by the resurgence of COVID-19 and changes to COVID Alert Levels can apply for a 2-week COVID-19 Resurgence Wage Subsidy payment. This is for "New Zealand employers who have had, or expect to have, a revenue drop of at least 40% because of COVID-19, for a 14 day period between 12 August to 10 September."

On August 24, New Zealand's Ministry of Health Ministry announced a $68 million Tu Manawa fund for community led play, active recreation and sport. The new fund support the mental wellbeing for people after their lives have been disrupted by COVID-19.

On August 25, New Zealand's Ministry of Health announced $19.5 million towards increasing the resourcing and capacity of those working to combat this virus. The funding package will be used to deliver on five key priority areas: (1) Enabling Pacific health and disability service providers in Auckland to meet the increased demand for their testing and wraparound support services; (2) Enabling Auckland metro DHBs (led by Counties Manukau) to sustain and expand their mobile outreach services and Pacific case management model (which now includes pathways for working with churches) that was established under the initial Pacific Response Package; (3) Establishing an enhanced Pacific priority outreach service as part of the National Close Contact Service (NCCS). This will be a specialised, priority mobile service which can be deployed to find, spot-test, and provide wraparound assessments for Pacific close contacts which cannot be traced through the main NCCS processes; (4) Bringing together a group of leading Pacific researchers and health care providers to analyse current intelligence and data on the Pacific experience of COVID -19, and use this to inform current and future policy and service delivery; and (5) Establishing a flexible pool of funding to assist disability support services and their Pacific COVID-19 response.

On September 8, New Zealand's Ministry of Education and NZQA are providing additional support for senior secondary students due to the continuing disruption from COVID-19. The following support will apply to students in Auckland: Additional places will be available in programmes led by Te Aho o te Kura Pounamu (Te Kura) from term 4; Te Kura will have extra places in their summer school this year.; Students working towards an NCEA can gain up to 6 extra Learning Recognition (LR) credits at Level 1 and up to 4 extra LR credits at levels 2 and 3; and the credit requirements for certificate endorsements have been reduced by 2 credits.
On February 5, New Zealand's Minister of Health announced a healthline number for health-related calls about Coronavirus.
On February 29, New Zealand's Ministry of Health launches a Coronavirus public awareness campaign with ads on radio stations and social media content.
On March 22, New Zealand released COVID-19 information in sign language.

From March 30, New Zealand Ministry of Social Development regional commissioners are making check-in calls to older New Zealanders who may not be receiving information on where to get the help that they need.

On April 7, New Zealand launched COVID-19 mental health support campaigns such as the "Getting through together" campaign to help people cope with the stress of COVID-19, telephone support, and online resources.

New Zealand's Ministry of Health, along with several district health boards, launched a new website, PreparePacific.nz, as a public awareness measure on April 9, 2020 dedicated to providing information for Pacific communities across the nation. The goal of the website is to help stop the spread of the Coronavirus by providing up-to-date and relevant information in a one-stop shop portal and from Pacific perspectives.
On April 28, New Zealand launched a helpline to provide businesses with advice and connect them to additional support due to COVID-19 restrictions.

Effective April 9, all persons arriving to New Zealand by air (other than excluded arrivals) must quarantine for at least 14 days, but no more than 28 days) at an approved isolation facility. This order expires April 22, unless earlier revoked or extended).

New rules for hospitality sector under Covid-19. People going to bars, restaurants and casinos will be expected to stay at least a metre away from each other, and venues will have to do head counts to make sure there are not >100 people indoors. A register of guest details will also have to be kept for four weeks, including full name, address and contact phone and email details.
NZ announces that public venues are closed (e.g. libraries, museums, cinemas, food courts, gyms, pools, amusement parks) at March 22.
Businesses closed except for essential services (e.g. supermarkets, pharmacies, clinics) and lifeline utilities

On Easter Sunday (April 12), most super markets will be open in New Zealand. Usually, supermarkets are not allowed to open on Friday and Sunday during Easter. This year, the government has changed the rules so that some supermarkets can open on Sunday.

Starting April 20, New Zealand is allowing businesses to prepare to reopen on 11:59 PM April 27, such as employees accessing their premises to receive stock. Employees must stick to physical distancing rules and their bubbles.

The New Zealand Business Number (Organisation Parts Data) Order 2020 was passed. Businesses in NZ organized into parts will be able to choose to have a unique identifying number assigned to a part (or parts) of the business, and for that information to be displayed on the New Zealand Business Number Register. The unique identifying number will help the Government "s proposal to develop contact tracing systems in response to the effects of COVID-19. This order comes into force on 12 May 2020.
New Zealand announced that it would 'essentially lift' the restrictions on businesses and services, effective midnight June 9th, as long as contact tracing and several 'golden rules' were followed.

On August 12, New Zealand is requiring businesses and services to "display a copy of the QR code for the business or service in a prominent place at or near the main entrances to the workplace" and have other systems and processes in place to support contact tracing.

August 12. New Zealand businesses and services where food or drinks are sold or provided cannot have more than 100 customers in the space at once. Adjacent tables are arranged with at least 1-metre separation between seated customers and only 1 worker services at any table.

The Department of Conservation is closing its visitor centres to the public from today, and from tomorrow will cancel all walking hut and campsite bookings for the rest of the season (up to 30 June 2020). Rangers will visit tracks and facilities, alerting people about the changes and checking people are complying.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 26, New Zealand Director of Civil Aviation issued an Emergency Directive (ED) in response to the situation created by COVID-19.  To provide relief from certain requirements of Civil Aviation Rule, without compromising civil aviation safety, medical certificates for aviation licenses with expiry dates between 26 March 2020 and 23 June 2020 remain in force until 24 June 2020, unless renewed by the Director of Civil Aviation
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Effective April 10, New Zealand passed the Land Transport (Motor Wehicle Registraion and Licensing) (COVID-19 - Extension of Duration of Motor Vehicle Licenses) Amendment Regulations 2020. Motor licenses that were set to expire on or after January 1, 2020 will be valid up until October 10, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: From 23 May 2020 to 30 April 202, New Zealand alters the ability for hunters' claim to stands owing to the effects of COVID-19 Alert Levels. A stand claim held by an individual from the Open Season for Game 2019 will carry over to the 2020 season if the individual obtains by 23 May 2020 a valid game season licence for the Open Season for Game 2020. This shall be deemed a claimed stand.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Effective 12 August 2020, Panel Physicians in the Auckland region are unable to conduct immigration medical examinations under COVID-19 Alert Level 3. These restrictions will be in place until at least 26 August 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: NZ announces new restrictions of mass gatherings as further restrictions were applied.

From March 23, New Zealand's Ministry of Health states that public funeral services and private tangihanga are prohibited. "Only people who lived within the same household 'bubble' as the deceased are permitted to go to the funeral home and cemetery."

On May 13, New Zealand announced that private events and gatherings can have up to 10 people (except for funerals and tangihanga which can have up to 50 people). Public events are allowed up to 100 people.

On June 12, New Zealand's National Hospital Response Group issued guidance for hospital visitation allowing regional "DHBs to determine the visiting arrangements necessary for each of their clinical areas, within the context of the ongoing global pandemic, and with the use of some common messaging."

August 12. New Zealand is requiring organizers of social gatherings to keep records to enable contact tracing in relation to the social gathering. (This policy applies to all of New Zealand except for the Auckland region.)
On August 12, New Zealand is prohibiting social gatherings that exceeds 100 people. (This policy applies to all of New Zealand except Auckland region.)
Effective August 12, New Zealand (except for Auckland) is limiting all gatherings to 100 people.

Announced on August 24, New Zealand postpones their general election and referendum to 17 October 2020. It was originally scheduled to be held on 19 September 2020. These regulations are revoked on 16 October 2021 pursuant to the "Electoral Amendment Regulations (No 3) 2020."
At 11:59pm on Wednesday 23 September, Auckland, New Zealand will allow social gatherings, funerals and tangihanga in groups of up to 100 people.
NZ announces new recommendation regarding social distancing for public transport at March 21.

On August 12, New Zealand businesses and services must ensure all people who enter the workplace or use its services to remain 2 meters away from each other and from the workers. In addition, all workers who enter the workplace or carry out work must remain 1 meter away from each other.  (this policy is applicable to all of New Zealand except for the Auckland region).
Effective August 30, everyone in New Zealand must wear a mask or face covering on buses, trains, ferries, and planes.
On May 7, the Norwegian government annouced that Folkeh "gskoler (folk high schools) are kept closed for the school year, with the exception of the short courses.

On May 7, the Norwegian government annouced that from May 11 Universities, colleges and vocational schools must continue distance education. Students who must be at the learning site to maintain study progression can access. The places of learning must comply with the requirements for the prevention of infection-related activities.

On February 13, the The Norwegian Institute of Public Health advises Norwegian citizens not to travel to Hubei Province in China (including Wuhan city) due to widespread infection spread in this province.
Healthcare professionals conducting patient care are temporarily prohibited from traveling abroad

Norway 13 March, 2020
"The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has decided, on the basis of an overall assessment, to advise against trips to the United States and France that are not strictly necessary. The background for the decision is the prevalence of coronavirus in both of those countries and in Norway. In addition, U.S. authorities have introduced travel restrictions for people coming from the Schengen Area, which includes Norway."

Norway, 14.03.2020 
"The Ministry of Foreign Affairs advises against all international travel that is not strictly necessary. The reason is the increasing spread of coronavirus internationally and the unpredictable and difficult situation faced by many travellers. For now, this advice will remain in effect until 14 April."

On March 14, the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs "advises against all international travel that is not strictly necessary. The reason is the increasing spread of coronavirus internationally and the unpredictable and difficult situation faced by many travellers. For now, this advice will remain in effect until 14 April."

On May 13, Norway's government relaxed the restrictions for external broder control for foreigners who can normally enter the country. However, for all other foreign travellers who have no resident permit or were not exempted before (e.g. seasonal workers form EEA, or persons with property), will still not be allowed to enter the country.

From the 21st of August the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Norway is now advising against non-essential travel to Austria, Greece, Ireland and the UK.
In addition to Andorra, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, the Faroe Islands, France, Iceland, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Spain, Switzerland as well as certain regions in Denmark: Zealand, Central Jutland and Greater Copenhagen.
And Sweden:  "sterg "tland,  "rebro, Blekinge, V "rmland, Uppsala and Dalarna

The status of Norrbotten in Sweden will change to  "yellow, " and the Ministry "s travel advice will therefore no longer apply to this region.

People who have returned to Norway from a country that becomes  "red " after their return must monitor their health for symptoms of Covid-19.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Norway decided at the 26th of August that from the 29th of August on against they will advise against non-essential travel to Germany and Liechtenstein, as well as to the regions of Kalmar and V "sterbotten in Sweden.
In addition to Germany and Liechtenstein, the Ministry advises against non-essential travel to the following countries and regions in the Schengen area/EEA: Andorra, Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, the Faroe Islands, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Spain, Switzerland, the UK, and certain regions in Sweden and Denmark.

On March 22, the Norwegian Health Network ( 'Folkehelseinstituttet') and the Norwegian Institute of Public Health has published an web-based solution to report for those suspected to have coronavirus, which facilitates self-reporting of symptoms from all inhabitants.

On April 16, Norway announced the launch of the 'infect stopp' app, which will make it easier to detect and stop the spread of the coronavirus. The app is voluntary to download the app, but it is urged that everyone has it.

At the 19th of August the norwegian Ministery of Foreign Affairs declared from the 21st of August on people who have returned to Norway from a country that becomes  "red " after their return must monitor their health for symptoms of Covid-19.

In the Cabinet of Ministers on February 28, the Ministry of Health and Care, by royal decree, was given authority in the courtroom and delivery of medicines and equipment: The decision gives the Ministry of Health and Care Authority the authority to impose wholesalers and similar reporting obligations and restrictions on sales, distribution and export of medicines and equipment, and to impose restrictions on sales and delivery of medicines and equipment to pharmacies and retailers.

On March 27, Norwegian government announced to increase its support for the work to develop vaccines against the virus that has caused the current Covid-19 pandemic and against future epidemics by NOK 2.2 billion.

In Norway, the first experimental treatment of patients infected with COVID-19 has started from March 28. Oslo University Hospital is one of 22 venues in the country carrying out the major international study by the World Health Organization.The study will involve tests of three drug treatments, with both malaria and Ebola medicines involved.

On April 27, the Norwegian Directorate of Health announced that as of March 30, 2020, an export permit is required to export personal contamination equipment. The ban is limited to mouthwashes, goggles, disposable gloves and protective suits. The Directorate of Health is responsible authority for processing export permit applications.

On March 31, the Norwegian government announced increased production of emergency ventilators. The Norwegian companies Laerdal Medical and Servi have developed an emergency ventilator in collaboration with the Norwegian Defence Research Establishment that could help to double the number of breathing machines at Norwegian hospitals by the end of May. The government guarantees project funding for this production.

On March 29, Norwegian health authorities say they are set to start performing random coronavirus tests among all citizens, to detect how many of those who appear to be infected actually have the coronavirus and how wide the spread of the virus is.

The Norwegian Armed Forces is implementing an extended systematic infection screening as part of the Armed Forces " health service for new recruits. The testing of recruits entails several different types of investigations: capillary tests/rapid tests for the detection of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2; blood tests for serological antibody analysis and to validate the results of rapid tests; deep nose/throat tests for virus detection. Serological and nasal/throat tests are repeated after three and six weeks.

On July 1, Norway announced that Health personnel who comes from Sweden must be tested when they come to Norway. Specifically, Two tests are required after arrival in Norway with a minimum of 48 hours. Until the first negative test is available, the person must have a quarantine obligation. If the first test is negative, the person can work in Norway without prejudice to the quarantine obligation, but in his spare time the person must be in quarantine. If other tests are also negative, the person is exempt from the quarantine obligation both at work and in leisure time.

Starting June 17th, passengers will be required to use their own mouthwash on Norwegian flights. This is in line with the recommendations of European Aviation Authorities (EASA). SAS (Scandinavian Airlines) introduced mouthwash requirements on May 18th.

As of May 15th, only Norwegian citizens, permanent residents, critical personnel and people employed in Norway may travel from Svalbard (an archipelago part of the Kingdom of Norway) to mainland Norway.

On 31 January 2020, the Ministry of Health and Care Services delegated a mandate to the Directorate of Health to lead and coordinate the health sector's efforts in handling the outbreak of the coronavirus. Therefore, the authority of the Ministry of Health and Care Services in accordance with the mandate provisions in the Health Emergency Act has today been delegated to the Directorate of Health. The decision to use is given for a limited period and a maximum of 1 month.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 21, The Norwegian parliament (storting) adopted temporary legislation ('Coronavirus act') that will authorise the Government to carry out necessary and proportionate adaptive measures for a limited period to address the effects of the coronavirus.  Parliament gave therefore 'emergency powers' to government.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On April 20, the Norwegian Institute of Public Health creates a group for vaccination planning against covid-19.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On April 24, the Norwegian government has set up an independent commission ('Koronakomisjon') to get a thorough and comprehensive review and evaluation of the authorities' handling of the Covid 19 pandemic.The Commission will look at both the preparedness we had ahead of the pandemic and how the crisis was handled.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On June 5, the Norwegian Institute of public health announce that Norwegian municipalities have been given a new infection detection tool for use against coronavirus. It should make the infection detection easier. The tool will also mean that in Norway we will gradually get a national overview of where infection takes place. The tool is called DHIS2, which gives a better overview of the current infection situation.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description:
The first decision related to the corona eruption was adopted by the Ministry of Health and Care Services on 31 January, and amended two regulations:

Regulation 31 January 2020 No. 92 on amendments to the Regulations on Dangerous Infectious Diseases and Regulations on the Notification System for Infectious Diseases (MSIS Regulation)

The change meant that the 2019-nCoV (coronavirus) was added to a list that lists what should be considered as general-infectious diseases, and that the coronavirus was added to a list of serious systemic diseases that all doctors and laboratories are obliged to report on suspicion of infection or confirm the case.

The Norwegian authorities have contacted the EU to get Norway into the Re-open EU, the Union's overview of travel advice and restrictions during the corona crisis. The website is to help Europeans find out how they can travel and what rules apply was launched last week. As a foreign country, Norway is not included, but at the same time we are part of the Schengen area and are encouraged by the European Commission to open the borders in line with the other countries.

Norway's volunteer coronal line, the national emergency telephone that has relieved the Directorate of Health and answered corona issues, will be closed on June 30 due to lesser demand. The helpline was created by the National Association for Public Health, the Norwegian Women's Sanitary Association and the National Association for Heart and Lung Disease in mid-March.

Quarantine after traveling outside of Norway: The regulations apply to persons who have come to Norway after 27 February 2020. The regulations mean among others that persons who come to Norway from countries other than Sweden and Finland must stay in quarantine for 14 days after they came to Norway. This also applies to those who have come to Norway from Sweden and Finland who have been in other countries during the past 14 days.
On March 16, Norwegian government declared that all persons who had close contact (within 2m distance and longer than 15 minutes) with a COVID-19 patient have to go into self quarantine for 14 days.

As of May 15th, Norwegian citizens, permanent residents, critical personnel and people employed in Norway traveling to the mainland from Svalbard must spend 10 days in quarantine on arrival, either at home or in another suitable place.

Norway will decide by July 20th if travellers from other European countries than the Nordics can visit Norway this summer. For now, anyone who arrives in Norway from abroad must be in home quarantine. Exceptions include other Nordic countries (Denmark, Finland, Iceland, the Faroe Islands, Greenland,  "land, and the island Gotland in Sweden).

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Norway decided at the 26th of August that from the 29th of August that people arriving in Norway from Germany and Liechtenstein will be required to go into quarantine for 10 days. 
 Germany and Liechtenstein changed from  "yellow " to  "red " on the map showing the status for quarantine on entry to Norway from Europe.

On March 15, the Norwegian Directorate of Health has decided to close a number of businesses to stop the spread of corona virus disease (covid-19). 
The decision applies to the following public and private enterprises outside the specialist health service, unless the enterprise can comply with the health authorities' order on infection protection: a) Physiotherapists, including manual therapists b) Chiropractors c) Opticians d) Chiropodists e) Speech therapists f) Psychologists g) Companies that perform complementary and alternative medicine h) Companies that perform alternative treatment i) Other businesses outside the specialist health service that offer services that are not considered necessary health care where the service involves physical contact with persons less than two meters away and with a duration of more than 15 minutes, including dentists.

On April 8, the Norwegian government announced that the following businesses will be remained closed as decided on March 12: establishments in the hospitality industry, such as restaurant, bar, pub and nightlife (with the exception of places where food is served, ie canteens and eateries, which can facilitate visitors at least 1 meter distance, and food should not be served as a buffet), Gyms, Swimming pools, water parks (and the like), driver schools. 

On May 7, the Norwegian government annouced that from May 11 that Driving schools and  bingo halls and the like can open can be opened. They must follow the infection protection requirements that apply to other one-to-one contact businesses.
The Norwegian government is allowing foreign cruise ships to sail along the Norwegian Coast. The ships are not allowed to go to port or land crew or passengers.

On March 13, the Norwegian National police announced that all non-critical administrative services will be closed from Friday 13 March until Thursday 26 March. The services which are now closed includes the issuance of passports and emergency passports, submission of crime reports, immigration, firearms, lost property and enforcement services, and closure of the conciliation board.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 12, the Norwegian Directorate of Health has decided to ban and close: cultural events, Sports events and organized sports activities both indoors and outdoors, all establishments in the hospitality industry (with the exception of serving places where food is served, ie canteens and eateries, which can facilitate visitors at least 1 meter distance. Food should not be served as a buffet; The hospitality industry includes restaurant, bar, pub and nightlife). Gyms,  Companies that offer hairdressing services, skin care, massage and body care, tattooing, piercing and the like;  Swimming pools, water parks and the like.

As of July 3rd, the  Norwegian Ministry of Culture has extended the ban on football for 3rd Division Men and 2nd Division Women. Only top (professional) football is allowed to play and practice. This measure will be reevaluated in August.

On March 16, the Norwegian government agency 'Folkehelseinstituttet' announced/specified 3 levels of social distancing which have been implemented in society. These are: 1) population in general is not in quarantine, but should keep more distance than usual. 2) Those who may be infected but are not sick are quarantined. 3) Those who are ill must be in isolation. Generally, it is adivsed to keep oneself away from others, at work, outdoors and anywhere else. Furthermore, it is advised to limit the number of people you have close contact with and get to visit a few at a time.

On May 7, the Norwegian government announced that employers should ensure that employees can keep a distance of at least one meter throughout their working hours. In areas of the country where employees rely on public transport, employers are encouraged to facilitate home office and electronic meeting activities as much as possible, with physical presence in the workplace only when needed.

Norway has released new transportation tips when using public transport. The country has adopted a "traffic light model" to convey risk of infection - as of July 2nd the country is at the "yellow" level.

Poland is closing all schools and universities for two weeks. Speaking at a joint conference following a special meeting on coronavirus, the ministers said that pre-schools and schools would stop teaching on Thursday the 12th of March, but limited care would still be provided this week to the youngest children.
Update: From the 6th of May, kindergartens may reopen. Other schools and universities remain closed.
Poland is introducing a general lock-down: until April 11 inclusive, people will not be able to move freely outside their living, health and professional goals.
The Polish government is introducing a state of emergency in Poland on 13th of March.

From Sunday, 15 March, Poland will close its borders to foreigners. All Polish citizens who are presently abroad can return to their homeland. International passenger air flights and international rail travel will be suspended for 10 days, with possibility of extension.
Poland announces that it closes its borders for 10 days starting 15 March due to coronavirus. Poland is imposing border checks.
Polish government cancels all visa appointments as of 18th March 2020 until further notice.

The state of emergency in Poland due to Coronavirus has pushed the country to extend visas for all internationals who hold work permits, national visas, or a temporary residence permit, for 30 days after the end of the emergency state, Secretary of Management on Affairs of Foreigners Jakub Dudziak announced.

The Polish government is introducing sanitary controls at borders and airports on the 9th of March. The collected data will be used to contact the passengers in case that there is a risk of having the coronavirus.
In Poland, all procedures recommended by WHO have been implemented in the Polish health system.
On March 12, the Polish government announced that it has transformed 19 medical facilities into infectious hospitals specialised for corona patients.

The Ministry of Health and the Chief Sanitary Inspector announced that the Protective Vaccination Programme (the vaccination programme with compulsory vaccinations for young children) must be temporarily halted until the 18th of April.
On the 31st of March, the Polish government announced that stores that are still allowed to be open must offer disinfectant and rubber gloves to their customers.

The Polish Ministry of health announces a new online platform called 'Teleporada' on the 14th of April through which an online consultation with a medical worker can be arranged. People who have symptoms of corona can get a consultation without having to leave their house.

The Polish government announced on the 9th of April a requirement for people to cover their mouth and nose in public, beginning next Thursday the 16th of April. Asked about whether masks will be provided, health minister Lukasz Szumowski replied that a piece of material, such as a scarf, can be used instead.

The Office of the President of the Republic of Poland donated 50,000 protective face masks to Iraq "s health authorities, following Iraq "s request for support in response to the COVID-19 global pandemic.

On June 19, a plane loaded with medical supplies for Armenia took off from the airport of Wroclaw, Poland. The humanitarian aid includes 20,000 medical masks, 2,400 face shields and 2,700 liters of hand and face sanitizers.
On June 25th, Poland will use air transport to deliver to Azerbaijan surgical masks, visors and disinfectant liquid worth nearly 87,000 zlotys.

On June 29th, Poland sent critical medical assistance to Georgia, consisting of around 6,800 protective face shields and 5,400 litres of disinfectant detergent for hands and surface equipment, in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Poland announced on the 23rd of March that it would let some prisoners serve their sentences at home under electronic supervision to curb the spread of the coronavirus in prisons. Previously, only offenders serving a maximum of 1 years would qualify for electronic supervision at home, now offenders serving a maximum of 18 months qualify.

From 6th of April in Poland inmates have limited or suspended opportunities for employment outside prisons and are subjected to mandatory hand disinfection and temperature checks upon leaving and returning to prisons
As of the 20th of April, all minors under the age of 13 must be accompanied by an adult when going outside (before 20th of April this was all minors).

From June 27th to July 31st, The Polish Development Fund (PFR) will pay out some PLN 60 bln (EUR 13.5 bln) in government pandemic aid to small firms, out of the total of PLN 75 bln (EUR 16.8 bln) planned
As of July 24th, Poland will double the budget of the Fund for Local Investments to PLN 12 billion (EUR 2.7 billion).

Despite there not being confirmed corona cases yet, Poland has started quarantining people with symptoms or who are suspected cases. On February 27, 55 people were quarantined, after on the 25th of February the Ministry of Health urged people who thought they had symptoms to contact health centres. Update: On March 10, the police started enforcing this quarantine.

On the 23rd of March, the Polish government urges seniors to stay at home to avoid corona infection. The National Chamber of Physiotherapists and the Ministry of Health prepared the preventive program "Active senior at home" so that seniors can stay active within their houses.

Poland announced on the 26th of March that the housemates (family members or other persons you are living with) must also go into quarantine if one of the members of the household has been placed in quarantine.
On the 31st of March, the Polish government announced that minors (any Polish resident under the age of 18) will not be allowed to walk outside unaccompanied by an adult.
Poland is closing all theaters, cinemas, and museums, for two weeks to curtail spread of coronavirus, starting 12th of March.

Poland introduced a closure of public services; including bars, restaurants (excluding take-out), shops and spas on the 14th of March. Places of worship may stay open, but may not have more than 50 people at a gathering.

On the 14th of March a closure of non-essential businesses was announced, which included bars, restaurants, spas and most shops. On the 31st of March other businesses were included: Hotels, cosmetic and tattoo saloons, massage parlours and hairdressers must close. On the 20th of April: shops were allowed to open under restrictions. The other businesses remain closed for an undetermined period (including personal grooming, bars, spas etc).

On the 14th of March a closure of non essential businesses was announced by the Polish government, this was made stricter to include more businesses on the 31st of March. The Polish government has since in steps allowed certain business to open up. From the 4th of May restaurants/bars, fitness centres, recreational areas, cinemas, and personal grooming (hairdressers etc) remain closed.

On the 14th of March a closure of non essential businesses was announced by the Polish government, this was made stricter to include more businesses on the 31st of March. The Polish government has since in steps allowed certain business to open up. on 6th June it will open the remaining businesses: cinemas, theatres, operas, ballet, swimming pools, gyms, fitness clubs, play rooms, and theme parks. Fairs, exhibitions, and congresses will also be allowed. Saunas, solaria, tatoo and massage salons will also be opened (from 30th of May)

Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki decided on Tuesday March 10 to cancel all mass events in the country, among other preventive measures undertaken to contain the virus. A mass gathering is defined as at least 1000 people at locations other than buildings, or at least 500 people inside a building.

The Polish government is issuing a complete ban on gatherings of more than 2 persons from March 24th onwards. There are two exceptions: families (i.e. 2 parents walking with their 2 children is allowed) and places of worship (maximum of 5 people).
Poland imposes rules for public transport: travellers must keep enough distance so they must leave a row of seats between them. This means that only half the seats can be used.
Portugal "Council of Ministers changes the schedule for the  access to higher education in 2020"April 9 2020
The president of Portugal announced on March 18 the national state of emergency to last for 15 days.
Portugal issued a "ban on disembarking passengers from cruise ships, except for residents in Portugal" on March 13
The Prime Minister of Portugal Ant "nio Costa announced border closure with Spain for " leisure and tourism". March 15

Portugal "restores, on an exceptional and temporary basis, the documentary control of people at the borders in the context of the epidemiological situation caused by the new coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 and the disease COVID-19" March 16
Portugal suspends flights from outside the European Union on March 19 with the exception of destinations with a strong connection wot Portugal. Decree extended by 30 days on April 17.
Portugal "extends suspension of flights to Italy", March 24

Air transport will  be limited in Portugal during the period from 9 to 13 April. National airports will be closed, in an "exceptional measure that aims to prevent circulation from abroad to Portugal or from Portugal to abroad"

Portugal orders the "Immediate acquisition, by all hospital units of the National Health Service and the Ministry of Health, of medicines, medical devices and personal protective equipment, to reinforce their respective stocks by 20%" March 11

Portugal authorizes "the hiring of workers for the constitution of fixed-term employment bonds , for a period of four months, with a view to strengthening the human resources necessary to prevent, contain, mitigate and treat the pandemic COVID-19" March 15
The Minister of Labor, Solidarity and Social Security of Portugal, "determined the mobilization of the 16 inns of the INATEL Foundation"

Portugal approved a "exceptional and temporary regime for the design, manufacture, import, national marketing and use of medical devices for human use and personal protective equipment was approved." April 9
Portugal announces "Acquisitions and investments to provide the NHS hospitals with the necessary means to face the new coronavirus" April 10, 2020
Portugal announces that the "Number of beds in intensive care increased from 528 to 713" on May 9
The Portuguese Minister for the Environment and Climate Action announces regulations for public transportation. March 22

The Council of Ministers of Portugal announced on April 2 a "ban on any travel outside the municipality of habitual residence, except for people who have to travel to exercise professional activities", during the Easter period.
Portugal forbids "to circulate between municipalities on the weekend of the 1st of May" April 24

Portugal started the "organization of public services, namely the reinforcement of digital services, the establishment of frequency limitations to ensure the possibility of maintaining a safe distance and the centralization of information to citizens about the presence of services"
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Portugal started "monitoring the situation by a subcommittee, within the scope of the National Civil Protection Commission, on a permanent basis, as the structure responsible for collecting and processing information on the current epidemic outbreak, ensuring permanent monitoring of the situation"
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Portuguese Prime Minister has "appointed five Secretaries of State to coordinate regional implementation of the state of emergency"
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 13, Portugal increased in the readiness of the security forces and services and of all civil protection agents, with reinforcement of means for eventual support operations in the area of <U+200B><U+200B>public health.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Portugal "stablished exceptional and temporary measures related to the epidemiological situation of the new Coronavirus - COVID 19" March 13
On March 13, Portugal declared the National State of Alert, to last until April 9.
Portugal's Council of Ministers "approved a set of measures aimed at ensuring the mitigation of economic impacts, both in terms of supporting the treasury of companies and protecting jobs"
The Council of Ministers of Portugal "approved measures to support the social protection of workers and their families"March 13.

Portugal "The National Authority for Emergency and Civil Protection (ANEPC), in collaboration with the General Directorate of Health (DGS), is sending a warning to the population by SMS, in order to inform citizens about the risk situation related to the COVID 19 pandemic". March 17

The Portuguese Ministry of Internal Affairs - through GNR, PSP and SEF - "started this Thursday to distribute an information leaflet with the rules to be followed due to the state of emergency to prevent the contagion of the Covid-19 pandemic." March 26
On March 13, Portugal suspended "the operation of restaurants and drinks establishments that have rooms or spaces for dancing"
Portugal restricted the "functioning of discos and similar"
Portugal clones "bars every day at 9 pm" as of March 14
Portugal suspends "any and all activities of dentistry, stomatology and dentistry, with the exception of situations proven to be urgent" March 15
Portugal suspends !driving education and in-person training for the certification of professionals as a way of combating the epidemiological situation of the new coronavirus - COVID-19" March 15
Portugal orders shops and non essential businesses to close.
Portugal "regulates the situation of users of camping and caravan sites and motorhome service areas", only allowing permanent users to stay on the facilities. March 22
Portugal regulates "the operation of vending machines, and the activities of itinerant sellers and the rental of goods and passenger vehicles" March 23

The Prime Minister of Portugal  "referred to the decision to generalize teleworking to all civil servants" and "face-to-face service will only exist by appointment and the Citizen Stores will be closed" March 19
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Portuguese Minister for the Environment and Climate Action "signed three orders aimed at guaranteeing essential services to the country in the areas of water supply, urban waste management, energy, electricity, gas and fuel supply and also urban transportation", March 22
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Portugal's Dire " "o-Geral do Patrim "nio Cultural "informs that all national monuments, palaces and museums under its direct management are closed" March 14
Portugal's National Maritime Authority "forbids the gathering of people on the beaches" March 14.
Portugal Government "prohibits events with more than 100 people and alcohol consumption on the street" March 15
Portugal announced that "shopping centers and supermarkets will establish frequency limitations to ensure the possibility of maintaining a safe distance" on March 13
Portugal suspended the visits to  "homes across the national territory" as of March 13
Portugal "establishes an exceptional and temporary regime regarding the formalities of postal service" April 9

The Russian legislature passes amendments to the administrative and criminal codes on March 31 classifying violations related to epidemiological safety, states of alert or emergency, and the spread of misinformation related to such situations as administrative and/or criminal offenses with increasing punishments if said violations lead to deaths.
Russia on March 13 directs the Ministry of Education to prepare for the possibility of distance learning
Russia recommends grade schools move to distance learning on March 14.
Russia moves universities to online learning as of March 16
On March 19, the Russian Ministry of Education adopts a plan to combat coronavirus, including disinfection of buildings, health checks on employees, information flow, monitoring, and reporting.
On March 16, the Russian Ministry of Education postpones yearly Olympiad competitions for school students, to begin March 20, and plans to move the competitions online.

Russian schools will go on vacation until April 12 because of the coronavirus pandemic. This was stated by Minister of Education Sergei Kravtsov at a meeting of the working group to support regional education systems on Wednesday, March 18. Support will be organized for distance learning of schoolchildren and educational resources will be opened.

In Russia on March 18, the Ministry of Education announced that from March 23 to April 12, all primary and secondary schools are either on holiday or conducting distance learning. Vocational secondary schools are transferred to remote learning. Parents who cannot stay at home with their children will have the opportunity to send their students to school (schools will follow strict social distancing, hygiene, and health monitoring procedures).
Russia announces a holiday for schools from March 23-April 12.
Russian universities go on holiday from March 28-April 5

The Russian Ministry of Education recommends on March 27 that regional departments organize small group education and care for preschool and (if urgently needed) 1-4 graders whose parents will be working in essential jobs during the national days off. March 30-April 3.

In the Altai Republic of the Russian Federation, 20 March 2020, the Ministry of Education and Science of the Altai Republic informs that from April 1, 2020, to April 12, 2020, schools will be transferred to online remote learning

The Russian legislature passes amendments to the administrative and criminal codes on March 31 classifying violations related to epidemiological safety, states of alert or emergency, and the spread of misinformation related to such situations as administrative and/or criminal offenses with increasing punishments if said violations lead to deaths.

The Russian Ministry of Education sends recommendations for regulations and measures to its regional departments that should be followed when governors allow schools to re-open including small group work and social distancing. Final decisions on rules will be decided at the regional level.

The Russian Ministry of Education announces that schools can finish the school year ahead of schedule for grades 1 "8, but fourth-quarter material should be carried over to next year. Schools may also set annual grades  based on the results of the first three quarters (or two trimesters). For high school students, there will be no early end of the year.

The Russian Ministry of Education issues guidelines on April 30 for conducting certifications for college and vocational training via online methods for the 2019-2020 school year. The decisions as to whether traditional or online methods will be used is taken by the regional leaders.

The Russian Federal Service for the Supervision of Education and Science announced on April 29 that the final Russian language essay exams for 9th graders will be postponed from May 6 to May 25 on account of the national non-working days.
The Russian Federal Service for the Supervision of Education and Science announced on April 17 that standardized exams for 4-8 grades will be postponed until September.

The Russian government approved the procedure for remote/online defense of dissertations during the coronavirus on May 26 as a way to support students during the time of school and university closures.
The Russian legislature passes a law on March 31 allowing the Prime Minister's cabinet  (the Russian government) to declare a state of high alert or emergency.

The Russian legislature passes amendments to the administrative and criminal codes on March 31 classifying violations related to epidemiological safety, states of alert or emergency, and the spread of misinformation related to such situations as administrative and/or criminal offenses with increasing punishments if said violations lead to deaths.

The Russian president passes a decree giving governors the power to declare states of emergency in their regions (e.g. suspend the operation of organizations, limit the movement of people and vehicles) from the period April 4-30.
Russia begins inspecting airline passengers with travel history in China (previous 14 days), from December 31, 2019
Russia introduces increased sanitary-quarantine control at all border checkpoints from January 9.
Russia recommends on January 21 Russian travelers to China take increased precautions (issues a specific list) and recommends not traveling to Wuhan
On January 24, Rospotrebnadzor recommends Russian travelers refrain from traveling to China.

On January 29, the Russian Task Force on coronavirus instructed Rosselkhoznadzor to ensure, until March 1, 2020, a temporary restriction on the import and transit through the territory of the Russian Federation of all species of exotic and decorative animals, insects, and arthropods, as well as fish and aquatic organisms from China.

Starting February 1, Russia requires all passengers arriving from China to undergo lab test upon arrival (at the airport), after which they are transferred under medical supervision to place of residence for 14 days.
Russia closes the Mongolian border checkpoints to Chinese citizens (except those with Russian residence permits) from February 1.

Russia limits air traffic between Russia and China with the exception of Aeroflot's flights to/from Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Hong Kong, and 4 Chinese airlines that can fly to Moscow Sheremetyevo, beginning February 1.

Russia discontinues visa-free entry for tourists, issuing permission for Russia employers to hire foreign workers, issuing visa invitations, and the accepting of documents for work visas for any Chinese citizens, from February 2.

Russia institutes a travel ban on all foreigners coming from China, with the exception of citizens of member states of the Eurasian Economic Union, as well as crews of aircraft, members of the official delegations and persons holding a residence permit, from February 4.
Russia introduces a ban on charter flights to/from China from February 14.
The Russian government recommends its citizens refrain from traveling to Iran, beginning February 26.
The Russian government recommends its citizens refrain from traveling to Italy, beginning February 26.
Russian introduces enhanced control and medical supervision of citizens arriving from the Islamic Republic of Iran, the Republic of Korea, Italian Republic
The Russian government recommends its citizens refrain from traveling to South Korea, beginning February 26.

Russia temporary restricts entry of foreign citizens traveling from Iran by air, with the exception of Eurasian Economic Union citizens, flight crews, diplomatic persons, and those with a Russian residence permits. Flights are limited to those operated by Aeroflot and Mahan (Iranian) Airlines into Moscow Sheremetyevo airport, from February 28
Russia introduces visa restrictions for citizens of Iran for work, tourism, private, and transit purposes from February 28.

Russia temporary restricts entry of foreign citizens traveling from South Korea by air, with the exception of Eurasian Economic Union citizens, flight crews, diplomatic persons, and those with a Russian residence permits. Flights are limited to those operated by Aeroflot into Moscow Sheremetyevo airport (and subsidiary charter carriers for the purpose of repatriating citizens), from March 1
Russia suspends its train service from Moscow to Nice (France) starting March 4 until further notice.
Residents of the Altai Territory are recommended to temporarily refrain from trips to China, Korea, Iran and Italy.

Russia closes the border with Iran, allowing only those foreign citizens who are a part of the Eurasian Economic Union, flight crews, diplomatic persons, and those with Russian residence permits to enter or transit through Russia, from March 7.
Russia recommends all government workers to cancel travel to countries affected by coronavirus from March 10.
Russia directs its government officials to cancel all non-urgent/priority international travel from March 10.

Russia closes the border with Italy from March 13 (for all foreign citizens with some exceptions: Italians with business or humanitarian visas, Eurasian Economic Union citizens, flight crews, diplomatic persons, foreigners with Russian residence permit).
Russia, from March 13, places a ban on issuing visas to Italian citizens except for business, humanitarian, diplomatic and business visas
Russia restricts air travel (only through Moscow/Sheremetyevo airport and charter flights for repatriation) to/from Italy, Germany, Spain, France from March 13
The Russian Prime Minister urges citizens to refrain from traveling abroad on March 14.

Russia closes land borders (to foreigners coming for work, tourism, or private purposes) with Poland and Norway from 15 March, with the exception of Belarussian citizens, diplomatic persons, and those with Russian residence permits.
From March 16, Russia runs trains from its non-contiguous region of Kaliningrad through Lithuania without stops.
On March 16, Russia closes border with Belarus indefinitely.
Russia, from March 16, restricts flights to/from Norway, Switzerland, and all EU countries tp flights into Moscow Sheremetyevo, and charter flights for purpose of repatriation
Tomsk region enforces to send employees on business trips abroad and to Russian regions that are in high risk due to a new coronavirus infection, in exceptional cases only.

In the Altai Republic of the Russian Federation, 19 March 2020, complying to the order of the government of the Russian Federation that restricted entering Russia for foreign citizens and stateless persons from 18 March 2020 to 1 May 2020, the "Tashanta"  border checkpoint of the Altai Republic (Russian-Mongolian border) is closed for foreign citizens and stateless person, according to the press service of the Border Service of the Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation. 
Entering Russia is allowed for people who are visiting a close relatives' funeral when providing a document that confirms the death of a relative.

On March 16, the Russian Government announces it will close its borders from March 18-May 1 to foreign citizens with a few exceptions (diplomatic missions and consular posts in the Russian Federation, drivers of cars of international automobile traffic, crews of aircraft, sea and river vessels, train and locomotive brigades of international railway traffic, members of official delegations and persons having diplomatic, official, ordinary private visas issued in connection with the death of a close relative, persons permanently residing in the territory and the Russian Federation, as well as persons traveling in transit through air border crossing points)

In the Altai Republic of the Russian Federation, 19 March 2020, complying to the order of the government of the Russian Federation that restricted entering Russia for foreign citizens and stateless persons from 18 March to 1 May 2020, the "Tashanta"  border checkpoint of the Altai Republic is closed for foreign citizens and stateless person, according to the press service of the Border Service of the Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation. 
Entering Russia is allowed for members of diplomatic service and their family, and members of official delegations
Russia closes Its border to foreigners from March 18 to May 1, with few exceptions

In the Altai Republic of the Russian Federation, 19 March 2020, complying to the order of the government of the Russian Federation that restricted entering Russia for foreign citizens and stateless persons from 18 March 2020 to 1 May 2020, the "Tashanta"  border checkpoint of the Altai Republic (Russian-Mongolian border) is closed for foreign citizens and stateless person, according to the press service of the Border Service of the Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation. 
Entering Russia is allowed for drivers of cargo transport services of international road service.

In the Altai Republic of the Russian Federation, 19 March 2020, complying to the order of the government of the Russian Federation that restricted entering Russia for foreign citizens and stateless persons from 18 March 2020 to 1 May 2020, the "Tashanta"  border checkpoint of the Altai Republic (Russian-Mongolian border) is closed for foreign citizens and stateless person, according to the press service of the Border Service of the Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation. 
Entering Russia is allowed for citizens of Russia coming from trips abroad and people with the permanent residency permit.

In the Altai Republic of the Russian Federation, 19 March 2020, complying to the order of the government of the Russian Federation that restricted entering Russia for foreign citizens and stateless persons from 18 March to 1 May, the "Tashanta"  border checkpoint of the Altai Republic (Russian-Mongolian border) is closed for foreign citizens and stateless person, according to the press service of the Border Service of the Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation. 
Entering the Russian Federation is allowed for members of diplomatic service and their family, and members of official delegations.
Despite border closures from March 18-May 1, starting March 29 Russia allows citizens of Ukraine and stateless persons living in the Donetsk and Lugansk regions of Ukraine to enter Russia.
Russia restricts flights to/from the US, UK, and UAE, except for those into Moscow's Sheremetyevo airport and charter flights for the purpose of repatriating citizens from March 20

Despite border closures from March 18-May 1, starting March 20 Russia allows citizens of Commonwealth of Independent States countries and Abkhazia and South Ossetia to enter Russia as long as they are en route to their home country.

Russia's Federal Air Transport Agency announced on March 22 that passenger air travel would be suspended from March 23 with the exception of flights to and from Moscow and exempted locations, and charter flights for the purpose of repatriation.

Russia's Federal Air Transport Agency announced on March 26 that as of March 27 all regular and charter air traffic is suspended with the exception of repatriation flights and as well as cargo, mail, sanitary, humanitarian flights, haulage of empty aircraft for maintenance, transit flights with landing for refueling (crew changes) in the Russian Federation and flights carried out according to individual decisions of the Government of the Russian Federation.

In Russia, the Government decided on March 27 to temporarily restrict movement through automobile, rail, pedestrian, river and mixed checkpoints across the state border of the Russian Federation, as well as through the land section of the Russian-Belarusian state border with certain exceptions.
Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being (Rospotrebnadzor) issues quotas for maximum number of Russians returning per day beginning April 1.
On April 6, Russia suspends train travel to/from the non-territorially contiguous region of Kaliningrad because it requires travel across international borders and through Lithuania.

In Russia, by presidential decree, it is decided on April 18 that foreign citizens migration status is extended from March 15 to June 15 including period of legal stay, registration, migration cards, certificates of refugee or compatriot migration status, work documents, and deportation orders. Foreign citizens without work documents are allowed to work. No new migration violations will be conferred (no new deportation or expulsion orders)

In Russia, a change to the migration legislation is introduced on April 24 as a permanent amendment, allowing workers from visa-free countries of the former Soviet Commonwealth of Independence States to renew their work documents (patents) repeatedly each year (no limit on the number of renewals) without leaving the country.

President Vladimir Putin has extended the period in which foreign nationals whose Russian visas expired after March 15 can stay in the country. Foreigners already in Russia will now have their visas automatically extended through Sept. 15.

On July 1, the Russian government decides that trains will begin running to Kaliningrad (the non-territorially contiguous region in Europe) from Moscow and St. Petersburg, but only those who permanently reside in Kaliningrad are allowed to travel. The policy regulates external borders since the trains must travel across multiple international borders.

The Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin signed a decree on July 24 to resume issuing visas and allow entry into Russia for citizens of the UK, Turkey, and Tanzenia. All other restrictions on foreign citizens remain in place, with exceptions for certain categories of people (diplomats, employees of international organizations, transport crews, family members of Russian citizens, permanent residents who are in transit, and certain categories of citizens who have visa-free privileges, participants of the migrant repatriation program, athletes and coaches, transit passengers, Belarussian citizens working for resource companies, employees of the Baikonur space center in Kazakhstan, those seeking medical treatment, those who need to care for close family members who are ill, and highly qualified specialists on a list approved by the Federal Security Service and Ministry of Internal Affairs). The policy ends August 1 when it is superseded by a new policy that allows citizens of Switzerland and Abkhazia to enter Russia.

The Government of the Russian Federation decided on July 24 to resume international flights from August 1. Air traffic from the airports of Moscow, Moscow Region, St. Petersburg, and Rostov-on-Don to the UK (London), Turkey (Istanbul and Ankara), and Tanzania (Zanzibar) will resume from 00 h. 00 min. On August 10, 2020, flights from these Russian cities to Antalya, Dalaman, and Bodrum (Republic of Turkey) will also resume.

The Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin signed a decree on August 1 adding citizens and permanent residents of Switzerland and Abkhazia to the list of those allowed entry into Russia (prior only available to UK, Turkey, and Tanzenia). All other restrictions on foreign citizens remain in place, including exceptions for certain categories of people (diplomats, employees of international organizations, transport crews, family members of Russian citizens, permanent residents who are in transit, and certain categories of citizens who have visa-free privileges, participants of the migrant repatriation program, athletes and coaches, transit passengers, Belarussian citizens working for resource companies, employees of the Baikonur space center in Kazakhstan, those seeking medical treatment, those who need to care for close family members who are ill, and highly qualified specialists on a list approved by the Federal Security Service and Ministry of Internal Affairs). The policy ends September 2 when new policies are passed allowing additional countries citizens' to enter Russia (Egypt, Maldives, and UAE)

The Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin signed a decree on September 2 to resume issuing visas and allow entry into Russia for citizens of the UAE, Egypt, and the Maldives (adding these to the list of UK, Turkey, Tanzenia and Switzerland, and residents of Abkhazia--Georgia and Donetsk/Lugansk--Ukraine). All other restrictions on foreign citizens remain in place, with exceptions for certain categories of people (diplomats, employees of international organizations, transport crews, family members of Russian citizens, permanent residents who are in transit, and certain categories of citizens who have visa-free privileges, participants of the migrant repatriation program, athletes and coaches, transit passengers, Belarussian citizens working for resource companies, employees of the Baikonur space center in Kazakhstan, those seeking medical treatment, those who need to care for close family members who are ill, and highly qualified specialists on a list approved by the Federal Security Service and Ministry of Internal Affairs). The policy ends September 12 when it is superseded by a new policy adding South Ossetia to the list of permitted countries.

The Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin signed a decree on September 12 to open borders with South Ossetia (Georgia), adding this opening to the list of countries with Russia resumes issuing visas and allow entry into Russia (citizens of the UAE, Egypt, the Maldives, UK, Turkey, Tanzenia and Switzerland, and residents of Abkhazia--Georgia and Donetsk/Lugansk--Ukraine). All other restrictions on foreign citizens remain in place, with exceptions for certain categories of people (diplomats, employees of international organizations, transport crews, family members of Russian citizens, permanent residents who are in transit, and certain categories of citizens who have visa-free privileges, participants of the migrant repatriation program, athletes and coaches, transit passengers, Belarussian citizens working for resource companies, employees of the Baikonur space center in Kazakhstan, those seeking medical treatment, those who need to care for close family members who are ill, and highly qualified specialists on a list a
Russia recommends that regional governments monitor Chinese students returning from New Years holidays from January 24.

On January 30, the Russian Ministry of Health issues temporary recommendations for treating coronavirus and distributes informational materials to the regions. The guidelines are an effort to manage health resources in the prevention of coronavirus.
In Russia, those in contact (not close, e.g. work) with diagnosed patients are monitored in their homes for 14 days beginning January 31.
On January 31, Russia's head sanitary doctor recommends medical monitoring at home or isolation 14 days for those returning from China

Starting February 1, Russia requires all passengers arriving from China to undergo lab test upon arrival (at the airport), after which they are transferred under medical supervision to place of residence for 14 days.
In Russia, all arriving travelers returning from Iran and South Korea undergo medical monitoring for 14 days beginning March 2
Russia introduces a new electronic form and registration via mobile phone to track those (citizens) coming into the country and monitor their quarantine/isolation from March 30.

The Russian legislature passes amendments to the administrative and criminal codes on March 31 classifying violations related to epidemiological safety, states of alert or emergency, and the spread of misinformation related to such situations as administrative and/or criminal offenses with increasing punishments if said violations lead to deaths.

The Russian legislature passes amendments to the administrative and criminal codes on March 31 classifying violations related to epidemiological safety, states of alert or emergency, and the spread of misinformation related to such situations as administrative and/or criminal offenses with increasing punishments if said violations lead to deaths.
Russia develops a test kit to diagnose coronavirus on January 21.

Russia directs its regional governments to preparing medical facilities, supplies, and staff (including transportation and infrastructure), and assess their readiness to meet an epidemiological crisis from January 24.
Russia begins offering translation services (Russian-Chinese) to assist with recording the medical history of suspected coronavirus patients from January 29
Russia directs its regional governments to create quarantine facilities and transportation to them from border checkpoints, as of January 31.
Russia recommends increasing medical personnel to conduct home health checks of those returning from China, from January 31.
Russia adopts a National Plan on January 31 to combat the coronavirus, which includes preparation of adequate supplies of medical resources.
In Moscow (Russia) airport Sheremetyevo, terminal F is designated as place for incoming flights that need increased sanitary-quarantine measures from February 1.
Russia directs its regional governments to conduct education courses for medical professionals on the diagnosis, treatment and prevention of coronavirus from March 2.
Russia directs its regional governments to hire additional medical personnel to meet the needs of coronavirus monitoring and treatment beginning March 2.
Russia enacts a ban on the export of respirators, medical masks, gloves,  protective suits, etc. (except that allocated for humanitarian aid) from 2 March.
Russia directs its regional governments (i.e. governors) to create hotlines for citizens to report cases of coronavirus.
On March 14, Russia directs the regional governments of Moscow (city and region) to provide employees of individual medical organizations advanced training courses on biosafety

On April 18, the Russian government passed a resolution to simplify and speed up the duty-free import of medical products including tests for COVID-19, artificial ventilation devices, medical masks, and protective suits. From March 16 to September 30, such products can be imported without paying customs duties, provided that they are intended for direct transfer to medical institutions. The intended purpose of the goods must be confirmed by a special document. Previously, such documents were issued by regional governments. Now such powers are also assigned to the Ministry of Industry and Trade and the Ministry of Health.

On March 16, the Russian government authorized "hospitals to treat coronavirus patients with an unregistered batch of generic hydroxychloroquine from China, assuring people that the Chinese formulation meets international standards and is similar to formulations already approved and registered in Russia. The safety and effectiveness of the treatment will be monitored by the Federal Service for Surveillance in Healthcare (Roszdravnadzor).

Beginning March 16, specialists of the Scientific and Research Center for Pulmonology and Infectious Diseases of the Ministry of Health of Russia will conduct distance seminars and round-the-clock consultations for medical workers in the regions.

The Russian Ministry of Health passes an order on March 16 establishing federal remote advisory centers for COVID-19 and pneumonia to assist with diagnosis and treatment, operating under a single call-center number, and recommending that regional similar call centers are established in the regions to coordinate with the federal centers.
On March 16, the Russian Ministry of Health announces that infectious and resuscitation services have been put on high alert.

On March 17, in order to increase access to health resources, the Russian President passes a decree allowing the retail sale of over-the-counter medicines online by authorized pharmacies. The decree directs the government to establish a procedure to issue permits (which was later introduced as Federal Law #105 on April 3).

The Russian government passed a decree on March 18 allowing expedited registration of 36 types of medical equipment including insulating and surgical suits, insulating and operating gowns, surgical and examination clothing sets, masks, shoe covers, respirators and gloves.

On March 18, the Russian government allocates 1.6 billion rubles to subsidiary organization the Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being to distribute as incentive payments for health care workers.
On March 18, the Russian government allocates 10.2 billion rubles to the Ministry of Health to distribute to the regions for incentive payments for health care workers.

On March 20, the Russian government announces that it is preparing teaching materials for its regional governments to train and prepare health workers to treat coronavirus as a way to bolster health resources.
On March 20, Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being announces it will begin testing a coronavirus vaccine.

Russia "continues the construction of a new multifunctional medical center in the Orenburg region.
On March 20, in the regional center on the territory of the hospital on Parkovoy Avenue, the construction of a two-story multifunctional medical center for 60 beds began. This is one of the centers that are currently being built on behalf of the President of Russia and the order of the Minister of Defense in different regions of the country.
In addition to the medical center itself, a free-standing car disinfection point is also being erected, as well as a sewage treatment station. In addition, military builders will carry out landscaping work: the green area will be 2825 m2.
In parallel with the construction, the supply of medical equipment was organized: computer tomographs, anesthesiology devices, endoscopy, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, and X-ray complexes. A stock of medicines is being formed. Medical personnel are undergoing advanced training courses at the S.M. Kirov in St. Petersburg." The health resources policy takes effect starting from March 20.

On March 21, in order to increase health resources, the Government of Russia allocates 5 billion rubles from its reserve fund to the Ministry of Industry and Trade for the purchase of thermometry devices, non-contact thermometers and air disinfection units. The sole contractor for the equipment will be Joint Stock Company Shvabe until December 31, 2020. The Ministry of Industry and Trade may pre-pay the contract in full.
On March 21, the Russian Government cancels the yearly medical exam/check-up for the adult population in order to divert health resources to treating coronavirus patients.

On March 21, in order to increase health resources, the Government of Russia allocates 7.5 billion rubles from its reserve fund to the Ministry of Industry and Trade for the purchase of ventilators and ECMO machines.

Russia "In order to ensure the protection of public health and the non-proliferation of the new coronavirus infection (COVID-19) in the Russian Federation:
the highest executive bodies of state power of the subjects of the Russian Federation to ensure the temporary suspension of preventive medical examinations and clinical examination of certain groups of the adult population in medical organizations participating in the implementation of territorial programs of state guarantees of free provision of medical care to citizens." The health resources policy takes effect starting from March 21.

The Russian Ministry of Health made recommendations on March 19 that doctors throughout the country provide prescription medications either electronically or in 3 month supplies with monitoring by telephone.
The Russian government announces that as of March 23, 5 test systems have been developed and licensed for diagnosing coronavirus.

Russia's Ministry of Health announces on March 23 the start of production of a new test system for the diagnosis of coronavirus by AmpliTest SARS-CoV-2 Polymerase Chain Reaction. The new test system differs from analogues available on the market at the time by its higher sensitivity to RNA coronavirus. The planned production capacity is up to 50 thousand tests per day.

On March 23, as an effort to increase health resources, the Russian government directs the Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being to research whether alcohol-containing products (including cosmetics) can be repurposed for disinfection purposes

The Russian government directs regional leaders (governors, mayors) on March 23 to prioritize the distribution of masks and PPE to medical personnel and those at risk of coronavirus (those in contact with infected people, or showing signs of illness). These efforts are made to ensure health resources are distributed as needed.

On March 23, the Russian government organizes quarantine facilities to house all returnees as part of organizing the repatriation of citizens from abroad. These measures increase the health resources in the country.
