The Russian Government announces that as of March 23, there are 15 laboratories that can process coronavirus tests throughout the country.

On March 23, as an effort to increase health resources, the Russian government directs the Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being to research whether medicines could be used outside their normal indications to treat coronavirus symptoms.

The Russian Ministry of Health together with the Ministry of Communications launched an electronic coronavirus service for citizens, announced on March 24, that utilizes the public services portal (www.gosuslugi.ru) to provide a special "coronavirus services "including determining risk categories, and a diary of health monitoring. Connecting these services to a medical ID number is intended to help provide seamless care if medical intervention is needed.

Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being changes testing protocols so that tests originating in  tests from Central Federal District, North-Western Federal District, North-Western Federal District and North-Western Federal District are sent to Moscow for a 2nd test confirmation (instead of the "Vector" lab in Novosibirsk, Siberia) beginning March 24.

On March 25, the Russian government allocates 1.4 billion rubles from its reserve fund the Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being in order to support the work towards the prevention and diagnosis of new coronavirus infection. This is a measure to increase health resources .

On March 26, the Russian legislature passes amendments to federal laws allowing the government to intervene and regulate maximum prices of medicines and medical equipment, as a way to manage health resources.
In an effort to increase health resources (test kits), manufacturers began the production of additional and improved test systems (with a reduced pre-analytical phase) on March 27.
Russia ensures the continuous supply of testing materials (consumables) to its regions from March 27.

The Russian Minister of Health announces changes on March 27 to the medical protocols recommended to the regions, including new procedures to treat mild coronavirus cases on an outpatient basis. He reminds regional health care officials that they are personally responsible for implementing Ministry of Health directives and should not delegate decisionmaking.
From March 30, the Russian government begins to provide health resources to closed cities and monotowns, including personal protective equipment, test systems and medical equipment.

The Russian Ministry of Health deploys 40,000 medical workers, mobilizing those completing their education at medical universities and secondary educational institutions, including resident doctors and specialists undergoing postgraduate studies, beginning March 30.
In order to increase health resources, on March 30 Russia extends permission to domestic manufacturers to produce test tubes for coronavirus testing.
On March 30, Russia's Federal Medical and Biological Agency announced it had opened 3 centers exclusively for coronavirus patients in order to increase health resources in the country.

In order to increase health resources, on March 30 Russia's Federal Medical and Biological Agency allocates an additional 2595 beds for coronavirus patients (total of 3633 beds: 600 resuscitation beds, 506 equipped with mechanical ventilation, 1339 beds with oxygen that can be converted to resuscitation beds).
In order to ensure an adequate supply of health resources, on March 30 the Russian government creates a biweekly schedule for providing medical organizations with masks.
The Russian Ministry of Health announced on March 30 that it had increased the capacity of health resources in the country to 100,000 hospital beds for coronavirus patients.
In order to increase health resources (test kits), Russia's Federal Service for Surveillance in Healthcare issued permits to seven domestic companies for the production of test systems on March 30.

To address increasing needs for health resources, "on March 30 the Russian government announced it is organizing the procurement of 79 mechanical ventilation apparatuses (IVL) and 10 extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) machines.

The Russian government establishes rules on March 31 that specify how information should be collected from coronavirus patients, establishing a standard form to be used by practitioners to gather health and contact data.

On March 31, the Russian Ministry of Health announced that medical students would begin assisting in the fight against coronavirus by working on hotlines and with remote monitoring of outpatient care as a part of their residency programs. Among other things, students will be able to take part in consulting support of the population on the issues of organizing medical care, including advising those who are on self-isolation, preparing information messages, conducting preventive and awareness-raising activities among the population, delivering food, medicines, and essentials those who are on self-isolation.

The Russian legislature passes a law on March 31 giving heads of regions (e.g. governors) the right to set extraordinary deadlines for medical organizations applying for inclusion into the state insurance system, and gives governors increased control over funds transfers to medical organizations, during states of high alert or emergency.

The Russian Ministry of Health announced on April 1 as a part of the ongoing effort to reallocate health resources, that seriously ill patients currently in federal medical centers that will be temporarily reassigned to treat patients with coronavirus will be transferred to other hospitals in Moscow to continue treatment.

The Russian legislature passes amendments to the administrative and criminal codes on March 31 classifying violations related to the sale of pharmaceutical products and advertisement of counterfeit products as administrative and/or criminal offenses.
The Russian government announces plans on March 30 to repurpose medical facilities to treat coronavirus patients beginning April 1
The head of Republic of Tyva announced on April 1 that there are 80 ventilators in Tuva, another 82 units are expected to arrive through the Ministry of Health of Russia.
The Russian government announces it has increased testing capacity to 36,000 tests per day through around 300 lab facilities, not including commercial labs, from April 1.
The Russian government allocates 5.2 billion rubles on April 1 to buy and deliver 1,200 ambulances throughout the country.

On March 21, in order to increase health resources, the Government of Russia allocates 10 billion rubles from its reserve fund to the Ministry of Trade for the production and purchase of equipment and products for the diagnosis, detection, prevention and treatment of epidemic diseases, personal protective equipment, medicines and medical devices (both domestic and import purchases).
The Russian legislature passes a law on March 31 giving the government control over medicines and medical devices, and their registrations, during a state of alert or emergency
In order to increase health resources, the Russian government announces that coronavirus testing will begin at Moscow's new infectious disease hospital in Kommunarka from April 2.
On April 3, to regulate health resources, the Russian Government adopts rules on the circulation of medicines used in emergency or epidemic situations, including the regulation of prices.

On April 3, the Russian government adopted a resolution to simplify the procurement, import, batch registration, and sale of medical devices that can be used to fight coronavirus in order to increase health resources in the country.

In order to respond to the Russian government's direction on March 23 to increase access to testing for coronavirus, the Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Wellbeing implements a procedure on April 3 to register private labs to begin testing.

To bolster the country's health resources, on April 3, the Russian government allocates 321 million rubles to the Federal Medical-Biological Agency (under the Ministry of Health) for incentive payments to medical workers.
On April 3, the Russian Prime Minister cancels the VAT (value-added tax) on the import and domestic sale of essential medicines and medical supplies in order to increase access to health resources.

The Russian government announces the organization and funding (allocating 242 million rubles) of a volunteer effort that envisions 15,000 volunteers serving 200,000  citizens over 60 through help at home, including the purchase of products, medicines and other essentials.
In response to increasing consumer demand for medical devices such as ventilators, the Russian government places restriction on the wholesale and retail trade of medical devices on April 3.

The Russian government announces 14 hospitals (3,853 beds) in Moscow are reallocated to serve coronavirus patients from April 6, an additional 13 hospitals (5628 beds) from April 13, and 5 hospitals (836 beds) after April 15.
The Russian Government suspends preventative medical visits as of April 6 in order to preserve health resources for the treatment of coronavirus patients.

Russia's "Federal Service for Surveillance in Healthcare (Rosdravnadzor) has developed an "express" coronavirus test that can test at 94% accuracy within 40 minutes. The Ministry of Industry and Trade announced the registration on April 6.

The Russian Ministry of Health on April 8 directs that medical waste generated during the treatment of COVID-19 should be managed as class B medical waste for the collection of waste, methods and method of disinfection, temporary storage and transportation. Class B medical waste includes: Materials in contact with patients with infectious diseases; wastes from laboratories, pharmaceutical and immunobiological productions working with microorganisms of 1-2 groups of pathogenicity; Wastes from the medical and diagnostic units of tuberculosis hospitals (dispensaries), contaminated by sputum of patients, wastes from microbiological laboratories

The Russian government announces on April 8 that medical workers will receive similar insurance coverage to those in the military. The Ministry of Health is directed to submit draft legislation by April 9.

Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Wellbeing announces on April 9 that any lab can process coronavirus tests upon filing a notification with the Service in order to increase health resources in the country. Labs that organize tests must report results to the Service. As of this announcement  222 labs were already processing tests.

The Russian Federal Air Transport Agency on April 10 approved the modification of the standard design of the Ansat helicopter to expand the applications to medical aviation and increase health resources in the country, including the ability to transport isolation boxes.

On April 17, Russia announced a new antibody test developed by the Novosibirsk State Research Center of Virology and Biotechnology "Vector" and tested on 200 medical workers of the National Medical and Surgical Center N.I. Pirogov. The test system "SARS-CoV-2-ELISA-Vector" uses  the method of enzyme immunoassay (ELISA) and was registered by the Federal Service for Surveillance in Healthcare (Roszdravnadzor) on April 10, 2020.

On April 12, the Russian Government allocated 640 million rubles from the reserve fund to repurpose medical organizations located in closed administrative-territorial entities. The Federal Medical-Biological Agency is to report the results to the government by February 1, 2021.

On April 13, the Russian Ministry of Health announces that a group of leading Russian scientists and clinicians have prepared "temporary guidelines " "Drug treatment of acute respiratory viral infections (ARVI) in outpatient practice during the COVID-19 epidemic. " "The manual includes information on the differential diagnosis of SARS caused by influenza virus, other viruses (rhinovirus, adenovirus, parainfluenza, human metapneumoviruses) and bacterial pathogens, and COVID-19.

On April 13, the Russian government allocated funds to medical institutions of the Ministry of Defense (2.3 billion rubles), Federal Guard Service (Rosgvardia) (22 million rubles), Federal Medical-Biological Agency (284 million rubles), Federal Security Service (120 million rubles), Federal Penitentiary Service (223 million rubles), and the Office of the President (195 million rubles) for payments to physicians working with coronavirus patients.
In Russia, on April 15 a temporary procedure for the distribution of coronavirus tests was established by the government as a way to increase the health resources in the country.

On May 15, the Russian government allocated more than 7.6 billion rubles for bonuses to employees of inpatient social institutions including doctors, nurses, lab techs, social workers, teachers, and other personnel. Different amounts are paid depending on whether cases of coronavirus are detected in the institutions.

On April 15, the Russian Ministry of Health and Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Wellbeing approve the sale of fabric ("hygiene") masks in pharmacies, made of textile materials, knitwear, non-woven material and implemented in accordance with established requirements. This will increase access to health resources.

On April 16, the Russian Ministry of Health recommends that regional health care systems consider whether they should temporarily suspend childhood vaccination programs and what precautions might be necessary if the programs go forward. This measure is meant to divert health care resources to the care of coronavirus patients and to prevent further spread.

The Russian legislature passes an amendment to the Tax Code on April 22, allowing tax exemptions for the purchase of medical devices and  disinfection equipment, and incentive and stimulus payments made to medical workers and small/medium sized businesses. It also allows these taxpayers to pay quarterly instead of monthly. These efforts support the acquisition and maintenance of health resources.

The Russian Ministry of Health announced on April 24 that it had developed "methodological recommendations "on the diagnosis and treatment of coronavirus in children. These protocols serve as a health resource to systematize treatment across the country.

The Russian Ministry of Health issued guidelines on April 24 for medical care of pregnant women, women in labor, women in childbirth and newborns with a new coronavirus infection COVID-19. This contributes to health resources by providing protocols for treatment.
On April 24, the Russian government designates a total of 51 hospitals in 28 regions of the country that will be redesigned and used for the treatment of coronavirus patients.

The Russian Ministry of Health announces on April 27 that the first license for production of biomedical cell products is issued in Russia by the Federal Service for Surveillance in Healthcare to a Russian pharmaceutical company. Biomedical cell products can be autologous (related), allogeneic (non-related), and combined.  Allogeneic products are widely studied and used worldwide for the treatment of systemic diseases, such as gonarthrosis, cardiovascular diseases, gastrointestinal diseases, and severe life-threatening conditions, such as acute myocardial infarction or ARDS, which is one of the main complications in severe COVID -19.

The Russian Ministry of Health announced on April 28 that it has approved clinical trials of a drug for the treatment of COVID-19. The Russian Ministry of Health issued a permit to a Russian pharmaceutical manufacturer to conduct an adaptive multicenter randomized open comparative clinical trial of the efficacy and safety of the antiviral drug favipiravir in patients hospitalized with COVID-19. A clinical study will be held in 17 medical institutions in several regions of Russia. 

Favipiravir is a chemical that is used as an antiviral drug against various types of RNA viruses. The drug was developed as an anti-influenza drug with effectiveness against severe infections caused by high viral load, and was previously approved as an influenza drug in Japan. According to Chinese scientists, the drug has been shown to be effective in treating patients with COVID-19.

The Ministry of Health announced on May 9 that a "group of specialists from the Ministry of Health of Russia and the Federal Service for Surveillance in Healthcare (Roszdravnadzor) sent to the Republic of Dagestan by the Minister of Health Mikhail Murashko "completed the work on organizing the provision of medical care to patients with "coronavirus.
The Russian Ministry of Health announces on May 10 that it has taken direct control of the provision of medicines for patients with coronavirus in Dagestan. "

In Russia on May 18, Alexander Gintsburg, the Ministry of Health's Director of the Institute of Epidemiology and Microbiology gave an interview to update the public on the development of a vaccine.  At the time of the interview, small volume trials on humans were being conducted with an anticipated date of registration and production in August.

On May 22, the Russian Ministry of Health announced that they had implemented an action plan to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in the Republic of Dagestan starting May 20, utilizing a team of specialists from federal medical research centers. According to experts, insufficient work has been done to set up the proper sanitary norms in medical organizations serving patients with COVID-19.

The Ministry of Health in Russia announced that 30 Class C ambulances will be delivered to the Republic of Dagestan in the coming days. "The Ministry of Industry and Trade, by agreement with the Russian Ministry of Health, will send 6 Ford cars, 13 Ulyanovsk Automobile Plant cars, 11 ambulances under the GAZ brand. "

On May 22, the Russian Ministry of Health issued instructions on how a doctor should be dressed while treating COVID-19 patients in the form of a graphic memo on the use of personal protective equipment by health workers.
The Russian Ministry of Health announced on May 23 that in Dagestan three hospitals are being constructed and equipped by the Ministry of Defense as an initiative of the President of Russia.

On May 27, the Ministry of Health of Russia approved guidelines "for coding cause of death in morbidity statistics related to COVID-19. The recommendations are based on new principles established by the World Health Organization's International Classification of Diseases (ICD-10), taking into account the International Guidelines for the identification and coding of COVID-19 as the cause of death. The approaches to coding and selection of cause of death, proposed in recommendations approved by the Ministry of Health, are based on a thorough study of the course of COVID-19 and its effect on the body as a whole and will provide the most relevant, objective and detailed statistics about this disease.

The Russian Ministry of Health announced on May 27 that it has developed a unique test system that detects specific antibodies to the isolated receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the coronavirus, which characterizes the degree of the immune response in a particular person.

On May 28, the Russian Ministry of Health issued a statement about the use of hydroxychloroquine in COVID-19 patients. Based on the results of numerous foreign studies confirming the effectiveness of the drug in experiments and critical trials, as well as expert opinions on the effectiveness and safety of hydroxychloroquine. The use and safety of this and other drugs used in Russia for the treatment of COVID-19 are under the constant supervision of the Russian Ministry of Health and its subordinate organizations.

On July 2, The Republic of Tyva announced that Military medics of the Central Military District (CVO) have started their work at the Republic of Tyva in a mobile hospital deployed in the city of Kyzyl.

On April 20, the Republic of Tyva announced that 217,500 disposable medical masks, 200 bottles of skin antiseptics, and 500 express-tests donated by Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu to fight the new coronavirus were donated to the infectious diseases hospitals of the Tyva Republic.
The Udmurtiya Republic announced on 23rd of July that 4 Ambulance cars were distributed to Udmutriya from the reserve fund of the Government of Russia.
Russia establishes diagnostic procedures and informs the regional governments to follow them beginning January 21
In Russia, all arriving travelers returning from Iran and South Korea undergo coronvirus testing from March 2

Russia's regions are directed on March 13 to test everyone who has been in Europe in the past two weeks, or who have returned from abroad within the previous month and are showing symptoms of the coronavirus

On March 31, Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being advocated the use of mass testing as one of the most important factors to stop the further spread of infection.

The Center for Molecular Diagnostics of Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being opens on April 6 for testing on demand for anyone living in Moscow city or Moscow region (oblast) who wants to be tested.
Russian government is allocating about 3.5 billion rubles for the production of test systems to diagnose corona virus.

Train Voronezh - Moscow No. 25 has been canceled since Tuesday, April 7, the press service of Russian Railways reported. It will not be possible to leave Moscow for Voronezh by train # 26 starting from April 8th.
Russian Railways stopped double-decker trains between Moscow and Voronezh from Wednesday, April 15. Two trains were temporarily canceled: No. 737/738 and 739/740.

The Russian legislature passes amendments to the administrative and criminal codes on March 31 classifying violations related to epidemiological safety, states of alert or emergency, and the spread of misinformation related to such situations as administrative and/or criminal offenses with increasing punishments if said violations lead to deaths.
Russia creates a new Coronavirus Coordinating Council on March 14 to be led by the Prime Minister
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Russian President establishes a State Council to address the spread of coronavirus on March 15.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 19, the Russian Ministry of Education creates a coronavirus taskforce. Regional directors of the education departments are directed to follow all guidelines of the taskforce and to establish taskforces of their own by March 20 that will report on a weekly basis to the federal taskforce.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Russia directs its regional governments to create coronavirus taskforces by March 19
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Russian Federal Service for the Supervision of Education and Science creates a coronavirus task force on March 25.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Russia increases control and monitoring of disinfection procedures in public transport and public areas (shopping centers, theatres, etc.) from 24 January.
Russia recommends that its regional governments create plans/procedures to deal with COVID-19 (and to allocate funds to those measures) beginning January 24.

Russia institutes temporary restrictions on the import and transit through the territory of the Russian Federation of all types of exotic and ornamental animals, insects and arthropods, as well as fish and aquatic animals from the People's Republic of China, from January 29.
Russia institutes a quarantine for agricultural products coming from the People "s Republic of China from January 31.
Russia delivers testing/diagnostic tools to EAEU and CIS countries beginning February 1.
Russia plans to deliver humanitarian aid to China, beginning February 4.
Russia introduces new procedures for disinfecting airplanes coming from China on February 6.
Russia evacuates citizens that were on the Diamond Princess cruise ship from Japan on February 22.
Russia strengthens sanitiary and quarantine control at airports in St. Petersburg, Krasnodar, Yekaterinburg and the Moscow Region from February 27, 2020.
Russia recommends that travelers returning from countries with coronavirus cases report their arrival and contact information to the hotline beginning March 2.
Russia gives test kits to Mongolia on March 10.
Russia allows Kyrgyz citizens being evacuated from Iran to pass through Russia, from March 10.
Russia sent the test kits it had developed to North Korea and Iran as of March 12.
Russia directs regional governments to work with businesses to create disinfection procedures, and to directly oversee sanitary procedures in food service and retail sectors, beginning March 13.
Russia announces plans to send test kits to Egypt, Serbia and Venezuela on March 20.
Russia extends humanitarian aid to Italy beginning March 22.
On March 23, as part of organizing the repatriation of citizens abroad, the Russian government decides to organize buses for transportation to nearby regions.
On March 23, the Russian government announces that they will organize a mass repatriation via train for Russian citizens in Ukraine.

On March 23, the Russian government begins organizing the repatriation of Russian citizens, all of whom will be quarantined for 14 days. A list of all those wishing to return is to be compiled by March 26.
From March 30, Russia's Ministry of Transport organizes flights to repatriate Russian citizens, to inform them of existing quarantine procedures and communication requirements.
Russia's president passes a decree declaring paid days off (national holiday) from March 30-April 3.

The Russian legislature passes amendments to the administrative and criminal codes on March 31 classifying violations related to epidemiological safety, states of alert or emergency, and the spread of misinformation related to such situations as administrative and/or criminal offenses with increasing punishments if said violations lead to deaths.
Russia restricts grain (wheat and meslin, rye, barley and corn) exports (no more than 7 million tons) to non-Eurasian Union countries  from April 1 to June 30, 2020.

Russia leads a meeting of health officials of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (Russia, China, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Pakistan) where they decided to create a joint document on measures taken by the SCO countries to counteract the spread of COVID-19.
Russia donates $1 million to WHO for the fight against Coronavirus on April 3.
Russia sends humanitarian aid to Serbia beginning April 3.
The Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin officially declares April 28 to be the Day of the Ambulance Worker.
On May 20, the Russian Ministry of Education announces preparations to repatriate its Russian language teachers working abroad in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan through a humanitarian program.
Russia directs regional health directors to undertaking public awareness campaigns from January 24.
The Russian Health Services begin issuing daily updates on coronavirus from January 28
Russia recommends that if people have symptoms they stay at home and call medical services for a distance consultation as of March 2.
On March 10 Russia recommends to the public 7 steps to prevent coronavirus including hygiene and social distancing
Russia's regions are directed to undertake public information campaigns aimed at those over 60 or immuno-compromised about the risks of coronavirus, beginning March 13.
The Russian Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being issues guidelines on how to disinfect mobile phones on March 13 as a public awareness campaign
The Russian government establishes a new website https://xn--80aesfpebagmfblc0a.xn--p1ai/ofdoc/ as a comprehensive information portal from March 15.
Russia directs its government to undertake a public awareness campaign with easily understandable information about coronavirus for citizens by March 16

Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being posts the results of a scientific study on the origins and evolution of coronavirus on their website on March 17 as a public awareness measure.
Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being posts WHO guidelines for preventing coronavirus on their website on March 17 as a public awareness measure.
Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being issues recommendations for citizens over 60 on how to prevent coronavirus on March 18.

On March 19, Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being issues an explanation on the differences between CV and flu, based on guidelines by WHO, as a public awareness measure.
Russia launched a hotline to support and coordinate assistance to people over 60 who are at risk of the spread of a new type of coronavirus

On March 19, Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being posts the joint guidance of WHO, UNICEF and the International Federation of the Red Cross for the development of an action plan on their website as a public awareness measure.

On March 19, the Russian Ministry of Education directs the heads of the education departments in the regions  to create a hotline and email address for addressing urgent questions, as needed, as a public awareness measure.

On March 22, Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being posts expert advice on their website from researchers at universities in the UK and Netherlands as a public awareness measure.

On March 22, Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being posts the results of a scientific study on incubation periods of coronavirus as a public awareness measure.
The administration of the Tomsk region expands the channels of information about coronavirus in the region from March 23.
On March 23, the Russian Ministry of Education issues an infographic with tips on keeping students healthy while distance learning as a public awareness measure.

Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being publishes UNICEF guidelines on how to talk to a kid about coronavirus along with an infographic on March 26 as a public awareness campaign.

Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being posts WHO guidelines for managing coronavirus in healthcare facilities and society on March 26 as a public awareness measure.
Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being translates and posts WHO guidelines on staying active amid quarantine on their website on March 27.
Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being issued recommendations on March 28 for parents to main hygiene and maximize social distancing/isolation.
Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being issued recommendations on March 30 for the proper use of single and multiple-use masks.

All citizens of the Russian Federation who arrived from China with symptoms of acute respiratory infections, identified during the sanitary and quarantine control or those who sought medical help themselves are required to isolate themselves for 14 days after arrival, starting from January 24. Those citizens will also be hospitalized and examined for the entire list of possible SARS pathogens, including coronavirus infection.

All citizens of the Russian Federation who arrived from China with symptoms of acute respiratory infections, identified during the sanitary and quarantine control or those who sought medical help themselves are required to isolate themselves for 14 days after arrival, starting from January 24. Those citizens will also be hospitalized and examined for the entire list of possible SARS pathogens, including coronavirus infection.
Russia begins hospitalizing those who have been in close contact with diagnosed patients are hospitalized starting January 31

Russian Federation, Altaiskiy Krai, on January 31, the Governor of the Altai Krai signed a Plan of organizational sanitary and anti-epidemic measures to prevent the import and spread of a new coronavirus infection.

The Ministry of Health, and Rospotrebnadzor conduct an examination of all residents of the region who came from the PRC or were among those in contact with presumably infected people. Doctors are in constant contact with them, for 14 days these citizens will be at home under observation.
Russia recommends home quarantine for those returning from China from January 31.
In Russia, those in contact (not close, e.g. work) with diagnosed patients must self-isolate in their homes for 14 days beginning January 31.
Russia implements a quarantine for citizens of Belarus entering Russia across land borders from China from January 31.

Russia institutes mandatory health checks and potential of up to 14 days in quarantine for Chinese citizens with Russian residence permits returning from China or entering through Mongolia, starting February 1.
Russia institutes mandatory isolation or hospitalization for those suspected of having coronavirus from February 3.
Russia isolates and monitors pilots on flights where cases of coronavirus were detected, beginning February 7.
Russia quarantines evacuated citizens from the Diamond Princess cruise ship from February 22.
In Russia, all arriving travelers returning from Iran and South Korea undergo home quarantine for 14 days beginning March 2

Tomsk Region, Russia, enforces 14 days self-isolation for those who returned from the countries most affected by the coronavirus - China, South Korea, Iran, Italy, France, Germany and Spain from March 16.

In Tomsk, Russia, citizens who have arrived from China, Korea, Italy, Iran, France, Germany and Spain should provide self-isolation at home for 14 days from the day they return to the Russian Federation from May 17.
Russia decides that all people arriving from abroad will be required to self-isolate at home for 14 days from March 19.

On March 23, the Russian government begins organizing the repatriation of Russian citizens, all of whom will be quarantined for 14 days. A list of all those wishing to return is to be compiled by March 26.

From March 23 in the Irkutsk region All citizens arriving from abroad should be in self-isolation for 14 days, even if they have no symptoms of the disease. It is necessary to stay at home, to minimize contacts.
Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being issued recommendations on March 28 for parents to main hygiene and maximize social distancing/isolation.

Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin on March 30 asked Russia's regional governors to consider imposing restrictions on movement to halt the spread of the coronavirus, following the example of Moscow.

The Russian legislature passes amendments to the administrative and criminal codes on March 31 classifying violations related to epidemiological safety, states of alert or emergency, and the spread of misinformation related to such situations as administrative and/or criminal offenses with increasing punishments if said violations lead to deaths.
All people arriving to Russia as of April 10 must remain isolated for 14 days.
Starting from September 24, Russian citizens returning from foreign countries will have to comply with a self-isolation regime until the results of testing for COVID-19 by PCR are obtained.

On March 27, ahead of the presidentially decreed non-working week from March 30-April 5 when only essential businesses will function, the Russian government determines the list of essential goods that can be sold (with the exception of food products) in order to further clarify the restrictions and regulation of businesses. Regional governments have the right to amend the federally-determined list as needed for their region.
Starting from March 28, the hotel and sanatoriums of Crimea will stop accepting new visitors.
Russia directs its regional governments to close ski slopes and other mass recreational facilities until June 1.

In Mariy-El, Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin instructed
to suspend from March 28, 2020 to April 5, 2020 the activities of catering organizations, with the exception of distance selling.
Russia closes restaurants and catering facilities, except delivery/take out
Russian president announces March 30-April 3 as paid days off

The Russian legislature passes amendments to the administrative and criminal codes on March 31 classifying violations related to epidemiological safety, states of alert or emergency, and the spread of misinformation related to such situations as administrative and/or criminal offenses with increasing punishments if said violations lead to deaths.

The Department of State Policy in the Field of Vocational Education and Advanced Training of the Ministry of Education of Russia advises Driving Schools on April 16 that they should conduct the theoretical portions of training online and, depending on the regional situation, delay the practical part or take measures for social distancing.

The Russian government directs regional leaders (governors, mayors) on March 23 to suspend the activities of nightclubs (discos) and other similar facilities, cinemas (cinemas), children's playrooms and children's entertainment centers, other entertainment and leisure facilities; and introduce a ban on smoking hookahs in restaurants, bars, cafes and other similar facilities.

The Russian government adopted a policy on shift and rotational work groups on April 28, which involves assuring that employers provide temporary housing, transportation, and medical services to employees to reduce the spread of coronavirus.
Russia recommends regional government to prepare starting March 13 to move to remote work.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: In the Altai Republic of the Russian Federation, 17 March 2020 according to the release of orders, in the "Rosseti" branch of the Altai Republic, to prevent the spread of acute viral infections in the Altai Republic, until 31 March 2020, customer service was also transferred only to online services: Internet reception www.mrsk-sib.ru (requests, applications); personal account (requests to technological connection, applications for accounting devices); "Svetlaia Strana" portal (energy supply quality); TP.RF portal (applications for electrical services); 8800 1000 380 hotline phone (any reference information round the clock). Offerings of technological accession agreements will be sent to applicants by post of Russia.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description:
In the Altai Republic of the Russian Federation, 17 March 2020, according to the order of the group of companies "Rosseti'" dated from 5 March 2020 #104 "On measures to prevent influenza and other acute respiratory virus infections" and dated from 16 March 2020 #113 "On the organization of work in the context of the spread of viral respiratory infections", the branch of "Rosseti Sibir'" (Public Join Stock  "Interregional Distribution Grid Company of Siberia ") in the Altai Republic transfers people to work from home through remote access. 
Since 17 March 2020, a part of the employees of the group of companies "Rosseti" works remotely, maintaining the current conditions of payment of labor. The exception is the staff who must be in the office or at the production facility.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Starting from 19 of March, the courts of Russia stop restrict access to their facilities for visitors.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Russian Federal Service for the Supervision of Education and Science on March 23 recommends that institutions do not apply for new accreditation or licenses while inspections and field visits are suspended (to April 30).
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Russian Federal Service for the Supervision of Education and Science announces on March 23 that it suspends all inspections related to licensing and accreditation of educational institutions, with the exception of those for suspected violations related to the current safety and health measures related to coronavirus until April 30.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Russia directs government agencies to move to remote work for the maximal possible number of employees, privileging pregnant women, women with children under the age of 14 years and workers over 60 years of age from March 27.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Russia closes state-affilitated resorts, sanatoriums and children's camps until June 1.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Starting from March 28, the registry office and the Pensions Fund will stop accepting new applications and will work only remotely.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Russia suspends registering marriages and transfers all other civil registration services online starting March 30.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Udmurtiya Republic's all multifunctional centers of the republic (MFC) will stop accepting and issuing documents for the provision of state and municipal services from March 30 to April 3,
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Russian president announces March 30-April 3 as paid days off
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Russian legislature passes a law on March 31 giving the government control over the extension and renewal of licenses and permits for 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Russian legislature passes a law on March 31 allowing the government to declare a moratorium on bankruptsy proceedings in exceptional circumstances such as a natural or man-made emergency.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Minister of Education Sergey Kravtsov signed an order on April 30 to extend the validity period of teaching qualification expiring April 1, 2020 to September 1, 2020 until December 31, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Russian legislature passes a law on March 31 suspending planned inspections of small and medium-sized enterprises with the exception of inspections for issues that may be causing harm or threat of harm to the life or health of citizens related to the occurrence of extreme natural and man-made disasters.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Russian legislature passes a law on March 31 allowing the government to declare a moratorium on bankruptcy proceedings in exceptional circumstances such as a natural or man-made emergency.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On April 3, the Russian Government passed regulations on how permits and licenses should be renewed during the crisis in 2020, including identifying priority areas for automatic renewal, simplified procedures, and video inspections.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Russian government on April 3 revises its procurement  (of goods and services for state and municipal needs) procedures to account for new sanitary norms related to the coronavirus (e.g. video conferencing, electronic documents and signatures).
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On July 13 it was announced that swimming is restricted for children in 13 recreation zones in Belarus.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Russia postpones the Russian Investment Forum
Russia has canceled its flagship annual St Petersburg International Economic Forum

Russia recommends its government agencies minimize the number of mass events, including business, sports, cultural and entertainment, and, if possible, hold them in video format or without spectators.
Russian defense ministry cancels Moscow International Security Conference (1,000 delegates from 115 countries, scheduled for April 22-23)
In Russia, the Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being recommends that regional governments limit mass events beginning March 11.
Russia directs regional governments to limit mass gatherings as of March 13.
The Russian Prime Minister instructs the reduction of mass events throughout the country from March 14.
On March 16, the Russian Ministry of Education postpones yearly Olympiad competitions for school students, to begin March 20, and plans to move the competitions online.
The Russian legislature passes a law on March 31 allowing electoral commissions at the federal, regional, or municipal level to delay elections or referenda in a state of high alert or emergency.

The Russian legislature passes amendments to the administrative and criminal codes on March 31 classifying violations related to epidemiological safety, states of alert or emergency, and the spread of misinformation related to such situations as administrative and/or criminal offenses with increasing punishments if said violations lead to deaths.
The Russian Federal Service for the Supervision of Education and Science announced on April 17 that standardized exams for 4-8 grades will be postponed until September

The Russian Federal Service for the Supervision of Education and Science announced on April 29 as a restriction of mass events that the final Russian language essay exams for 9th graders will be postponed from May 6 to May 25 on account of the national non-working days.

On May 21 the Russian Ministry of Education recommends that schools conduct last bell (last day of school) and graduation celebrations online according to templates provided by the federal level. Decisions are left to the regions but will be monitored by the Ministry.
Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being issues recommendations for citizens over 60 on how to prevent coronavirus on March 18.
On March 22, Russia's Federal Service for Supervision of Consumer Rights Protection and Human Well-Being recommends that all citizens minimize visits to public places.
Russia recommends that citizens restrict travel, including for tourism and recreation beginning March 27.
Russia recommends that its regional governments restrict the operation of mass events and public spaces (e.g. shopping centers)

The Russian legislature passes amendments to the administrative and criminal codes on March 31 classifying violations related to epidemiological safety, states of alert or emergency, and the spread of misinformation related to such situations as administrative and/or criminal offenses with increasing punishments if said violations lead to deaths.
ON March 12, Slovak government announces intention to close schools and universities beginning Monday March 16, to be upheld for at least 14 days.
An emergency situation will apply for all of Slovakia as of Thursday, March 12.

On February 27, Slovak Government advises citizens to reconsider travel to risk countries (list of which is issued and continually updated by Slovak Foreign Ministry). Emergency SMS will be sent to travelers upon return to inform them of COVID-19 prevention measures.

On March 12, Slovak Government announces the closure of all three international airports. Temporary border checks will also be instated on land border crossings with all neighbor countries except for Poland - only citizens or long-term residents will be allowed into the country. All arriving travelers need to self-quarantine for at least 14 days after their arrival.

On February 24, Slovak Government announces measures regarding all planes landing in Slovakia from Italy. All passengers will be asked to fill out a form which would store their information in the case they would need to be contacted later on. Passengers are also encouraged to make use of the coronavirus callcenter hotlines should they have any questions or concerns.

Citizens who have recently traveled are advised to monitor their symptoms for at least 14 days and contact their doctor via telephone or email should they observe symptoms similar to those of COVID-19.
On 28 February 2020, the government of Slovakia is starting with temperature screening of passengers for all passengers arriving in Slovakia by air.
On March 24, Slovak Government ruled that there are to be temperature checks at the entrance of hospitals, shops, factories and places where people gather.

On February 17th, Slovak Government dedicates funds to purchase equipment and improve diagnostic capabilities of specialized medical centers. Practices in Slovak hospitals in preparation for an eventual outbreak of the coronavirus are also planned as of February 10.

On March 15, Slovak government announces the state of emergency in 22 state-run hospitals spread throughout all regions. This enables the government to control and move health resources and personnel according to the regional concentration of COVID-19 infections.
Slovak crisis council advises owners of businesses, stores, buildings and managers of public transport infrastructure to ask their employees / customers to wear a medical mask.
Slovak police and army are to assist in the logistical management of hospitals most hit by the coronavirus.
On March 24, Slovak Government decides that residents should only appear in public with a mask covering their mouth and face.

Slovak Government ruled that there are to be 3 specialized COVID-19 hospitals established - one in the east, central region and west of the country. In other hospitals, there is to be an independent ward / pavilion to be established exclusively for COVID-19 patients.
On March 24, Slovak Government announces plans to ban the export of essential health materials, both protective and therapeutic.

Slovak medical administration will give priority to licensing COVID-19 testing and treatment. New proposed therapeutics will be prioritized and their approval process will be streamlined as much as (safely) possible.
On April 1st Slovakia published instructions on new sampling sites that will be raised in front of hospitals in Slovakia, totaling up to 29 sampling sites.
Health Minister of Slovakia signs off purchase of 88 lung ventilators on April 13.

Slovak government decided that COVID-19 testing will be fully centralized controlled by the state. Private laboratories and testing companies are prepared to help, but will not sell testing kits or test patients for a fee. Overall, there are 4 testing centers throughout Slovakia, each with the capacity of 700 tests a day.

On March 24, Slovak Government announced that all hospitals which carry out coronavirus testing will set up a testing station in their parking lot, so that samples can be taken without patients leaving their vehicles.
On March 12, Slovak Government announces (further unspecified) restrictions on travel via bus and train.

Based on their recommendation, the government of Slovakia will pass legislation on the limitation of the free movement of people, which effectively bans people from moving around. It will apply from April 8 at 7:00 in the morning until April 13, i.e. the week before Easter. 
The following exceptions will apply: getting to and from work, shopping, visiting the doctor's, taking care of relatives or helping neighbours, funerals, and outings into nature but only within the district that one lives in.
On February 27, first meeting of the Crisis Council  in connection to the novel coronavirus takes place. The body will assess and monitor the situation closely on a daily basis.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On January 27, the Slovak government addresses the novel coronavirus and starts a public awareness campaign. The campaign includes an email address and phone number for the population to contact in case of questions regarding the disease, as well as issuing behavioral recommendations for travelers to risk countries.

On March 6, Slovak Government advises against visiting hospitals and retirement homes. In addition, it plans sending an emergency SMS to all telephone numbers registered in Slovakia in order to inform citizens about prevention measures. Ministry of Health has compiled several versions of information leaflets which are available at doctor's offices and handed out at border crossings.
On March 24, Slovak Government announces plans to cooperative with mobile network providers and send emergency messages with COVID-19 information directly to the phones of vulnerable citizens.

Everybody entering the territory of Slovakia after April 6 at 7:00 will have to undergo mandatory isolation in a facility chosen by the state. The isolation will last until they receive test results showing whether they are infected with the coronavirus or not.
In the case of a negative result, they will have to stay in home isolation for 14 days. The same will apply for everybody living in the same household.

On March 12, Slovak government announces the closure of non-essential businesses, including ski resorts, wellness centers, amusement parks, swimming pools, bars, clubs and cultural centers. Over the weekend, citizens can only buy food, groceries and medicine in shopping malls.

On March 24, Slovak Government announces that all shops which remain in operation are to be closed on Sundays. The purpose of this policy is to use the day to disinfect store facilities as well as alleviate the strain on workers employed in essential businesses.
On March 24, Slovak government announces shopping hours (between 9am and 12pm) exclusively for citizens over 65 years of age.

On March 28 the Slovak government introduced additional hygienic measures to be upheld in stores. Everyone present inside the store has to be wearing a mask, either hand sanitizer gel or disposable gloves are to be available to all customers and employees. Only a limited number of customers are allowed into the store at a time - specifically, one customer per 25 square meters. Temperature checks are not mandated, but advised.
If such measures are to be upheld, some restrictions on non-essential businesses may be lifted in the near future.
Slovakia government restricts opening hours in some governmental offices and bureaus.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 9, Slovak Government announces a ban on public, cultural and sporting events, to last 14 days with the possibility of extension. In addition, all travelers returning from Italy, Iran, China or South Korea should self-isolate together with their families.
Slovakia suspends free train transport for pupils and students from April 1.
On March 24, Slovak Government mandates citizens to maintain 2 meters distance away from each other when standing in a queue.
On March 12, the Government of Slovenia adopted the decision to temporarily close kindergartens and schools between March 16 and March 29.
On March 12 at 6 p.m., Slovenia declares an epidemic. At the same time, the national emergency response plan is activated.
On 10 March, Slovenia advises citizens against travelling to the South Korean area around Daegu and Cheongju and against all but essential travel to other parts of the Republic of Korea.

Slovenia bans aircrafts from Italian airports, in places where risk of infection is higher, from China, South Korea, and Iran. The ban applies from 10. 3. 2020 to 31. 3. 2020, with a possibility of extension. This does not apply to emergency and medical flights.
On March 10, the Slovenian MFA advises against all travel to Italy.
On March 10, Slovenia advises "against all but essential travel to China and against all travel to the province of Hubei until further notice."
On March 11, "Passenger train traffic between Italy and Slovenia has been suspended."

The Slovenian government adopted a decision to start carrying out border control checks in the vicinity of the border between Slovenia and Italy on 11 March 2020. This will include checking for negative SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) result certificates issued by a competent authority.
On March 16, the Slovenian Government bans international air transport in the Republic of Slovenia from March 17 until March 30.

On March 24, Slovenia announces setting up of thirteen checkpoints at the border with Austria from March 25.  Entry to Slovenia will be permitted only to foreign citizens with a recent health certificate or to those with body temperature under 37.5C and no clear signs of respiratory infection. This excludes Slovenian citizens.

On April 4, The Defence Ministry announced that the rotations of contingents of the Slovenian Armed Forces in international operations and missions planned in the next three months will not be carried out. The contingents which are currently abroad will need to extend their service for three months. Around 250 troops are deployed in Kosovo and eight in Mali.
On March 14, Slovenia announces a change in diagnostics, where the number of severely ill persons requiring hospital care will be monitored through testing, not the total number of infected persons.

On March 9, Slovenia announces that all preventive activities of health centres at Metlika, Novo mesto, Crnomelj and at Novo mesto general hospital will be suspended and all non-urgent specialist examinations will be rescheduled until further notice, except for acute illnesses and conditions that could lead to a deterioration of health. Visits to a personal doctor should be made by prior telephone appointment.

On March 12, Slovenia prohibits health staff from taking annual leave, restricts their right to go on strike and the right to participate in training and education provided in infected areas or areas at immediate risk of coronavirus outbreaks
On March 14, Slovenian government froze the prices of protective equipment in order to achieve a reasonable cost for individual items.
On March 15, Slovenia allows the allocation of doctors without licenses to be published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Slovenia from March 15.

On March 12, Slovenia announced that "As of 16 March 2020, specialist examinations and surgical operations except cases rated as  "emergency " or  "urgent " or  "express " will be cancelled. This will exclude oncology and pregnancy treatments. Wherever there is a possibility of e-consulting services, it should be used to the maximum extent."
On March 29, Slovenia announces the mandatory use of masks (or equivalents, such as scarves that cover the mouth and nose) and protective gloves in indoor public spaces.

On April 4, The Slovenian government restricted the usage of drugs containing chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine or azithromycin to make sure enough of those substances are available to patients who need them.
On March 15, Slovenia places a temporary ban on public transport of passengers, with the exception of auto-taxi services.
On 8 May, Slovenia announced that public transport will be relaunched on 11 May.
On March 12, the Civil Protection Service of the Republic of Slovenia was put in charge of coordinating the measures to combat the spread of the virus, in cooperation with the relevant departments.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 14, Slovenian "Prime Minister Janez Jan_a said that the Government established the crisis unit to contain and manage the COVID-19 epidemic at its first session [...]. The crisis unit will include support groups, the most important of which will consist of medical experts."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 9, Slovenia announces that "all travellers crossing the Slovenian border will be informed via SMS notification of the preventive measures in force in this country regarding the coronavirus" and "leaflets containing coronavirus action instructions will be distributed to all Slovenian households via the Post of Slovenia."
Slovenia sets up a call centre to assist inhabitants in finding information regarding the coronavirus.
On March 27, the Slovenian government announced all Slovenians returning from coronavirus hotspots would be put into state-administrated quarantine.

On March 29, Slovenia imposed a temporary general prohibition of movement and public gathering in public places and areas in the Republic of Slovenia and the prohibition of movement outside the municipality of permanent or temporary residence from March 30.

On April 3, the Slovenian Government announced a mandatory 14-day quarantine for most people entering the country from April 4, punishable by fines. It does not, however, apply to people who have to travel for work, those involved in cargo traffic or who are passing through Slovenia on their way to another country without staying overnight.

On March 15, Slovenia announces a temporary ban on the provision and sale of goods and services directly to consumers in the territory of the Republic of Slovenia from March 16 at 00.00. The temporary ban excludes remote provision and sale of goods and services to consumers and certain activities such as pharmacies, stores with food, shops with medical devices, petrol stations, banks, post offices, delivery services.
The government of Slovenia recommends event organisers to ban events of fewer than 500 people from March 7.
Minister of Health of Slovenia signs an Order banning gatherings of more than 500 people at public events in indoor public places.
Slovenia prohibits indoor public gatherings for 100-plus visitors from March 3., with the exception of shopping malls, small commercial venues, weddings, funerals and religious ceremonies.

On March 9, Slovenia announces that employers should alert or urge workers who are ill to stay at home and follow instructions. Work from home is advised to the greatest possible extent. Non-urgent business trips are strongly advised against.

From March 19, grocery shops in Slovenia "must be open from 8am to 8pm, and for the first two hours, until 10am, groups particularly vulnerable to infections - the elderly, pregnant women and disabled persons - must be given priority."
On March 29, Slovenia entered into force a law allowing a one-month suspension of a prison sentence and an early release of prisoners up to six months before the end of their sentence.

On Mar 22 2020 KCDC announced, "Citing the recent incidents of misinformed use of salt water sprays and methanol, the KCDC stated that the spread of COVID-19-related misinformation ( "infodemic ") is posing a threat to the safety of citizens and stressed that it is important to check the reliability of the sources of the information they receive from word of mouth, social media, online videos and forums, and news media. The KCDC asked citizens who come across suspicious COVID-19-related information to check the sources of information and confirm the validity of information by utilizing resources such as official websites of KCDC and the Ministry of Health and Welfare and infectious disease call center (1339)."
On 5 Feb 2020, Korea's Ministry of Education recommends universities to postpone the upcoming semester

In South Korea, "fever tests will be conducted at least twice a day before entering to a classroom and during the day, and fever and respiratory symptoms will be checked frequently before the start of each class. If there is any suspected symptom, those who show the symptoms will be guided to receive medical examinations and diagnostic tests at the screening stations immediately."
The head of Korea's Central Disaster Management Headquarters declares a status of the national warning.
On 2 Feb 2020, the Korean government enforces entry restriction of travelers from Hubei.

On Mar 9 2020, KCDC announced, "At this moment, it is required to take both measures, control of local transmission and prevention of additional importation, taking into account the current global situation.
There have been 101 thousand confirmed cases with 3,700 deceased in 96 countries except Republic of Korea. According to WHO, 53 countries have local community transmission. Although transmission in China seems decreasing, there is a surge in other countries, such as Italy and Iran. Furthermore, more than 200 cases have been confirmed in the Unites States and Japan respectively. The situation and transmission trends in these countries are closely monitored. Central Disease Control Headquarters will share the monitoring results with the public in a timely manner and consider strengthening the quarantine inspection on travellers from the countries with local transmission."

On Mar 12 2020, KCDC announced "To prevent further imported cases, special immigration procedures will be expanded to the European region in response to the recent rapid increase of local transmission. The procedures will begin to take effect at 0:00 of 15 March for all Korean and international travelers arriving after having visited or lived in France, Germany, Spain, the U.K. or the Netherlands."

On Mar 18 2020, "The KCDC strongly recommended canceling or delaying of all international travel on non-urgent matters. Persons who are unable to avoid traveling out of the country for a critical reason are advised to refrain from visiting any closed facilities or healthcare facilities, and voluntarily disclose any symptoms and their international travel history upon returning to Korea and follow appropriate guidelines and instructions."

On Mar 17 2020, "In light of the recent rise in the number of confirmed cases from airport quarantine, the KCDC announced that the Special Entry Procedure will be extended to all travelers arriving at port beginning at 0:00 of 19 March. The Special Entry Procedure requires the traveler to be checked for fever, provide a confirmed contact information at port entry, and report their symptoms daily for the next 14 days via self-health check mobile app. Travel history of all travelers entering Korea will be provided to healthcare providers via the International Traveler Information System for reference."

South Korea's Health Insurance Review & Assessment Service revealed that the information of inbound travellers from the countries affected by COVID-19 has been being provided to all care-taking institutions since 10th January through DUR system on a real-time basis.
The Department of Health and Welfare declares PRC as a contamination zone and implementation of the monitoring of inbound travelers.

On 26th January, Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (KCDC) announced that all inbound travellers from China are required to fill in 'Health Questionnaire' from 28th January as China will be  designated as an 'infected region'.
On 12 Feb 2020, a self-check mobile phone application is enforced to download for new arrivals from the risk zones
On 16 Feb 2020, policies are set out for international students from China
On 16 Feb 2020, guest workers from China are advised for a two-week holiday after their arrival.

On 18 Feb 2020, the Ministry of Health and Welfare enforces measures to prevent infection in 5,500 nursing homes and 74,000 nursing care workers nationwide with many senior citizens, including elderly inpatients.

The Ministry of Health and Welfare (Minister Park Neung-hoo) announced that the revision of the Infectious Disease Prevention and Management Act, the Quarantine Act, and the Medical Service Act passed the plenary session of the National Assembly on February 26 (Wednesday).

South Korean KCDC announced on March 7, "The staff at the facilities should strictly follow personal hygiene practice, avoid going out when having fever or respiratory symptoms, and monitor the symptoms for 3-4 days."

South Korean KCDC announced on March 7th 2020, "considering that the transmission spreads from community facilities, KCDC advised to designate a reporting person at every community facility so that suspected cases could be immediately reported to the local government and public health authority upon the onset of symptoms."
The Ministry of Health and Welfare announced screening units at hospitals and medical centres.
The government announces the expansion of quarantine personnel and conversion of public health centres
On 5 Feb 2020, the Korean government enforces to control over the export of masks.
On 4 Feb 2020, the Ministry of Health and Welfare announces the expansion of testing facilities to hospitals from 7 Feb.
On 26 Feb 2020, the Korean government controls over exporting masks. Firms should supply 50 per cent of their daily production to designated retailers in Korea.
South Korea aids the Egyptian government with 220,000 USD to contain the spread of the coronavirus and levy its economic and social circumstances.

Ivory Coast is receiving a donation of 300 000 000 FCFA from South Korea on 18th September. This concerns a sanitary kit consisting of Rt-Pcr type screening kits, stretchers with isolation chamber specially manufactured for medical use, Kf-94 sanitary masks, 5 overlapping filters, thermal cameras.
On 3rd January, South Korea government checks temperatures of all inbound travellers from Wuhan. Symptomatic travellers will be all quarantined to designated National Care Wardens and tested.

KCDC and 17 Health and environmental research institutes have expanded the rapid diagnosis test in 24 hours at national-wide from January 24 2020 in South Korea. In preparation for the spreading, private clinics and medical centers will set up the diagnosis test system till the beginning of February.

On Mar 18 2020 KCDC announced, "In Daegu, testing is being conducted for every person at high-risk facilities such as nursing homes. A current total of 74 confirmed cases (57 patients, 17 staff) have been reported from Hansarang Convalescent Hospital in Seo-gu, Daegu City, and 13 other confirmed cases have been reported from other nursing homes in the city. Further epidemiological investigation and control measures are underway."

On Mar 24 2020, KCDC announced, "Starting 22 March, the KCDC is conducting COVID-19 diagnostic testing for every inbound traveler entering from Europe. Yesterday (23 March), of the 1,203 inbound travelers from Europe, 101 were symptomatic and 1,102 were asymptomatic. For more efficient use of quarantine resources, starting 14:00 today, asymptomatic travelers who are Korean nationals (with domestic residence) will be directed to go into self-quarantine at home and get tested at their local public health center within 3 days of arrival (rather than getting tested at quarantine facility before going home for self-quarantine). Foreigners will be quarantined at facility and tested. Persons staying long-term who test negative will go into self-quarantine at home for 14 days."

In response to South Korea's first imported case, on January 20 the KCDC urged the "public to practice preventing infection including hand washing, cough etiquette, and wearing masks if you have respiratory symptoms."

On Mar 12 2020 KCDC announced, "Extra care should be taken to keep clean any frequently used surfaces in living spaces. Individuals with fever and respiratory symptoms should refrain from leaving home including going to work or school and watch the symptoms for the next 3-4 days."

On Mar 12 2020 "KCDC urged everyone to keep strict adherence to personal hygiene and social distancing measures, including covering sneezes and coughs with arm sleeves to prevent transmission via respiratory droplets and refraining from visiting closed community spaces or public gatherings."
Set up a community-based response system against a rise in Chinese travelors
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Ministry of Health and Welfare announces a task force to respond to corona virus
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On 15 Feb 2020, Korean nationals from Wuhan who had arrived by the government's transfer and had been quarantined
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On 28th January, South Korea Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport carries out full-scale sanitization measures in all public transportation.
On 16 Feb 2020, the Ministry of Employment announces support for Employment Support Fund with sales tests relaxed.

On Mar 19 2020, "Acknowledging the growing anxiety, fatigue, and stress felt by the public as the outbreak prolongs, the KCDC reminded citizens of mental health and psychological care support available for patients and their families as well as those who have been discharged from isolation, and asked citizens to seek professional help when needed."
On 23rd January, South Korea's Ministry of Interior and Safety begins sending Emergency Natural Disaster text messages, including safety and prevention instructions on COVID-19.
Korea Department of Health and Welfare declares rules for preventing infectious diseases during the Lunar New Year holidays.
The Ministry of Health and Welfare announces the distribution of measures to daycare centres
On 16 Feb 2020,

Mar 16 "KCDC stressed the need to continue to stay vigilant, as smaller case clusters continue to emerge from community and religious facilities. Emphasized that the strict adherence to infection prevention measures should remain a top priority in everyday life and should become a  "new normal ", stressing that workplaces and schools as well as society at large need to create an environment that strongly encourages those with suspected symptoms to stay at home and watch their symptoms. Recommended that workplaces improve their on-site environment to enable distancing measures, periodically ventilate and disinfect their facilities, and adopt remote working environments for employees. Stressed continued adherence to social distancing measures to prevent transmission to high-risk groups. Expressed concern that the virus may be contracted by healthy adults and children via workplaces and schools and transmitted to the vulnerable groups such as the elderly and people with underlying illnesses via healthcare facilities, social welfare centers, religious gatherings, or other community spaces and events. Strongly advised that the elderly stay at home as much as possible and refrain from visiting places visited by a large number of people. Urged everyone to adhere to personal hygiene and social distancing measures, and encouraged businesses and public facilities to keep handwash and sanitizers in stock and put up posters to remind users to practice hand hygiene in all places."

On Mar 18 2020, "The KCDC again reminded everyone that personal hygiene and social distancing practices are effective measures to prevent infections. Any person who suspect onset COVID-19 symptoms are advised to call the KCDC call center (1339) or local call centers (area code + 120), ask a local public health center, or visit a screening facility, before visiting a regular healthcare provider directly. All persons who visit a screening center should wear a mask and drive their own car if possible."

On Mar 20 2020, KCDC announced, "In a recent survey, 58.4% of respondents said they have heard hate speech related to COVID-19 within the last week, and 62.6% said they fear the blame or discrimination they might face if they become infected. KCDC reminded everyone that COVID-19 is an infectious disease that can affect anyone and that infection shouldn "t be grounds for blame or social stigma. The KCDC asked citizens to send warm regards and encouragement to those who are affected by the virus, including confirmed patients and their families, people under self-quarantine, and recovered patients. Excess blame can cause patients to suffer the aftermath of psychological trauma even after recovering from the infection. Such a culture can potentially result in people refusing to be tested for the fear of social stigma, causing in turn more infection to spread to local communities. The transparent, timely disclosure of infection-related information is provided for the purpose of infection prevention only, as it helps to find potential cases unable to be traced by epidemiological investigation by informing those who may have been exposed to the virus. The KCDC asked reporters and others to refrain from citing or reporting on privacy-sensitive information or information that can identify the patient."

On Mar 29 2020, " In the meantime, KCDC cooperates with relevant organizations to deal with digital divide that people with special needs might experience in regard to COVID-19 information. For people with impaired vision, a voice code is used in COVID-19 promotional materials, which converts the written information into vocal format when a hearing aid or smartphone is touched. Furthermore, sign language is provided during KCDC daily briefing so that people with impaired hearing could have an access to COVID-19 information. KCDC also distributed COVID-19 prevention guidelines in 14 languages and the website is availabe in English and Chinese.
- KCDC stated that it would provide the information through customized platform for the information have-nots, so no one would be deprived of any necessary information due to disabilities or language barriers."
On 2 Feb 2020, the government enforces 14-day quarantine on residents of foreign nationals who arrive from Hubei, China and have symptoms.
On 2 Feb 2020, the government and Ministry of Health and Welfare enforce a 14-day self-quarantine on travelers of citizens who visited Hubei, China.

South Korea government have updated the response guideline to abolish the categories of  'close contacts' and 'daily-life contacts' and universalise them into single category. Those are in self-quarantine will be assigned a civil servant at a municipal level, maintaining 1:1 management and support.
On 8 Feb 2020, Korea provides financial assistance to the quarantined who are not on paid leaves.

On Mar 11 2020, KCDC announced "Considering the increasing trend of global transmission, Central Disease Control Headquarters additionally designated Italy and Iran as the quarantine inspection required areas. Therefore, anyone with suspected symptoms should submit a health questionnaire at the point of entry, pass the special entry procedure, and install self-diagnosis application on their cell phone. They could be quarantined at the quarantine station and get tested for COVID-19 when necessary."
