On Mar 16 KCDC announced, "In light of 4 new confirmed cases from airport quarantine during 14-15 March, the KCDC urged all travelers to take caution; the Special Entry Procedure has been extended to travelers from all European regions as of 0:00, 16 March, which requires the traveler to provide a confirmed contact information and report their symptoms daily for the next 14 days via self-diagnosis app on their mobile device. Travelers who have visited Europe in the past 14 days are advised to minimize movement, adhere to personal hygiene measures, and keep watch for fever or respiratory symptoms carefully for the next 14 days. Upon noticing symptoms, they should visit a medical center with a screening facility with a mask on or call the KCDC at 1339."

On Mar 17 2020, KCDC announced, "Travelers who have visited Europe, the U.S., or Asia in the past 14 days are advised to minimize movement, adhere to social distancing personal hygiene measures, since infected persons with mild symptoms in initial stages of the disease may unknowingly transmit the virus to other people."

On Mar 20, 2020 KCDC, "recent surge in the number of COVID-19 cases in the European region including Italy, Spain, France, the U.K., as well as the rise in the number of imported cases found both at airport quarantine and in local communities (total imported cases=86; imported cases from Europe=50), stronger entry procedures will be implemented from 22 March for people traveling from Europe. All persons arriving from Europe will be required to answer a questionnaire on their health condition, get checked for fever, and get tested after being escorted to an appropriate facility "quarantine facility for persons with symptoms and designated temporary living facilities for those without symptoms. Those whose test comes out positive will either be moved a hospital or a Life Treatment Center based on the severity level assessed for each case. In principle, Korean citizens or resident aliens who test negative go into self-quarantine at their place of residence. Those without a place of residence in Korea will be quarantined at a facility. Foreigners who are temporarily staying in Korea for a short time will subject to active monitoring during their stay in Korea. Travel histories of all travelers entering Korea will be provided to healthcare providers via the International Traveler Information System for reference. The names of all entrants will be provided to local public health centers for more active monitoring of potential imported cases for the first 14 days upon their arrival."

On Mar 25 2020 KCDC announced, "The Central Disaster and Safety Countermeasure Headquarters will strengthen the management of inbound travelers under self-quarantine. Persons subject to self-quarantine will be issued a self-quarantine notice at the airport. Failure to comply is punishable by imprisonment up to 1 year or a fine up to 10 million won. They are also required to install the self-quarantine mobile app (made by the Ministry of the Interior and Safety) on their phone, so that their local government can monitor their self-quarantine."

On Mar 25 KCDC announced, "In light of the recent surge in COVID-19 cases in the United States and the rise in the number of imported cases from the US, starting 0:00 of 27 March, a stronger screening process will be applied for inbound travelers from the United States. All symptomatic persons entering from the US, regardless of nationality, will be required to wait for testing in a facility within the airport. Persons who test positive will be transferred to a hospital or  "Life Treatment Center ". Persons who test negative will enter self-quarantine at home for 14 days. Korean nationals and foreigners with a domestic residence who are asymptomatic at the time of entry will enter self-quarantine in their home for 14 days and get tested if symptoms begin to occur. Foreigners who are on a short-term visit without domestic residence and thus are unable to self-quarantine will be tested in at a temporary facility. If they test negative, they will be allowed entry under enhanced active monitoring."

South Korea has required a 14-day quarantine for all arrivals from outside the country since April 1. Passengers with symptoms are tested at airport checkpoints and either sent to health institutions or other quarantine sites, in addition to being required to fill out a medical questionnaire and install a government-developed health app to monitor their symptoms.

On Mar 12 2020, KCDC announced, "In light of the recent rise in case clusters from closed spaces including gym facilities and call centers,  "Guidelines for intense management of business entities* for COVID-19 prevention " have been created by Korea "s public health authorities. (*includes call centers, Internet cafes, gyms, religious gatherings, private academies, etc.)."

On Mar 22 2020, KCDC announced, "Korean government will restrict the operation of some facilities, such as religious facilities, indoor sports, and entertainment facilities which are at high risk of infection. Inevitably, when operating, it is necessary to strictly follow the guideline set by the KCDC, such as disinfection and ventilation, social distancing, and wearing a mask."

South Korea's nationwide "Level 2" social distancing guidelines shut down 12 types of high risk businesses, including nightclubs, karaoke rooms, bars, standing concert halls. The nationwide "Level 2" enforcement began on August 23, 2020 and is expected to end on September 20, 2020.

South Korea enforced a "Level 2.5" social distancing mandate to the Seoul metropolitan area. Under "Level 2.5," operating hours were slashed for restaurants, bakeries and bars, with only takeout and delivery services allowed after 9 p.m. Dining in was banned at franchise coffee chains, franchise bakeries and ice cream shops, with only takeaway and delivery services allowed. Private cram schools and indoor sports facilities were shut down. This enforcement began on August 30, 2020 and is expected to continue until September 13, 2020.

South Korea enforced the "Level 2.5" social distancing rules to the Seoul metropolitan area from August 30, 2020, to September 13, 2020. Under "Level 2.5," One-third of all employees working in the government, state-run agencies and public institutions are required to work from home.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On Mar. 8 2020, "KCDC recommends everyday preventive actions to help prevent the spread of respiratory diseases, and social distancing to avoid population crowding or cancel/suspend gathering activities."
On Mar 12 2020 "KCDC also encouraged businesses and workplaces to adopt remote working environments for employees such as work-at-home and online collaboration."

On Mar 16, was announced, "In light of the recent emergence of new confirmed cases by local transmission at close-contact indoor gatherings, the KCDC again strongly recommended that all such gatherings be canceled or refrained as best as possible."

South Korea enforced "Level 2" Social Distancing Guidelines across the country from August 23, 2020, to September 20, 2020. Under Level 2, indoor gatherings of more than 50 people are banned along with outdoor gatherings of more than 100 people.
As shifting the strategy from containment to mitigation, KCDC has released the 7th edition of COVID-19 protocol and guideline as effective the beginning on 2 March.

On Mar 11 2020, KCDC announced, "Since the contact with the confirmed cases in a closed place increases the possibility of transmission, it is recommended to work at home or adjust desk locations so as to keep a certain distance among people in the office. More detailed guidelines for local governments and high-risk working environment will be distributed soon."

On Mar 22 2020 KCDC announced, "In light of the continued emergence of outbreaks in religious group, and other facilities, the KCDC stresses the public to strictly comply with social distancing from 22 March to 5 April for 15days before opening the school. The KCDC urged the public to stay at home excluding necessary reason like purchasing daily necessity, visiting at health facilities, and commuting."

On Mar 27 2020, "The KCDC urged all inbound travelers to follow the precautionary measures, including not leaving home for 14 days, minimizing contact with other people, not going to work, washing hands, covering sneezes and coughs. Persons entering from Europe or the US should return home straight after arriving at the airport, refrain from using public transportation, travel in their own vehicle, and wear a facemask during movement. Beginning 28 March, airport limousine bus or KTX train will be provided for inbound travelers without access to their own vehicle."

As part of its declaration of emergency, Spain on March 14 cancels educational activities on all levels including university education as well as any other educational or training activities taught in other public or private centers. During the suspension period, educational activities will be maintained through distance and online modalities, whenever possible. (Article 9)

Since the second stage of the de-escalation, coming into force all over the territory on 25th May 2020, the regulation relating to the closure of schools is vested in the power of regions. However, national regulation rules that gatherings need to be avoided and a safety distance of 1,5m needs to be respected.

The Spanish Health ministry announces on April 30 that starting from May 2, Spanish citizens aged 14+ years are allowed to go out for a walk or exercise from 6 to 10 am and from 8 to 11 pm. People who need special attention and people aged 70+ can go out from 10-12 am and 7-8 pm accompanied by one person. Children are allowed to go out between 12-7 pm, accompanied by one person. Only one outing a day is allowed. Children are allowed to stay out for one hour maximum. The outing has to take place within one km from home (individual exercise excluded), with a distance of 2m from other people. Adults can go with max. 1 person living in the same household. In villages with less than 5000 inhabitants the different time frames don "t apply, everyone can go out under the same conditions between 6am and 11pm.

Spain on May 3 announces that starting from May 4 the other federated athletes may carry out training individually, in open air spaces, twice a day, between 6:00 and 10:00 and between 20:00 and 23:00, within the limits of the municipal area in which they have their residence. They will also be able to access the natural spaces that they require.
Spain has declared a state of emergency and mobilized the military on March 13
On May 22, the Spanish government announced that the Community of Madrid would be authorized to transition from Phase 0 to Phase 1 of the Coronavirus reopening plan.
On June 5, 2020, the Spanish government approved the Madrid region to transition to Phase 2 of the Coronavirus reopening plan on June 8.
On June 21, the Community of Madrid transitioned to "the New Normal" along with the rest of Spain as the country lifted the state of emergency.
On March 10, the Government of Spain decreed the immediate cancellation of all direct flights from Italy to Spain until 25 March.
Spain is forbidding all direct flights from spain to italy and vice versa on March 10
On March 12th Spain and Morocco have together suspended all passenger flights and maritime connections between the two countries.

Spain closes its borders starting from March 17, "only Spaniards, residents and citizens who cite force majeure will be able to enter national territory - Freight will still be able to enter the country in order to guarantee the supply of goods"

The Spanish Ministry of Health advise that U.S. citizens who are residents of Spain, and/or have access to long-term accommodation and the financial means to remain in Spain for an extended period, should not travel at this time.
Spain is shifting its external boarder restrictions to target all countries except Spain, EU and Schengen countries. Spain's borders are now open to persons residing in these countries.

Spain is developing a protocol for action in the event of the appearance of possible suspected cases of coronavirus in Spain on Jan 24. The aim is to review the situation, the epidemiological update, as well as the diagnostic capacity and response actions in Spain.

Effective June 10th, Spain will require that "Interprovincial air and land transport operators" as well as "operators of maritime transport... with pre-allocated seating" will have to "collect contact information for all passengers and keep the lists a minimum of four weeks after the trip" in case one or more of the passengers gets Covid-19. They will also be required to "provide these lists to public health authorities when they are required, with the purpose of performing contact tracing."

Effective June 29th, Spain imposed health monitoring measures at airports and maritime ports of entry. All passengers who arrive at these points of entry will have their temperature taken with "no-contact thermometers or thermal cameras," in addition to undergoing a "visual inspection," and filling out an online "public health questionnaire" which will be presented through QR code upon entry. Tourist companies and airlines are responsible for reminding travelers about their "obligation to present the public health questionnaire at the airport or port of destination."  

"Passengers with a temperature over 37.5  "C (99.5 "F)," or those that are "suspected to suffer from COVID-19 or another pathogen" based on the written and visual health inspections will be subjected to further health inspections to evaluate the risk they pose to public health. If suspicion of a public health hazard is confirmed, "established health crisis protocols will be activated" and the person will be taken to a "health center."

These rules will remain in effect "until the government declares an end to the health crisis caused by COVID-19."
The Spanish Ministry of Health on March 1 recommends its health workers to limit their travels to international congresses in order to avoid contagion.
Spain announced that private health providers and their facilities into public control as the spread of COVID-19 continues to grip the country on March 9

Spain on March 15 obligates any company within its territory which deals with the manufacturing or import of health equipment (such as masks, gloves, glasses, ...) to send information within 48 hrs to the Ministry of Health about their current stock of products, their location as well as their production capacities

Spain issues measurements to reinforce health personnel on March 15 for a period of at least 3 months: contracts of health workers in relevant fields in their last year of postgraduate training are prolonged, they are prepared to work in areas that need reinforcement; it is now allowed to hire people with a B.A. in health professions without a speciality course, also students in their last year of medicine and nursing degrees can be hired for health support functions; retired health professionals (younger than 70 yrs) should be available in case they are needed
Spain's Ministry of Health starts distributing 1 Million masks among the autonomous communities starting from March 17
Spain speeds up the work permit applications of 200 foreign health professionals already residing in Spain on March 27
The Spanish Ministry of Health distributes 1 mio rapid test kits among the autonomous regions on April 5.
Spain started rapid antibody detection tests will increase the chances of early diagnosis of COVID-19 on April 07

Spanish government establishes special measures for the granting of licenses to operate facilities and for the commissioning of certain medical devices (in particular, masks and surgical gowns) without CE marking.
Spain distributes more than 23 million masks and 1,7 million gloves among the Autonomous Communities on april 6
Spain distribute 10 million Masks throughout Spain to the workers who return to their professional activity between April 12 and April 13

Spain on March 19 establishes that hygienic face masks must be labelled with the following information: the company data; product denomination; container content; composition; recommended period of use; essential features including size if relevant; manufacturing batch; place of origin; health warnings; recommendations for use, placement and maintenance; Technical specifications; bacterial filtration efficiency and breathability and final price. Additionally, unit-sale of face masks is only allowed in pharmacies. This is part of a set of measurements to ensure that citizens can access hygienic preventive products in informed and economic conditions.

The Spanish Government has decreed the Spanish Agency for Medicines and Health Products (AEMPS) controls the distribution of hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine phosphate for COVID-19 in the Hospitals in order to control its stock in the face of the growing demand to treat the disease of COVID-19.
The Spanish government distributed 9.3 million surgical masks based on the request of the Ministry of Health in the week of June 1.

Spain announces on May 3 that starting from May 4, businesses must comply with special hygiene measures: if clothing or footwear are sold, each garment, as well as the testers, must be disinfected after each use. A disinfection of the premises will be necessary twice a day, one of them, at its closure. And employee uniforms will have to be washed daily with water over 60 degrees. Customers may not use the toilets except in cases of need. If a safety distance of two meters is not possible, masks will be mandatory. All businesses must make hydroalcoholic gels available to their customers.

Spain announces on May 3 that starting from May 4, the wearing of face masks is compulsory in all types of public transport. In case people are not living in the same household but sitting in the same vehicle, they also have to wear the masks in private cars.

The Spanish government is requiring that face masks be used by everyone age six or older in enclosed spaces and public areas where it is impossible to maintain six feet of social distance. The order recommends but does not require mask use by children between age three and five. Those individuals who are engaged in activities that make mask use problematic or those with a medical condition where mask use is contraindicated are excepted from the requirement.
Authorities in Spain set up about 30,000 roadblocks to prohibit traveling during the lockdown, to be lifting at the end of the "State of Alarm".

Spain on May 3 announces that starting from May 4 athletes qualified by the Higher Sports Council as being of a high level or of national interest, may carry out training individually, outdoors, in the province where they reside. They may freely access, if necessary, those natural spaces in which they must carry out their sporting activities, such as the sea, rivers, or reservoirs. The duration and schedule of the training will not be limited and may be accompanied by a coach and another companion in the case of Paralympic modalities.

Effective June 2nd, Spain will allow "passengers and vehicles as passengers on passenger ships" in the ports of the Canary Islands to "embark and disembark... on the maritime lines between the peninsula and the Autonomous Community of the Canary Islands."
Starting on 21st June 2020, Spain reopens its internal borders and there is free movement between all provinces and autonomous communities.

The Spanish Government plan issued on April 28th to de-escalate the measures taken as a consequence of the COVID-19 outbreak is structured in 4 phases with a duration of 2 weeks per phase. The de-escalation will be carried out based on the control of the pandemic in each province and islands and at the speed allowed by the health situation in that area, in accordance with objective criteria. The process will not be uniform, but asymmetric and with different speeds.

The Community of Madrid, Spain, moved into phase 1 of the reopening plan on May 25, 2020, ending the lockdown that had been in place since mid-March. Inter-regional travel is still not permitted.

"Residents in the two cities can now meet in groups of up to 10 people in their homes or on the terraces of bars and restaurants. The gates of the capital's parks will also be reopened, and major museums will be able to receive a limited number of visitors."

The Community of Madrid, Spain, moved to Phase 2 of easing lockdown restrictions on June 5, 2020. Phase 2 includes "Bigger social meetings, more freedom of movement & more time to exercise." Groups of up to 15 people can meet with social distancing and mask wearing if 2 meters of space is not possible. Exercise is allowed at any time except for hours reserved for elderly people. Retail stores can open to 40% capacity, while large shopping centers can have 30% capacity in common areas and 40% in stores. Restaurants and bars can open indoor spaces with 40% capacity and hotels are limited to 30%. Outdoor spaces may have 50% capacity with a limit of 10 people per group. Nightclubs remain closed. Cultural activities and libraries may operate with 30% capacity. Tourism can operate in groups of up to 20. Non-professional athletes may train, while professionals are limited to 14 people and 50% of the facility's capacity. Churches may open with 50% capacity and weddings may have up to 50 guests indoors or 100 outdoors. Casinos may open at 50% capacity. Funerals may have 25 people outside or 15 people inside. Bull rings may fill 30% capacity with pre-assigned seats but may not exceed 400 people.
Spain  announces the convening of an Interterritorial Council to address the situation of the coronavirus on Feb 01 due to a confirmed case in La Gomera
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Spain agrees to create the Inter-Ministerial Coordination Committee to address the public health threat posed by the coronavirus on Feb 04
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Spanish Government on March 21 constitutes the Scientific Technical COVID-19 Committee
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On 24 March, the Spanish government seized control of private nursing homes nationwide, and announced a judicial inquiry after deployed troops found nursing home patients who had died of CoVid-19 left dead in their beds.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Spain on April 6, during the session held by the Interterritorial Council of the National Health Service (CISNS), agreed that the Autonomous Communities appoint two managers (technical and political) to act as interlocutors for the reduction phase of the isolation and social distancing measures once the pandemic situation is considered controlled according to epidemiological data.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Spain recommend holding mass sports competitions with teams from risk areas behind closed doors on March 3. Behind closed doors will be those professional sports competitions where a high presence of amateurs is expected from the coronavirus risk areas, the four regions of Northern Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Piedmont and Emilia Romagna), China, Japan, South Korea, Iran and Singapore).

As part of its declaration of emergency, Spain on March 14 establishes a set of measurements for its internal transport: the frequency of public transport shall be reduced by at least 50%. This applies to both private and state owned road, rail, air and sea passenger transport services. If for technical or operational reasons the direct application of the percentages established from the first day is not feasible, the quickest possible adjustment of the services should be carried out, which may not last more than five days. (Article 14)

Spain (Mallorca) closes nuring home as 90% of elderly residents test positive for coronavirus. The residents are either transported into hospitals or taken care  for by healthcare professionals at family members " homes

Spain has approved a rule to authorize the development of a mobile phone application that allows the health authorities to geolocate all citizens for the "purpose of verifying that they are in the autonomous community in which they claim to be" on April 06.

Spain launches public awareness and information campaign #EsteVirusLoParamosUnidos (We are stopping this virus together) directed at all citizens starting from March 15, the campaign reminds people to stay at home, wash their hands frequently, no to share fake news, amongst others - it is distributed on different kinds of public and private media

Traffic Management Centres in Spain are continuously providing essential information to citizens and freight transport professionals. Variable Message Panels are updated with the status of the situation, including information on border crossings.

Spain on march 9 recommends to all elderly people, who suffer from chronic, multipathological diseases or with congenital or acquired immunosuppression states that limit the exits from their home or residence. In any case, it is recommended to avoid crowded places where it is not possible to maintain the interpersonal safety distance of at least one meter. Additionally, People who begin to experience respiratory symptoms and/or fever are recommended to stay at home and avoid going to health centres, provided that their clinical situation allows it, and to their workplace.

Effective May 15, passengers arriving in Spain from other countries will be required to quarantine at their home/place of accommodation for the 14 days immediately following their arrival. During the mandatory quarantine period following your arrival in Spain, you will only be allowed to leave your home/accommodation to shop for food, medications, or other basic necessities, to seek medical assistance, or in other very limited emergency circumstances.
Spain enforces a two-week quarantine on all individuals coming from abroad, with exceptions for cross-border workers, crews, working health professionals and transporters of goods.

On June 21, Spain declared that all individuals entering the country not from the EU, Schengen member states and a list of approved third countries will be required to be subjected to a 14 day quarantine (with the exception of "basic activities only, such as buying necessary products or for health reasons.")

Spain (risk areas, Madrid, Victoria, Labastida) recommends carrying out teleworking whenever possible.
Review and update of the plans for continuity of the work activity in case of emergencies. Flexibility in working hours and staggered shifts to reduce worker concentrations. Favouring meetings by videoconference.

As part of its declaration of emergency, Spain on March 14 suspends the opening to the public of retail establishments with the exception of retail commercial establishments for food, beverages, products and basic necessities, pharmaceutical establishments, medical, optical and orthopedic products, hygienic products, hairdressing salons, newspapers and stationery, automotive fuel, tobacconists, technological and telecommunications equipment, pet food, internet commerce, telephone or correspondence, dry cleaners and laundries. Any other activity or establishment that in the opinion of the competent authority may pose a risk of contagion is suspended.
La Liga Santander (Spain's top-flight football league) suspended indefinitely.
Spain ordered the closure of all hotels, holiday apartments and campsites from March 24

The Spanish Health ministry announces on April 30 that starting from May 2, non-professional activities of care and collection of agricultural products can be carried out in the same municipality or in the neighbouring ones. It will have to be done individually, except if accompanied by a dependent person or child.

Spain announces on May 3 that starting from May 4 shops of less than 400 square meters may be opened to the public, always by appointment, which must be arranged by email or telephone. They must reserve a priority schedule for those over 65 years old, which must coincide with the time frame assigned to them for walks (although in this case it is for those over 70): from 10-12 am  and from 7-8 pm. There can be no more than one customer per employee.

"Bars and restaurants in Madrid and Barcelona will be allowed to reopen from Monday on pavements and terraces at half capacity. Churches can also reopen and people will be free to travel around their own province."
"Theatres, cinemas, art galleries and museums can reopen in Madrid and Barcelona from Monday at no more than a third of capacity. Trips between provinces remain prohibited."
The Prado, Reina Sofia, and Thyssen-Bornemisza museums in Madrid, Spain, were closed from March 11, 2020 until June 6.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Spain has announced that state museums managed by the Ministry of Culture and Sport will reopen to the public on Tuesday 9 June during standard opening times. The museums will temporarily adapt their exhibitions and reduce the number of rooms that can be visited in order to guarantee compliance with prevention measures.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Aena, Spain's state-owned airport operator, opened terminal 1 of Barajas Airport in Madrid on July 1, 2020. Previously, only terminal 4 was open.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: As part of its declaration of emergency, Spain on March 14 suspends the opening to the public of museums, archives, libraries, monuments, as well as of the premises and establishments where public shows take place. Hotel and restaurant activities are suspended, and home delivery services can be exclusively provided. Festivals, parades and popular festivals are also suspended.

Spain on March 9 recommends workers in the areas of significant community transmission (to date Madrid, Vitoria, Labastida) to work from home where possible, or to work in staggered shifts to reduce worker concentration and encourages to hold meetings via videoconference.

Spain suspends all visits to its prisons and social integration centers in the risk areas Madrid, Vitoria and Labastida for 14 days, communication with lawyers and priests shall be carried out through visiting rooms via calls.
Spain announced that starting from March 10, Temporary Centers for Immigrants (CETI) have to set up a room where a COVID-19 patient could be isolated.

As part of its declaration of emergency, Spain on March 14 rules for its public transport, that in those services in which the ticket grants a seat or cabin, the transport operators will take the necessary measures to ensure the maximum possible separation between the passengers. (Article 14)

As part of its declaration of emergency, Spain on March 14 orders that those commercial establishments whose opening is still allowed cannot serve food within the establishment. Apart from that, employees and consumers have to ensure a safety distance of at least 1m.

Spain enforces measures in relation to places of worship and
civil and religious ceremonies as part of the declaration of the state of emergency on March 14 - people attending any ceremony, including funerals, should avoid crowds of people and ensure a distance of at least one metre

Spain announces on May 3 that starting from May 4, in private and complementary private transport (company vehicles whose main activity is not the transport of goods, such as a transport truck from a brewery) of up to nine seats, including the driver, for each row of seats, two people are allowed to be on board, provided they use masks and respect the maximum possible distance between the occupants.

Spain announces on May 3 that starting from May 4 in regular public transport in which all occupants must travel seated, no more than half of the available seats may be occupied. In any case, in the buses the row after the seat occupied by the driver will always be kept empty. In collective public transport of urban and peri-urban travelers (metro, line buses), where there are platforms enabled for the transport of standing passengers, the reference will be the occupation of half of the seats seated and a maximum of two travelers standing per square meter.
With Spain's mandatory face mask order for everyone over the age of six, the order also recommends but does not require mask use by children between age three and five.

The Spanish Prime Minister announced on May 2, that starting May 4, "using masks will be compulsory on the street, in open spaces and any closed place of public use, when it is not possible to maintain a safe distance of at least two metres (6.5ft)." This includes public transportation.

The Swedish National Board of Health and Welfare have clarified that elderly will not be exempt from ICU care due to age discrimination, debunking a rumour that the Board claims to have been spread by media. This was anounced on April 27th, 2020. The Board clarifies that the law states that the patient(s) with highest chance of survival should be prioritized if the ICU unit doesn't have sufficient capacity, in accordance with Swedish law.

The Swedish National Board of Health and Welfare has anounced that the media reporting of risky masks distributed by the Board are untrue. The Board points out that the masks have been tested and certified, as well as approved by the Swedish Work Environment Authority.This was anounced on July 10th, 2020.
Sweden announces the closure of High Schools, Universities and Adult Education - with the recommendation of distance education from March 18.

The Swedish Transport Authority has retracted IranAir's operating authorisation, effectively stopping direct flights between Sweden and Iran. The Authority made the decision on March 2nd after recommendation from the Public Health Authority.

The Swedish Ministry for Foreign affairs have, after recommendations from the Public Health Agency, decided to recommend not to travel to Northern Italy. This was anounced and implemented on March 6th. The risk of infection for travellers to Northern Italy is high, according to the Public Health Agency.
The Swedish Ministry for Foreign Affairs advises against non-essential travel to all countries from March. 14 until April 14
The Government of Sweden announces the closure of borders for all non-EEA or Swiss citizen that travel to Sweden for non-essential travel from March. 19

The Swedish Ministry for Foreign Affairs advises against non-essential travel to all countries except for Belgium, France,
Greece, Iceland, Italy, Croatia, Luxembourg, Portugal, Switzerland, Spain, Hungary, Monaco, San Marino and Vatican
City. For countries in EU/EES and Great Britain not mentioned before, the advise against travel expires on July 15th.
For the rest of the countries the advise against travel is extended until August 31st. Countries that was advised against
to travel to before March 14th by the Ministry for Foreign Affairs, the advise against travel is still valid.

The Swedish Ministry for Foreign Affairs advises against non-essential travel to all countries except for Belgium, France,
Greece, Iceland, Italy, Croatia, Luxembourg, Portugal, Switzerland, Spain, Hungary, Monaco, San Marino and Vatican
City. For countries in EU/EES and Great Britain not mentioned before, the advise against travel expires on July 15th.
For the rest of the countries the advise against travel is extended until August 31st. Countries that was advised against
to travel to before March 14th by the Ministry for Foreign Affairs, the advise against travel is still valid.
The Swedish ministry of foreign affairs advise against travelling to countries outside UK, EU, EES and Schengen until August 29th. This was anounced on July 14th.

The Swedish ministry of foreign affairs advise against travel to UK, EU, EES and Schengen countries except for Belgium, France, Greece, Iceland, Italy, Croatia, Monaco, Luxembourg, Portugal, San Marino, Andorra, Spain, Hungary, Poland, Germany and Vatican City. Switzerland is also except due to a separate policy for the country. This was anounced on July 14th, and is valid until July 29th, 2020.

The Swedish ministry of foreign affairs have advised to avoid unnecessary travel to Switzerland, in order to hindering the spread of coronavirus. This was anounced on July 14th and is valid from July 15th until July 29th, 2020.
The Public Health Agency recommends contact tracing for COVID-19 cases in elderly care facilities in Sweden. This was anounced on May 29th.This applies both to the elderly and to personnell.

The Public Health Agency of Sweden has announced that they are increasing the capacity for laboratory testing of the new coronavirus. The increased capacity is motivated to shorten the transport of tests and because it is desirable for the regions to have capacity and preparedness to perform diagnostics. In total, eight microbiological laboratories will be expanded with the capacity of diagnosing the new coronavirus: Ume ", Uppsala,  "rebro, Sk "vde, Halmstad, Lund, Stockholm and Gothenburg. This was announced by the Public Health Agency of Sweden on February 13, 2020.

The Swedish Armed Forces have conducted a exercise together with the Public Health Agency, Uppsala University Hospital and the Civil Contingencies Agency to establish a temporary, mobile laboratory to be used in case of a large coronavirus outbreak in Sweden. This was anounced on February 26th, shortly after completing the exercise.

The Swedish Medical Products Agency has together with the regional governments in Sweden and the Swedish Association of Local Authorities and Regions mapped out which drugs that are of extra importance. These drugs will be continually monitored in order to predict, prevent and remediate shortages, after being tasked by the Swedish national government. The mapping took place between March 12th and April 3rd, and was anounced on March 12th, 2020.

The Swedish Armed Forces have provided two lab technicians to the Public Health Agency to support the agency's work in containing the spread of the coronavirus. This was announced on March 13th and the technicians will be transferred from March 17th on (2020).

Karolinska Institute has, by request from the Swedish National Board of Health and Welfare, launched online courses for workers in the health care and elderly care sectors in how to handle patients and caretakers infected by coronavirus. The request from  the Swedish National Board of Health and Welfare was anounced on March 9th, 2020 and the courses were launched on March 18th, 2020.
Sweden announced it will use domestic producers to produce an additional 200 000 face masks each month from March 19.

The Swedish Armed Forces have put up a field hospital adjacent to  "stra sjukhuset in G "teborg. The field hospital could accomodate a total of 50 patients, of which 20 for intensive care. The field hospital will be handed over to  "stra sjukhuset on March 27th, 2020. This was announced on March 25th.

The Swedish Armed Forces have provided a field hospital in Stockholmsm "ssan,  "lvsj " that will be able to receive up to 600 patients when finished. The field hospital is ready to receive patients on March 28th and this was announced on March 25th.
Sweden is enforcing a limitation on possibilities to retract more prescripted medications from pharmacies than you need for three months, starting on April 1.

The Swedish Medical Products Agency has limited the prescription of Chloroquine and Hydrochloroquine to be allowed only by doctors with "a certain speciality. The reason is that the medication has been prescribed to COVID-19 related patients even though the medication is not approved to  treat the disease, which leads to a risk of shortage of the medications. This was anounced on April 2nd and is valid until October 31st, 2020.
The Swedish armed forces have delivered masks and other protective material to J "nk "ping, Kronoberg and Sk "ne Regions. This was announced on April 8th, 2020 and the delivery occured on April 5th.

The Public Health Agency in Sweden have started using mobility data from cell phones provided by the telekom company Telia in order to make better decisions to hinder the spread of coronavirus. This was anounced on April 8th.

The Swedish Medical Products Agency has, together with the Swedish Board of Agriculture, has asked veterinarians to be extra restrictive to prescribe medication to animals that is also approved to be used on humans in order to support the healthcare sector during the coronavirus outbreak. This was published on April 8th 2020.
The Swedish Armed Forces have adapted several helicopters to give them the possibility to transport COVID-19 patients. This was announced on April 17th, 2020.
The Swedish National Board of Health and Welfare have on behalf of the Government been instructed to lead an expansion of capacities of beds for intensive care beginning March 20.
The Swedish Armed Forces have supported Norrbotten, S "dermanland and Sk "ne Regions with a total of 12 extra ambulances. This was announced on April 24th, 2020.

The Swedish Medical Products Agency has decided to temporarily allow that manuals for medical products may be written in English, Danish or Norwegian if the product is going to be used by trained helathcare personell to treat COVID-19 patients. This was anounced on May 20th, and is valid from May 20th until December 31st 2020.

The Swedish Medical Products Agency has decided to prohibit the sales of four kinds of face masks that had been stopped in a control by the Swedish Customs due to a lack of proper documentation and certification. The masks had not yet been sold to any customers. This was anounced on June 5th.

The Swedish Public Health Agency has recommended the healthcare system to test Swedes who have been to Northern Italy and is developing COVID-19 symptoms within 14 days after coming home. The recommendation was announced on March 3rd but started on March 2nd.
The Public Health Agency of Sweden announced that they will increase testing of COVID-19 by instructions from the government on March. 31

The Public Health Agency in Sweden are sampling 4000 individuals to test for coronavirus, in order to assess the spread in the country. This was anounced on April 7th. The sampling is similar to a smaller investigation conducted by the Agency previously in the Stockholm area. The Swedish Armed Forces will aid the Public Health Agency in conducting the sampling.

The Public Health Agency in Sweden has anounced a investigation for antibodies in Sweden nationally, from May 3rd until June 28th, in order to assess how many in the population that has COVID-19. This was anounced on May 20th. The investigation is conducted by analysing blood samples in nine regions: J "mtland, J "nk "ping, Kalmar, Sk "ne, Stockholm, Uppsala, V "sterbotten, V "stra G "taland och  "rebro. The investigation is conducted in cooperation with SciLifeLab and Kungliga Tekniska H "gskolan.

The Public Health Agency recommends health screening for COVID-19 cases in elderly care facilities in Sweden. This was anounced on May 29th.This applies both to the elderly and to personnell, that either moves in or are returning from healthcare.

The Public Health Agency in Sweden has recommended increased testing in elderly care, both among elderly and personell. They have also published information to help elderly care centers implement testing in their facilities. This was anounced on May 29th.

The Swedish National Parliament has accepted a proposal from the Government to change the national budget in order to grant the regional governments an additional SEK 60 million to increase the testing capacity. The new budget was decided upon on June 17th and is valid from June 22nd until the end of the year.

The Swedish Public Health Agency are sampling 4000 for testing in order to assess the spread of coronavirus in Sweden. The sampling is conducted between July 29th and July 31st. This was anounced on July 29th, 2020.

The Swedish Public Health Agency has initiated a sampling of individuals for testing of coronavirus in order to assess the spread in Swedish society. 4000 individuals will be sampled from a panel of participants. This will take place from August 28th until the beginning of October, and was anounced on August 28th, 2020.

The Public Health Agency in Sweden has on March 24th anounced recommendations for workouts, exercises, sporting and small-scale sporting events. They are to continue, but those that are sick should not participate, those over 70 shouldn't take part in indoors activities, water bottles and similar shouldn't be shared among participators, contact is to be minimized, crowding avoided and sanitary facilities provided. Sporting facilities such as gyms can be kept open and small-scale events can still take place.
The Public Health Agency in Sweden have recommended not to travel within the country unless necessary, due to the risk of spreading coronavirus to other geographical regions within the country.

The Swedish Armed Forces has, after being adviced by the Public Health Agency, decided to make conscripts stay for an additional 14 days in the garrison in order to decrease the risk of coronavirus spreading between the regions in Sweden. This was anounced on April 3rd and the conscripts will stay until April 17th, 2020.

The Government of Sweden has decided to allow for school closures of all schools in the country, a region or singular schools depending on the need to hinder the spread of the coronavirus. The decision could be taken by the Government, a Region, a Municipality, a Headmaster or an expert agency such as the Public Health Agency. The decree was published on March 13th 2020, and is valid from March 16th 2020 until 30th of June 2021. It also allows the school(s) to offer distance education, have tuition on weekends, public holidays and/or extending the school semester in order to provide the pupils their right to education.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Public Health Agency of Sweden has presented a new advisory group, that will consist of external experts to support the agency's decision making. This was anounced on April 17th, 2020. The new advisory groupe will however not be given any direct decision-making power.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Swedish Parliament has decided to grant the Swedish Governement the authorization to sign an agreement on COVID-19 vaccine and to grant the Public Health Authority the possibility to lend up to SEK 2 billion at the Swedish National Debt Office. The decision was made on June 23rd and is part of a change in the national budget, which expires at the end of the year.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Public Health Agency of Sweden have written information available at the Arlanda airport for travellers on how to act if one has visited an area affected by the new coronavirus and then develops symptoms. As of February 24th, this applies to China and some parts of South Korea, Italy and Iran. The Public Health Agency of Sweden recommmends those that have visited any of those places to call 1177 V "rdguiden for assessment.

The Government of Sweden has decided to issue a public annuncement to: stay home if having symptoms; avoid non-necessary visits to nursing homes and hospitals; and to often wash hands with soap and water. The public announcement was announced on March 15th in accordance with the Public Health Agency, the Swedish Civil Contingencies Agency and the National Board of Health and Welfare. The Swedish Civil Contingencies Agency has the responsibility to spread the public announcement to anyone currently in Sweden and to establish effective channels of communication with the public.

The Swedish Medical Products Agency have published information that antipyretic drugs, that alleviates fever, are neither beneficial or harmful effects on COVID-19 as of the current scientific data. The information was published due to questions brought to the agency. This was published on March 16th, 2020.
The Swedish Medical Products Agency has published a warning that a self-test for COVID-19 is not enough to be considered a diagnosis of the disease. This was anounced on March 19th, 2020.

The Swedish Medical Products Agency has anounced an encouragement for doctors and patients to keep up the treatments with ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin II receptor blockers even though the patient is diagnosed with COVID-19, since there are no clinical evidence that prove any harmful effects of the medications on patients with COVID-19. This was anounced on March 23rd, 2020.

The Public Health Agency in Sweden has informed the public that the vaccines against the flu or pneumococci doesn't help against the lung infection caused by the coronavirus. The Agency points out that there is no vaccine against the coronavirus yet. This was anounced on March 26th.

The Swedish Medical Products Agency have published information stating that Chloroquine and Hydroxychloroquine should not be used for self-medication, and that it should only be used to patients who are participating in clinical studies. This was anounced on April 2nd, 2020.

The Swedish Medical Products Agency discourages the public and companies to buy and use self-testing kits for the coronavirus, since they don't live up to the standards for self-testing kits. Using and misinterpreting immunity to coronavirus might lead to a wider spread of the virus. This information was anounced on April 21st, 2020.

The Swedish Medical Products Agency advises against self-testing to prove COVID-19. Such tests can be purchased on the internet, but you run the risk of doing more harm than good because they are not reliable enough, states the agency. This public awareness anouncement was published on April 22nd, 2020.

Sweden's Public Health Agency have published information regarding Walpurgis night, first of May demonstrations and Ramadan with Eid al-Fitr. The Agency ask people to avoid parties and not to form crowds. They highlight the importance of social distance even tohugh it's outdoors. They also remind that mosques will be closed.

The Swedish Medical Products Agency encourages the public to report suspected side effects of medication to COVID-19 that they experience during treatment. The side effects ould both be reported to healthcare personell or directly to the Medical Products Agency. This was anounced on April 24th, 2020.

Sweden's Public Health Agency has informed the public that graduation ceremonies from schools are recommended to be held small and to avoid crowding. Private events to celebrate the graduation is also seen as unsuitable. Individuals in risk groups are recommended not to participate in graduation ceremonies at all. This public awareness anouncement was published on April 28th.

Sweden's Public Health Agency have published information recommending pregnant individuals with risk factors (obesity, high blood pressure or diabetes, etc.) to be extra careful to avoid the virus. This was stated on April 29th.

The Public Health Agency in Sweden has published updated information to the public regarding the immunity and antibodies and the coronavirus. According to the Agency, a person who have antibodies after a COVID-19 infection is regarded to have an increased protection against the coronavirus that is estimated to decrease gradually during the first year. Longer term protection varies, depending on the individual. This was anounced to the public on May 4th, and is based on research from Karolinska Institutet.

Sweden's Public Health Agency, together with Stockholm Region, have created a national phone number where Swedish citizens can call to get information about the coronavirus. The number is aimed at non-Swedish speakers and has telephonists speaking six languages: Arabic, Somali, Persian, Tigrinya and Russian. Swedish speakers already have a number for health concerns. This was announced on June 3rd.

The Swedish Public Health Agency has published a new guidance on contact tracing as of July 21st, 2020. The guidance specifies that a coronavirus infected individual should take responsibility and inform those that they possibly could have had contact with, and to do it as soon as possible. This guidance take into effect on July 23rd, 2020.

The Swedish National Board of Health and Welfare has anounced a clarification due to a misunderstanding of a previously issued regulation regarding the prohibition to visit nursering homes. The Board clarifies that the elderly in nursing homes can leave as they please, by themselves or with personell, but it is prohibited for visitors to visit outside areas belonging to the nursering homes (terraces etc.). This was anounced on August 19th, 2020 due to a confusion in news media.

The Swedish Prison and Probation Service has decided to limit the possibility to visit convicts, in order to hinder the spread of the coronavirus. This is due to hinder the loss of personell and protecting convicts, who have a generally lower health status and less possibilities to protect themselves from being exposed.
The Public Health Agency has rekommended people over the age of 70 to limit contact with other people unless absolutely necessary. The recommendation was issued on March 16th

The Swedish Transport Agency have decided to implement recommendations from EASA to disinfect planes that are returning from destinations with high risk for coronavirus spread. Also, aircraft carriers are encouraged to spread out travellers on flights that are not fully booked and provide disinfection napkins. This was decided on March 13th.

The Public Health Agency of Sweden has asked those companies that have the possibility to, to recommend their employees to work from home. It would help alleviate the health care system and dampen down the spread of the coronavirus, according to the Agency. This was announced on March 16th.

The Swedish Medical Agency has decided to prohibit two self-testing kits for coronavirus sold to Swedish customers by the companies ZandCell AB and Dental Clinic Sweden. The testing kits lack proper certification. This was anounced on March 24th, 2020.

The Public Health Agency in Sweden has decided to lift some rules on production of disinfectants. Producers doesn't, until December 31st 2020, have to denature alcohol for disinfectants and will also be allowed to choose from a wider range of denaturing substances. This was decided and anounced on March 27th, in order to alleviate for producers to meet the increased demand for disinfectants.
The Swedish Public Health Agency recommends those who can to work from home to avoid crowds during commute and in work places. This was anounced in April 1st and is valid until December 31st, 2020.

The Swedish Medical Agency has decided to prohibit self-testing kits for coronavirus sold to Swedish customers by
the company lifelab.se. The testing kits lack proper certification. This was anounced on April 9th, 2020.

The Swedish Medical Products Agency has decided to allow an exception and allow medication to be transferred between pharmacies under certain circumstances. This was anounced on May 6th, and is valid from April 21st until December 31st, 2020.

The Swedish Medical Agency has decided to prohibit self-testing kits for coronavirus sold to Swedish customers by the
companies Arsan medical AB, Spyder Group and Sypip AB. The testing kits lack proper documentation. This was anounced on May 4th, 2020.

The Swedish Medical Products Agency has allowed several excemptions from the regular rules for pharmaceutical products, so that some products may have foreign packaging or have outdated manuals. This was anounced on May 5th, 2020.

The Swedish Medical Agency has decided to prohibit self-testing kits for coronavirus sold to Swedish customers by the company aponea.se. The testing kits lack proper documentation. This was
anounced on May 18th, 2020.

The Public Health Agency in Sweden has released guidelines for businesses that offer antibody testing for coronavirus antibodies. The guidelines offer information on how to interpret results, the limitations of different tests etc. The Agency published the guidelines on June 8th.

The Swedish National Parliament has approved a law proposal from the Govenrment, stating that restaurant, bar and other serving places owners have responsibility to limit crowding and have routines in place to hinder the spread of coronavirus. The municipal governments together with Police are to be enforcers of the new law. The law is valid from July 1st until the end of the year and was decided on June 17th (2020).

The Swedish Parliament has approved a proposal to extend the mineral exploration rights that would otherwise be expiring after July 1st, 2020 to be extended for another year. However, coal and oil exploration rights are except from the extension. The reason is that prospecting companies otherwise risk to be heavily impacted by the spread of the coronavirus. The extension is valid from July 1st, 2020 and the Parliament made the decision on June 23rd, 2020.

The Swedish Public Health Authority has published their guidelines on how caf "s, restaurants, bars and other places that serves food and drinks are to regulate their businesses in order to hinder the spread of the coronavirus. These guidelines specify the implementation of a previous law regarding the matter and are therefore comulsory. Local authorities and the Police are therefore responsible to make sure that the guidlines are followed, as stated in the previous law. This was anounced on July 2nd, and the guidelines are valid from July 7th, and is dependent on the previously decided temporary law which expires by the end of 2020.

The Swedish Armed Forces decided to put the Swedish Home Guard's education and operations on hold from March 23rd, 2020 until August 31st, 2020 due to the risk of coronavirus transmission. This was decided on April 7th.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Swedish Government has decided to extend the validity periods for seamens' and ships' certificates for six months, to give them time to qualify for a extension that involves (among other things) doctor visits and education that now is more difficult to get due to the coronavirus. This was decided on March 26th 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Swedish Authority has decided to implement a EU regulation to extend the validity of driving licenses and vehicle inspections that was due between February 1st and August 31st for an additional 7 months. This applies from June 4th and was originally published on June 1st, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Swedish National Board of Health and Welfare has allowed for self-testing for cervical cancer (Human papillomavirus infection), the screening of which had been stopped in several regions due to a focus on the coronavirus. It is also due to difficulties of receiving patients for human papillomavirus caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The new guidance is valid from June 30th, 2020 until June 30th, 2021. This was anounced on June 30th, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Sweden announces restrictions to public gatherings, with a limitation of 500 people, going into effect on March. 12

After recommendation from the Public Health Agency of Sweden, the Swedish Sports Confederation has decided to cancel or postpone all sports contests, competitive games and similar in Sweden in all kinds of sports. Except from this is friendly games, that are recommended to be postponed but can take place if the recommendations from the Public Health Agency is followed otherwise, including the recommendation to limit gatherings to a maximum to 50 persons. This was anounced on April 2nd, and was valid until June 14th when the Public Health Agency changed its recommendations.

The Public Health Agency in Sweden has recommended not to celebrate the spring's holidays, for example easter, ramadan, eid al-fitr, pesach and others with friends and family. Instead, the Agency recommends everyone to be mindful to hinder the spread of the coronavirus. This was anounced on April 9th, 2020.

The Swedish Transport Authority has decided to stop carneval wagons and other celebratory platforms pulled by another vehicle. This includes the traditional studentflak for graduates from upper secondary school. This was announced on May 14th, and the prohibition runs from May 15th to 31st of December 2020. It was decided after a recommendation from the Public Health Authority, who wants to hinder crowding on and around platforms.
Sweden's Public Health Agency introduced a policy that only allows table service at restaurants, bars, night clubs, and caf "s from March 24.

The Public Health Agency in Sweden have released recommendations for travelling in the summer. The Agency recommends that people walk, bike and avoid public transport. If public transport is to be used, it is preferrable to book a seat, if possible. This was announced on June 11th, and are valid from June 13th.

The Swedish Public Health Agency has released new voluntary recommendations for choir leaders and participants in order to make choir repetition and practice as safe from coronavirus transmission as possible. They recommend at least 2 metre distance between participants, and that it is better to have choirs singing outside or in large venues with good ventilation rather than inside smaller venues. This was anounced on August 13th.
The Swiss Federal council announces on March 13th that all schools will be closed effective immediately until at least April 4th.
March 16 Switzerland Schaffhausen, school closure

"At its meeting on April 29, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council decided to further ease the measures introduced to protect the population against the coronavirus. From Monday, May 11 in schools of the upper secondary level (age above 16) and the tertiary level as well as other training facilities, classes involving up to five students, including music lessons can resume. Exams can be held, provided the rules on hygiene and social distancing are respected. Classes involving larger groups should be possible from 8 June."

on February 28, 2020 the Swiss federal council declares a "special situation" (spezielle Lage) , the first step in the epidemics act, allowing the federal council to take over some competences from the cantonal level.

On June 19, 2020  the Swiss Federal Council announced the return to the "particular situation" [spezielle Lage] according to Swiss Epidemics Act the same day.
( the extraordinary situation is ended)
On January 25, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health recommended on its webside not to travel to Wuhan/Chine and recommends precautionary measures for all persons travelling to Chine.
On February 4, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health recommended on its webside not to travel to the province Hubei/China and recommends precautionary measures for all persons travelling to China.

Since the 9th of March 2020, the swiss border controls set up a monitoring system to monitor the effectiveness of the Italian measures. The border control (EZV) uses intensified sampling and checks that are carried out on a risk basis at the border to Italy. An example of such measures would be the checking of passports and work permits.

The swiss federal council decided that from the 11th of March 2020 on Switzerland cross-border travelling from Italy to Switzerland will be limited to only a few borders crossings. The small border crossings will be closed and the border traffic will be channeled to the big border crossings. 

Following the closed border crossings -> alternative open border crossings

Pedrinate -> Chiasso strada (Ponte Chiasso)
Ponte Faloppia -> Novazzano Brusata (Bizzarone) or Chiasso strada
Novazzano Marcetto -> Novazzano Brusata (Bizzarone) or Chiasso strada
San Pietro di Stabio -> Stabio Gaggiolo
Ligornetto Cantinetta -> Stabio Gaggiolo
Arzo -> Stabio Gaggiolo or Brusino Arsizio
Ponte Cremenaga -> Fornasette or Ponte Tresa
Cassinone -> Fornasette
Indemini -> Dirinella (Zenna)

Since the 9th of March 2020 the swiss border controls setup a monitoring system to monitor the effectiveness of the Italian measures. The border control (EZV) uses intensified sampling and checks that are carried out on a risk basis. An example of such measures would be the checking of passports.

On March 13th 2020, the Swiss Federal Council re-opens federal border checks including Schengen checks, designed to limit incoming and outgoing traffic to Italy. Only Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons are allowed to enter Italy. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from Italy.

On March 13th 2020, the Swiss Federal Council re-opens federal border checks including Schengen checks, designed to limit incoming and outgoing traffic to Italy. Only Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons are allowed to enter Italy. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from Italy.

From the 17th of March onwards, the Swiss Federal Council extends the travel ban introduced to Italy to France, Austria and Germany. Entrance remains allowed for Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland, people traveling through Switzerland, and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed.

On March 18, the Swiss Federal Council extends the external border checks introduced to Germany, Austria, Italy and France to foreign travelers from Spain and all non-Schengen states. Entrance remains allowed for Swiss citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland, people traveling through Switzerland, and people who have to travel to Switzerland for professional reasons as well as supporting health care workers. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from these countries.

The list of countries considered as risk countries was updated on 23 July 2020 by the Swiss Government. From July 6th on all persons who enter Switzerland and who have been in a high risk country within the last 14 days have to quarantine for 10 days. They have to report to the cantonal authorities that carry out spot checks. Contact details are provided by flights or bus services selected at random. Quarantined persons do not get loss of earnings compensation. Non - compliance can be fined.
Excepted are persons who
professionally transport people or goods across borders
whose activity is necessary the functionality of the health system, public security or some international institutions
have stayed in a risk country in the course of their professional activity in companies involved in rail, bus, ship or air transport 
have to travel to Switzerland daily or up to 5 days for occupational or medical necessities
transit passengers
just pass through Switzerland
list as of July 23th: Argentina, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Bolivia, Bosnia Herzegovina, Brazil, Chile, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Eswatini, Guatemala, Honduras, Iraq, Israel, Cabo Verde, Qatar, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Colombia, Kosovo, Kuwait, Luxembourg, Maledives, Mexico, Moldova, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Oman, Palestine, Panama, Peru, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, South Africa, Suriname, Turks- and Caicos islands (UK), UAE, USA, Puerto Rico, American Virgin Islands

The list of considered risk countries was updated on August 8, 2020 by the Swiss FOPH. As before all persons entering Switzerland coming from a risk country have to quarantine for 10 days, a negative test result does not exempt from the mandatory quarantine requirement. They have to report to the cantonal authorities that carry out spot checks. Exempted are transport professionals, transit passengers, cross border commuter, professionals needed in health system, public security, in some international institutions.
beside some areas the list of risk countries as of August 8th: Argentina, Armenia, Bahamas, Bahrain, Bolivia, Bosnia Herzegovina, Brazil, Cabo Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Equatorial Guinea, Eswatini, Guatemala, Honduras, Iraq, Israel, Qatar, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Kosovo, Kuwait, Luxembourg, Maledives, Mexico, Moldova, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Oman, Palestine, Panama, Peru, Romania, Sao Tome and Principe, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Singapur, Sint Maarten, South Africa, Suriname, Turks- and Caicos islands, USA ( including Puerto Rico, American Virgin Islands)

The list of considered risk countries was updated on August 8, 2020 by the Swiss FOPH. As before all persons entering Switzerland coming from a risk country have to quarantine for 10 days, a negative test result does not exempt from the mandatory quarantine requirement. They have to report to the cantonal authorities that carry out spot checks. Exempted are transport professionals, transit passengers, cross border commuter, professionals needed in health system, public security, in some international institutions.
on the list as of August 8th:  mainlaind Spain (except Balearic and Canaric Islands)

The list of considered risk countries was updated on August 20, 2020 by the Swiss FOPH. As before all persons entering Switzerland coming from a risk country have to quarantine for 10 days, a negative test result does not exempt from the mandatory quarantine requirement. Quarantined persons do not get loss of earnings compensation, but exempted they could not know in advance that their travel destination will be a risk area. They have to report to the cantonal authorities that carry out spot checks. Exempted are transport professionals, transit passengers, cross border commuter, professionals needed in health system, public security, in some international institutions.
list of risk countries as of August 20th: Albania, Andorra, Argentina, Armenia, Aruba, Bahamas, Bahrain, Belgium, Belize, Bolivia, Bosnia Herzegovina, Brazil, Cabo Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Eswatini, Faroe Islands, Gibraltar, Guam, Guatemala, Honduras, India, Iraq, Israel, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Kosovo, Kuwait, Luxembourg, Maledives, Malta, Mexico, Moldova, Monaco, Montenegro, Namibia, North Macedonia, Oman, Palestine, Panama, Peru, Qatar, Romania, Sint Maarten, South Africa, Suriname, Turks- and Caicos islands, USA ( including Puerto Rico, American Virgin Islands)

The list of considered risk countries was updated on August 20, 2020 by the Swiss FOPH. As before all persons entering Switzerland coming from a risk country have to quarantine for 10 days, a negative test result does not exempt from the mandatory quarantine requirement. Quarantined persons do not get loss of earnings compensation, but exempted they could not know in advance that their travel destination will be a risk area. They have to report to the cantonal authorities that carry out spot checks. Exempted are transport professionals, transit passengers, cross border commuter, professionals needed in health system, public security, in some international institutions.
on the list of risk countries as of August 20th: Spain including Balearic Islands and except Canary Islands

The list of considered risk countries was updated on September 7th, 2020 by the Swiss FOPH. As before all persons entering Switzerland having stayed in a risk country within the last 14 days have to quarantine for 10 days, a negative test result does not exempt from the mandatory quarantine requirement. Quarantined persons do not get loss of earnings compensation, but exempted they could not know in advance that their travel destination will be a risk area. They have to report to the cantonal authorities that carry out spot checks. Exempted are diplomats, transport professionals, transit passengers, cross border commuter, professionals needed in health system, public security, in some international institutions.
list of risk countries as of September 7th: Albania, Andorra, Argentina, Armenia, Aruba, Bahamas, Bahrain, Belize, Bolivia, Bosnia Herzegovina, Brazil, Cabo Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Croatia, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Faroe Islands, French Polynesia, Gibraltar, Guam, Guatemala, Guyana, Honduras, India, Iraq, Israel, Kosovo, Kuwait, Lebanon, Libya, Maledives, Malta, Moldova, Monaco, Montenegro, Namibia, North Macedonia, Palestine, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Qatar, Romania, San Marino, Sint Maarten, South Africa, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago, Turks- and Caicos islands, Ukraine, United Arab Emirates, USA ( including Puerto Rico, American Virgin Islands)

On Sept 11, the Swiss Federal Council decided on the quarantine rules after Sept 14 for persons entering Switzerland: only those regions of neighbouring countries with a high infection rate will be added to the list of risk countries, not the whole country. Border regions may be exempted. As before all persons entering Switzerland having stayed in a risk country within the last 10 ! days have to quarantine for 10 days, a negative test result does not exempt from the mandatory quarantine requirement. Quarantined persons do not get loss of earnings compensation,(except change of list after departure).They have to report to the cantonal authorities that can adjust the duration of the quarantine and carry out spot checks. Starting Sept. 14  professionals re-entering after participating in an event complying with a protection concept; e.g. sports competition or cultural event or a specialist congress are exempted and as before diplomats, transport professionals, transit passengers, cross border commuter, professionals needed in health system, public security, in some international institutions. list of French risk areas as of September 14h: Centre-Val de Loire, Corse, Hauts-de-France,  "le de France, Normandie, Nouvelle-Aquitaine, Occitanie, Pays de la Loire, Provence-Alpes-C "te d'Azur and following overseas areas: French Guyana, Guadeloupe, La R "union, Martinique, Mayotte

Border regions may be exempted. As before all persons entering Switzerland having stayed in a risk country within the last 10 ! days have to quarantine for 10 days, a negative test result does not exempt from the mandatory quarantine requirement. Border regions may be exempted. On Sept 11, the Swiss Federal Council decided on the new list of risk countries as of Sept.14. All persons entering Switzerland having stayed in a risk country within the last 10 ! days have to quarantine for 10 days, a negative test result does not exempt from the quarantine requirement. There is no loss of earnings compensation (except change of list after departure). Travelers have to report to the cantonal authorities that can adjust the duration of the quarantine and carry out spot checks.  risk countries Sept. 14h: Albania, Andorra, Argentina, Armenia, Aruba, Bahamas, Bahrain, Belize, Bolivia, Bosnia Herzegovina, Brazil, British Virgin Islands, Cabo Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Croatia, Czech Republic, Dominican Republic, Gibraltar, Guyana, Honduras, India, Iraq, Israel, Kosovo, Kuwait, Lebanon, Libya, Maledives, Malta, Moldova, Monaco, Montenegro, Namibia, North Macedonia, Palestine, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Qatar, Romania, San Marino, Sint Maarten, Spain (incl. Balearic and Canaric Islands), Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago, Turks- and Caicos islands, Ukraine, UAE, USA ( incl Puerto Rico, US Virgin Islands, Guam)

On its press conference on February 25, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health informed about the first person in Switzerland confirmed as being infected with the new coronavirus 2019-nCoV. People in close contact with the individual are being notified and placed in quarantine and their condition will be monitored over the next 14 days. On its webside ( February 16) the FOPH informed:" Should there be cases, the sick people would be isolated. Close Contact persons would have to be in quarantine for two weeks." On the webside for health professionals ( Feb 17) the term close contact is specified:
Contact from less than 2 meters and for more than 15 minutes. People who live in the same household. Care or medical examination without protective gear. Direct contact with body fluids. The cantonal departements of Health (Kantonsarzt) are responsible for tracing contact persons and monitoring their condition.
Swiss Federal Health Authority releases guidelines for healthcare workers, including protective wear necessary and protocol for workers experiencing flu-like symptoms on April 2nd 2020.

On May 8, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council announced to issue a temporary ordinance (amended May 14) for the pilot phase of a mobile application (proximity tracing app) that informs its users when they have been around infected people for too long. 
The app is expected to be tested by employees of the Swiss Federal Institutes of Technology in Lausanne and Zurich, by members of the armed forces and employees of hospitals as well as the federal and cantonal administrations. 
The parliament decided this week (May 5) that a legal basis must be created before the launch of the App. To this end, the Federal Council will amend the Epidemics Act accordingly and submit an urgent message to be adopted by parliament
The app is designed to help break chains of infection. With the app, potentially infected people can be warned at an early stage and the spread of the virus can be contained without compromising their privacy. Use of the app is voluntary. No personal data or location details of the app users are used. All data in the app are continuously deleted after 21 days. The app should only be used in the containment phase.

At its meeting on June 24th, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council adopted the Ordinance on the Proximity Tracing System for the Coronavirus. 
This means that the SwissCovid app can be used throughout Switzerland from June 25th.
The Federal Council recommends that the public use the app, which complements classic contact tracing. 
If an app user has been in close contact with one or more infected individuals, they receive a message telling them that they may be infected with the new coronavirus. They are also notified of the day on which the contact took place along with details of the FOPH Infoline that they can call free of charge to obtain advice.

On March 13th the Swiss Federal council releases guidelines for the provision of health resources within Switzerland related to COVID-19. These provisions include the procurement of COVID-19 tests by the Swiss red cross, a fair allocation of protective, treatment and diagnosis devices. Also, a requirement for hospitals, manufacturers and cantons to give supply information to the federal government to regulate stocks nationally.
