The Swiss Federal Council implements an export control on health resources including protective gear to ensure Swiss supply remains high during the COVID-19 pandemic. Exports will be allowed for items which all Swiss cantons are in satisfactory stock of. Implemented on March 13th 2020

On March 27th, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health announced that with the help of Swisscom "s analyses and visualisations, it is assessing whether the ban on gathering of more than five people in public ( by the Federal Council as of March 21st) is being respected. At no point location data from Swisscom are provided, merely analyses and visualisations. The data on which the analyses are based are anonymised and aggregated. It is not possible to make inferences about specific individuals. As soon as COVID-19 Ordinance 2 is abrogated, the Federal Office will not be provided with any further analyses.

The Swiss Federal Council is giving the Confederation more powers to coordinate the supply of important medical goods to combat the corona virus, including the obligation of individual cantons to report medical supply stocks in order to avoid bottlenecks in supply, enacted on April 3rd 2020

The COVID-19 response strategy for Libya presents the joint approach of the humanitarian community to respond to the public health needs and immediate humanitarian consequences (both direct and indirect) of the pandemic across the country.
The Swiss Federal council and health organisation recommends the use of personal protective gear for healthcare professionals and vulnerable people on April 24th 2020.

On January 25th, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Public Health informed on its webside about a new Coronavirus outbreak in Chine.
The National Reference Center for Emerging Viral Diseases (NAVI) in Geneva is able to detect the new coronavirus by laboratory diagnostics. Suspected cases would be clarified according to the existing guidelines for MERS and, if necessary, treated.
The Head of the Division of Infectious Diseases of the university hospital of Geneva told Swiss public television on January 24: that the test is very simple: a swab is taken from the back of the throat or from the nose with a cotton bud. It would be applied to people coming back from China who present cold-like symptoms that include coughing, fever, muscular pain and breathing difficulties.

On March 13, the Swiss Federal Council announces the immediate closure of ski areas and mountain railways in the canton of Grisons. The cantonal government had allowed operation until March 15. The federal regulation is above the canton regulation.
On March 26, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health issued guidelines for burials of those who died on Covid 19.

On its press conference March 20, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council announced that it was not imposing a lockdown but appealing to the people's responsibility to adhere to the rules.
On March 22, the recommandations on the FOPHs webside "Protect yourself and others" were changed to
Stay at home from now on. Except in the following cases:
    You have to buy groceries
    You have to go to the doctor "s/to the pharmacy
    You have to help others
    You are unable to work from home and have to go to work
Switzerland mobilises 8000 members of the army (including civilians with military training) to help in the efforts against COVID-19 (mostly healthcare) on March 16th 2020.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Swiss Federal Council appoints a scientific advisory board, made up of researchers from higher education and private scientific sector who aim to improve the situation regarding COVID-19 in Switzerland from March 31st 2020 onwards.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: The Swiss federal government is to set up a liaison office for civil society to better harness the efforts being made in civil society against COVID-19 on April 9th 2020.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 13th 2020, the Swiss federal council decides to close all ski resorts effective on March 14th 2020. Previously different cantons had been making their own decisions regarding ski resort closure.
On March 14, the Swiss Federal Army announces the suspension of recruitment as of March 16 until May 25.

On the 21st March 2020, The Swiss Federal Department of Foreign Affairs (FDFA) releases the plan to return 630 Swiss tourists from Latin America (Peru & Colombia) in cooperation with the airline Edelweiss, with Two charter flights planned for 24-25 March 2020.

On March 27, the Swiss Federal Government allowed Cantons under certain circumstances (insufficient capacities, elevated number of cross-border commuters) to temporarily restrict or stop the activity of entire economic sectors as opposed to the federal law. This policy was politicised as "Lex Ticino" as it was tailormade for its case.

On January 30, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Office of Health launched a telephone-hotline to meet requiries concerning the new Coronavirus and to inform travellers about health risks related to Corona. this was announced January 29.

On February 24, 2020 The Swiss Federal government has decided to provide more information to the population  in connection with the coronavirus outbreak. 
Therefore an information campaign for travelers and commuters at the borders and airports was started. A second information campaign on personal protection measures "So sch "tzen wir uns" (Protect yourself and others) is aimed at the general public. In a first step, the FOPH would like to make three important hygiene and behavior rules known: Wash your hands thoroughly, cough and sneeze into a tissue or the crook of your arm, stay at home if you have fever or a cough.

On April 9, 2020 the Swiss FOPH promoted a free online Eastern - themed game emphazising that the message, even over Easter, is to stay at home and not have friends or family round. Only then can we continue to curb the spread of the new coronavirus. Play Bunny Madness to pass the time instead! A reward is being offered for the highest score by the end of the day on April 13.

The Swiss Federal Council releases public awareness campaign to promote Keeping your distance, washing your hands thoroughly and sneezing into the crook of your arm despite other covid-19 related restrictions easing.

On June 29th, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Public Health announced a new Infochannel on WhatsApp providing a wide range of information about the coronavirus.
You can choose from the following topics:
    Contact Tracing
    SwissCovid app
    Masks
    Precautionary measures
    Travel
    Situation in Switzerland
    Background knowledge
Contact details are anonymised and not stored.

On February 4, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health recommended on its webside to all persons having returned from China within the last 14 days: If you develop symptoms of a respiratory tract infection (fever, cough, shortness of breath)  stay at home, do not go out in public and contact a doctor immediately, by telephone first.

On February 16, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health informed on its webside."The risk of infection with the new coronavirus is currently in Switzerland low. So far, no one has been found to have the virus. Should there be cases, the sick people would be isolated. Close Contact persons would have to be in quarantine for two weeks." On the webside for health professionals ( Feb 17) the term close contact is specified:
Contact from <2 meters and for> 15 minutes. People who live in the same household. Care or medical examination without protective gear. Direct contact with body fluids.

The Swiss Federal Office of Public Health informed on its webside for health professionals ( February 17, 2020) that suspected cases (meeting the test criteria) and persons who tested positive for the coronavirus have to be isolated. The cantonal departements of health decide if the person is to be isolated at home or its hotelroom or is transferred to a hospital isolation ward. 
According to some newspapers and cantonal websides the people who tested positive had to be isolated in isolation wards of hospitals.

On its press conference on February 25, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health informed about the first person in Switzerland confirmed as being infected with the new coronavirus 2019-nCoV. People in close contact with the individual are being notified and placed in quarantine and their condition will be monitored over the next 14 days. On its webside ( February 16) the FOPH informed:" Should there be cases, the sick people would be isolated. Close Contact persons would have to be in quarantine for two weeks."  On the webside for health professionals ( Feb 17) the term close contact is specified:
Contact from less than 2 meters and for more than 15 minutes. People who live in the same household. Care or medical examination without protective gear. Direct contact with body fluids.

On March 6, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health releases guidelines (valid from March 9th) for symptomatic persons and their contacts:
Persons with symptoms of an acute respiratory illness (fever and cough):
 " Stay at home for up to 24 hours after the symptoms have subsided (self-isolation)
 " Only call a doctor if Your state of health requires this:
   - If the risk of complications is increased (particularly at risk) 
   - in case of dyspnoea
   - if respiratory symptoms worsen
Your close contact persons (people living in the same household, intimate contacts) are instructed to pay attention to their state of health so that they can go into self-isolation as soon as they develop symptoms.

On March 6, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health releases recommendations ( valid from March 9th) for persons who had close contact with someone tested positive for the coronavirus.
Hospital doctors and doctors in private practice instruct the close contact persons (people living in the same household, intimate contacts) of the confirmed cases to stay at home for 5 days after the onset of symptoms (of the confirmed case) and to pay attention to their state of health, and to go into self-isolation if symptoms occur.
Health professionals who had unprotected contact with a confirmed case (professional or private) continue to work, always wear a surgical mask, ensure perfect hand hygiene and monitor their health.

On March 6, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health releases guidelines for dealing with confirmed cases from March 9, 2020 and an information sheet (March 7): What to do if you are infected with the new Coronavirus.
confirmed cases are isolated:
  " At home, if the general condition permits (self-isolation)
Removal of isolation: 48 hours after the symptoms have subsided, provided that at least 10 days have passed since the onset of symptoms
  " In severe cases in the hospital:
 Return home as soon as the clinical condition permits, or removal of isolation in the hospital in accordance with the criteria listed above.
The Swiss Federal Office of Publich Health releases guidelines for self-isolation and/or quarantine for Swiss residents displaying symptoms synonymous with COVID-19 on April 6th 2020.

At its meeting on 1 July, the Swiss Federal Council took decisions on various measures to prevent the renewed spread of the coronavirus. With effect from Monday, 6 July, travellers entering Switzerland from certain regions will have to go into quarantine for ten days. The FOPH has a list of the countries concerned, which it updates regularly. Travellers affected will be notified during the flight, on board coaches and at border crossings. They will have to register with the cantonal authorities on arrival. The new ordinance will be adopted and published the next day ( July 2).

On September 25th, 2020 the list of considered risk countries (valid from Sept 28th) was updated by the Swiss FOPH. As before all persons entering Switzerland having stayed in a risk country within the last 10 days have to quarantine for 10 days ( at home or in a suitable accomodation). A negative test result does not exempt from the mandatory quarantine requirement. Quarantined persons do not get loss of earnings compensation (except change of list after departure). They have to report to the cantonal authorities that carry out spot checks. Exempted are diplomats, transport professionals, transit passengers, cross border commuter, professionals needed in health system, public security, in some international institutions and  professionals re-entering after participating in an event like sports competition, cultural event, a specialist congress. risk countries as of September 28th: Albania, Andorra, Argentina, Armenia, Bahamas, Bahrain, Belgium, Belize, Bolivia, Bosnia Herzegovina, Brazil, Cabo Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Croatia, Czechia, Denmark, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Guyana, Honduras, Hungary, Iceland, India, Iraq, Ireland, Israel, Jamaica, Kuwait, Lebanon, Libya, Luxemburg, Maledives, Malta, Moldova, Monaco, Montenegro, Morocco, Namibia, Nepal, Netherlands, North Macedonia, Palestine, Oman, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Portugal, Qatar, Romania, Spain, Slovenia, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago, Ukraine, UAE, UK, USA.

At its meeting on March 6th, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council adjusted its strategy  and focused on protecting particularly vulnerable people.  The FOPH has issued recommendations for the world of work: Absence from the workplace should be considered if no distancing or other temporary employment is possible for particularly vulnerable people who are exposed to an increased risk of infection in the workplace.
risk factors are: above 65 years of age, hypertension, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, chronic respiratory disease, an immune system weakened by disease or treatment, or cancer

At its meeting on March 6th, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council adjusted its strategy. The FOPH has issued recommendations for the world of work: 
- Ensuring consistent compliance with personal hygiene measures (hand washing).
- Employees should, if operationally possible, keep their distance from one another e.g. by creating spatial adjustments, office splitting, teleworking / home office, etc. Masks are not recommended.
- Goodwill should apply when a doctor's certificate is requested. It should be requested from the 5th day at the earliest.
- Employers should make their employees' working hours as flexible as possible so that peak times in public transport can be avoided.
- Employees are to be informed of personal and workplace-related protective measures according to the current guidelines of the FOPH.
The Swiss Federal council announces an extraordinary situation whereby all non-essential businesses must close by midnight on March 16th 2020 until April 19th.

On March 18, 2020 the Federal Office of Health in Switzerland published guidelines on social distancing and hygiene for essential businesses that remain open after the closing of non-essential businesses on March 17:
- compliance with social distancing
- daily cleaning of handles and touched surfaces
- limiting the number of persons (customers and employees) to one person per 10 squaremeter





.

In Switzerland on April 16, 2020 the Federal Council announced that as of April 27 following non-essential business will be allowed to reopen:
personal grooming ( hairdresser, massage studios, tattoo studios); garden center, florists and nurseries; Do-it-yourself shops; self-service facilities ( car-washing, solarium, pick-your-own-crops).
All business have to follow a protection protocoll including hygienic measures, hand sanitation for customers, allowing social distancing. For personal grooming masks are obligatory, in shops not more than one customer per 10 qm is allowed.

"In Switzerland on April 16, 2020 the Federal Council announced that as of April 27 in a first step some non-essential business will be allowed to reopen, but following non- essential business will have to remain closed:
-retail commerce ( except home-delivery and  Do-it Yourself, Florist)
-shopping center
-restaurants, bars ( except take-away, staff canteens)
-leisure and entertainment ( cinema, theatre, casino, fitness center)
-camping sites
The next step of business reopening is scheduled as of May 11.

At its meeting on April 29, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided to further ease the measures against the coronavirus as of May 11.
But following publicly accessible facilities remain closed to the public:
leisure and entertainment facilities, e.g. cinema, theater, casino, sports facilities, swimming pool, spa, amusement parks, ski resorts, mountain rail and cableways.

On April 29, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council announced the second step of easing business restrictions starting May 11. 
All shops, retail business and markets are allowed to reopen according to their protection concept ( one customers per 10 qm, compliance to the guidelines of the Federal Office of Health in regard of social distancing, hygiene).
Private museum and private libraries may open according to their protection concept.
Restaurants and bars can take the first step of resumption: only for seated consumption, groups of up to 4 per table, distance between tables, closure from midnight to 6 am, no live musik or events, masks recommended for employees

On May 27, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council is easing most of the remaining business restrictions as of 6 June. 
All leisure and entertainment businesses such as casinos, amusement parks, cinema, theatre, discos may reopen, as can swimming pools and spas. Strip clubs may also reopen and services offered by sex workers may resume. Hygiene and social distancing rules must still be observed. If it is not possible to respect social distancing rules, contact tracing must be assured, e.g.by means of attendance lists.
For groups of more than four people restaurants it is required to take the contact details of one guest per table.Customers may still only be served when seated. All establishments, discos and nightclubs are required to close at midnight and may not admit more than 300 people a night. Discos are limited to one customer per 4 qm.
.

The Swiss Federal Council votes to restrict government services, including the postal service, the police force will only focus on essential crimes and health care services are only to be used for essential life-threatening procedures.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description:
On March 20, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Coucil announced that the following statutory deadlines stand still as of March 21 till may 31:
- Deadline for submitting signature lists for a popular initiative 
- Deadline for the treatment of popular initiatives
- Deadline for the submission of a popular initiative 
The following actions are not carried out during the standstill.
- Disposal of the creation of referenda
- Popular vote on a federal referendum
The collection of signatures is prohibited.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description:
On February 28th, 2020 the Federal Council of Switzerland bans public and private events in Switzerland at which more than 1000 people would gather. This ban on events comes into effect immediately and will last until at least March 15.The cantons are responsible for enforcing the ban.
In the case of public or private events at which fewer than 1000 people would gather, event organisers must carry out a risk assessment in conjunction with the competent cantonal authorities to decide whether or not the event can be held.

At its meeting on March 13, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided on further measures: With immediate effect and until April 30, the council bans all public or private events with more than 100 people. The limit of 100 persons also applies to leisure and entertainment facilities. Cantonal authorities can approve exceptions for reasons of public interest. Events and gatherings with less than 100 participants can take place provided that measures are taken
a. to exclude people who are sick or who feel sick 
b. to protect persons belonging to a risk group
c. measures to inform those present about protective measures such as hand hygiene, keeping their distance or coughing and runny nose hygiene
d. Adaptation of the spatial conditions so that the hygiene rules can be adhered to."

On March 16, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Council banned all public or private events, including parties, sports events, political demonstrations and General assemblies as of March 17.
Exempted are private gathering in small groups ( in public spaces and at home), playing children (recommended group size 5) and business meetings which should be limited to 1 person per 4qm in closed rooms.
March 20 Federal Council prohibits the gathering of more than five people

On May 27, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided at its meeting on further easing the measures put in place to fight the new coronavirus starting May 30. 
Till and including May 29 gathering of more than five people in public is  banned (start March 21st). Social distancing is compulsory for all persons in public. Non-compliance can be fined. 
As before (start March 17, 2020) and till presumably June 7 th all public or private events, including parties, sports events, club activities, political demonstrations and general assemblies remain forbidden. Event organizising can be punished. 
Exempted are private gathering in small groups at home, playing children at school play-grounds and business meetings, training of competitive athletes in permanent teams, amateur sports in groups of five, markets, religious services and celebrations including funerals (protection concept).

On May 27, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Council decided to relax the ban on gathering of persons in public spaces from 5 persons to 30 persons as of May 30. Gathiering in groups over 30 persons can be fined, not adhering to social distancing rules is no longer to be fined. Nevertheless social distancing remains highly recommended. Exempted are school children at school playgrounds and business meetings. 
All private and public events remain forbidden, organisators can be punished. 
The next relaxation step is scheduled for gatherings and events as of June 6th.

On May 27, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided at its meeting on further easing the measures put in place to fight the new coronavirus. Public and private events will prematurely be allowed as of June 6th. 
 As before (start March 17, 2020) and till June 5 th all public or private events, including parties, sports events, club activities, political demonstrations and general assemblies remain forbidden. Event organizising can be punished.  Exempted are private gathering with up to 30 persons ( since May 30), playing children at school play-grounds ( since May 11) and business meetings ( since March 17), training of competitive athletes in permanent teams, amateur sports in groups of five( since May 11), markets ( since May 11), religious services and celebrations ( since May 28) including funerals (protection concept).

On May 27, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council decided that 
from June 6th, private and public events with up to 300 people are to be allowed.This includes family events, fairs, concerts, sports events, theatre performances and film screenings, as well as political and civil society demonstrations.
On condition that all events have appropriate sets of precautionary measures in place. Hygiene and social distancing rules must still be observed. If it is not possible to respect social distancing rules, contact tracing must be assured, by means of attendance lists, for example. 
Summer holiday camps for children and young people will be allowed to go ahead from 6 June as long as appropriate sets of precautionary measures are in place. Children and young people should remain in the same groups wherever possible. The upper limit for camps is 300 people and organisers must keep an attendance list.
Spontaneous gathering in public spaces remain restricted to 30 persons. Cantons can allow exemptions for important reasons.

On March 14, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health issues guidelines for wearing masks.
chirurgical/ hygiene masks are recommended for
- health staff under certain conditions
- caregiver for particularly vulnerable persons ( e.g. staff in nursing homes)
- persons with respiratory syndroms or tested positiv who have to leave their home e.g. to see a doctor
Masks are not recommended for healthy persons in public spaces.

On April 1, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided to temporarily change the regulation on electronic signatures. The change provides a general way of video identification when issuing certificates, making physical signatures redundant. This way, trips and personal contacts can be avoided

The Swiss Federal Council has made adjustments to the asylum procedure in Switzerland which is to be coordinated across all cantons from April 1st 2020. The changes include greater physical distance in the asylum interview process (fewer individuals in the room etc) and additional accommodation for asylum applicants who are unable to leave due to COVID-19 to be made by converting military accommodation.

The Swiss Federal Council releases new guidelines for protecting at-risk employees from returning to work prematurely on April 16th in light of corona restrictions being eased. If an individual considers their health to be at risk by returning to work their employer must facilitate work from home through giving the employee alternative tasks or other means. Wages must continue to be paid to those unable to return to the workplace for health reasons.

On April 22nd, 2020, the Swiss federal government has decided not to impose a general obligation for residents to wear face masks with the exception of situations in which social distancing is not possible. It recommends the wearing of masks in public transport.

On April 16 and April 22, 2020 the Swiss Federal Coucil announced that with the stepwise reopening of business starting as of April 27 the branches and businesses are obliged to accompany the resumption with protection concepts which may include the use of masks, especially when keeping distance is not possible.

On June 19, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council announced that there is no upper limit for the number of people able to attend a demonstration, but it will be mandatory to wear a face mask. This change concerning political and civil society demonstrations will apply from Saturday, 20 June.
Gathering of less than 30 persons are excepted from mask obligation.

With an alarming amount of disinformation about the new coronavirus circulating on social media, Turkish police have decided to start investigating people spreading hoaxes or fake news about the deadly COVID-19, authorities said Saturday( March 7)
In Turkey, as of March 16, all schools will be shut down until 30 March

Turkey on March 23 launched TV-based distance learning for around 18 million primary, secondary and high-school students, with Education Minister Ziya Sel "uk giving the first lecture as he advised families to create the necessary conditions for their children at home.

Distance learning will be aired through three channels provided by the state-run Turkish Radio and Television Corporation (TRT) and Education Informatics Network (EBA). The TRT-EBA TV will air school lessons for the primary, secondary and high school students through separate channels, which will be supported by the digital EBA system.

Turkey extends distance learning till late May over virus.

Turkish national education minister on Wednesday announced that the country's distance education will continue until May 31 as part of measures to stem the spread of the novel coronavirus.
Country began distance education in March 23 as part of measures to mitigate spread of coronavirus

Turkey has said it won "t reopen schools until September, but distance learning programs will continue until June 19 in line with the government "s gradual plan to reopen the country amid the continued COVID-19 pandemic. 

 "The 2019-2020 education year for the schools under the Education Ministry has been terminated. The new school year will begin in September, " President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said in his address after a weekly cabinet meeting late May 18. 

As part of measures to curb the spread of the novel coronavirus, Turkey shut down the primary, secondary and high schools on March 16 and launched a distance learning program on March 23 for around 18 million students.

The Turkish Interior Ministry imposed on Saturday a partial curfew on people aged 65 and over to prevent the spread of a new strain of the deadly coronavirus (COVID-19) on the elderly populace.

Citizens aged 65 years and older, as well as those with chronic medical conditions, will be restricted from leaving their residences effective midnight, the ministry said.
Turkey imposes curfew in 31 cities for two days starting with 10.04.2020 00:00 and ending at 12.04.2020 at 00:00
In Turkey, on April 10th a 48-hour curfew on all citizens was imposed on 31 provinces, starting from 12:00 am, April 11th.
Turkey has imposed a 3-day curfew in 31 provinces beginning Thursday midnight (May 1) in an effort to stem spread of the novel coronavirus, which has claimed 3,174 lives in the country.

Turkey will impose a four-day partial curfew beginning Friday midnight before ending on the midnight of Tuesday, May 19, at the end of a day marked by a national holiday, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced on Monday (May 11).

Turkish Airlines announced on Friday that it would temporarily halt flights to and from four destinations in China due to the coronavirus outbreak.

"In order to evaluate the situation and recent developments regarding the coronavirus with national and international authorities, we are suspending our flights to the cities of Beijing, Guangzhou, Shanghai and Xian until Feb. 9," Yahya  "st "n, the airlines " senior vice president for media relations

Turkey's health minister said the border with Iran would be closed from Sunday (February 23) due to the number of coronavirus cases in its eastern neighbor.

Fahrettin Koca said flights from Iran would also cease from 8 p.m. local time (1700 GMT). Road and rail crossings between the two countries would be shut three hours earlier.

Turkey announced late Friday it will close all border gates to passengers coming from nine European countries to fight the coronavirus outbreak.

An authorization letter signed by Turkish Interior Minister Suleyman Soylu said passengers coming from Germany, Spain, France, Austria, Norway, Denmark, Sweden, Belgium, and the Netherlands will not be allowed into Turkey beginning 8 a.m. local time (0500 GMT) Saturday.

It also said that travelers from Turkey to those countries are temporarily suspended.

The Turkish government has decided to close its rail and land border with Greece and Bulgaria amid fears over the coronavirus spread, AFP quoted Turkish media as saying.

 "The land and rail border gates will be closed to exits and entries from 2100 GMT today (Wednesday March 19) ", as ordered by a circular issued by the interior ministry, the private Dogan news agency reported.

With cases of coronavirus rising worldwide, Turkey has advised its citizens against traveling to Iraq and Italy unless absolutely necessary.

In two separate statements, the Turkish Foreign Ministry said Wednesday (February 26)  it  "strongly advised " the public not to visit infected areas in Iraq and Italy.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has imposed additional nationwide restrictions to contain the spread of coronavirus in the country.

While stopping short of declaring a lockdown, Erdogan on Friday announced the suspension of all international flights to and from Turkey as well as strict monitoring of domestic travel. Erdogan did not give a timeline as to when the restrictions would end.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has imposed additional nationwide restrictions to contain the spread of coronavirus in the country.

While stopping short of declaring a lockdown, Erdogan on Friday announced the suspension of all international flights to and from Turkey as well as strict monitoring of domestic travel.

National flag carrier Turkish Airlines (THY) has extended the cancellation of its international flights due to the coronavirus outbreak, the company said Tuesday.

The company will not fly on international routes until May 20, 2020 "in accordance with the decisions taken by the authorities of Turkey and to protect the public health from novel coronavirus pandemic."

Looking to restart domestic and international flights after a suspension due to coronavirus, Turkish Airlines has drafted a flight plan for June, July, and August, sources told Anadolu Agency on May 6. 

Turkey's national flag carrier will resume domestic flights in June and reintroduce international flights gradually, said the sources, who spoke anonymously due to restrictions on speaking to the media.
Turkish defence and electronics firms are teaming up to produce 5,000 ventilators to help treat coronavirus patients, the head of a military drone manufacturer said on Tuesday (March 16).

Turkey "s postal system will begin distributing medical face masks to citizens free of charge, following the government "s decision to mandate the wearing of face masks in public spaces as part of new measures to combat the spread of the novel coronavirus.

Turkey continues its fight against the COVID-19 outbreak with two new hospitals set to open in Istanbul and the launch of an experimental plasma therapy.

Turkey will establish two new hospitals with a capacity of 1,000 beds each in Istanbul to aid in the fight against the coronavirus pandemic, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced on April 6

The country also launched the plasma therapy tests on April 7 as a possible treatment for COVID-19, the life-threatening disease caused by the novel coronavirus..

The Turkish Red Crescent collected 3,970 immune plasmas donated across the country amid the novel coronavirus outbreak, according to the group's top official.

Kerem Kinik, head of the aid agency, told Anadolu Agency that the immune plasma therapy is considered as a supportive treatment for COVID-19, adding that the agency has taken steps along with the Health Ministry on this
issue.

The first plasma, Kinik said, was donated on April 7, and some 3,500 Red Crescent employees worked in two shifts during this period in plasma apheresis centers in 14 cities to receive blood and plasma donations.

The Turkish government will allow the sales of face masks with the maximum price of 1 Turkish Lira each, and the price will depend on the quality of the masks aily H "rriyet reported on May 6.

Pharmacies or markets will be able sell them under the upper limit set, if they want to. However, sales above this price will not be allowed. Institutions will also strictly supervise pharmacies and markets after the start of the mask sales.

A new treatment for the deadly coronavirus developed by Turkish healthcare institutions is now awaiting state permission for testing.

The drug, called TR-C 19, was developed by Istanbul-based Health Sciences University and VSY Biotechnology, a firm with offices in Istanbul, Europe, and India.

Research to find a cure for COVID-19 is going on worldwide, and Turkey has taken serious steps in this direction, said Dr. Cevdet Erdol from Health Sciences University.

Turkey has sent medical aid to 80 countries to fight the novel coronavirus, the country "s vice president said Thursday (May 14).   

 "We have had the opportunity to help 80 countries that have asked us for help so far, " Fuat Oktay said.

The main demand from these countries was face masks, gloves and respirators, Oktay said.  

He said two-thirds of the countries in the world, or close to 70%, had requested assistance from Turkey.

Turkey will begin animal testing next week in its effort to develop an anti-serum to tackle the novel coronavirus pandemic, a senior official announced on Friday (May 15).

"The animals will undergo illness, if lightly. Their antibody count will go up and we will get these antibodies by separating them from the blood and other elements," explained Bekir Pakdemirli, minister of agriculture and forestry.

In the study, which will last until September, Turkish scientists will inject test subjects with isolated and inactive virus samples in efforts that will serve as a precedent for vaccine research

"TurkishBeam", a ray treatment system developed in Turkey, was officially invited for testing and analysis by the Cleveland Clinic of the US and New York University, its developer RD Global INVAMED, said on Friday.

The treatment ensures the complete destruction of organisms such as microorganisms, fungi, bacteria and viruses and does not damage the cells and DNA of humans in this process, said the research group in a statement.

The method was first established and developed after three years research by Turkish scientists under the name of "TurkishBeam Selective-Sensitive UVC and Laser Therapy", for short the "TurkishBeam".

A clinical study application was made to the Turkish Ministry of Health After receiving positive and promising results from animal testing regarding the treatment of viral diseases such as COVID-19, and the application was approved on May 4, 2020.

Computed tomography (CT), one of the key strengths of Turkey's medical sector, has been the cornerstone of Turkey's success against the COVID-19 pandemic, experts say. Early diagnosis with lung tomography reduced pandemic-related deaths, the head of an Istanbul hospital hosting one of the city "s leading imaging centers said.

Ramping up its testing capabilities since confirming its first COVID-19 case on March 10, Turkey has carried out more than a million coronavirus tests so far.

According to Health Minister Fahrettin Koca on Thursday (April 30), Turkey carried out 42,004 tests in the last 24 hours, bringing the total number of tests to 1,033,617. The figure puts Turkey seventh in the world in terms of the total number of COVID-19 tests carried out.

Turkey expanded its coronavirus testing after its first case was diagnosed on Wednesday, but only to those who have travelled abroad and are showing symptoms, said a member of the Health Ministry "s Coronavirus Committee. The testing will be widened from people who had visited high-risk countries to include all those who are ill and reached Turkey over the past 14 days, Milliyet newspaper said, citing the official, Prof. Dr. Tevfik  "zs ".

Turkey is planning to run tests on up to 150,000 people across the country to see the extent of the spread of the coronavirus, the health minister has said.

As of May 6, Turkey has carried out well over 1.2 million tests while the number of confirmed COVID-19 cases has climbed to nearly 132,000. The death toll from the outbreak has exceeded 3,500.

 "Those tests will not be limited to a certain region or regions but cover the entire country. We are working together with the Turkish Statistics Institute [T "IK] for this mass screening tests, " Koca said following a Science Board meeting.

Turkey has made it mandatory for people to wear protective face masks in 10 provinces as the country has rolled out the first phase of the normalization program.

The residents of Adiyaman, Afyonkarahisar, Aydin, Balikesir, Bartin, Denizli, D "zce, Kastamonu, Mugla and Usak are now required to wear face masks when they go out.

The decision regarding mandatory face masks were recommended by the provincial hygiene boards in the respective provinces.

Moreover, the provincial hygiene boards recommended that people should wear protective face masks in crowded streets and marketplaces in the provinces of Gaziantep, Adana and Izmir.

Turkey has put a limit on all passengers taking public transport within and between cities. Public transport will from now on only accept passengers up to 50% of the entire carriage capacity of the vehicle.

Turkey on March 27 introduced more stringent measures for the COVID-19 pandemic in 30 big cities, bans intercity travels.
According to the new measures the president announced, traveling between cities will now be possible with the permission of local governors.

The Turkish public largely followed preventive measures against coronavirus and a mobile application will be used to track inter-city travels, the country's health minister said on May 20. 

"The mobile app by the Health Ministry will be used to track inter-city travel," he said.

The citizens will use the code from the app to show that they are not sick or carrying the virus and be able to board planes and trains within Turkey.

Turkey has decided to impose a 4-day nationwide lockdown over the Eid al-Fitr holiday between May 23-26 as part of measures taken against the coronavirus pandemic, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced Monday (May 17) following a weekly cabinet meeting.

Ankara has imposed lockdowns across major cities over the past five weekends, as well as on national holidays, in order to slow the spread of the new coronavirus.

The Turkish government is planning to ban layoffs for three months in a bid to protect those lacking job security and to ease damages to the economy due to the coronavirus outbreak, according to a draft legislation.
The bill would apply to anyone who had been laid off or put on unpaid leave as of March 15 and is not eligible for unemployment benefits. They would be paid daily 39.24 liras ($5.80) by the government.

Turkey has established a 24-hour coordination and support center under the Foreign Ministry to tackle concerns about coronavirus, the country's top diplomat said Sunday (March 15)

Speaking to Anadolu Agency, Mevlut Cavusoglu said some 8,300 Turkish expats have called on the existing helpline with concerns about the pandemic that has sounded a global alarm.

Cavusoglu said the need was felt to launch a separate support center to cater to growing demands..

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan unveiled a 100 billion-lira ($15.4 billion) plan to help businesses ride out the economic storm caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

The government will introduce a set of new measures from tax cuts and payment deferrals for businesses to an increase in minimum pension payouts

President launches National Solidarity Campaign

Turkey's president on Monday launched a National Solidarity Campaign to aid fight against the novel coronavirus, donating seven of his monthly salaries to the initiative. He underlined that the aim of the campaign would be to provide additional support to low-income people suffering economically due to the measures taken against the spread of the disease.

Turkey has taken sweeping steps to cushion the economic fallout of the coronavirus pandemic to protect both employers and employeesAny firm forced out of business due to a Force Majeure such as the pandemic can approach the governmentThe government will pay 60 of the staff salaries for a period of three monthsWith this shortterm employment allowance the government will make direct transfers  within the ranges of 1752 Turkish liras 260 to 4381 liras 650  in the employees " bank accounts directlyThe government will also pay for their health insurance during the periodThe country backs employers with minimum wage and tax supports besides the shortterm employment allowanceTurkey increased the minimum pension to 1500 Turkish 223

Turkey has initiated a partial normalization process as the country "s fight against the coronavirus pandemic has proven effective and a decline in the number of new infections and deaths is reflected in the figures. (May 4) Now, an action plan for the tourism sector is set to be implemented to revive the country's virus-hit industry safely and steadily.

The normalization process for the industry will include various measures, from imposing social distancing rules in crowded places to providing face masks to the tourists.

According to the newly announced action plan, a certification system will be implemented for both hotels and transfer vehicles. All details were taken into consideration for the certification program, from the training of the hotel employees to the reorganizing of buffets, restaurants, meeting rooms or pool areas.

Disinfectants will be available at every transfer vehicle, while the seats on each side of the passenger will be left empty.

The hotels will be given a maximum occupancy permit of 60% and the hotel owners will provide masks to tourists without masks. At the entrance of the hotels, visitors' body temperatures will be checked and lines marking social distancing will be used at reception and lobby.

President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced earlier this week( May 4) that the measures will start to be eased as of May 11 but added that  "nothing will be like the normal we knew. "

As part of this process, shopping malls, barber shops, and some stores will open, travel restrictions will be lifted for seven cities, excluding Istanbul, Ankara and Izmir, senior and youth citizens will be allowed outside for four hours for one day a week starting this weekend.

Consumers will be required to wear face masks when they visit shopping malls, and their temperatures will be checked at the entrance. Stores inside the malls will have larger empty space to ensure social distancing. Only a certain number of shoppers will be allowed inside the stores one at a time. Fitting rooms will be regularly sanitized.

Clothes, which consumers try on, will be disinfected with UV light. At the cashiers, shoppers will stand two meters apart from each other. Escalators will be disinfected regularly, while elevators won "t operate.

Turkey will start easing coronavirus containment measures as of May 11, President Tayyip Erdogan said, lifting intercity travel restriction in seven provinces and easing a curfew imposed for senior and youth citizens at the weekend after weeks.
Shopping malls, barber shops, and some stores will be allowed to open on May 11 as long as they abide by normalization rules

Turkey's daily COVID-19 cases dropped below 1000 with 23 deaths on Wednesday.

Total number of recovered patients surpasses 113,000, Health Minister Fahrettin Koca announced.

The total number of recoveries from coronavirus in Turkey rose to 106,133, the country "s health minister said on Friday (May 15).

The death toll from the pandemic rose to 4,055 as the country reported 48 new fatalities over the past 24 hours, Fahrettin Koca said, citing the Health Ministry data.

Fifteen banks in Turkey have been fined nearly 20 million Turkish liras, the country's banking watchdog announced on Friday (May 15).

The Banking Regulation and Supervision Agency (BRSA) announced on Friday that it fined the banks a total of 19.65 million liras ($2.84 million) over transactions that did not comply with new rules introduced to deal with the economic fallout of the novel coronavirus pandemic.

Without naming which banks were fined, the BRSA said in a statement that it had imposed the penalties after receiving complaints from banks' clients and that the inquiry process is ongoing.

According to sources familiar with the issue, the watchdog also aims to draw attention to unfair banking practices during the virus-induced economic turmoil.

A Turkish state agency has extended a helping hand to over 165,000 Turkish people in 14 countries amid the novel coronavirus outbreak.

In a written statement, Turkey "s Presidency for Turks Abroad and Related Communities (YTB) said the agency does not leave Turkish expats alone during the pandemic that claimed thousands of lives worldwide.

It reached out to families in need all over the world through its support and cooperation program, it added

Turkey expects to have domestic tourism start late May, while internationally after mid-June, the country's culture and tourism minister said Saturday (May 16).

"I hope, tourism will start with some tourism mobility domestically by May 28," said Mehmet Nuri Ersoy, speaking to broadcaster NTV.

"We also expect international tourism to start with some countries after mid-June," Ersoy added.

The total number of recoveries from coronavirus in Turkey rose to 108,137, with active cases dropping to 35,834, the country "s health minister said on Saturday.

The death toll from the pandemic rose to 4,096 as the country reported 41 new fatalities over the past 24 hours, Fahrettin Koca said, citing the Health Ministry data.

The number of patients in intensive care and the proportion of fatalities in intensive care patients is decreasing, Koca said, stressing that there is a predictable slowdown in the recovery rate.

The country also registered 1,610 new cases, bringing the tally to 148,067.

As many as 42,236 tests were conducted in the country over the past 24 hours, bringing the total number of tests to over 1.58 million, Koca said.

Ankara has so far brought back 70,000 nationals from 107 nations as part its fight with COVID-19 pandemic.
Nearly 700 Turkish nationals were repatriated Saturday (May 16) from the US and Kyrgyzstan as part of an initiative by Ankara over the coronavirus pandemic.

An exclusive Turkish Airlines flight with 354 Turks from the US landed in the Black Sea province of Ordu.

Separately, 330 Turks were evacuated from Kyrgyzstan and landed in Istanbul.

Turkey will accept certain types of medical patients and health tourists from 31 countries as of May 20, as it eases its COVID-19 restrictions, Anadolu news agency said.

The countries include Iraq, Libya, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Greece, Ukraine, Russia, Djibouti, Algeria, Kosovo, Macedonia, Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Romania, Serbia, Bulgaria, Moldova, Somalia, Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain, Oman, Germany, Britain, the Netherlands, Pakistan, Kyrgyzstan, and the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus.

A Turkish Health Ministry statement said the patients and up to two people accompanying them will be tested for COVID-19 or samples will be taken for the PCR test for a fee when entering Turkey. If tests are available in their countries, they will be required to take a COVID-19 test within 48 hours of their journey and bring proof of a negative result.

Turkey's daily COVID-19 death toll continued to follow a downward trend as the number of deaths rose by 25 and the number of new cases continued to stay under 1,000, Health Minister Fahrettin Koca announced Sunday (May 31).

Turkey "s hospitals are largely expected to return their normal operations and start to receive regular patients as of June 1 in line with the government "s plan to ease some of the measures imposed to curb the spread of the coronavirus outbreak.

Accordingly, the number of pandemic hospitals across the country will be gradually reduced but some of those hospitals in certain cities, such as Istanbul and Ankara where the virus cases are still higher compared to other provinces, will not cease operations, H "rriyet newspaper has reported.

The normalization program for hospitals foresees that health institutions will return to their pre-outbreak functions and receive regular patients.

Turkey's Trade Ministry stepped up to support export-oriented businesses amid the pandemic by organizing the first virtual trade fair on June 1-3, following a trade delegation's online meetings
The emergence of the coronavirus pandemic had initially halted world trade by not only disrupting supply chains and export-import channels but also causing the cancellation or postponement of various small- or large-scale global trade fairs. Countries now looking to find new solutions to resume trade are considering their options. Meanwhile, Turkey "s Trade Ministry stepped up to organize trade fairs online, the first one of which is scheduled for June 1-3.

The Interior Ministry has unveiled a series of measures to be implemented on the country "s highways during summer, when vehicle traffic between provinces and road accidents increase.

In a circular sent to the governor offices in 81 provinces, the ministry stressed that this summer those measures will be enforced from June 1 to Oct. 1 at a time when traffic curbs designed to control the spread of the coronavirus and the easing of COVID-19 precautions will be in place simultaneous

Thus, the ministry said that during traffic controls security forces will particularly check if social distancing rules are observed on intercity buses. According to travel curbs, half of public transport vehicles " seats should be kept empty and passengers are required to put their masks on.

At checkpoints, police and gendarmerie units will also adhere to social distancing. They will inform and warn drivers and travelers about social distancing rules.

Security units will be  "more visible " on the routes where road accidents happen more often to give drivers the impression that they risk getting caught if they break the rules.

The ministry also underlined that traffic circulation will increase in July and August, which mark the vacation season, as more vehicles will hit the road and as the number of coronavirus cases will decline.

Turkey started to carry out telephone diplomacy with 70 countries to inform them about the country "s health infrastructure over the pandemic, the culture and tourism minister said on May 18. 

Turkey in a certification system detailed that the country is a safe place for tourism, regarding measures against COVID-19, said Mehmet Nuri Ersoy in a written statement.

The country's Culture and Tourism Ministry launched a "healthy tourism certification" project to ensure the fulfillment of high health and hygiene standards at airlines, airports and other transportation facilities, accommodations and food venues, the ministry had said earlier.

 "Turkey acts responsibly in all these processes, not only for the health of our citizens but also for its guests to ensure that they have their holidays at peace, " Ersoy noted.

More than 28,000 Turkish citizens are in quarantine after returning from abroad as part of measures to stem the spread of the novel coronavirus, an official said on Sunday (May 3).

A total of 28,700 citizens are in isolation at dormitories across 76 provinces, said Youth and Sports Minister Mehmet Kasapoglu.

Some 37,468 citizens have so far been released from quarantine after completing the mandatory 14-day period, he added.

Turkey keeps updating its contingency plan against coronavirus as more cases are reported. Those arriving from Europe are being placed in quarantine.
As the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in Turkey rose to 18 Monday(March 16), the country imposed new measures in the fight against the deadly outbreak. Authorities announced that student dormitories in Istanbul were being evacuated to accommodate people returning from coronavirus-hit European countries. Travelers will be quarantined there for 14 days.

Nearly 9,700 Turkish citizens are in quarantine as part of measures to stem the spread of coronavirus, the country's youth and sports minister said on Wednesday (May 13).

A total of 9,647 citizens are in isolation at dormitories across 76 provinces, Mehmet Kasapoglu said in a statement.

Meanwhile, 62,593 citizens have so far been released from quarantine after completing the mandatory 14-day period, he added.

He said there was close cooperation between state institutions in facilitating the process.

"We are hosting our citizens from all corners of the world in our dormitories," Kasapoglu said.

Until now, a total of 72,240 citizens have been held in quarantine, with 971 new admissions in the last 24 hours.

Turkey is restricting all supermarkets in all cities and provinces to take in a maximum of one-tenth of their maximum customer capacity. However, supermarkets will still be able to operate between 9 am and 9 pm.

Turkey's Interior Ministry implemented new measures at marketplaces Friday as part of efforts to curb the novel coronavirus outbreak.

In marketplaces offering staple foods or cleaning materials, the sale of non-essential items will not be allowed, according to a circular.

Fresh vegetables and fruits sold unpackaged in marketplaces must be packaged by the sellers, avoiding customer contact with the items.

The sale of non-essential items such as clothing, toys, ornaments and bags will be temporarily suspended as of March 27 at 17:00 (1400 GMT).

At least three meters distance must be left between stalls to reduce the density in marketplaces.
Fans will not be allowed to attend any sporting events in Turkey until the end of April as part of measures to tackle the coronavirus outbreak, reported state-run Anadolu news agency on Thursday.

Turkey announced new measures to contain the spread of coronavirus that go into effect at midnight on Monday (March 16).

According to the Turkish Interior Ministry, these public places will be closed for an unspecified period of time:

Theaters, concert halls, wedding halls, music halls, taverns, cafeterias, game halls, beer halls, cafes, coffee parlors, tea parlors, hookah bars, Internet cafes, gaming cafes, all indoor playgrounds, tea gardens, amusement parks, pools, saunas, gyms, spas, sports complexes and massage parlors

The Presidency of Religious Affairs (Diyanet), Turkey's top religious authority, has announced on March 16 a nationwide ban on prayer gatherings, including Friday prayers, in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak.
"Until the danger of spreading the new type of coronavirus disappears, it has become necessary to interrupt prayers with the community in mosques and masjids, especially Friday prayers," Erbas told a news conference

Turkish communities around the world have celebrated Hidrellez with joy, but this year devoid of the colorful ceremonies that would normally have echoed across many of the nations.

This year, in an effort to prevent the virus " spread, events and festivals were canceled, rescheduled, or modified.

The novel coronavirus forced the cancellation of normally well-attended events of Hidrellez, a traditional festival observed in several countries every year on May 6.

All football, basketball, volleyball and handball leagues in Turkey have been postponed until further notice over the growing coronavirus pandemic, Youth and Sports Minister Muharrem Kasapoglu announced Thursday (March 19).

Turkey's parliament on Tuesday (April 14) passed a law to allow tens of thousands of prisoners to be released to curb the spread of the coronavirus in the country's overcrowded prisons, but the exclusion of those jailed on "terrorism" charges in the crackdown following the 2016 coup drew criticism.

Turkey has extended mandatory military service for its male citizens by at least one month, in a move aimed at preventing the further spread of the coronavirus during the discharge period characterised by the mass movement of people.Following a meeting with military commanders, Defence Minister Hulusi Akar said in a statement late on Tuesday

Turkey "s Interior Ministry issued a circular on April 22 on measures that will be taken against the novel coronavirus during the Islamic fasting month of Ramadan.
According to the circular, crowded events and tents where people would usually convene for iftar or to break their fast will not be allowed. The ministry said all necessary precautions will be taken during iftar and sahur  " the meal before starting the fast at dawn - to maintain social distancing outdoors.The selling time of pide, a traditional round and flat bread generally consumed during the fasting month, will be terminated two hours before iftar in order to prevent crowds from gathering at bakeries.

Turkish Labor, Social Services and Family Ministry on Friday (May 8) announced visitors will not be allowed to retirement and nursing homes across the country on Mother's Day Sunday, and also during traditional Eid al-Fitr holiday at the end of Muslim holy month of Ramadan.

The head of Turkey "s top religious body Diyanet announced Friday (May 15) that plans are in place to reopen mosques for communal prayers on June 12, following a three-month hiatus announced due to the coronavirus outbreak

Taxis in the three most populous Turkish provinces were restricted as part of measures to stem the spread of the coronavirus, the Interior Ministry said on Sunday (29 March).

Taxis whose last number of their license plates is odd will be allowed to operate from 12.01 a.m. Monday for the next 24 hours, said a circular by the ministry, adding mobility of taxis whose last number of their license plates is even will be allowed for the same duration next da
A large number of people across Turkey have been fined for violating the rules the government has introduced to stem the spread of the coronavirus.

The England region in the UK appointed an anti-fake news unit (announced in April 2020) to the government to clamp down on phising scams and help the public get access to correct information. False narratives about the coronavirus and  "falsehoods and rumours " about the illness could potentially cost many lives.
On March 18, the UK announces closing of schools, colleges and early years, except in the case of children of key workers and vulnerable children, from March 28.
As of 28 January 2020, the Foreign and Commonwealth Office (FCO) in UK are advising against all but essential travel to the Hubei Province.
As of 31th January, evacuating flights from Wuhan to the UK began; first flight carrying 83 British nationals and 41 foreign nationals.
UK Visas and Immigration operations in China are suspended from 6 February until further notice. Both British and foreign nationals require essential document to leave China.
UK's Prime Minister Boris Johnson advises all those over 70 and those with serious medical conditions against going on cruises.
On 12 March, UK's Prime Minister Boris Johnson advised against international school trips.
on 13 March UK Foreign and Commonwealth Office is advising against all but essential travel to Spain due to Spanish government declaring state of emergency.

As of 13 March, the Foreign & Commonwealth Office in UK is advising against all but essential travel to the regions of Madrid, La Rioja and the municipalities of La Bastida, Vitoria and Miranda de Ebro.
On 14 March, the Foreign & Commonwealth Office in UK advises against all but essential travel to Poland due to the country closing its borders.
From 16 March, for ships entering the UK, they are required to notify the port of arrival of any illness on board by submitting a Maritime Declaration of Health (MDH).
The United Kingdom advises against all non-essential travel from March 17 for a period of 30 days.

On 17 March, UK introduced an emergency bill; one of its measures detailing that the emergency legislation enables Border Force to temporarily suspend operations at airports or transport hubs if there are insufficient resources to maintain border security.
On March 23, The UK advises all British travellers to return to the UK.
On 23 March, Foreign Secretary strongly advises all British travellers to return to the UK now.
On 24 March, the UK government is helping to reduce travel costs by encouraging airlines to have maximum flexibility on changing return tickets.
On 26 March, the UK Visa Application Centre in Accra, Ghana will be closed to the public until further notice.
On 26 March, the UK Visa Application Centre in Accra, Ghana, will be closed to the public until further notice.

On 27 March, the UK government temporarily suspends competition law to allow ferry operators in the Isle of Wight to work together and maintain a crucial lifeline between the island and the mainland during the COVID-19 outbreak.

On 30 March, Vrgin, Easyjet, Jet2 and Titan Airways have signed a memorandum of understanding negotiated by the UK Foreign Secretary and Transport Secretary to bring fly home stranded British travellers.
On 30 March, the UK government pledged up to  "75 million government funding for special chartered flights to bring UK travellers back home.
On 4 March, UK's Foreign & Commonwealth Office (FCO) extends advice against travelling overseas for an indefinite period.

Travelers from the UK will be able to visit Germany, Belgium, Croatia, and Switzerland without quarantine or restrictions upon arrival, but they will still have to face mandatory quarantine upon their return to the UK.

Public Health England has been directed to trace all individuals that have traveled back to the UK from Wuhan in the past 14 days. Anyone that has traveled back from Wuhan has been asked to self-isolate for 14 days.
UK aid will support WHO's Flash Appeal to stop the spread of coronavirus in developing countries with  "5 million. This includes training of staff and spreading awareness of the disease.

"To relieve potential pressures on global supply chains, [UK] suppliers have been asked to carry out a risk assessment on the impact of coronavirus on their business. As an extra precaution, companies have also been asked to retain existing stockpiles of medical supplies, compiled as a contingency measure ahead of [the UK's] exit from the EU, where possible"

"On 18 March the Defence Secretary announced new measures to enable armed forces personnel to support public services in response to the coronavirus outbreak."
This includes "providing medical and logistical support for the NHS; acting as liaison officers; and deploying specialist skills such as engineering and accounting."
On March 18, the UK asks retired healthcare professionals, including GPs, doctors, pharmacists, nurses, midwives, NHS 111 advisers and social care staff, to come back and help the NHS.

On March 24, The UK Government launches a new scheme to 250,000 volunteers to support the NHS through the coronavirus pandemic, consisting of "people in good health to help the NHS, for shopping, for the delivery of medicines and to support those who are shielding to protect their own health"
On April 3, the UK opens its first government Nightingale emergency hospital in east London to treat coronavirus patients.
On April 4, the UK Health Minister launches a new online 'Coronavirus Status Checker' survey system to collect additional data on the outbreak.

In the UK, "a clinical trial has been given approval to determine if plasma donated by patients who have recovered from COVID-19 can help those battling the illness".
"The collection of plasma would be ramped up over April and May to deliver up to 10,000 units of plasma to the NHS every week, enough to treat 5,000 COVID-19 patients per week."
The coronavirus test developed by Public Health England is being rolled out to laboratories across the UK, allowing for around 1000 people to be tested per day for England alone.
On April 2, The United Kingdom Health Secretary sets out plan to carry out 100,000 coronavirus tests a day by the end of April.
"Boris Johnson set out a new target of capacity for 200,000 tests a day by the end of May"
"Prime Minister Boris Johnson has pledged tests would be processed within 24 hours by the end of June"

The UK will be placed into Category B starting August 1, 2020. The health ministry reiterated that passengers arriving from Category B countries are required to present a negative test result taken within the last three days.

The England region in the UK published a set of hygiene guidelines on March 12, 2020 by the NHS to help workers in the healthcare field practice proper sanitation methods. This list includes guidelines for:
 " patient placement/assessment for infection risk
 " hand hygiene
 " respiratory and cough hygiene
 " personal protective equipment (PPE)
 " safe management of care equipment
 " safe management of the care environment
 " safe management of linen
 " safe management of blood and body fluids
 " safe disposal of waste (including sharps)
 " occupational safety/managing prevention of exposure (including sharps).

On March 17, UK Prime Minister sets up new ministerial structures to coordinate, prioritise and respond to the coronavirus pandemic across government, including one for Healthcare, General Public Sector, Economic and Business and International.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: UK government pledges  "20 million to fund the development of a vaccines for coronavirus and other infectious diseases
Foreign Secretary, "Dominic Raab has confirmed the evacuation flight back to the UK for British people on the Diamond Princess in Japan, following the coronavirus outbreak."
UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announces statutory sick pay, which is now available from the first day of sickness rather than the usual fourth day.

The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) "will consider any evidence that companies may have broken competition or consumer protection law, for example by charging excessive prices or making misleading claims about the efficacy of protective equipment. And it will take direct enforcement action in appropriate cases."

"At 6.15pm on 5 March 2020, a statutory instrument was made into [UK] law that adds COVID-19 to the list of notifiable diseases and SARS-COV-2 to the list of notifiable causative agents."
"This change in law requires GPs to report all cases of COVID-19 to Public Health England."

Government outlines further plans to maximise the number of volunteers. "Volunteers  " who already play a central role in helping the health and social care system function  " will be given additional employment safeguards so they can leave their main jobs and temporarily volunteer in the event of a widespread pandemic."

On March 30, the UK Government announces a new government partnership with airlines (Virgin, Easyjet, Jet2 and Titan Airways) to fly back more tourists stranded abroad due to the coronavirus pandemic.

"The [UK] government will temporarily ban the use of statutory demands (made between 1 March 2020 and 30 June 2020) and winding up petitions presented from Monday 27 April, through to 30 June, where a company cannot pay its bills due to coronavirus. This will help ensure these companies do not fall into deeper financial strain. The measures will be included in the Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill".
"Government is also laying secondary legislation to provide tenants with more breathing space to pay rent by preventing landlords using Commercial Rent Arrears Recovery (CRAR) unless they are owed 90 days of unpaid rent."

On January 20, Public Health England in the UK advises people travelling to Wuhan, China to "maintain good hand, respiratory and personal hygiene and should avoid visiting animal and bird markets or people who are ill with respiratory symptoms. Individuals should seek medical attention if they develop respiratory symptoms within 14 days of visiting Wuhan [...]".
A UK Foreign & Commonwealth Office spokesperson advised against non-essential travel to Wuhan, and advised UK nationals travelling to Wuhan to remain vigilant.
UK government funds a campaign to help inform the public of safer practices in order to slow the spread of coronavirus and reduce the burden to the NHS
British Embassy in Beijing provides a Q&A regarding coronavirus for British nationals and their dependents currently in China
On March 3, The United Kingdom publishes its Coronavirus Action Plan.

The health and social care system across the UK created a 'Coronavirus (COVID-19) action plan. "This document sets out what the UK as a whole has done  " and plans to do  " to tackle the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak, based on [their] experience dealing with other infectious diseases and [their] influenza pandemic preparedness work."

A public information campaign focusing on the importance of washing hands for 20 seconds has been started in the UK to slow down the spread of coronavirus. "The campaign will appear in the print media, radio, online and in public places, including billboards".
On March 28, the UK launches an information service on WhatsApp.
UK is providing guidance to UK consumers regarding food hygiene in response to the coronavirus outbreak.

'The Health Protection (Coronavirus) Regulations 2020' has been put together to impose restrictions on individuals at risk of spreading coronavirus in the UK. "The regulations apply to any individuals seeking to leave supported isolation before the current quarantine period of 14 days is complete"

From the 8 June 2020, individuals entering the UK must quarantine and self-isolate for 14 days. Lorry drivers, seasonal farm workers, and coronavirus medics will be exempt. The requirement will also not apply to those travelling from the Republic of Ireland, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man.

On March 20, the UK announces that all cafes, pubs, bars, restaurants,  nightclubs, theatres, cinemas, gyms and leisure centres should close as soon as they reasonably can on March 20, and not to open on March 21.

The United Kingdom has published guidelines to allow researchers and lab staff continue to work in their businesses safely while following the recommended health guidelines. This document is to help employers,
employees and the self-employed in the UK understand how
to work safely during this pandemic.

UK 'Driver and Vehicle Standards Agency' banned all driving tests in England, Scotland and Wales for up to three months in order to prevent the spread of coronavirus. This does not apply to critical workers (health and social care, education and childcare, key public services, local and national government etc), who can apply for an emergency test.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 23, the UK closes public premises such as libraries, playgrounds and outdoor gyms, and places of worship.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 16, the UK banned mass gatherings from March 17.
On March 23, the UK stops all social events including weddings, baptisms and other ceremonies, but excluding funerals.
On March 23, The UK has banned public gatherings of more than 2 people except for members of households, the police can disperse such gatherings.
US Health and Human Services Secretary declares public health emergency retrospectively for January 27, 2020 on Friday, January 31, 2020.
President of the US declares a state of national emergency, March 13 2020.
United States, President Donald Trump approved "Colorado's expedited request for a major disaster declaration, a move that will free up more federal money" on March 28

On April 3rd, 2020, the United States federal government issued a "major disaster declaration for West Virginia, triggering the release of federal funds to help communities recover from the Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic."
On January 31 the United States President signed a proclamation barring entry to the United States of most foreign nationals who traveled to China within the past 14 days.

On February 29, President Trump signed a proclamation that expanded restrictions to include all aliens who were physically present within the Islamic Republic of Iran during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States. "

On March 11, President Trump signed a proclamation that restricts travel to the United States from foreign nationals who have recently been in certain European countries. " This does not apply to U.S. citizens or legal permanent residents. "
On March 14, President Trump signed a proclamation that restricts travel to the United States from foreign nationals who have recently been in the United Kingdom and Ireland. "
On March 17,2020 the US Ministry of Health Agency CDC issued a warning (Warning - Level 3, Avoid Nonessential Travel "Widespread Ongoing Transmission) on travel with cruiseships.

On March 20, 2020 The United States announced to have reached mutual agreements with Canada and Mexico to restrict non-essential travel across our northern and southern borders.
The United States will expeditiously return aliens who cross between ports of entry or are otherwise not allowed to enter the country, as the facilities in which these aliens would normally be held cannot support quarantine for the time needed to assess potential cases.
These aliens are processed in stations designed for short-term processing, where distancing is not a viable option, creating a serious danger of an outbreak.
After pledging on Twitter to end immigration during the pandemic, US President Trump moved to block new green cards but stopped short of ending all work visas (April 21).

President Trump instituted a travel restriction into the United States on all foreign nationals present in Brazil during the 14 day period preceding their attempted entry into the United states. This will begin applying to flights departing on or after May 27th, 2020. American citizens, legal permanent residents, and immediate family members may enter following enhanced medical screenings at specially designated airports.

Entry to the United States is suspended, per Presidential Proclamation, of foreign nationals of all nationalities, including Brazilians, who were present in Brazil within 14 days prior to their arrival at the port of entry in the United States. This policy, which is intended to prevent the spread of COVID-19, enters into effect 11:59 p.m. eastern daylight time on May 28, 2020.

On Feb 15, 2020 the US announce that 17.8 tons of personal protection equipment and medical supplies were delivered, and more than 800 people were evacuated from Wuhan, China, amidst the Novel Coronavirus outbreak.

On March 18, 2020, the US President announced more groundbreaking steps to slow the spread of the virus and help every American community brave the storm:

The Defense Department will massively expand medical resources, making 5 million respirator masks and 2,000 ventilators available for use
FEMA is now activated in every region of the country and at the highest level
The Department of Housing & Urban Development will be suspending foreclosures and evictions until the end of April
Health & Human Services will also suspend foreclosures and evictions
Navy hospital ships are being deployed to impacted areas
America and Canada will halt all non-essential travel across their border

US President Trump issues Executive Order on Prioritizing and Allocating Health and Medical Resources to Respond to the Spread of Covid-19. 

To ensure that our healthcare system is able to surge capacity and capability to respond to the spread of COVID-19, it is critical that all health and medical resources needed to respond to the spread of COVID-19 are properly distributed to the Nation "s healthcare system and others that need them most at this time.

Accordingly, I find that health and medical resources needed to respond to the spread of COVID-19, including personal protective equipment and ventilators, meet the criteria specified in section 101(b) of the Act (50 U.S.C. 4511(b)).  Under the delegation of authority provided in this order, the Secretary of Health and Human Services may identify additional specific health and medical resources that meet the criteria of section 101(b).

March 23, 2020 the US government issues an Executive Order on Preventing Hoarding of Health and Medical Resources to Respond to the Spread of COVID-19.
The president writes "Accordingly, I am delegating to the Secretary my authority under section 102 of the Act (50 U.S.C. 4512) to prevent hoarding of health and medical resources necessary to respond to the spread of COVID-19 within the United States.
